DOC.HEAD: Carter Hopes For Honest Elections In Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter, an official observer of next month's elections in Nicaragua, said Monday he's confident the voting will be fair and honest. ``I think it's going to be, relatively speaking, a superb election,'' Carter, just back from that Central American country, told a national security symposium at the Carter Presidential Center. ``What is protecting the integrity of the election is that both sides believe they are going to win,'' he said, referring to the Sandinista government and the opposition. Carter has been invited to observe the general elections, along with representatives of the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, a group of former chief executives which Carter heads. Carter returned from a trip to Nicaragua Sunday night. ``We're doing everything we can to ensure that technically the election is almost perfect,'' he said Monday. The Sandinistas have been cooperative, realizing they will not look good if Carter and other international observers brand the elections as fixed. The former president expressed the hope that the trend toward free elections might spread to Cambodia, Afghanistan and other troubled nations. ``This is the kind of approach that can be a new evolution in addressing long-standing armed conflict in troubled parts of the world,'' Carter said. Carter also said that with pro-democracy movements around the world, the United States has an important opportunity ``to use these tremendous resources we have been wasting on weapons _ and sometimes spending wisely on weapons _ for other purposes.'' He said the defense budget could be halved within a decade, leaving an adequate military coupled with national security based on friendship and cooperation between nations. ``Will we do it?'' he asked. ``I don't know. ... It might take us a year or two to realize we have this opportunity, but such wonderful things can be done.''

DOC.HEAD: 74 Arrested In Vegas Union Protest
DOC.TEXT: Striking hotel workers briefly closed the main streeet downtown Monday night in a noisy sit-in that ended with police arresting 74 of the demonstrators. The strikers linked arms and sat in a circle in the middle of glittering Fremont Street between the Golden Nugget and Binion's Horseshoe Club, where union workers walked off the job Saturday after working without a contract for eight months. About 30 police officers confronted the strikers and, after they refused to disband, began arresting them one by one. There was no violence and the demonstration was over in 30 minutes. Culinary Union Local 226 leader Jim Arnold was among those put in plastic handcuffs and taken to a waiting police bus for transportation to the Clark County Detention Center. Metropolitan Police Lt. Randy Oaks said the strikers arrested would be booked on misdemeanor public nuisance charges. Union officials said they had made arrangements to bail strikers out. Pickets marching in front of the Horseshoe Club chanted slogans in support of the strikers in the street, as curious tourists sipped drinks and watched the action from the other side of the street. The strike was the first by the Culinary and Bartenders' unions since 1984, when a walkout against most of the city's resorts cost millions of dollars in lost revenue and resulted in nearly 1,000 arrests. Arnold, secretary-treasurer of Local 226, said he had heard nothing from Binion's president Jack Binion since the strike began. Arnold accused Binion of trying to break the union at the resort. ``We knew it could be a long one and we're prepared for it,'' Arnold said of the walkout. Union officials said 90 percent of the 1,100 kitchen workers, bartenders, porters and other union members walked off their jobs, but an attorney for the Horseshoe said half the workers were crossing picket lines. The casino is the first to be struck since union contracts expired June 1. The Horseshoe is one of 14 resorts that have not reached new pacts with the union, but 20 resorts, including most major casinos along the Strip a couple of miles from downtown, agreed several months ago to five-year pacts.

DOC.HEAD: Donahue Goes to Flint, Mich., for Show on `Roger and Me'
DOC.TEXT: Phil Donahue's audience took turns blasting General Motors Corp. and filmmaker Michael Moore on Monday as they discussed the quirky documentary ``Roger and Me.'' About 2,000 people jammed Whiting Auditorium for a segment of Donahue's nationally syndicated television show devoted to Moore's film. The crowd included auto workers, who accused GM of sending American jobs overseas, and Flint boosters, who said Moore's movie made conditions in Flint look worse than they are. ``You showed the slummiest areas,'' one woman told Moore. ``Roger and Me'' purports to depict what happened to Flint when GM shut down factories in the community, idling 30,000 workers over several years. In the film, Moore unsuccessfully pursues GM Chairman Roger Smith to ask him to come to Flint to see what GM's layoffs have done to the city. The documentary, made for $260,000 and released nationwide by Warner Brothers this month, has won several awards and is being touted as a possible Academy Award winner for best documentary. But Moore has come under fire by some film critics for misrepresenting some time sequences, such as the span during which layoffs occurred. Moore, a Flint native, said his movie's message was that ``after 10 years of Reagan and Bush, it's not morning in America for us. We're all working harder for less.'' Moore said GM has a responsibility to the community where it got it started. ``The American dream used to be you work hard, the company prospers, you prosper. Now, you work hard, the company prospers, you lose your job,'' he said, noting that the layoffs came when GM still was making millions a year in profits. GM critics accused Smith of earning millions for himself, while workers were losing their jobs. ``While Roger Smith was pocketing this money we were standing in line for moldy cheese,'' said one woman. Donahue was scheduled to do a single one-hour show Monday, but decided to tape a second show immediately after the first, because many in the crowd had yet to be heard after showing up before dawn Monday for the 4 p.m. show. Donahue said GM declined to send anybody to appear with Moore. ``We are not interested in doing anything that might help promote a film that is inaccurate and totally unfair to the city of Flint and the thousands of dedicated GM employees working there,'' according to a GM statement read by Donahue. The company also asked its dealers not to advertise during the Donahue show about the film, Donahue said. Moore and many in the audience objected to Donahue's suggestion that GM workers were to blame for the company's loss of market share and their jobs. ``You made a lot of lousy cars,'' Donahue said. But Moore contended the company refused to listen to consumers and focused on making cars cheaper. Moore was booed when he admitted to owning a Honda Civic, but said that even some so-called American-made cars are built with many foreign made parts. The show was shown live to about 40 cities and will be shown Tuesday in more than 150 others.

DOC.HEAD: The British Bobbie: Scandals Tarnish His Cherished Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Times aren't good for the British bobby, the policeman so admired and respected he never needed to carry a gun. With disturbing regularity these days, his image is being tarnished by scandals that range from evidence-rigging to falsified crime-busting rates. The scandals have triggered alarm about the integrity of the nation's 146,000-member police force, and prompted some highly public soul-searching by senior officers. Until recently, the criticism came chiefly from left-wingers whom the police could dismiss as chronic malcontents. Where corrupt officers were exposed, they were portrayed as the few ``bad apples'' in a fundamentally healthy barrel. Britons who follow the police developments closely say it is not the level of abuses that has increased, but the public's awareness of them. The criticism is coming increasingly from opinion makers, who say the ``bad apple'' excuse is no longer good enough. ``If the public's confidence in the police is lost, I cannot see how it can be regained,'' columnist Bernard Levin wrote in The Times. ``And if it is not regained, the damage to our entire way of life would be immense, so vital is the need for a force which can be relied upon.'' A public opinion poll published in November indicated the police are held in esteem by only 43 percent of Britons now in contast to 83 percent in 1959. The worst case of what The Independent newspaper calls ``institutional rot'' occurred in October when the Court of Appeal freed four people serving life terms for bombing British pubs during a 1974 wave of Irish Republican Army attacks. The court quashed the conviction of the ``Guildford Four'' after seeing evidence that police from the Surry county force falsified records and lied in court to strengthen their case. Civil libertarians are pressing to reopen other IRA convictions, notably the jailing of six Irishmen for a 1974 pub bombing in Birmingham, in central England, which killed 21 people. The six claim they are innocent and were beaten into confessing. In December, a court ordered Scotland Yard in London to pay a record 100,000 pounds ($165,000) in damages to a black man falsely accused of carrying illicit drugs. It was one of a series of cases from 1984-85 in which police in the Notting Hill district of west London were accused of planting drugs on blacks. In September, investigators found that police in Kent had increased crime-detection rates by pressing convicted prisoners to confess falsely to extra crimes. It led to the dismissal of a detective sergeant and heavy fines for six of his colleagues. Public opinion was further inflamed by news that the policeman who exposed the corruption was being cold-shouldered by his colleagues and was threatened with dismissal when he demanded a transfer. The British force is divided into 52 constabularies, mostly on county lines, and usually officers from one county are called in to investigate suspected abuses by another. Commented The Independent: ``At the moment, with half a dozen of our major forces investigating one another, the police are in danger of running out of investigators to investigate the investigators.'' Signs of a dramatic new approach came in August, when Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear of the West Midlands force took the unusual step of dismantling his entire serious-crime squad over allegations of fabricated confessions and doctored evidence. More than 50 officers were sidelined. Dear got what appeared to be crucial backing a month later from Sir Peter Imbert, commissioner of Scotland Yard, in a watershed speech to a police conference. ``Sometimes it must seem that we set out deliberately to frustrate the inquirer, and in doing so we manage to turn a grievance into a crusade,'' he said. Police reticence, he added, carried ``quiet but strong implications of corruption.'' The scope of abuses is expected to narrow sharply with the new Police and Criminal Evidence Act, which requires interrogators to record every word said in the room and hold no one for more than 36 hours without court authorization and access to a lawyer. By 1991 all interrogations will have to be tape-recorded. That law already has led to hundreds of detectives requesting transfers on grounds that they could not cope with the exacting new procedures, said Barry Irving, director of the Police Foundation, an independent research group. Scotland Yard's Imbert urges more emphasis on old-style policing based on close consultation with local communities, especially ethnic groups. ``The public have a right to be actively involved in determining how policing is developed,'' he said in his September speech. P.A.J. Waddington, a Reading University expert on police, says that ``policing is inherently scandal-prone. What seems to vary is the extent to which people perceive problems as being scandals.'' Waddington said in an interview that police malpractice is ``substantially less than at any time in our history,'' and the fact that police violence still makes headlines demonstrates that it is still regarded as an unusual phenomenon. But in recent times, the old image of the friendly neighborhood bobby has been supplanted by a new breed, hardened by inner-city riots in the early 1980s and frequent picket line violence. Criminologist Robert Reiner of the London School of Economics thinks the accumulation of gross abuses ``is extremely disturbing, but I don't think it's a sign the police have gone bad.'' The police are doing their job as they always did, he said in an interview. The difference is that the public perception of them has changed. ``There is a crisis in the public legitimacy of the British police,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientific Advances Often Come in Fits and Starts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: On the corner of Dr. David Page's desk rests a foot-high stack of newly published genetics textbooks. They matter-of-factly describe the location of the sex-determining factor, the single gene that settles the question of whether a fertilized egg will be a boy or a girl. The gene was Page's discovery. Its rapid rise to the status of accepted wisdom is hardly a surprise, for when he revealed it at a news conference, the announcement was a major event in the world of genetics. Isolating the gene was a milestone in basic biology, the prize in an exhausting race and the kind of achievement on which distinguished careers are built, clearly a breakthrough in a field that uses the word sparingly. Or so it seemed. The story was simple: One tiny bit of genetic code rules gender. If we have it at the moment we are conceived, we will be male. If not, we'll be female. Just two years after Page's announcement, the precise location of the sex-determining factor is a mystery again. The gene he found, while interesting and probably important, is almost certainly not it. The case illustrates the skittish and often whimsical way science moves. Rather than flowing forward in a neat, sane way, facts _ and theories cobbled together to fit them _ emerge in a jerky tango of discovery and setback. A new set of lab results can turn breathtaking insight to smoke. Page is a staff scientist at the Whitehead Institute, an elite center for genetics research across the street from Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While still in training at MIT, he used to smile at a cartoon on a biology professor's door: ``Theory, like mist on eyeglasses, obscures vision.'' Page's theory, accepted by many, is now in shambles. But it's not the first time people have been wrong about the location of the sex-determining factor. A decade ago, many believed it was a gene called H-Y, and some textbooks still state this unequivocally. Page's quest to find the sex switch began in 1982. Like others, he tried to track it down by a process of elimination. Everyone is born with 46 strings of genes called chromosomes. Two of these, called X and Y, are the sex chromosomes. Women have two X's, while men have an X and a Y. Scientists reason that the gene that makes men different from women must be located someplace on the Y. Page and others have concentrated on apparent exceptions to the rule, so-called XX males. To all outward appearances, these people are physically normal men. But their cells contain the double X's of women. Through a genetic mix-up, one of their X's contains a tiny fragment of Y, enough to make them men. Among those he studied was an XX man with just half of 1 percent of a Y chromosome. Within this bit of DNA he found a gene that was shared by other XX males. He postulated this was TDF, testis-determining factor _ the sex switch. His description of the gene and his idea of what it did were published in December 1987 in the journal Cell. It was a depressing moment for Dr. Peter N. Goodfellow at the Imperial Cancer Research Fund in London, whose team was just a few months from making the same discovery. Page was almost certain he had correctly identified TDF, but remembers feeling uneasy when colleagues flashed slides during lectures that confidently called it that. ``You try as hard as you can to say that something is a working hypothesis, and it gets boiled down, even in a textbook, to established fact.'' To be on the safe side, he named his gene ZFY, or Y-linked zinc finger protein, a reference to the kind of chemical structure it makes. Then he and other scientists searched for evidence that ZFY is TDF. But when new pieces of the puzzle emerged, they didn't quite fit. ``If you get something that is right, more and more things start clicking into place,'' said Goodfellow. ``What happened with the ZFY story is that it didn't get stronger and stronger.'' Among the conflicting details: _Page knew from the start that there was a related gene on the X chromosome. But when its structure was decoded, it was disquietingly like ZFY. If ZFY is uniquely male, why would females have a very similar gene? _All mammals have their own version of ZFY. But among the marsupials, such as kangaroos, the gene isn't on the Y chromosome at all; it lies on one of the non-sex chromosomes that presumably has nothing to do with sex determination. _Other XX males turned up who did not carry ZFY. _In mouse embryos, the gene did not seem to be doing anything at the time when sex is determined. _Efforts to transplant ZFY into female embryos didn't produce male mice. Alone, any of these tidbits could be explained away. Maybe the male mouse embryos weren't producing the ZFY protein because scientists were looking for it after the gene had already turned itself on and off. Maybe marsupials and their distant relatives among placental mammals have simply evolved different means of sex determination. Together, though, the tidbits raised doubts. ``As the data accumulated, it seemed to be more and more puzzling how it could be the sex-determining gene,'' said Benajmin Lewin, editor of Cell. ``That is quite a common situation. One sees an assumption, a model is proposed, and then more data accumulate that are not consistent with the model, and then the model breaks.'' The breaking point for this model came with a paper in December in the journal Nature. Goodfellow had found four XX males who carried a bit of the Y chromosome, but not the part with ZFY on it. He argued that somewhere in the fragment they shared was the true sex-determining factor. While Page was unmoved by the earlier skepticism over ZFY, Goodfellow's discovery was a shock. ``It hit me, sure, in part because I did not know this was coming until it was published.'' He could dismiss the other evidence as circumstantial, but Goodfellow had used precisely the same line of reasoning to attack ZFY's role as Page had used to support it. ``This makes it clear that ZFY is not the only sex-determining function on the Y,'' Page said. ``It's possible that ZFY has little, if anything, to do with sex determination.'' Goodfellow isn't gloating. If he had found ZFY first, he said, he would have written the paper Page wrote. ``A lot of people have said to me, `It shows that David Page got it wrong.' Everyone likes to see a hero fall. ``It's not really like that. Yes, his interpretation was incorrect. But if you go back and look at it, he put forward what seemed to be the best hypothesis at the time.'' Now Goodfellow and Page are back where they were, competing to find the sex trigger gene. ``I'm not in the position of wanting to stand up and crow,'' Goodfellow said. ``We are testing the most likely hypothesis. That may be wrong, or maybe David will publish finding a gene in this region tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Strife, Competition Dim Prospects for Port of Baltimore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Once an economic power that drew ships from around the world to its piers at the head of the Chesapeake Bay, the Port of Baltimore is losing ground to its competitors and its reputation for labor troubles. Even the unexpectedly quick settlement of a three-day dockworkers' strike last week failed to appreciably brighten prospects for the $1 billion complex. ``Even a three-day walkout has reverberations. It's like the shot heard round the world _ Baltimore goes out again,'' said state Delegate Eileen Rehrmann. ``It sends a message all over the world that we're unreliable.'' The Jan. 19 strike by about 2,000 members of the International Longshoremen's Association stranded cargo containers on piers and prompted about a dozen vessels to divert to competing waterfronts, officials said. The dockworkers, who struck over jurisdiction of clerical jobs, went back to work Tuesday and ratified a new contract that gave up 60 of those jobs. Yet it may be more significant that the union gave up its ``rain clause,'' a local work rule blamed for higher labor costs. The new contract lets managers, instead of the union, decide when weather is too hazardous to work. U.S. Rep. Helen Bentley, R-Md., who acted as a mediator in the contract dispute, said eliminating the rain clause alone would save steamship lines about $2.5 million a year. ``The damage has already been done, internationally and within our own state,'' said Gov. William Donald Schaefer, who had threatened a state takeover of the port's operations long before last week's strike. Schaefer returned from European and Middle East trade missions last year complaining about the port's labor image abroad, and for years has complained of lagging modernization to keep up with the boom in containerized shipping. Richard Hughes, head of the ILA local representing clerical workers, contends that the port should control its administrative costs _ eliminating such things as executive bonuses _ and make its rates more competitive with regional competitors. Hughes, whose jurisdictional complaint led to the three-day strike, said he doesn't consider the contract satisfactory, raising the possibility of another wrangle when the pact expires in November. ILA District President Horace Alston, who heads the five ILA locals working in the Port of Baltimore, didn't return a phone call. Baltimore, a 12-hour sail up the bay from the Atlantic Ocean, once was insulated from hard times by its position as the harbor closest to the nation's industrial heartland. Freight deregulation in the 1970s turned that into a liability, with customers shopping for competitive truck and rail rates from ports that huge steamships could reach more conveniently. In the mid-1980s, the port authority began to step into labor negotiations between the ILA and dock employers, represented by the Steamship Trade Association. Port officials were anxious to obtain union concessions to improve the port's reputation for reliability and lower its costs. But that only strained relations between the ILA and the employers, who lease the docks and hire from the labor pool. Richard Trainor, head of the Maryland Port Commission, said the economic effect of the strike goes far beyond the 2,000 or so ILA members. He estimated that 30,000 to 40,000 people make a living from the port's business. Even that is far less than what used to be. Ten years ago, a state study found the port directly or indirectly supported more than 100,000 people. Port of Baltimore officials say 28 ship lines have folded, merged or deserted Baltimore in the past five years. While shipping volume has declined worldwide, Baltimore's market share has been sapped by other Atlantic seaboard ports, especially Virginia's Hampton Roads complex at Norfolk. Port of Baltimore figures show that between 1982 and 1988, its share of Midwest-bound freight dwindled from 18 percent to 10 percent while Norfolk's climbed from 6 percent to 9 percent. Baltimore's Mid-Atlantic share went from 30 percent to 20 percent while Norfolk's rose from 13 percent to 18 percent. The Sun in Baltimore reported Thursday that last year, for the first time, Virginia ports probably surpassed Baltimore in the amount of general cargo handled. Maryland port officials said their 1989 numbers weren't yet prepared for publication, but figures through September show a 6.4 percent drop in general cargo from the year before. Trainor said the port must become more financially attractive to shippers. ``If you're in business selling something for $1 and everybody else is selling it for 50 cents, you might as well make up your mind you're in the wrong business, because the public is going to make it up for you,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Candidates Quit, Citing Contra Links, Sandinista Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The opposition coalition is suffering widespread losses even before Feb. 25 elections: at least 150 of its municipal candidates and three National Assembly candidates have quit the campaign in recent months. Officials of the United Nicaraguan Opposition, or UNO, say some of those who withdrew were secret Sandinista sympathizers who infiltrated UNO to embarrass it. But many others were taken in by a campaign of the ruling Sandinistas that includes intimidation and warnings of a return to the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza, UNO says. For Olivia Bermudez, who quit her local race in December, ``the Contra connection'' was the last straw. Mrs. Bermudez ended up accepting Sandinista accusations that her own opposition coalition was linked to U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas and might bring back the days of Somoza, who was overthrown in 1979. ``Return to the past? Never!'' said Mrs. Bermudez, sitting in a rocking chair on the front porch of her modest cement home, her 1-year-old baby on her lap. Mrs. Bermudez, 40, is a homemaker, mother of 10 and owner of a couple of farms in the central province of Chontales. This is the cool, lush heartland of Nicaragua's cattle region ``where the rivers are made of milk and the stones of cheese,'' as a local saying has it. It is also Contra territory. The Contras have the sympathy of many local cattlemen and small farmers who don't like anyone butting into their business, seizing their land or forcing them to join co-ops. Raul Bello Cordero, 50, withdrew in mid-January as town council candidate for Esquipulas, a village in north-central Matagalpa province. He said two local Sandinista party officials threatened to have his house and truck confiscated if he didn't resign. ``They said the Front (the Sandinistas) has already won the elections, so if I didn't want to lose my property and have my family affected I should resign,'' Bello said. Another threat, said Bello, was that his son would be drafted, although the draft has been suspended at least for the duration of the campaign. The Sandinistas deny intimidation, saying the candidates quit after seeing that UNO is the ``civilian arm'' of the Contras. It's a teme the Sandinistas have hammered at in their campaign. One staunchly pro-government newspaper, El Nuevo Diario, regularly refers to UNO as ``GN-1.'' GN are the Spanish initials for National Guard, as the generally hated army was called under Somoza, and UNO means ``one'' in Spanish. President Daniel Ortega, seeking another six-year term, constantly calls UNO and the Contras ``the Somocista Guard.'' He is running for the Sandinista National Liberation Front against UNO's Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa. UNO does indeed include former members of the Contra resistance, but they say the Sandinista attacks are unfair because they have given up arms and agreed to join the political process. Mrs. Bermudez, who quit her town council race in mid-December, said the coalition has been hampered by constant bickering among its disparate parties that joined forces for the sole purpose of beating the Sandinistas. She said it also suffers from a lack of money for campaign activities. ``Let's face it: Nobody is in a position nowadays to shell out money from their own pockets,'' said Mrs. Bermudez. The opposition has said the Sandinista-controlled bureaucracy is blocking distribution of its election funds. Candido Moreno Salgado, 40, said he quit a National Assembly race after men who identified themselves as state security agents visited his home and threatened to have his ranch confiscated unless he resigned. Moreno, from the Matagalpa town of Dario, said the ultimatum was preceded by telephoned death threats. Julio Cesar Fletes of the Atlantic Coast town of Bluefields, a candidate for the regional council in his area, said he was pressured by military and state security authorities. Fletes said he was given a jar of a black substance and told to add it to food served at a UNO gathering. He said he was told the substance was poison, and he refused to comply. He has remained a candidate, though he has fled to Managua. Hernaldo Zuniga, head of a Conservative Party faction within UNO, said 40 cases of alleged intimidation had been presented to the Supreme Electoral Council, but no reply had been received. Zuniga said many of those who withdrew because of threats preferred to keep a low profile and would not complain.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Questions to Soviet Foreign Minister and His Answers
With PM-Shevardnadze, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze gave written answers to questions submitted in advance of a face-to-face interview last week with the AP's Moscow bureau chief, Michael Putzel. Here is a text of the written portion of the interview.
The following is the text of questions submitted to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and his written answers in advance of a face-to-face interview with The Associated Press.

Q: The Bush Administration has been in place for a year now. Its long policy review has been completed, and presidents Bush and Gorbachev have held their first summit meeting. How would you describe the state of U.S.-Soviet relations and superpower efforts to solve regional conflicts? A: I believe that in analyzing Soviet-U.S. relations we can, on the whole, look with satisfaction back to the past year. And the prospects, too, seem to be favorable. It has been possible not only to maintain the positive momentum in the development of relations between our two countries, but also to elevate them to a new dimension. Both sides agree that having renounced the spirit of confrontation and achieved certain mutual understanding we must now move on to mutual action. This need arises virtually in all spheres of Soviet-U.S. relations, not in the last instance _ in the area of solving regional conflicts that you have mentioned. We have seen some tangible improvements here, although difficulties persist, too. The successes of the past year, to be credited also to Soviet-U.S. contacts, include the settlement in Southwest Africa and the achievement of independence by Namibia. The machinery to promote a Cambodian settlement is shifting into higher gear. It seems we can now see the light at the end of the tunnel there. We keep constantly in sight the problems of the Middle East. It is important that Israel, too, should take advantage of the opportunities that are there. A political settlement in Afghanistan is literally knocking on the door. Reliance on military force has outlived itself. The peace process in Central America has traveled a long and difficult path. In this connection the U.S. action against Panama, undertaken at a very crucial period for that region, gives rise to grave concern. We have expressed our attitude toward the use of force, toward contempt for international law. We hope that a sense of realism will prevail in Washington and that respect will be shown for the legitimate interests of Central American states and their right to free choice. It can be seen from this brief inventory that there will be something for us to talk about with Secretary of State James Baker early in February in Moscow. We expect to have productive discussions. Q: President Bush has said that the United States wants closer cooperation with the Soviet Union, and Secretary Baker has suggested that cooperation might include technical advice in areas such as international monetary affairs. The U.S. administration is moving toward removal of trade barriers. What forms of cooperation would you say are most needed or would be most effective, and what short-term benefits are expected from improved trade relations? A: In the sphere of economic cooperation we think, just like the United States does, both of short-term and long-term mutual benefits. For all the difficulties of economic conditions in our country, the situation is not such that we need ``the last straw.'' We have vast reserves. And the purpose of perestroika is to mobilize the reserves. At this time perestroika is going through perhaps the most difficult period of transition from one economic management system and political structure to another. It turned out that the most difficult revolution is a peaceful revolution, a change in the minds of people. We have a perestroika concept. We are continuing our creative search for approaches to implementing some of its individual elements. Despite all the difficulties, we keep moving steadily ahead. And we are convinced of our ultimate success. One of the elements of the economic program of perestroika is the integration of our country into the world economy system. Our economic ties with the United States could have no small role to play here. The strategic goal is truly large-scale, mutually advantageous cooperation and interaction of Soviet and American economies. This would benefit both sides. Unfortunately, what stands in the way is the remaining discriminatory barriers, whether the absence of the most-favored-nation treatment or the outdated COCOM regulations (restricting high-technology exports). We hope that the readiness the U.S. Administration declared in Malta to move toward normalization of trade and economic relations will be translated into concrete deeds.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: concrete deeds.
DOC.TEXT: Q: The United States and Soviet Union are pressing for a strategic arms reduction agreement in principle by June and for signing of a START treaty this year. Yet, there has been little if any progress reported on the most difficult longstanding obstacles to agreement. Will the Soviet Union sign and implement a strategic arms reduction treaty that does not limit sea-launched cruise missiles or restrict the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative? A: One of the most important results at Malta was the political decisions of the sides to conclude a START treaty in 1990. Generally speaking, this year can become ``the disarmament year.'' It is quite realistic to reach agreements also in areas such as the reduction of conventional armed forces in Europe and the elimination of chemical weapons. Thus, our joint policies have been defined very clearly. It now remains to translate them into negotiating positions. As to the fundamental issues that you have touched upon, we submitted back in Wyoming compromise proposals on sea-launched cruise missiles. We are willing to limit them outside the treaty framework on the condition that the relevant provisions will be recorded concurrently with the treaty, will be mandatory and subject to verification. We are willing to sign and implement a START treaty even without agreement on space if the sides continue to observe the ABM (Anti-ballistic Missile) Treaty as signed in 1972. That was also a major step that we took in Wyoming. It is to be hoped that Secretary Baker will bring to Moscow adequate responses to our initiatives. It is not too long before he comes here. Q: Does the United States' support for the independence of the Baltic republics contribute to the separatist campaign in Lithuania and elsewhere, and will you seek a change in U.S. policy as part of President Gorbachev's effort to prevent breakup of the union? A: We know the position of the United States, which does not recognize the entry of the Baltic republics into the Union. Our assessment of it must be well known to you, too. As to the specific aspects of establishing a truly federative structure of our country to supercede the unitarism that actually existed, and setting up a new mechanism of relationships between the republics and the center, these problems are addressed in the course of a broad dialogue in our country taking into account the interests of all the ethnic groups. The secession of some particular republics from the Union would produce not only additional military-political and economic stresses for their population, but could also result in a major destabilization of the existing international structure. It is in no one's interest to see this happen. The problems of inter-ethnic relations are so delicate and sensitive that one should avoid any outside interference in the process of their development. Otherwise, one can provoke unpredicatble repercussions. I should say that on the whole we see that responsible politicians are aware of this. Thus, recently the U.S. administration has reaffirmed that since the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, the United States recognizes the territorial integrity of our country. The principles, recorded in the Helsinki Final Act to which the United States affixed its signature, are also well known. Q: An article signed ``Z'' in the American magazine ``Daedalus'' has provoked something of a sensation with its contention that President Gorbachev's attempts at reform are futile and that the West should therefore not try to help them succeed. Perhaps the article is getting particular attention right now due to the climate, with Lithuania trying to break from Moscow, the Caucasus ablaze with ethnic quarrels and the economy unable to provide basic food and consumer goods to people throughout the country. How would you respond to ``Z''? A: I know about the article by ``Z'' from its newspaper version. It is strange that the bag of cliches it contains about the demise of socialism is portrayed as something of a sensation. This was written and spoken about many times over the past 70 years. And such forecasts always turned out to be in the dump of history. The article's author, who seems to be prone to stereotype thinking, has completely distorted ideas about the content of perestroika and about the nature of the ongoing processes within Soviet society. It is our impression that the changes occurring in the world are not to his taste altogether and that he does not like the administration's course, which is supported by most Americans, for a ``new closeness' with the Soviet Union. As to our own difficulties, we do know about them, and we do not conceal them. But we are confident that these difficulties will be overcome because there is no alternative to perestroika. There is much work ahead of us, and we are prepared to do it.

DOC.HEAD: Military Assault Pulls Russians into Ethnic Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Unrest
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to send troops to quell the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict has dragged native Russians into the conflict, throwing a volatile new ingredient into a simmering ethnic stew. Both Armenians and Azerbaijanis now accuse Gorbachev and the Russian-dominated Kremlin leadership of letting the 2-year-old battle over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region slip out of control. The decision on Jan. 19 to send soldiers to crush armed nationalists in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, has focused resentment on Slavic soldiers, their dependents, and Russians who live in the region. While Gorbachev pleaded for a united Soviet Union to help solve the Caucasus dilemma, Russian mothers were telling him they were not interested in risking their sons' lives to stop the killing. In their view, the Armenian-Azerbaijani dispute was more like the unpopular war in Afghanistan than an issue of internal security. Major Gen. Sergei Kupreyev, a member of the special commission from Moscow administering Nagorno-Karabakh, complained in the Jan. 23 issue of the weekly New Times magazine that neither Armenians nor Azerbaijanis wanted to compromise. ``No reasonable words are accepted now,'' he said. ``We are doing everything we can to talk our informal leaders into starting negotiations, but the war is going on, and our efforts are all in vain.'' The military move, intended to restore order in Baku after Azerbaijanis began attacking and killing the minority Armenians, united Azerbaijanis against Moscow. The Azerbaijan government demanded withdrawal of the Soviet soldiers and an end to the state of emergency. It threatened to secede from the Soviet Union. Never before had it so openly defied Moscow. Most of the republic went on strike in protest. In an area where the truth often is obscured by a maddening blurring of the facts, the number of people killed by the military was a source of exaggeration. ``Comrades! In Baku more than 9,000 people were killed,'' read one sign carried by two young men in a march in Moscow the day that the dead actually were being buried in Baku. But in the Azerbaijani capital, there were not 9,000 graves. There were 119, and that figure was higher than that offered by official sources, which put the toll at 83 including 14 servicemen and members of their families. Baku journalist Shain Hadjiev said most of the soldiers sent into Baku appeared to be Russians. Posters declaring Gorbachev ``the butcher of the Azerbaijani people'' were displayed during rallies in Baku, he said. In a period of high ethnic awareness spurred by Gorbachev's reforms, Russians now are regarded by some in republics such as the Baltics and Moldavia as unwelcome colonizers. Until now, they had managed to stay out of direct involvement in the conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis. But world chess champion Garri Kasparov, a Jewish-Armenian native of Azerbaijan who got 60 of his friends and relatives out of Baku during the ethnic violence, told a Moscow news conference that the conflict in Baku could envelope the Russian population. ``If clashes are provoked between Russians and Azerbaijanis, and if there are victims or refugees among the Russian population, just think what might happen if they show up in Moscow,'' he told a news conference. It was unclear how many of the victims in Baku were family members of servicemen, but Soviet officials took the threat seriously. By Wednesday, more than 16,000 dependents had been evacuated. Officials reported that the evacuation program was suspended Thursday because of assurances from the Azerbaijan People's Front that dependents no longer were in danger. The labor newspaper Trud reported attacks on the homes of some of Baku's 100,000 Russians, and said Azerbaijanis were refusing to sell food to Russians. The Interfax news service, a publication of the official Radio Moscow, said anti-Russian and anti-military speeches were being made at rallies in many Azerbaijani cities. Russian parents were having none of Gorbachev's appeals. The flashpoint was a decision to call up reserves on Russian territory north of the Caucasus Mountains to help restore order in Armenia and Azerbaijan. ``I won't give up my son!'' a woman shouted in film broadcast nationwide by Soviet TV from Stavropol, Gorbachev's political power base. ``We put up with everything, we put up with it, we put up with it, how long are we going to put up with everything?'' ``We don't want the peoples of these republics to call us occupants. We don't want another Afghanistan,'' said another. Faced with such ire, the Kremlin unceremoniously backed down. Kupreyev noted that the bitter experience in Afghanistan and Gorbachev's opening of Soviet society had affected soldiers' attitudes. ``Soldiers don't want to die in domestic ethnic clashes,'' he said. ``There is some displeasure among the troops.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mark J. Porubcansky has reported on Soviet and Eastern European affairs from Moscow for The Associated Press since February 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti Clampdown: On the Road Back To Duvalierism?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haitians were outraged in 1988 when thugs beat a priest and killed 13 members of his congregation. A coup ousted the ruling general and installed Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril as president. Now, 16 months later, many Haitians are wondering whether Avril is leading them back into the morass of corruption, repression and fear they knew under his predecessor, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, and during the 29-year reign of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc.'' Over the past two weeks, soldiers have reportedly rounded up, arrested and brutalized a dozen political activists and forced at least seven into exile. Declaring a 30-day ``state of siege,'' Avril suspended four articles of the constitution and then imposed censorship on television and radio stations, the main source of news in a nation where 85 percent of the population is illiterate. The military government declared the state of siege Jan. 20, one day after gunmen killed an army colonel, his wife and their maid. The clampdown, Avril said, was necessary ``to protect democratic accomplishments against terrorism,'' implying that enemies of the government carried out the assassination. Skeptics saw it, however, as a pretext for Avril to consolidate his power and renege on his promise to hold legitimate elections in October. ``The government will now either show its teeth and demonstrate there will be no elections or have elections without the opposition's participation, with controlled candidates,'' said Paul Latortue, a Haitian economist at the University of Puerto Rico. President Bush's administration has sharply protested Avril's ``blatant attack on basic civil liberties'' and indicated there will be no early resumption of Washington's $60 million annual aid package. Anguished telephone calls at all hours to a reporter in Port-au-Prince, the capital, suggest an underlying sense of forboding in Haiti. Marie-Michelle de Ronceray, whose husband, Hubert, was among the opposition politicians beaten and exiled, tells of police cars arriving at her house every four hours with sirens blaring. ``I don't know what my status is,'' she said. ``I'm not leaving the house.'' ``I'm on the edge of a nervous breakdown,'' said an adviser to a former presidential candidate. ``All these events remind me of life under Papa Doc.'' Papa Doc, the country doctor who encouraged peasants to regard him as the personification of Baron Samedi, the voodoo god of the dead, ruled Haiti by naked terror. His agents were the omnipresent Tonton Macoutes _ in Creole folkore, a macoute is a bogeyman _ with their dark glasses, sneers and guns. By the time of his death in 1971, Duvalier had amassed a multimillion-dollar fortune through graft. Haiti, which was once a lush French possession, had become one of the poorest nations in the world. An estimated 80 percent of the country's 5.7 million people live in extreme poverty. Baby Doc, his slow-witted son, carried on the family tradition, but with more attention to throwing opulent costume balls in the National Palace than to the affairs of state. A popular uprising finally forced him into exile in France on Feb. 7, 1986. Namphy, then head of the army, was left in charge, but any hopes that he might move Haiti toward democracy were dashed when the country attempted to hold the first fair elections in its history on Nov. 29, 1987. Assassins in cahoots with the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations, giving Namphy the opportunity to abort the election. Washington suspended its foreign aid. The following January, the army staged an election won by university professor Leslie Manigat. But when Manigat moved to control the army, he was overthrown by Namphy in June of the same year. On Sept. 11, 1988, hundreds of people elbowed their way into St. Jean Bosco's Roman Catholic church to hear the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, fiery champion of human rights and No. 1 enemy of the military regime. He had just begun his sermon when 20 or so thugs wielding guns, machetes, spikes and clubs burst in and set upon the congregation. They killed at least 13 people and wounded 70, including a pregnant woman who was stabbed in the stomach, and then burned the church. In a nation accustomed to violence, the outrage sent a new wave of revulsion through the population and the ranks of the army. One week later, non-commissioned officers overthrew Namphy, and Avril, the army adjutant, became president. Having survived a soldiers' rebellion last April with the support of his 1,100-man Presidential Guard, Avril appears secure for the time being.

DOC.HEAD: Super Bowl Celebrating Starts Early in San Francisco
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: The Super Bowl victory celebration, San Francisco's fourth in nine years, spilled onto the streets of the city even before Sunday's game in New Orleans ended. ``They did a perfect job. From the beginning, we knew they would win,'' said Tasi Silifaiva, among a carload of young San Francisco 49ers fans in the Mission District. Late in the fourth quarter, with the 49ers well on their way to a 55-10 victory over the Denver Broncos, car horns were blaring on the city's thoroughfares. Firecrackers were popping, and police said there were reports of some celebratory gunshots being fired. Crowds spilling off sidewalks in some areas blocked traffic, and some groups of fans rocked stopped buses. By early evening, there were no reports of celebration violence such as occurred in 1982, the night the 49ers won their first Super Bowl. Fan Ernesto Gonzalez, declared, ``The 49ers are a great team and it was a great game. It was lopsided, but Denver needed to be taught a lesson, to be told where San Francisco was coming from.'' On Monday, the team will be honored with a parade down Market Street. Not everyone in the City by the Bay shares the football enthusiasm. Teacher Sonja Jones took advantage of the sunny weather and empty streets to take a long bike ride while her husband was watching the game on TV with friends. ``On Super Bowl Sunday, I kiss him off for about five hours,'' Ms. Jones said. ``The streets were empty. All you saw were big fat men waddling out of bars yelling the score,'' she added. ``It's a mutual testosterone celebration.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Warns Republics' Secession Could Destabilize World Order
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze says secession by some independence-minded Soviet republics would cause military, political and economic problems for them, and also could ``result in a major destabilization of the existing international structure.'' ``It is in no one's interest to see this happen,'' he said in a written response to questions submitted before a rare one-on-one interview. Shevardnadze's home republic, Georgia, is among those with an active nationalist movement. ``The problems of inter-ethnic relations are so delicate and sensitive that one should avoid any outside interference in the process of their development,'' he said when asked if U.S. support for the independence of the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia contributes to separatist feelings there. ``I should say that on the whole we see that responsible politicians are aware of this,'' he said, noting the United States has reaffirmed its recognition of the territorial integrity of the Soviet Union. The interview in Shevardnadze's wood-paneled office on Thursday and the text of the written exchange with The Associated Press were released by mutual agreement on Sunday. The Soviet foreign minister acknowledged widespread concern in the West for the survivability of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev but ascribed it more to a popular desire that Gorbachev's reforms succeed than to any real threat to the Communist Party chief's political power. Asked about oft-stated worries in the West that spreading chaos in the Soviet Union could cause a backlash that would sweep Gorbachev from power, Shevardnadze replied: ``I believe that this particular preoccupation stems from sincere feelings, from sincere support for the process of perestroika that is under way in the Soviet Union.'' The soft-spoken, white-haired Georgian, a Gorbachev ally on the ruling Politburo, noted it was Gorbachev ``who spearheaded this arduous but holy struggle.'' ``There is some segment of the population that is definitely disappointed'' by Gorbachev's efforts at reform, he said. But he claimed, ``Gorbachev and the political leadership of this country on the whole do enjoy the support of the bulk of the Soviet people, in spite of the fact that we are experiencing great difficulties; we have empty shelves in stores; we have a host of other social, economic and inter-ethnic difficulties.'' Shevardnadze, 62, a longtime Communist Party boss in Georgia before Gorbachev tapped him to take over the Foreign Ministry nearly five years ago, said the Soviet leader's opponents ``do not really constitute a significant force.'' Communist Party sources say the party is becoming more polarized, with hard-liners expected to mount a challenge to Gorbachev's leadership when the national body's Central Committee meets in Moscow on Feb. 5. A progressive faction also has formed, and sources say it may stage an attack at the same meeting on the party's constitutional monopoly on power, and demand a virtual apology for decades of totalitarian Communist rule. The strength of either group is difficult to measure, but the problems for Gorbachev, who seeks to portray himself as a centrist, have mounted in recent weeks. Lithuania's Communist Party broke with Moscow last month in a campaign for independence. This month, long-simmering ethnic hatreds and territorial disputes burst into open warfare in the southern Caucasus. ``Our life is not easy,'' Shevardnaze said in the interview, speaking seriously from the outset about the domestic crises and ambitious foreign-policy goals of the Gorbachev regime. ``It's difficult ... but without drama, there is no revolution. It is something that's concommitant to revolutionary change.'' He defended the decision to send troops into the southern republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia as one ``to use force for the purpose of saving people,'' saying the outbreak of ethnic violence there ``was nothing short of civil war.'' The decision, he said, ``does not correspond to either our internal convictions or to our sentiments in general, because in principle we are opposed to use of any force anywhere.'' ``As the situation in that region stabilizes, we will gradually withdraw our forces from there,'' he pledged. Juggling foreign policy issues and domestic problems, which he said can't be entirely separated from each other, Shevardnadze predicted ``the most important event of this year'' will be the June summit meeting in the United States between Gorbachev and President Bush. He expressed confidence that he and U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker, whom he referred to as ``my friend,'' will make further progress toward an agreement to halve the superpowers' strategic, or long-range, nuclear arsenals. The two are to meet in Moscow on Feb. 7 for a two-day session that was put off a day at the Kremlin's request to prevent its overlapping with the Central Committee meeting. Shevardnadze was asked if the Kremlin would sign a strategic arms reduction treaty that did not limit sea-launched cruise missiles or the U.S. ``Star Wars'' program _ two longtime sticking points in negotiations. In a written response, he said: ``We are willing to limit (the missiles) outside the treaty framework, on the condition that the relevant provisions will be recorded concurrently with the treaty, will be mandatory and subject to verification.'' ``We are willing to sign and implement a START treaty even without agreement on space, if the sides continue to observe the ABM (Anti-ballistic Missile) treaty as signed in 1972,'' Shevardnadze said. Noting that was an offer he made when he and Baker met in Jackson, Wyo., last fall, the Soviet negotiator added, ``It is to be hoped that Secretary Baker will bring to Moscow adequate responses to our initiatives.'' Shevardnadze said Soviet and U.S. efforts to work together in solving potentially explosive regional conflicts led to the political settlement that helped Namibia achieve independence. ``The machinery to promote a Cambodian settlement is shifting into higher gear,'' he added. And borrowing a phrase from the Vietnam era, he added: ``It seems we can now see the light at the end of the tunnel there.'' He called on Israel to ``take advantage of the opportunities that are there'' to find peace in the Middle East and said, ``A political settlement in Afghanistan is literally knocking on the door. Reliance on military force has outlived itself.'' Taking one jab at the United States for the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama, Shevardnadze said: ``The peace process in Central America has traveled a long and difficult path. In this connection, the U.S. action against Panama, undertaken at a very crucial period for that region, gives rise to grave concern. We have expressed our attitude toward the use of force, toward contempt for international law. ``We hope that a sense of realism will prevail in Washington and that respect will be shown for the legitimate interests of Central American states and their right to free choice.''
EDITORS: Michael Putzel heads the AP's Moscow bureau.

DOC.HEAD: Super Bowl Protesters Call for More Action on POWs, MIAs
DOC.TEXT: About 50 protesters took a bamboo ``tiger cage'' and a coffin to the Superdome on Super Sunday to dramatize their concern over soldiers missing in action and those they believe are prisoners of war. Participants in the protest dubbed Operation End Zone lined a street outside the domed stadium, chanting and waving flags and signs as thousands of Super Bowl ticketholders walked by. A few stopped to look or ask questions. At the Vietnam War Memorial just outside the Superdome, Ann Curran laid a wreath in honor of her son, Marine Capt. Patrick Curran. Curran, whose 46th birthday was Sunday, has been missing in action since his plane went down on a bombing mission over Laos in 1969, the government says. Mrs. Curran believes her son is a prisoner of war. ``I still look forward to him coming home or when I can go and get him,'' said the Bensenville, Ill., woman. ``I'm angry. I'm in pain. Does he think that he's been abandoned?'' During the demonstration, a long-haired, gray-bearded man sat passively inside the cage, a replica of those sometimes used to hold prisoners during the Vietnam War. A couple of feet away, the black coffin, draped with a folded American flag and a POW-MIA flag, sat on a white caisson. The protest was sponsored by EVAC, a Des Plaines, Ill.-based support group for POWs and MIAs. ``The message is there are still men and women unaccounted-for from Vietnam, Korea and World War II,'' said John Opager, founder of EVAC.

DOC.HEAD: Carnival Season's First Parade Rolls
DOC.TEXT: Three hours before the Super Bowl, members of the Krewe of Troy paraded through the streets of suburban Slidell to kick off the month-long Carnival season. The group was accompanied Sunday by marching bands, dance teams and masked revelers. ``I hope the NFL won't be upset at us if we take some of their crowd away from them,'' said Bob Lewis, captain of the club. Between now and Mardi Gras on Feb. 27, about 70 parades will roll through the area, which on Sunday was host of the National Football League's Super Bowl.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: As they approach their 50th birthdays, newsman Ted Koppel said he doesn't have the ``sex appeal'' to be an anchorman, and colleague Tom Brokaw said he expects to have a new job before he turns 65. NBC's Brokaw, born Feb. 6, 1940, and Koppel, who was born two days later, reflect on their careers in the Feb. 3 issue of TV Guide. ``By the end of this decade I will be doing, in one form or another, what I'm doing now _ reporting,'' said Koppel, of ABC-TV's ``Nightline.'' ``At one time I did want to be a news anchor, but I know I don't have the pizzazz. ``Apart from their talents as journalists, Peter (Jennings), Tom (Brokaw) and Dan (Rather) are also extremely attractive and have a level of sex appeal that I don't have.'' Brokaw, however, said he does not see himself doing the same thing down the line. ``I believe there'll always be a place for an evening network news program, but I don't think I'll be here for another 15 years,'' said the ``NBC Nightly News'' anchorman. ``I'd like more time I could count on, which I can't now because I'm so tied to world events.''

Phil Donahue claims competition from ``tabloid television'' is causing his 23-year-old talk show increasingly to buck serious subjects for sensational issues that will draw an audience. Recent ``Donahue'' shows have featured Zsa Zsa Gabor and the Australian tavern practice of dwarf-tossing. ``I didn't toss the dwarfs,'' protested Donahue. ``Someone else did it and demonstrated that it's being done actually as a commercial activity. I don't apologize for a moment that I exposed this activity on my program. It's important.'' There was a time when Donahue could build his 60-minute show around a single politician and focus a discussion on one issue. Now, Donahue said, the only congressional representative he could construct a show around would be Rep. Barney Frank, the homosexual Democrat from Massachusetts. ``If you don't understand how we survive in TV, no argument I make is going to make a difference,'' Donahue said in an interview published in Sunday's Los Angeles Times. ``We get paid to draw a crowd. When we don't draw a crowd, we don't get paid.''

Black filmmakers Wendell B. Harris and Charles Burnett won top honors at the Sundance United States Film Festival with two low-budget, deeply personal movies. ``Chameleon Street,'' a quirky look at a peerless con man, took writer-director-star Harris four years and nearly four dozen investors to make. The film, awarded the Grand Jury Prize, was produced by Harris' mother, Helen. ``To Sleep With Anger,'' an alternately haunting and comic account of a family crisis, was completed by writer-director Burnett just days before the festival began. It won a Special Jury Prize. Neither ``To Sleep With Anger'' nor ``Chameleon Street'' have distributors, but their victories this weekend are likely to propel them to theaters soon. The festival, which ended Sunday, was organized by actor Robert Redford's Sundance Institute to focus attention on independent, against-all-odds filmmaking. ``There's nothing worse than a commercially compromised art project,'' said Jim Stark, producer of the independent hits ``Stranger Than Paradise'' and ``Down By Law.'' ``You can't make a better `Top Gun' than the studios can.''

Country music star Waylon Jennings is singing a different tune since gaining a high school eqivalency diploma: ``Mamas, don't let your babies grow up to be dropouts.'' Jennings was scheduled to accept his General Educational Development certificate from Kentucky first lady Martha Wilkinson at the Capitol in Frankfort today. He enrolled in Kentucky Educational Television's ``GED on TV'' program last fall after talking about it with Mrs. Wilkinson, the wife of Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. He passed the exam in December after studying tapes on his tour bus. Mrs. Wilkinson said Jennings, whose hits include ``Mama, Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to be Cowboys'' (with Willie Nelson) and the theme to ``The Dukes of Hazzard'' TV show, was ecstatic when he had learned he had passed. ``I've got to admit, I don't think I've ever talked to a teen-ager more excited,'' Mrs. Wilkinson said. ``He yelled on the phone, `I really did it!' And it actually was a yell.''

New Kids on the Block, the hottest teen-age pop group since the Jacksons and Menudo, say they want to be role models for the youth of today. ``A lot of people associate musicians with drugs, and craziness, and being bad people,'' said New Kid Jon Knight, 20. ``But that's not what we want to be with this group.'' Last week, New Kids was named Favorite Pop Rock Group at the American Music Awards. Their album, ``Hangin' Tough Live,'' has sold 7 million copies and was named the Favorite Pop Rock Album at the awards show. ``Joining the group was something like basketball: If you play basketball you can stay off the streets, you can set a goal. Music has made a goal for us,'' Danny Wood, 19, said in an interview published in The Tennessean Sunday. The other members of the quintet are Donnie Wahlberg, 20, the group's oldest member; Jordan Knight, 18, and Joe McIntyre, who was 13 when he joined in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Fighters Worry Miami Zoo Plans Could Disrupt Surveillance
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard is opposing a planned 18,000-seat amphitheater at the Metrozoo, saying it could interfere with the war on drugs. The amphitheater would lead to road congestion and noise problems for the 400 Coast Guard personnel and family members stationed at a nearby command post that's used to monitor drug traffic off Florida, Cmdr. George Johnson has told Dade County officials. ``We're not against the project per se, but we're against moving forward with it until the concerns we've expressed are dealt with,'' said Johnson, who has asked the South Florida Regional Planning Council to delay action on the plans. Zoo officials say the amphitheater may help alleviate financial problems at the park, about 15 miles south of Miami. Under the present plan, Houston-based PACE Entertainment would get a long-term lease for the amphitheater and Metrozoo would receive a percentage of its income. Zev Bufman, one of the project's backers, said the developers are planning to present blueprints and other details to the Coast Guard next month. ``Our architects and engineers will gladly sit down with their people and make whatever changes they recommend so they feel secure,'' said Bufman, a co-owner of the National Basketball Association's Miami Heat. But Johnson said the materials used in the amphitheater construction may create intolerable radio static. ``Any time you put in a steel structure, it creates interference,'' he said. ``We need to know exactly what it's going to look like so we can determine if it will block transmission to the facility.'' The Seventh Coast Guard District patrols 1.8 million square miles of ocean from South Carolina to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

DOC.HEAD: Reporters May Face Hazardous Duty at Colombia Drug Summit
DOC.TEXT: White House reporters are mostly joking when they say they are nervous about covering the drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, next month. Mostly _ but not entirely. ``My mother has said plaintively to me, `Don't go to Colombia,''' said one journalist who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``What do you do? I don't want to lie to her.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater says the Secret Service is confident it can provide protection for President Bush in Colombia on Feb. 15, but it has no authority to do the same for reporters. Some journalists said they have discussed the possible danger of the assignment, but for the most part reporters covering the president regard it as part of their job. ``It's a trip,'' said Michel McQueen of The Wall Street Journal. ``He's going, so I'm going. That's the way that goes.'' Under usual procedure a White House press pool of 11 reporters would travel on Air Force One and spend about four hours on the ground while Bush meets with Colombian President Virgilio Barco and officials of Peru and Bolivia on Feb. 15. A larger contingent of reporters would fly in with the president in a chartered press plane, with some organizations sending crews ahead of time on their own. Plans were thrown into uncertainty, however, by reports this week that Colombian drug lords are plotting to shoot down the presidential plane. Although the White House scoffed at the reports, CBS News said the Secret Service was considering other ways of taking the president to Colombia. No details were provided. Fitzwater said Wednesday there was a ``good chance'' the White House would put most of the press in another country, such as Panama, Costa Rica or Venezuela, during the summit, taking only the small pool to Colombia. Tentative plans called for the White House to set up facilities for the press at a commercial airport at Cartagena near the expected summit site. The White House spokesman said he talked with a number of reporters and they were ``generally favorable to having the filing center in another country.'' Meanwhile, reporters cluster around the sign-up sheet in the White House press room looking at the names and joking about ``these brave souls, or these idiots, or whatever,'' said Karen Hosler of The Baltimore Sun. ``I am not worried about it,'' she said, ``but my family and friends have raised some questions.'' Movements of the press corps making the trip with Bush are expected to be severely limited. One reporter said the journalists most concerned were those who would be going down separately ahead of time. ``If I were going in with Bush I would feel a little better, but I don't speak Spanish even,'' said this reporter, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bill Headline, Washington bureau chief of Cable News Network, said, ``We have had some informal discussion among producers and White House reporters but have not really decided what we ought to do and what not to do. We will be looking at that in the next few days.'' Tim Russert, bureau chief for NBC News, said, ``We are still basically waiting for the White House as to what kind of arrangements will be made in terms of the president. Journalists want to report the news, but people aren't suicidal either, so we will take every possible precaution that guarantees our people's lives and still allows us to report the story.'' Russert said NBC cameramen are routinely provided with flak jackets for use on dangerous assignments and ``are certainly free to wear them whether they are reporting here or in Colombia.'' George Watson, Washington bureau chief for ABC News, said, ``The White House has indicated the Secret Service will do all that it can to protect the media in a more intensive fashion than they normally would do. None of our producers, correspondents or crews has declined to go or indicated in any way they don't want the assignment.'' Barbara Cohen, bureau chief at CBS, said there had been no reluctance there, either. ``In the press corps in general, there's the normal joking and kidding, but that's very predictable,'' said Jim Gerstenzang, White House correspondent for the Los Angeles Times. Nicholas Horrock, bureau chief for the Chicago Tribune, said he and one other Washington reporter were making the trip. ``I'm looking at the guy,'' Horrock joked. ``If he's reluctant to go to Cartagena, I'm going to kill him.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Bourbon Street Bar Filled with Super Bowl Revelers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with fire contained, two injuries. Pick up 3rd graf pvs: `It looked...
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in a Bourbon Street bar late Sunday as the streets of the French Quarter were jammed with fans celebrating after the Super Bowl, but was contained within an hour. A police officer and a firefighter were treated for injuries received fighting the blaze, said officials who weren't able to say how seriously they were hurt. The fire broke out on the third floor of the Cat's Meow bar about 9:30 p.m. and was contained by 10:20 p.m., said Fire Department Superintendent William McCrossen. The cause was under investigation. ``It looked like fog was rolling in and next thing the flames were shooting out from the building. Lots of black smoke. Quite scary actually,'' said Marty Swann of New Jersey, who watched from a nearby balcony. Between 75 and 100 people were inside the bar and several thousand strolled outside on Bourbon Street when the fire began. Police quickly evacuated and cordoned off the area surrounding the the three-story building, which is located in the heart of the city's historical district. ``The police finally came in and did a real good job. The mounted police came in and kind of pushed everybody away,'' Swann said. ``The crowd wasn't really sure why the police were moving everybody back at that point, they were too busy having a good time in the street.''

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Head Says His Corporate Experience Shows Safety Pays
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Gerard F. Scannell shudders when he recalls the amputations that some pharmaceutical workers suffered before he instituted safety reforms at Johnson & Johnson plants worldwide. As the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, he's banking on the conviction that corporate executives share that feeling. But as a former executive himself, he believes compassion can be bolstered by the bottom line: safety expenditures save money in the long run. He draws the conclusion from 11 years directing corporate safety for the New Brunswick, N.J.-based drug giant, where workplace injuries dropped more than 90 percent during his tenure. ``I made money for them,'' he says. ``Safety does pay.'' At the Labor Department, Scannell began translating some of that corporate-mindedness to safeguarding the nation's workplaces even before his October confirmation. ``My plan is to get to those CEOs,'' he says. ``I was on the firing line out there in industry. I think I know what I'm talking about and I think people know that. It's not going to be easy for people to bluff me.'' Health threats abound in office and factory air, in dangerous machinery, on construction sites, in stresses and strains from unnatural movements. Scannell is worried about repetitive strain injuries in everything from the wrists of word processing typists to the arms of meatpackers. He hopes to begin attacking the latter class of problems by releasing ergonomic guidelines for the red meat industry in February. His agency also is battling dentists who argue they cannot afford to meet proposed standards to protect health workers from blood-borne pathogens that cause hepatitis and AIDS. Scannell hopes to get those standards in place by year's end. Scannell, 54, has hopscotched between jobs in government and industry, including safety posts with Aetna Casualty & Surety Co., Thiokol Chemical Corp. and Rohm & Haas Co., and a stint at OSHA from 1971 to 1979. He has shown a willingness to confront possible detractors by seeking out labor leaders, industry officials, academics, doctors _ anyone who will listen. One of the adversaries he faced is safety gadfly Joseph Kinney, executive director of the nonprofit National Safe Workplace Institute in Chicago. ``Scannell is deeply committed to making progress,'' Kinney said in a telephone interview. ``He came here twice. It was kind of a surprise when he called us. I said, `Are you sure you've got the right organization?''' After all, Kinney says, government had not previously appreciated his group's work: ``The Reagan administration hated us passionately.'' Kinney is waiting to see whether Scannell continues slapping companies with large fines such as the $7.3 million against USX Corp. last November for alleged safety, record-keeping and health violations. But Scannell prides himself most on being a negotiator who can elicit voluntary compliance from a company rather than collect a stiff fine while bad practices continue. ``If I can get better protection for workers by lowering penalties, I'm going to do it. I'm going to extract more out of you in promises than I can probably legally cite you for,'' Scannell says. ``I want more than what the standards require.'' Those who know Scannell say that as the first person to dismantle a live Sidewinder missile back in the late 1950s _ he did so as a Navy explosives expert _ he knows what safety means. But others worry he will be hamstrung by the Office of Management and Budget. Scannell says he could use double the budget and personnel, but notes Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole has won from Congress another $14.9 million and 179 new inspectors. ``I have the support to make things happen,'' he says. Margaret Seminario, associate director for occupational safety and health at the AFL-CIO, sees promise with Scannell serving under Mrs. Dole. ``My impression of him is he's a serious individual who wants to run a serious, effective health and safety program,'' she says. Although she doesn't doubt Mrs. Dole's commitment to a stronger OSHA, she says questions remain about whether the White House and OMB are similarly committed. She's hopeful Scannell can resist industry pressures to weaken proposed standards for blood-borne pathogens and work in confined spaces such as tanks and manholes. Jordan Barab, health and safety coordinator for the 1.2 million workers of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said he was encouraged when Scannell reached out to labor before his confirmation and included a labor panel at the fall OSHA managers meeting. ``His heart is in the right place,'' Barab says. ``Under Reagan, we always had the feeling bureaucrats at best wanted to do nothing and at worst wanted to dismantle.''

DOC.HEAD: Number of Poor up, But Food Stamp Use Down
DOC.TEXT: The number of poor Americans has swelled, but fewer people are using food stamps, a paradoxical decline that's no surprise to participants. ``It's the same old story,'' said Mildred Lee, 76, of Raleigh. ``I had a hell of a hassle to get them. Ten dollars weren't worth the hassle I had to go through.'' Mrs. Lee, whose monthly income is a $406 Social Security check, has been receiving about $10 a month in food stamps for a year. Analysts see many reasons for the food stamp decline _ an economic rebound, Reagan administration regulations and an outcry against assistance. Many also say Mrs. Lee is right: Red tape keeps people away. ``I think the declining rates have been a sign of the success of the economy, but I think there are still plenty of people out there in need,'' said Phil Shanholtzer, a spokesman for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food and Nutrition Service. Participation declined to an average of 18.8 million in 1988 from 19.8 million in 1980, while the number of people living in poverty rose to 32.5 million in 1987 from 29.3 million in 1980, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a non-profit research group based in Washington. ``These figures are rather striking,'' director Robert Greenstein said. ``Essentially, we now know that the program has effectively been tightened _ and reduced in scope _ considerably more than has commonly been recognized.'' Food stamp usage has plunged in the Northeast, mid-Atlantic and Southeast during the 1980s, according a state-by-state study by the Washington-based Public Voice advocacy group. The greatest gains have come in the Southwest, the High Plains and Midwest, where poverty rates also have been running higher. Participating households now are forced to make a monthly economic status, forcing some eligible people to wonder, ``Why bother?''
