One of the dropouts is a former Lenoir County resident who remained eligible even after she landed a job as a waitress. ``The truth is, see, I worked, and I got a little bit of child support and each month I had to fill out a monthly report,'' said the 35-year-old mother, who was single at the time. ``It was not worth the hassle of having to go up there and do a monthly report. But when I did get them sometimes (they) helped a lot. Without them we would have starved.'' The woman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said she received between $10 and $100 a month. ``Even when I got the $10, the $10 would help get a little extra something special for my daughter,'' she said. ``Maybe she would want a hamburgers or pizza or something we didn't eat. Maybe with that $10 I would get her a small frozen pizza.'' Federal officials question any strict correlation between food stamp usage and the growing poor. ``The two usually go hand in hand but that has been less so in the past few years. And they don't know exactly why that is,'' Shanholtzer said. ``We've heard, too, that some people don't participate because of the hassle involved.'' In North Carolina, where participation is down more than 32 percent from 10 years ago, a task force is studying the program's waning popularity. In addition to a low jobless rate, federal policy changes that began around 1980 have had a ``tremendous'' impact, said Kay Fields, chief of public assistance in the state Division of Social Services. For example, families living under the same roof, such as a single woman with no children who is living with her parents, can no longer receive a food stamp allotment separate from her parents, Fields said. Federal outreach funds also were cut in half during the 1980s, she said. And in rural areas, small-town pride increasingly appears to be winning out over need, an attitude encouraged during the Reagan years. While participation fell in the Southeast, it grew 10.4 percent in the Midwest and 18.3 percent in the High Plains the first seven years of the decade. Wyoming, experiencing an economic downturn due to lower oil prices, had a jump of 81 percent over the last decade. The state increased its outreach efforts to boost participation among low-income elderly. Wyoming, North Carolina and other states are considering new approaches such as a food stamp credit card to help remove the stigma and cut down on lost and theft of stamps. But others say participation won't increase until the benefit does. ``The benefits aren't really high enough,'' said Jane Peel of New Hampshire's Division of Human Services.

DOC.HEAD: Bone-Breaking Experiments on Dogs Questioned
DOC.TEXT: New questions are being raised about Army-sponsored research on animals following the removal of a review panel member who voiced concerns about bone-breaking experiments on retired greyhound dogs. ``The public would be outraged at the excessive amount of tax dollars that are being wasted on research which does not contribute to human health,'' Jan Polon said this month, shortly after her removal from the voluntary post on the animal use committee at California's Letterman Army Institute of Research. Polon, an occupational therapist and the lone public representative on the review panel, had expressed opposition to several animal experiments over four years. But she blames her dismissal on two letters she sent to officials at Letterman _ one complaining about the inadequate time committee members had to review protocols and reference documents, the other requesting further review of the research protocol on the greyhound experiment. The decision by officials at Letterman, located at the Presidio in California, prompted Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., to question the operation at the research facility. ``It seems clear that LAIR does not want any questions asked about what is going on behind closed doors,'' Boxer said in a Jan. 5 letter to Army Col. Donald G. Corby, commander of Letterman. The California Democrat urged Corby to reconsider his decision, ``since it is certain to be perceived as punitive action which only elevates public concern about what is going on at LAIR.'' A spokesman at the Presidio said Polon was simply let go, and Army officials, in letters to Boxer, have steadfastly defended the experiments. ``This research effort, even to an untrained observer, is not a waste of money or animals,'' Army Maj. Gen. Philip K. Russell, medical corps commander at the Army Medical Research and Development Command at Fort Detrick, Md., said in an Oct. 5, 1989, letter. The removal of Polon is just the latest controversy surrounding the experiments on greyhounds which has drawn members of Congress, animal rights activists, Defense Department officials and representatives from the scientific community into the fray. The experiments are on hold _ the result of language in the defense spending bill for fiscal 1990 prohibiting money for the tests until the Army secretary certifies that the research has a military application, meets specific guidelines set by an animal use committee and is not duplicative. The experiments involve removing a piece of bone from the hind leg of each dog and replacing it with a synthetic compound. After two months, the greyhounds are killed and their legs examined to determine the effectiveness of the compound. The purpose of the experiments on 118 dogs, according to the Army, is to find better ways to treat battlefield wounds. Boxer argues that several physicians and veterinarians as well as the Physicians' Committee for Responsible Medicine believe the experiments serve little scientific purpose and cause unnecessary suffering for the animals. Some physicians have suggested using dogs who have already suffered bone injuries, Boxer says. The Army, in response, said the tests must be conducted on uniform animals to prevent inconsistent findings. The service is supported by several major organizations, including the Association of American Universities, the Association of American Medical Colleges, the Academy of Surgical Research, Auburn University, Columbia University and the Western Surgical Association. In letters to Boxer, the groups have countered the criticism and stressed the importance of the experiments. ``The proposed research project has been carefully reviewed by scientists and is most emphatically NOT an example of animal abuse, faulty science or unnecessary research,'' Dr. Ralph B. Dell of Columbia University said in a Nov. 3 letter. ``Animal research, responsibly and humanely conducted, saves human lives,'' Dr. M. Ward Crowe of the University of Kentucky said in a Nov. 22 letter. ``Animal life is not equal to human life.'' But Dr. Elliot Katz, a veterinarian who heads the animal rights group, In Defense of Animals, said the greyhound experiments at Letterman go ``against the grain of scientific standard operating procedure.'' Complicating the debate over the testing at Letterman was the initial disclosure that the dogs may have been illegally sold to the Army. Owners who thought they had given their dogs to racing circuits and local hospitals found out they had been sold to the Army for the experiments. The Army later released 19 dogs to their owners or animal rights activists for adoption. The service also promised to investigate possible legal action against the dealer who sold them the dogs. Boxer said the House Armed Services Committee plans hearings on the issue. Polon's removal ``is a terrible signal. It says, `if you don't go along with the program, you're out,''' Boxer said in a recent telephone interview. ``It's a slap to her, a slap at me and a slap at taxpayers.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Americans to Reject Bigotry
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush addresses religious broadcasters 2 p.m. EST; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, worshipping with a black congregation, says it is time for all Americans to reject ``racism and bigotry'' and accept the biblical admonition, ``Love thy neighbor.'' Bush today was sending Congress his $1.23 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 and later was addressing the National Religious Broadcasters' Convention and meeting with Douglas Hurd, Britain's new foreign secretary. On Sunday, before watching the Super Bowl on television with friends and family, the president and wife Barbara attended services at John Wesley A.M.E. Zion Church, where a former Bush aide was preaching. Bush briefly ascended the pulpit to speak out again about the still-unsolved racial violence that last month claimed the lives of a federal judge in Alabama and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia. Bush spoke of the ``new blossoming of liberty'' unfolding in Eastern Europe and elsewhere around the world, and said, ``It is exciting and our great country has played an important role in promoting this new breeze of freedom and working for peace. ``But I am reminded we can only be a great nation abroad if we are a great nation at home,'' said Bush, as voices in the congregation responded, ``Amen!'' ``Let us recommit ourselves to work for justice and for unity of all people. And let me add, no more letter bombs. No more racism. Leave the entire baggage of bigotry behind,'' said the president. ``It's about time in this country that we replace racism and bigotry with ... `Love thy neighbor,''' said the president. Bush came to the church to hear the guest preacher, Thaddeus Garrett, whom he called ``my old friend and trusted adviser.'' Garrett, a top aide when Bush was vice president, is now a private consultant here as well as associate pastor of Wesley Temple A.M.E. Zion Church in Akron, Ohio. Bush and the minister joked that Bush had asked Garrett to keep the sermon short. ``They're Episcopalians and ... they don't understand that sometimes we carry on a little bit,'' said Garrett, who proceeded to deliver a pounding, foot-stomping 20-minute sermon based on a passage in Luke (8:31-35) about a naked, crazy man who lived in a cemetery until Jesus drove out his demons. Garrett likened him to today's homeless that people step over on their way to work every morning. ``The world around him was ... sicker than he was, because it provided no housing for him, provided no comfort for him, no care, no love,'' said the preacher. ``It is not him who is sick. It is we who pass him by,'' said Garrett. He ended with an exhortation to the congregation to help those ``wandering through the cemeteries of life.''

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Nominee `Invisible' on Civil Rights Issues
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights job is white, wealthy and not known for quoting Martin Luther King's ``I Have a Dream'' speech. Even the nominee himself, former state Sen. John Dunne, says he's no civil rights activist. ``Nobody in candor can say I have been an out-front, visible civil rights activist,'' Dunne, 59, said last week. ``Those who criticize me for that have a factual basis.'' But he added, ``While I may not have been leading the charge, I was certainly among the faithful.'' On Thursday, Bush nominated Dunne to be assistant attorney general for civil rights, a post that has been vacant since December 1988. Bush's first choice, William Lucas, failed to win Senate confirmation last August. Dunne spent 24 years in the state Senate, where he was chairman of the Judiciary Committee. He resigned in September after losing a battle for Republican majority leader. Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said that Dunne has been ``invisible'' on civil rights issues. ``I've never seen John Dunne speak out or up on civil rights matters in any form,'' added Hazel Dukes, president of New York's chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Dunne's supporters said that in the Republican-controlled state Senate, it was Dunne who championed confidentiality in AIDS testing and equality in rates for women seeking to buy insurance. ``He's a man of unimpeachable integrity,'' said New York Court of Appeals Judge Fritz Alexander, a Democrat and the only black member of New York's liberal top court. ``He's a right thinker in terms of what needs to be done in society and with civil rights.'' Some of Dunne's old friends say he is simply a product of his staunch Republican background. They say that while he's no hard-core conservative, he's also not a trail blazer _ a sort of New York version of President Bush. Dunne has that dapper country club look. Educated at Georgetown and Yale Law School, he is a partner in one of New York's major law firms. He lives in the affluent Long Island community Garden City. Until last week, Dunne belonged to a men-only country club. He ended his 32-year membership in the Garden City Golf Club after it was reported by his local newspaper. He said his membership was ``inappropriate.'' While in Albany, Dunne regularly stayed at the exclusive Fort Orange Club near the Capitol. The club began allowing women members just last year. When inmates took over Attica prison in 1971, they wanted Dunne to help resolve the crisis. Dunne went to Attica and was highly critical of then-Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's handling of the prison's retaking, during which 39 inmates and guards were killed. Dunne then helped force changes in the state's prison system. It's that sort of thing that's made Dunne something of an enigma, and his nomination by Bush something of surprise. ``It's not that he's bad in these issues, it's that he doesn't really have a record on them,'' said Thomas Stoddard of the Lambda Legal Defense Fund, a homosexual rights group. ``On the other hand, he could have taken a leadership role on civil rights issues and didn't. He was hardly an advocate.'' Others see the choice differently. ``If the president has to pick a Republican, he couldn't pick a more decent person than John Dunne,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, a New York City Democrat and one of Congress' most influential black members. Rangel said Dunne has the legal experience that Lucas did not. A friendship with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh brought Dunne's name to the attention of the White House. Dunne was an early supporter of Bush and is close to the president's brother, New York City investment consultant Jonathan Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijan Warfare Compared to Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The bitter sectarian warfare in Azerbaijan has a senior Bush administration analyst suggesting the Soviet government may be mired in a situation comparable to Northern Ireland or Lebanon. ``No political solution is in sight. No military solution is in sight,'' said one administration source. ``The Caucasian region is on the way to becoming another Lebanon'' or Northern Ireland. Dozens of people have died in the civil warfare in the southern Soviet republic, where Moslem Azerbaijanis have been fighting Armenian Christians and the Red Army. But administration analysts for the time being have dismissed one worst-case scenario, in which the violence might spread to other Moslem areas of the Soviet Union, or beyond. A noted non-government analyst on Soviet nationalities said he did not expect ethnic fighting in Central Asia to reach the intensity it has in Soviet Caucasia, a mountainous southern region that includes the republics of Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia. But the analyst, Paul Goble, said no end is in sight to the bloodletting in those three tumultuous republics. ``There have been so many deaths in those three republics that with the tradition of blood feud in the Caucasus _ you killed my sister, I will now go kill your brother _ you are going to have constant incidents that will start this up again,'' said Goble, who recently left the intelligence division of the State Department to work at Radio Liberty, the U.S.-funded radio station that broadcasts to the Soviet Union. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev could have prevented much of the violence if he had quashed early demands by Armenians to take over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that is populated mostly by Armenians but is administered by Azerbaijan, said Goble, calling Kremlin policy on ethnic issues awkward and unenlightened. ``It is very frightening, in a sense, given all this ethnic assertiveness, you have a government in Moscow which is increasingly out of step with that development,'' Goble told a small group of reporters recently. ``Gorbachev is the first Soviet leader since Lenin never to have worked in a non-Russian republic a single day in his career, and the first to come to power ever without a single programmatic statement on nationality policy,'' he said. In Caucasia, even if Gorbachev granted the demand of Azerbaijani activists to unite as a separate country with ethnic Azerbaijanis in neighboring Iran, the Soviets likely would face cross-border fighting between the new nation and Soviet Armenia, both Goble and a senior administration analyst agreed. President Bush, in a news conference on Thursday, said he did not object to Gorbachev's use of force in Azerbaijan. ``I want very much for him to succeed,'' Bush said. ``And I don't think anyone is faulting him for the difficulties that he has encountered in Azerbaijan.'' Azerbaijan is separated from the republics of Central Asia by the Caspian Sea, but both populations are largely Moslem and speak dialects of Turkish. The Central Asians are unlikely to engage in radical opposition to Gorbachev because they are very poor and depend on heavy subsidies from Moscow, said Goble. ``In Central Asia, there is absolutely no move toward independence,'' said Goble. ``The fighting probably will not spark unrest in Central Asia,'' said the administration source. ``There are other factors at work behind discontent'' in the Central Asian republics, he said, citing high unemployment rates, a shortage of drinking water and a soaring infant mortality rate. The CIA has recently finished a study that reached the same conclusion, an administration source said. The people of Azerbaijan are mostly Shiite Moslems, like the majority in Iran. Most people in the Central Asian Republics of Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kirghizia and Tadzhikistan speak different dialects of Turkish and are by and large Sunni Moslems, like the population of Afghanistan to the south.

DOC.HEAD: Light Industrial Goods Best Prospects for US Export to East Europe
DOC.TEXT: Although it may be some time before the dust settles from political upheavals in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, an Agriculture Department think tank is already looking at the future of agricultural trade in the region. The Centrally Planned Economies Branch of the department's Economic Research Service used a computer model to estimate what Eastern Europe may buy and sell in the next decade or so, says an article in the February issue of Farmline magazine. Analysts said that for the region as a whole, the best U.S. export prospects are textiles, high-value processed foods and similar ``light'' industrial goods. ``By nation (the analysts) expect increased grain purchases by Yugoslavia, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria, but average or less-than-average purchases by the Soviet Union,'' the report said. The computer study also indicated ``a general upward trend'' in oilseed imports by the East Europeans. ``Hungary is expected to find it advantageous to export grain and import livestock, and Yugoslavia could become a livestock importer,'' the report said. ``Poland and Bulgaria are expected to increase livestock imports.'' But the region has many political and economic challenges as the individual countries _ with the exception of Albania _ adopt some form of market system and shift away from centrally planned economies. ``Key goals of all the nations are, first, to make their currencies fully exchangeable with other currencies _ a status known as convertibility _ and, second, to remove controls over prices and wages,'' the report said. Although some of the countries get around convertibility problems by using some forms of barter, U.S. businesses prefer hard currency. As of early January, Hungary, Poland and East Germany were seen as making the most progress toward convertibility. ``The Soviet Union has a two-steps-forward, one-back approach toward lifting economic controls,'' the report said. ``The USDA specialists say Moscow appears to be concerned about the speculative trading opportunities offered by an open marketplace, and it does not want to be considered an ally of the middleman.''

Agriculture Department scientists say many farm crops show good resistance to acid rain and that there is a possibility of developing even tougher strains. A team at the Agricultural Research Service's laboratory in Raleigh, N.C., exposed 216 varieties of 18 crops to simulated acid rain many times more acidic than found now in the eastern United States. ``The simulated acid rain caused no significant injury, nor did it reduce growth in most species,'' the agency said in a report. Acid rain contains pollutants from the atmosphere, such as sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide present in exhausts from factory smokestacks and automobiles. These chemicals make the rain more acid. The experiments were conducted by botanist Denis T. Dubay, plant pathologist Allen S. Heagle and plant physiologist Walter W. Heck. ``Tomatoes, eggplant, snapbeans, cotton, peanuts and soybeans were the only crops whose leaves showed damage of more than 5 percent after the one-hour exposure,'' the report said. ``The most sensitive variety of tomato had as much as 24 percent of its leaf area damaged by the single exposure.'' But at the other end of the scale, potatoes, corn, lettuce, winter wheat, orchardgrass, melons, fescue, cucumbers, alfalfa, clover and squash all had less than 2 percent leaf damage. Crops that suffered the greatest damage in the shorter-term acute tests also registered the most damage in chronic tests for up to 15 days of simulated acid rain at a time. Leaf damage varied greatly by varieties for tomatoes and soybeans, raising the possibility of breeding hardier strains of acid-resistant crops if those are needed someday, the report said.

A trade association says about 75 percent of the nation's 1990 winter wheat acreage has been put under multiple peril crop insurance protection, based on preliminary figures. Eugene Gantz, executive vice president of the American Association of Crop Insurers, said large increases in coverage were reported in Oklahoma, Kansas, Texas, Colorado and Nebraska. Overall, an estimated 80 percent of the wheat planted last fall in Kansas, Nebraska and Texas is insured, and 60 percent in Colorado and Oklahoma. The debate in Congress on new farm legislation includes controversy about operations of the Federal Crop Insurance Corp. in the Agriculture Department, which subsidizes multiple-peril coverage sold to farmers. Federal crop insurance is sold by private companies that are reinsured by FCIC against most losses. So-called master marketers sell and service policies directly on behalf of the agency. Participation in the federal crop insurance program has been slim in many years, with many farmers preferring to rely on emergency aid and disaster payments from USDA when drought or other disasters strike.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexual Priest Under Fire From Bishop; Could Start Own Church
DOC.TEXT: A recently ordained homosexual priest said he may start his own church if he is forced to resign from the Episcopal clergy because of his belief that monogamy is unnecessary for a Christian relationship. The Rev. J. Robert Williams resigned Saturday from Oasis, a church program ministering to homosexuals, but said Sunday he will remain an Episcopal priest at All Saints Episcopal Church in Hoboken. ``I'm not making a decision to leave the church unless they force me to leave the church,'' Williams said. ``Before I got ordained, I was thinking of starting my own church, and that may be something that I'll have to do after all in order to tell the truth.'' Bishop John S. Spong said he will request an investigation of Williams by the diocese of Newark, and may ask the priest to resign if he does not agree to uphold the principles of monogamy espoused by the church. Spong, who said the diocese would find a replacement for Williams in the Oasis program, ordained Williams last month despite objections of many conservative Episcopalians. Williams, a Texas native, provoked further controversy at a Jan. 13 church forum in Detroit by calling monogamy ``as unnatural as celibacy.'' The comments were carried by the Religious News Service, the Star-Ledger reported Sunday. Spong said in a statement that Williams would not have been ordained had church officials known of his views on monogamy. He said officials were unaware of it although Williams had been screened for ordination for two years. ``His own life needs to be conducted according to the same standards applied to all priests, homosexual or heterosexual,'' Spong wrote. ``If Mr. Williams is not able to conform to the standards of this diocese, then his resignation would be requested.'' Spong said he asked Williams to apologize, but the priest said he has no intention of changing his views on monogamy. Williams said few heterosexual or homosexual couples are faithful. ``I think monogamy is an option,'' he said. ``Some couples choose it and some couples don't. I believe you can have a successful and a Christian relationship either way.'' The priest said he felt that Spong was using him as a scapegoat for the pressure he was feeling from church authorities over his ordination. Williams has said hundreds of Episcopal priests are homosexual, but most keep their sexual orientation private. The General Convention of the Episcopal Church in 1979 approved a resolution saying it is inappropriate for the church to ordain a practicing homosexual. Williams, 34, has lived with James Skelly, 39, a hospital administrator, for four years.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,173.70, up 299.63 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Third World Debtor Countries Live Better Than Average
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank says people in countries that have gone deeply into debt enjoy higher living standards than the average Third World country. The bank calculates that Third World countries owe a total of $1.3 trillion. Some are in trouble with their creditors and have tried austerity measures to grow out of their difficulties, but they still seem to be in constant crisis. In many ways, however, debt seems to have little effect on their progress. Mexico, the largest Third World debtor after Brazil, has completed the biggest and most difficult arrangement yet for reducing the burden of the $104 billion it owes, using the strategy proposed last year by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Reduction in the actual debt is expected to be small because there also will be new lending to Mexico. More important is a reduction expected in the $7 billion that has been flowing out of the country every year, mostly as interest and repayment of principal. Compared with many Third World countries, Mexico is fairly well off, the World Bank found. In 1988 the average Mexican earned the equivalent of $1,820, compared with $1,970 for what the bank calls the average middle-income country _ a group that includes such diverse countries as Malaysia and Poland. The bank this week distributed to reporters its ``Social Indicators of Development.'' The document includes only approximate dates because some countries compile their figures more quickly than others, so that the latest statistics available come from different years, depending on the country.
DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Blames Contras for New Year's Ambush of Nuns
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. human rights group's investigation concludes that Contra rebel forces were responsible for the New Year's Day ambush and killing of two Roman Catholic nuns, including an American, in Nicaragua. The private human rights group, Americas Watch, said in a 53-page report Sunday that its investigation, which included numerous interviews and other data obtained in Nicaragua, found that the ambush was conducted by Contra forces. The report said it appears the attack was not aimed specifically at the nuns. The two nuns, including Sister Maureen Courtney, 45, of Milwaukee, Wis., were killed when the white pickup in which they were riding came under attack on a remote highway 165 miles northeast of Managua. A bishop and another nun survived the attack. The Contra rebels have denied any involvement. ``It is our conclusion, based on this investigation, that those responsible were a unit of the rebel Resistencia Nicaraguense, or Contras, firing indiscriminately at the vehicle without warning to stop, but also without knowledge that the vehicle belonged to the church,'' the report by Americas Watch said. The group had been asked by five members of Congress to investigate the shooting.
DOC.HEAD: Report: Barry Paved Way for Rasheeda Moore's No-Bid Contract
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry personally urged Hazel Diane ``Rasheeda'' Moore in 1986 to seek city funding for a no-bid contract to teach self-esteem training to inner city youths, according to a published report. Moore's former business partner, Carole Bland Jackson, was quoted by The Washington Post on Sunday as saying Barry came up with the idea at a Friday night party in June 1986. Jackson said she drew up the $52,488 ``Project Me'' program within a day and it was approved the following Monday. Jackson later became director of the project. At the time, Jackson and others said, Barry was seeking a sexual relationship with Moore. Moore is the woman who allegedly lured Barry to a downtown Washington hotel on Jan. 18, where the mayor was subsequently arrested and charged with possession of cocaine. Barry is currently in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he is undergoing treatment for chemical dependency. Jackson said she and Moore approached Barry at the 1986 party and asked him to emcee a fashion show. The mayor declined, but asked the women to come up with a program to supplement his summer youth program. After Jackson devised the ``Project Me'' program, she said Barry ``basically told people'' at the Department of Employment Services that they should give Moore whatever was needed for the program. ``I learned later that there's a process for getting the money and ours was pushed through,'' Jackson said.

DOC.HEAD: `Robin HUD' to Plead Guilty in HUD Thefts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing scheduled to start 10 a.m. EST; will be led
DOC.TEXT: The real estate agent dubbed ``Robin HUD,'' who admitted stealing millions in federal housing funds and claimed she gave much of it to the poor, said she sees prison as a chance to go to college. Marilyn Louise Harrell said she planned to plead guilty today at the start of her U.S. District Court trial. She is accused of stealing more than $5 million in government funds, lying to federal officials and filing false tax returns. ``I don't want to spend taxpayers' money in a court proceeding,'' the 46-year-old real estate agent from Waldorf, told The Sun newspaper in a story published Friday. Under an agreement with federal prosecutors, Harrell said she agreed to plead guilty to stealing government property and failing to report income for taxes. In return, she said, prosecutors agreed to drop two other tax counts, two counts of lying to HUD officials and one count of lying to a bank on a loan application. The two charges she said she would admit to carried a maximum sentence of 13 years in prison. But she said that under federal sentencing guidelines, she could serve 2{ to 3 years in prison. If convicted on all seven counts, Harrell would have faced up to 31 years in prison and more than $1 million in fines. Harrell and her lawyer, Anthony R. Gallagher, have unlisted telephone numbers and could not be reached for comment Sunday. The Sun said Gallagher declined to comment Friday. U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox declined to comment Sunday. Harrell said she hoped to be sentenced to perform community service but saw prison as a chance to get a college degree. ``I told the kids just think of it as Mom going away a few years for college,'' Harrell said of her son, John, and his wife, Vicki. Last year, Harrell told a congressional committee she took millions in U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development money and used most of it to buy cars and housing for the needy. Prosecutors said Harrell took at least $5.67 million from HUD, money generated by sales of HUD properties that Harrell handled as a private escrow agent for the agency. Prosecutors acknowledged some of the money went to charities, but alleged she spent most of the money on herself and her family. But Harrell said she has documents to prove that she took only $4.75 million in HUD funds and that ``less than 6 percent'' of the money benefited her family. Harrell said she has prepared herself for imprisonment since 1985, when she started diverting HUD funds. ``I really truthfully consider it an honor to give up years of my life to help some of the people I've helped,'' she said. Harrell, who confessed to government officials in December 1988, became a symbol of mismanagement at HUD when scandal erupted there last summer. Following her indictment last November, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the case was the largest involving the theft of federal funds by an individual.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded Monday, while the dollar edged down against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues regained 299.63 points, or 0.81 percent, ending at 37,173.70. It had lost 95.04 points Friday. The dollar closed at 143.22 yen, down 0.75 yen from Friday's close of 143.97 yen. It opened at 143.07 yen and ranged between 142.85 yen and 143.23 yen. Traders said the dollar opened sharply lower here as it was buffeted by a worse-than-expected showing of the U.S. gross national product. It moved narrowly afterwards as market players made position adjustments, they said. The U.S. Commerce Department reported Friday that the nation's gross national product grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 0.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. Some market analysts predicted that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board would ease its monetary policy to counter the nation's faltering economy. ``The market this week will try to see how far the dollar can go down,'' said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities, Co. in Tokyo. ``But the dollar already fell almost 3 yen from the 146 yen level last week, it is unlikely to fall further so quickly,'' he said, adding that the market is watching what U.S. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan says in speeches scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday. On the stock market, the index rose as market players were reassured by the yen's strength and was also helped by index-linked buyings by speculative investors, dealers said. But trading was inactive amid uncertainties over the direction of U.S. monetary policy, in addition to the major election here expected next month, said a dealer with Nomura Securities, Co. ``The Nikkei rose, but market players were just not in a mood to invest,'' he said on condition of anonymity. He added that the volume was unusually small for the first day of February contracts. In stock trading, monthly contracts start four days prior to the calender month. ``The market has cooled down, and it won't change unless these negative factors disappear one by one,'' the dealer said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Family and friends went with the flow when Bill Heflin and Susan Davis exchanged wedding vows thigh-deep in a steamy, 110-degree hot tub. ``We wanted it to be something special we can look back on and giggle about,'' Heflin said about Saturday's ceremony under a gazebo behind his home 25 miles southeast of San Francisco. Instead of a tuxedo, the 39-year-old Heflin wore a suit coat, T-shirt and cut-off suit pants. The bride wore a cream-colored blouse, a flowered hairpiece and the bottom half of a silk sari over Lycra shorts. ``I wanted to be formal from the waist up, informal from the waist down,'' said Davis, 35. Adding to the atmosphere were fragrant gardenias floating on the swirling hot tub water, rock music and the wedding march played on a harmonica by one of Davis' daughters, 9-year-old Jamie. ``I thought that maybe he'd lost his marbles,'' said Fay Bryan, the bride's mother and one of 40 guests. ``I think it's going to be great for her, though.''

When the Monroe Township Groundhog Society members meet, they shake hands and then snort at each other. The snort as a form of greeting is no laughing matter to a society in which members wear fake fur and groundhog hoods with ears, according to Dr. David Steele, the group's historian. The society requires the 18 members to ``pass the snort test and take at least one snort a year.'' The society was formed in 1929, but folded in 1935. With the discovery of some old society papers, the group re-emerged last January. Steele said that many people can't understand why a grown man wants to become a groundhog member, although the civic group raises funds for community projects in the central Indiana town about 30 miles northeast of Indianapolis. ``Each year we have $1,000 to $1,500 to put back into the community. At the same time, we get to act silly _ like little boys,'' he said. And to celebrate Groundhog Day in proper style. On Friday, at the society's annual ``swill'' breakfast on Groundhog Day, member Sam Lower will emerge from a groundhog mound made of pipe, bushes and canvas only after hearing the group's chant: ``Groundhog, groundhog, we must know. Is it spring or is it snow? Tell us, tell us, we can't wait. Come on out, you reprobate.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate To Demand Ouster Of Revolutionary Government
DOC.TEXT: More than 15,000 Romanians mounted the largest anti-government rally since last month's revolution, breaking through a line of soldiers and threatening to ``come get'' the new leader from his headquarters. Interim President Ion Iliescu, struggling to free his government from any association with Communism and the ousted Ceausescu regime, said later Sunday that opposition parties had agreed to broad talks. During the rally outside government headquarters in Victory Square, protesters said the ruling National Salvation Front should resign because of its decision last week to compete in elections. Many called for opposition participation in the interim government, claiming the front is not, for example, allowing its political competitors enough access to broadcast media. ``I was in the revolution .... I protected Iliescu and the front because I thought they were good people. But they are not, they are liars,'' said Mihai Gheorghescu, an official with the opposition National Peasants Party. The protesters had rushed through a line of armed soldiers and assembled at the doors of the government headquarters. Some scurried atop a half-dozen tanks guarding the building. The crowd booed Iliescu when he appeared on an upper floor of the building and tried to speak. The protesters chanted ``Resign! Resign!'' and ``Get out, or we'll come get you out!'' Iliescu was named head of a loose coalition of disaffected Communists and intellectuals who assumed power after the revolt ousted the 24-year regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed with his wife, Elena, on Dec. 25. But the front has come under intense criticism since announcing its intention to compete in free elections set for May 20 against newly formed opposition parties. Critics say the front cannot fairly compete in balloting it will also administer. They note that it contains some former ranking Communists and contend it supports a return to one-party rule. Pro-government demonstrators also crowded around the building Sunday, chanting ``Iliescu ... We are with you!.'' But they were outnumbered and out-shouted by the opposition forces. The two sides booed and hissed at each other, but there was no violence. No injuries were reported as the line of soldiers about 75 yards from the building gave way to the crowd. The soldiers then re-formed their line five deep at the building's entrances. After nightfall, truckloads of pro-government demonstrators were brought to the square, some shouting that the opposition protesters were ``provocateurs'' and ``gypsies.'' After the reinforcements arrived, Iliescu reappeared and shouted over a microphone that the front had met representatives of the three parties sponsoring the protest. ``All the political parties agreed to cooperate, including the three that sponsored this demonstration,'' Iliescu said. ``Next week, we will continue the dialogue.'' He said all of the more than 20 parties seeking to run candidates in the elections would meet with front leaders Thursday. Earlier, a spokesman with the opposition Peasants Party said that party leaders met Iliescu to demand that the front give way to a broader-based interim government. A small crowd held a separate protest at the headquarters of the state radio and television building and demanded access to the media to call for the resignation of the provisional government. About 2,000 of the National Salvation Front's backers held another rally earlier at a nearby district government building, chanting ``The front is us, and we are the people!'' Earlier Sunday, Iliescu had criticized the anti-government demonstrators in a televised speech. ``To destabilize the National Salvation Front right now means destabilizing the country,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Glitzy Resort Town Gearing up For Fur-Ban Referendum
DOC.TEXT: Simmering beneath the winter wonderland facade of this glitzy ski resort town is an emotional issue: whether to ban the sale of furs. Led by the mayor and his wife, animal-rights activists are urging residents to vote for the citywide ban in a special election Feb. 13. It would be the first time a U.S. city has taken such a step, says Katharine Thalberg, leader of the Aspen Society for Animal Rights and wife of Bill Stirling, mayor of this city of 3,500 full-time residents. ``Furs are frivolous,'' Stirling said. ``Aspen is not willing to earn sales tax on an industry based on cruelty.'' And Aspen, Stirling said, is ``avant-garde'' _ the first community in the nation to pass an anti-smoking law, to declare itself a nuclear-free zone and to pass a tax specifically to finance the acquisition of open space. ``I see Aspen again being out there at the head of the pack,'' he said. Opponents say the ban would infringe upon consumers' freedom of choice and could drive away big-spending tourists. ``We've made our reputation on tolerance,'' said furrier Mark Kirkland. ``Now we're wrecking that. ... I've had letters and the hotels have had guests tell them that if this passes, they'll find another ski resort to go to.'' Richard Parsons, executive director of the Washington, D.C.-based Fur Information Council of America, denied that fur farms are inhumane in their management of fur-bearing animals. He sees the issue as a local political question. ``It appears the mayor is trying to take his and his wife's personal moral agendas and legislate them,'' said Parsons. ``Furs today _ who knows what restaurant they'll tell what to serve tomorrow.'' On the ballot with the fur-ban plan is a proposal to scale a $70 million Ritz-Carlton hotel already under construction at the base of Aspen Mountain. The pro-fur people tend also to be pro-Ritz, Thalberg says. Meanwhile, Stirling and three of the four other City Council members face a March 13 recall election for their handling of both issues. An underlying factor in the election is ``the resentment of the incredible wealth that has been pouring in here,'' said Dave Danforth, publisher of the Aspen Daily News. Danforth noted that many Aspen workers are forced to live up to 65 miles away because of escalating real estate prices. A popular, somewhat bitter, line in Aspen these days talks about the ``billionaires driving out the millionaires,'' he said. Last year, the average home in the area sold for $1.1 million, said Gary Feldman, president of the Pitkin County Board of Realtors. There are few outward signs here of the heat generated by the proposed fur ban, aside from some anti-fur posters, calls to radio talk shows and letters to the editors of the two daily newspapers. ``The purchasing of furs has and always will be a marked distinction of wealth and of those aspiring to wealth, and the ban of such furs will do nothing but bring ridicule to the economic aspirations of such a fine cultural resort town,'' wrote Donna Maier of Denver. But Patrice Stinson of Reston, Va., wrote that she ``would love the opportunity to spend some time in a fur-free city.'' ``Imagine the increased revenue for your city when anti-fur animal activists learn that your city is fur-free,'' she wrote. ``We'll have someplace to go that is tailored to our lifestyles and conforms with our views.'' Stirling scoffs at claims that the ordinance would keep visitors away, saying the same arguments were made in 1985 when the town adopted its strict ban on smoking in restaurants, offices and just about all buildings except bars and private homes. ``Freedom of choice was constantly rearing its head during the smoking debate, just as it is now,'' Stirling said. His wife, who owns a bookstore, predicts the ban will pass. She notes that in 1986 voters approved an ordinance banning the sale of furs from animals caught in a leg-hold trap, though it proved unenforceable. ``This ordinance does not prevent the wearing of furs,'' Thalberg said. ``As for selling them, well, trade is not entirely unrestricted in this country. If society, for whatever reasons, decides something shouldn't be sold, then legislation is passed. It is not being shoved down anyone's throat. It's an election.''

DOC.HEAD: Castro Holds To Communist Line _ `Even If Moscow Pulls The Plug'
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro of Cuba, in defiant rejection of the democratic reforms sweeping other Communist nations, has declared that his country will stick to orthodox communism even if Moscow ends all support. Castro's remarks in speeches Sunday, quoted in news reports, represented the first time he has suggested the Soviets might cut off the assistance that helps power his 31-year-old revolution. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been urging Cuba to liberalize its political system and Moscow has cut back on aid. Castro said he understood that internal problems were leading the Kremlin to cut back on its $5 billion in annual aid to Cuba, an apparent reference to separatist movements and economic troubles plaguing Gorbachev. ``The Yankees are euphoric because they believe we will be isolated and cannot resist. There are even some who have virtually extended condolences because they believe the revolution will not survive the changes in the Socialist bloc,'' Castro was quoted as saying in a speech. However, he was quoting as saying Cuba stands ready to live ``under a wartime economy'' if need be. Virtually all of Cuba's crude oil comes from the Soviet Union at cut-rate prices. Castro said he would brook no political liberalization, rejecting a petition for recognition by an opposition party. ``We don't want fifth columns to be created here at a time when everything is at stake,'' Castro was quoted as saying. He said Cuba must resist U.S. ``imperialism'' for the sake of all Latin America. The Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina and the Mexican government news agency Notimex filed dispatches from Havana on Castro's remarks, which came in a three-hour speech to 2,500 delegates at the annual congress of Cuba's labor federation and an address to a rally of 15,000 people protesting U.S. plans for a television station to beam special programs to Cuba. The agencies were monitored in Mexico City. ``The (Cuban) Revolution will not back down one millimeter, not even if it is totally blockaded by the United States or if the Soviet Union totally cuts off its supplies,'' said Castro. ``We have prepared ourselves to engage in the struggle by all the people in defense of socialism,'' he said, warning that Cubans may have to tighten their belts and live ``at peace but under a wartime economy.'' ``It will not be here where the history of other countries will be able to repeat itself, and those who want to play at counterrevolution are going to have to face the people,'' Castro was quoted as saying in reference to demonstrations that have overthrown Communist governments in Eastern Europe. Castro, in power since a popular revoluton ousted dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959, has staunchly resisted any talk of liberalizing his rule. The sudden fall of President Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania in December gave rise to speculation that Cuba or Albania would be the next country to undergo major changes. In his remarks on Yankee ``euphoria,'' Castro may have been referring to reports that the Miami police department has established a contingency plan to control celebrations by Cuban exiles if Castro falls. The United States imposed a trade and financial embargo on Cuba more than 20 years ago, accusing the island nation's government of inciting revolution in other nations. In his speech, Castro confirmed reports that his government had rejected a petition from the Miami-based Christian Democratic Party to be given legal status and allowed to take part in politics. ``The secret of Cuban resistance in these 30 years of revolution has been the unity of the government, the people and the party, and a multiparty system would only result in internal weakening,'' Castro was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Arrested, Taken to Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with physician saying Honecker still not well enough to be jailed, unclear if prison has hospital unit. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker, who is expected to be indicted for high treason, was arrested Monday morning upon release from a hospital and taken to prison, the official news agency ADN said. The news agency said the 77-year-old Honecker was arrested after being released from East Berlin's Charite hospital, where he had undergone surgery for a malignant kidney tumor. Honecker was immediately taken to East Berlin's Rummelsburg prison, the brief dispatch said. Honecker joins other members of his ousted Politburo already in prison awaiting trial. Earlier this month, East German prosecutors said Honecker and former state security chief Erich Mielke would be charged with treason and corruption charges for misuse of their positions and state funds. Honecker, the aging hard-line Stalinist leader who ruled East Germany for 18 years until his ouster on Oct. 18, had previously been declared too ill to withstand imprisonment. ADN said that the director of Charite urology clinic, Dr. Peter Althaus, repeated on Monday that in his opinion Honecker was still not well enough to be jailed. On Sunday, West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper said Honecker would be arrested, but that he would be held at a prison hospital because of his condition. ADN made not mention if Rummelsburg prison was equipped with a medical facility. Earlier this month, East Germany's Luthern Church had offered to put Honecker up in a home for the aged upon his release from the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Lafontaine, Popular Leftist, Emerges as Kohl Challenger
With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine has risen with an electoral triumph from the shadows of regional office to position himself as Chancellor Helmut Kohl's challenger in December's federal elections. The 46-year-old governor of tiny Saarland state, an independent-minded leftist, led his party to resounding victory in regional balloting Sunday, virtually assuring his nomination as the party's candidate for chancellor. Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Union was handed the latest in a string of local setbacks. The Free Democrats, his centrist partner in the governing Bonn coalition, also lost seats. Nationally well-known and respected as a tough career politician, Lafontaine would be strong opposition in Kohl's bid for a third four-year term as West German leader. Sunday's vote in Saarland was an unexpectedly strong endorsement for Lafontaine's entry into national politics as his party widened its absolute majority in the state parliament. Lafontaine's campaign focused on the economic and social impacts of the wave of East Germans resettling in West Germany and the election's outcome illustrated the public's growing resentment over the influx. The Social Democrats polled 54.4, compared with 33.4 percent for the Christian Democratic Union and 5.6 percent for the Free Democrats. The environmentalist Greens party polled 2.7 percent, short of the 5 percent needed to enter the regional parliament. The ultra-rightist Republicans, making their debut in Saarland, received 3.3 percent of the vote. According to preliminary official results, the Social Democrats won 30 of the parliament's 51 seats, a gain of four. Kohl's party won 18, down two, while the Free Democrats dropped from five to three seats. For Kohl, it was a damper after last fall's sudden democratic changes in East Germany stirred hopes for German reunification and boosted the chancellor's standing. Lafontaine had urged that generous federal and state benefits for East German immigrants be cut to encourage them to stay at home and work for democratic change there. He said Sunday night that the Saarland vote was a warning to Bonn. ``A majority of the population does not tolerate that one talks about future forms of statehood but not about current social problems,'' he told West German television. ``It is nonsensical to offer bounties for leaving (East Germany).'' About 47,000 East Germans have fled political and economic uncertainty in their Communist-led homeland since Jan. 1, and up to 2,500 still arrive daily. Nearly 344,000 migrated to West Germany last year, putting great strain on social services and housing markets. Lafontaine recently called himself a ``German patriot in the tradition of enlightenment and tolerance.'' ``German unity is absolutely no problem, but it must be embedded in European integration,'' he added Sunday. He said he was surprised by the extent of the victory but refused to comment on a national candidacy. ``The other questions come later,'' he told West German television. Lafontaine already has the informal blessing of his party chairman Hans-Jochen Vogel to take on Kohl. Vogel predicts ``outstanding achievements'' for Lafontaine, who began a meteoric political career at age 21 in his party's youth organization. In Saarbruecken, he became the youngest mayor of any West German city at age 32. When he was voted deputy chairman of the Social Democrats in 1987, he had become known as a gadfly opposed particularly to the party's conservative wing, led by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt. Lafontaine vocally opposed plans to station U.S. medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany, pushed by Schmidt in the late 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Government Captures Leader of Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Troops early today captured a key leader in last month's coup attempt, and the military chief said the arrest would severely weaken efforts to launch a new bid to topple the government. Brig. Gen. Edgardo Abenina, captured outside a house in suburban Quezon City with two other rebel officers, is believed to be the most important leader arrested so far in connection with the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. Abenina jumped a fence fleeing the troops but fell and injured a leg, said Brig. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon, chief of the National Capital Region Defense Command. He then surrendered, Biazon said. The two other rebel officers arrested at the hideout were a major and captain, the military said. Biazon accused Abenina of forming the coalition of soldiers and supporters of the late President Ferdinand Marcos who led the December attacks, the sixth and bloodiest bid to oust President Corazon Aquino. Abenina was supposed to be a member of the military junta that would have replaced Mrs. Aquino had the coup succeeded, Biazon said. Abenina, a former Philippine Constabulary regional commander, was believed to be the senior officer in the coup attempt. At least 113 people were killed and more than 500 injured in the failed coup, the most serious effort to topple Mrs. Aquino since she was swept to power in the civilian-military uprising that ousted Marcos in February 1986. Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said Abenina's capture showed the determination of the armed forces to arrest those believed behind the coup attempt. ``Abenina's capture will undoubtedly weaken their movement and further reduce their capability to destabilize society,'' he said. De Villa said the arrest was made possible because of ``the widespread support of concerned civilians'' but gave no details. The military had offered a $45,500 reward for Abenina's capture. Mrs. Aquino told reporters she was ``very happy and very pleased'' about Abenina's arrest and said the government would spare no efforts to capture all rebels still at large. Earlier this month, Sen. Joseph Estrada released a letter from Abenina in which he said the coup participants wanted to eliminate government corruption and usher in social, economic and political reform. ``The Aquino government has failed,'' Abenina said in the letter. ``It has failed to govern and ensure the safety and well-being of its citizens. We need a government that reflects our virtues.'' Abenina was also implicated in an August 1987 coup attempt led by former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, who remains at large. Abenina was removed from his command in the central city of Cebu after that attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Moved to Isolated Cell in Miami Federal Prison
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega has been transferred from an apartment-like holding area in the federal courthouse to an isolated cell in a nearby prison, officials said. Noriega, who faces federal drug charges, had been held in the basement of the the downtown courthouse after being brought to the United States on Jan. 4. He was admitted to Metropolitan Correctional Center 25 miles south of Miami on Sunday evening, said the warden, Stephen Pontesso. The prison is medium security but has some maximum-security cells. Pontesso refused to describe Noriega's quarters in detail, calling it simply ``a cell.'' The Miami Hearld today reported that Noriega was placed in a specially-built large cell in the administration area where at least one guard will watch him at all times. Steven Kollin, a defense attorney, confirmed that his client was being held separately from the prison's general population. Noriega, who has appeared in court in his uniform, wore civilian clothes and slumped down in the back of a station wagon as he was driven past the prison entrance. He was taken there because it is the standard holding place for federal prisoners held in south Florida, said Jim Jones, regional spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Prisons. After Noriega was moved, Kollin met with him at the prison. ``Our position is that he should not be at MCC,'' Kollin said afterward. ``He should be at Homestead Air Force Base as a temporary measure because he is a prisoner of war, and he should be at Homestead only to await transfer to a neutral third country.'' On Friday, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ordered Noriega held without bond after he and his attorneys refused to participate at a bail hearing. They said they had sent a letter to Bush administration officials claiming prisoner of war status for Noriega, who surrendered two weeks after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama. Asked about Noriega's disposition, Kollin said his client ``is hopeful _ and confident _ that our position regarding his prisoner-of-war status will be upheld.'' Noriega was indicted in Florida in February 1988 on 12 drug-trafficking counts. His trial is scheduled for March 5. Four co-defendants _ former Panamanian Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, William Saldarriaga, Daniel Mirand and Eduardo Pardo _ also are being held at the prison, which houses about 1,000 inmates.

DOC.HEAD: Seventh Graders Line up For Chance to Take College Boards
DOC.TEXT: Some teen-agers taking the college boards probably were surprised to see the person in the next chair had not quite reached puberty. More than 35 percent of the 250,000 students who take the Standardized Achievement Test in January are 12 and 13 years old, said Roy Nicosia of the Educational Testing Service, which develops and administers the test. The three-hour exam measures aptitude in math, vocabulary, reading comprehension and grammar and is used by 1,600 American colleges to help determine admissions, according to ETS. Under a program called Project Talent, the test, usually reserved for juniors, seniors and the occasional sophomore, is open to seventh graders who excel in their schools. Whiz kids who score well on the test get to take advanced classes during summer school. ``I'm a little nervous because I just feel I'm going to do bad, because it's for older kids, and I'm not going to be able to do it,'' said Jennifer Twomey, 12, a seventh grader at the Lincoln Middle School in Brookline. Jennifer, who took the test Saturday, qualified for the talent search by scoring among the top 3 percent on an achievement test the town requires of its sixth graders, said Pam Capece, a Lincoln guidance counselor. ``I didn't even know people took the SATs when they were in seventh grade,'' Jennifer said. ``When I found out about it I was excited. I wanted to see if I could do it.'' Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore coordinates the talent search for 19 states in the Northeast and District of Columbia. Duke University, the University of Colorado and Northwestern University cover gifted students from the rest of the country. Linda Barnett, director of talent identification at Hopkins, said most of the seventh graders take the test simply to see how they do. ``It doesn't carry the same kind of pressure that a junior or senior would feel. It's not going to affect whether they get into college,'' she said. That's not to say 12-year-olds are too young to start thinking about college. The program was designed to better prepare the brightest students for the rigors of higher education, she said. ``We want them to start thinking about it so when they are juniors or seniors they don't say `Omigosh, why didn't I take more math?''' Barnett said. Not everyone agrees with that philosophy. Jennifer was one of 12 students eligible for the program from Lincoln, but not all qualified students participate, Capece said. ``It's a very hard test,'' said Capece. ``It's extremely difficult, and a lot of children's parents don't want to subject their kids to standardized testing that they don't have to be a part of.'' Jennifer said she was getting some tips from her 16-year-old sister Angela, a student at Brookline High School, who also took the test Saturday. ``She said, `You'll probably do better than me because you're so smart,''' Jennifer said. Asked who she thought would do better, Jennifer said her sister likely would ``because she's learned most of the stuff.'' The top score possible in each of the two categories on the SATs, verbal and math, is 800. The average college-bound senior male scores 430 verbal and 500 math, while average juniors and seniors score lower, said Barnett. If the youngsters score as high as the average junior or senior, they get citations, awards and the chance to go to career symposia or one-day seminars in humanities and math, Barnett said. Those who score as high as the average college-bound senior male get to go to three-week summer sessions in five locations throughout the country, as well as Geneva, Switzerland. They take high school math and sciences, or some college courses in language, Barnett said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Drenches South; Snow Falls in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain dampened parts of the South early today, and snow fell in Pennsylvania and Indiana. On Sunday, snow fell across the Northwest and the Rockies. Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas, and Alabama all reported rain early today. Rain also drenched Cincinnati. Snow advisories were posted today for southern Illinois, northeast Ohio, western Maryland, much of West Virginia, northwestern Virginia and northern Delaware. Winter storm watches were posted for tonight over much of eastern and central Pennsylvania, a large part of New York state and Vermont. By Sunday evening, a cold front reached from the Atlantic across southern Delaware, southwest Virginia, northwest Alabama, northwest Louisiana, and the central Texas Gulf Coast. Snow fell over south-central and southwest Pennsylvania, western Maryland, West Virginia, southern Ohio, southern Indiana, northern Kentucky and southwest Illinois. In southeastern Louisiana, floods that damaged at least 850 homes began to recede Sunday, but a threat of further flooding remained. A 50 percent chance of rain was forecast for today around Baton Rouge, which was hardest hit by flooding. Bertha Helmke of Baton Rouge recalled how she helped haul her family's belongings out of her home Friday and then sat back and watched the water pour in for the third time in 13 years. ``Throughout the whole thing I didn't shed a tear, but now it's all hitting me,'' Helmke said. ``You just feel like you're at God's end. I don't know what to do.'' In the West, a storm lashed Oregon on Sunday with strong winds and heavy rain to coastal areas and a foot of snow to the Cascades. Gusty winds knocked tree limbs into a power line near the studios of KVAL-TV in Eugene, interrupting broadcast of the Super Bowl for 40 minutes. By afternoon, about a foot of blowing, drifting snow had fallen in the mountain passes of Washington state in 24 hours. Interstate 90, the state's major east-west highway, was temporarily closed because of avalanche danger. Rain or snow was forecast for most of the state today and Tuesday. Rain also fell Sunday on northwest California. The Northeast basked in warm weather Sunday. Record highs for the date were set in New York, where temperatures reached 58 degrees, and in Caribou, Maine, at 42 degrees. The high for the nation Sunday was 84 degrees at Naples, Fla.
