DOC.HEAD: Funeral Held for McAuliffe's Father
DOC.TEXT: Funeral services were held for Edward C. Corrigan on the fourth anniversary of the Challenger explosion that killed his daughter, school teacher-astronaut Christa McAuliffe. At Sunday's funeral at St. Jeremiah's church, music was played on a carillon that had been donated in McAuliffe's memory. Corrigan, who died Thursday, had worked tirelessly in the years the explosion to keep his daughter's memory alive. ``It is ironic that the date that was the saddest day in Ed's life now marks his entry into the eternal joys of heaven,'' said the Rev. James Leary, of Bristol, Conn., who was a cousin of Corrigan. Corrigan, a retired accountant, was 67 when he died after a long bout with cancer. About 450 people attended the Roman Catholic service. McAuliffe, from Concord, N.H., and six other crew members of the Challenger died in the explosion seconds after the Jan. 28, 1986, liftoff. Leary said the faith of Corrigan and his wife, Grace, helped carry them through the tragedy of losing a daughter. ``They did not allow it to crush their spirit,'' he said. Stephen Corrigan, a son, said his parents ``had been traveling around the country, trying to convey the same message that Christa did about the importance of education.'' Corrigan is also survived by another son and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Delta, American Jets Grounded By Smoke in Cabin
DOC.TEXT: A Delta Air Lines jet that had taken off once and returned to the airport because of an engine warning light was evacuated during another takeoff try when smoke blew into the cabin, authorities said. Only minor injuries were reported when passengers slid down emergency chutes in Sunday's evacuation of the Boeing 727. Smoke also blew into the cabin of an American Airlines DC-10 flying from Dallas to Los Angeles on Sunday night, and the plane was diverted to Phoenix, an airline official said. None of the 239 passengers aboard was injured. In Tampa, the pilot of Delta Flight 606, carrying 114 passengers and eight crew members, was making his third attempt to fly to LaGuardia Airport in New York when smoke was detected, Delta spokesman Sam Murphy said. He said the source of the smoke was under investigation. The plane first tried to take off 2{ hours earlier, but an oil warning light lit up while it was taxiing on the runway and the pilot returned to the departure gate, Murphy said. Maintenance workers fixed the problem and the plane took off about a half-hour later, but the same warning light on another engine prompted the pilot to head back to the airport, Murphy said. As he prepared for landing, the pilot shut off the engine and dumped most of the jet's fuel in the Gulf of Mexico, airport spokesman Paul MacAlester said. He said dumping fuel is standard to lessen the chances of fire from landing trouble. After the jet landed safely, maintenance workers changed the oil filters in the two other engines and the plane prepared to take off an hour later, Murphy said. The plane was taxiing when smoke blew from air-conditioning ducts into the passenger cabin, Murphy said. ``People were grabbing at the oxygen masks,'' said Christen Cashman, 21, a student at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. ``I wasn't really that nervous because there was a businessman next to us and he told us it was no big deal and these things happen all the time. Then we lined up and went down the evacuation chute.'' The flight then was canceled. On the American flight, a loss of oil pressure in one of three engines caused smoke that the plane's air-conditioning system sucked into the cabin, said an airline official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said the smoke dissipated when the engine was shut down, but the plane landed at Phoenix International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Jack Iams, Journalist, Novelist and Editor, Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Jack Iams, a journalist, novelist and editor whose career spanned more than half a century, has died of a stroke. He was 79. Iams died Saturday while en route to New York from London with his wife, Joan Walker Wenning Iams. Samuel Harvey Iams Jr., was born in Baltimore in 1910. After graduating from Princeton University, he became a reporter for the Daily Mail of London. Iams also wrote for Newsweek and the Daily News of New York, was television critic for The New York Herald Tribune, and was an editor of Atlas Magazine, which is now known as the World Press Review. An author of comic and mystery novels, he wrote 13 books, including his 1939 novel, ``Table for Four,'' which The New York Times Book Review said was ``as brilliantly witty as the best of the British brand.'' Iams had moved 18 years ago to Opio in southern France, where he continued writing, but he and his wife sold their house and were returning to the United States when he died. He is survived by his wife and three children by his first marriage: John, a Moscow correspondent for The Associated Press; David, a society reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer; and Alice Kittredge of Panama. There are four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Carter: Sandinistas Agree U.S. Congressmen May Watch Elections
DOC.TEXT: The leftist Sandinista government, in a policy reversal, has agreed to let U.S. congressmen monitor national elections set for February, former President Jimmy Carter says. In addition, Carter said Sunday, U.S.-backed Contra rebels have agreed to end all attacks on government forces to let the electoral process move forward smoothly. He said they made the pledge at a meeting with him. In another development, four former rebel leaders returned Sunday and announced their intention to give up the armed struggle and join the political process in what they called a more democratic Nicaragua. On Saturday, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition presidential candidate, demanded the vote count in the Feb. 25 elections be conducted in public, saying she fears the Sandinistas are planning fraud. She made the demand during a rally attended by about 10,000 people in the northern town of Esteli, the largest campaign gathering yet by the U.S.-backed United National Opposition. Carter also said that an agreement was signed Sunday to expedite the release of money approved by the U.S. Congress for the 14-party opposition coalition. The congress appropriated $9 million in October. The former president has been invited to observe the general elections. He is chairman of the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, a group of former chief executives of the Western Hemisphere. President Daniel Ortega, who is seeking another six-year term, had vowed not to allow any U.S. congressmen into Nicaragua as official electoral observers and had denied such requests in recent months. Ortega said continued U.S. non-lethal aid for the Contra rebels indicated the United States did not support the Nicaraguan elections. But Carter said the government had changed its mind and decided to allow up to 12 members of Congress to serve as observers if they came as part of the Carter group. He did not give further details. The election is seen partly as a referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule, but the government has charged that the Contras are trying to sabotage the campaign by attacking Sandinista activists in the countryside. Carter, who spoke at a news conference, said: ``I think that both the Contra presence in Nicaragua and the Contra military actions in Nicaragua are very damaging to the electoral process. Two days ago, I met with Contra leaders in Atlanta and asked them to do everything possible not to interfere with the electoral process, to minimize any violence. They gave me their assurance.'' He said he met with Comandante Franklyn, the nom de guerre of the Contras' supreme commander in Honduras; Comandante Blas, the Miskito Indian leader among the rebels; and Dr. Henry, another Contra leader. The four former Contra leaders who returned Sunday accepted a government amnesty in exchange for moving their struggle from the battlefield to the political arena. ``We came to contribute to peace. We believe that we should no longer continue the bloodbath among Nicaraguans,'' Diogenes Hernandez Membreno told reporters on arrival at Managua's airport. He was accompanied by Tirso Moreno, Cesar Chavarria and Victor Sanchez Herdocia. The four held important military positions in the Nicaraguan Resistance heirarchy, but since the end of 1988 have opposed Col. Enrique Bermudez, the Contra military chief. In recent months, numerous former Contra leaders have returned to Nicaragua. Thousands of other Contras remain in camps in Honduras.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Mail-Bomb Probe Prompts New York Life to Change Super Bowl Ad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `O'Ferrell, who ...', to RESTORE dropped word `church'; pick up 11th graf, `Enterprise Mayor ...'
DOC.TEXT: The FBI's focus on an Enterprise businessman in its investigation of two mail-bomb slayings prompted an insurance company to change its advertising plans during the Super Bowl. The opening scene of New York Life Insurance Co.'s 30-second television spot during Sunday's game was to have focused on a water tower bearing the message ``Welcome to Enterprise, Alabama, City of Progress.'' But publicity stemming from the FBI investigation prompted the decision to drop that scene. The commercial featured New York Life Agent Fred D. Donaldson, 63, of Enterprise and his three sons, who are all also agents; and some of Donaldson's clients, the Gibbs McCormick family of New Brockton. Donaldson said he was disappointed but not surprised that the company changed the ad because of the probe into the December bombing deaths of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance of suburban Birmingham and Robert Robinson, a black lawyer in Savannah, Ga. ``We took part in the advertisement hoping there would be some favorable publicity for Enterprise,'' said Donaldson, who has been a New York Life agent for nearly 42 years. ``I was pleased they ran the ad at all,'' he said. ``We felt good about it that they ran the ad after having to make changes at this late date.'' Ben Barron, director of advertising for the company, said the decision to air the commercial, at a cost of $700,000 during the Super Bowl, was made Tuesday. Donaldson said the deletion of the original opening scene was prompted by ``bad timing,'' not at the request of the FBI or Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, the Enterprise salvage dealer who authorities have investigated intensely since early last week. O'Ferrell, who has not been charged, went to church Sunday and said later: ``Pray for the FBI, that they will find who they are looking for. And it sure ain't me.'' Enterprise Mayor Jacquelyn Thompson said Sunday the purpose of the ad remained the same although it was refocused. ``True, we would have like for the ad to have opened with the original scene,'' she said. ``But the real purpose was to honor the Donaldson family for what they've done for our community and the company.'' Ms. Thompson sees some good coming from the intense media focus on the city of 19,000. ``A lot of media people have told me they have a different opinion now of a small south Alabama town,'' she said. ``Some thought we were a bunch of rednecks. This case is the price we pay for people to see we're not a bunch of rednecks.''

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bomb Explodes at Pro-IRA Event, Killing Teen-Ager
DOC.TEXT: The IRA apologized for a bomb that killed a teen-ager and injured eight other people during a parade attended by supporters of the guerrilla group. The Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to oust the British from Northern Ireland, claimed responsibility for Sunday's bombing and said it regretted the death of the bystander, which it called a ``freak accident.'' The bomb was intended to kill security forces monitoring the Bloody Sunday anniversary march by Republican supporters, the IRA said. Bloody Sunday occurred on Jan. 30, 1972, when British troops shot and killed 14 people during a Roman Catholic civil rights march. Police today identified a teen-ager killed Sunday as Charles Love, 16, of Londonderry. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the blast also injured four police officers, a soldier and three civilians. A spokesman for the constabulary, which serves as the provincial police, said the IRA claim of a ``freak accident'' was ``another example of their nauseating hypocrisy.'' ``No one can be in any doubt that the sole responsibility for the events which led to the death of Charles Love rests with the IRA terrorists,'' said the spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with British tradition. ``They have yet again demonstrated their willingness to plant bombs without regard for anyone, friends or so-called foe alike,'' the spokesman said. The IRA placed the bomb beside a monument regularly used as a vantage point by security forces. The constabulary spokesman said the teen-ager had been standing nearby waiting for the parade to pass. Police said the youth died in the hospital from head injuries when he was struck by masonry falling from a wall. They said none of the marchers, who support British withdrawal from Northern Ireland, was injured and the parade continued through the city's largely Roman Catholic Bogside and Creggan areas. In October, the IRA issued a statement of regret when its gunmen mistakenly killed a British serviceman's infant daughter in West Germany. The 6-month-old girl was with her parents in their car when gunmen attacked, killing the father and child. The month before, the IRA said it mistakenly killed the wife of a British soldier stationed in West Germany. It said the gunman mistook the woman for a soldier. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland.
Here is the budget message of President Bush sent to Congress on Monday.
DOC.HEAD: To the Congress of the United States:
DOC.TEXT: I have the honor to present the Budget of the United States Government for Fiscal Year 1991. The American economy is now in its eighth consecutive year of expansion and growth. It is essential that the growth of the economy continue and increase in the future. The budget is designed to achieve that goal. The budget has five broad themes: _Investing in Our Future: With an eye toward future growth, and expansion of the human frontier, the budget's chief emphasis is on investment in the future. It proposes: a capital gains incentive for long-term private investment and new incentives for family savings; record-high amounts for research and dveelopment, space, education and Head Start; a major investment in civil aviation; and a large increase in spending to attack the scourge of drugs. At the same time, the budget maintains a strong national defense while reflecting the dramatic changes in the world political situation that are taking place; and it fulfills responsiblities to protect the environment, and preserve America's cultural heritage. _Advancing States as Laboratories: The budget recognizes the emergence of new ideas and initiatives originating at the state and local level. The federal government will foster innovation and experimentation in numerous fields, from transportation to health, through waivers of certain rules and regulations, and through demonstration grants. _Reforming Mandatory Programs: Entitlement and other mandatory spending now constitutes nearly half the budget, not counting an additional 14 percent for interest. The budget provides for full payment of Social Security benefits and funds growth in health, low income and other mandatory programs. However, it proposes reforms where warranted to slow the growth in some of these programs and thus leave more more in the budget for priority initiatives. _Acknowledges Inherited Claims: The budget faces up to such inherited claims as the cleanup of decades-old environmental damage at nuclear weapons facilities. It analyzes potential claims from unfunded annuities and federal insurance programs. It assess the growing volume of defaults in federal credit programs and proposes essential credit reforms. _Managing for Integrity and Efficiency: The budget contains suggestions for reforms in the way Congress deals with the budget. It provides more resources and suggests improved methods for managing the vast federal enterprise better. It identifies low-return domestic discretionary programs where a smaller investment of budgetary resources is warranted. The budget meets the deficit target of $64 billion for 1991 established by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, without raising taxes. It would balance the budget by 1993 as required by that law, begin reducing debt, and protect the integrity of Social Security. Each of the themes outlined above is discussed in more detail in Section One of the Budget, the Overview. The customary tabular and appendix material is contained in Section Two. I look forward to working with the Congress in the weeks and months ahead to produce a budget that meets the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings target, advances the nation's essential interests, and keeps the economy on the path of continued growth.
George Bush January 29, 1990

DOC.HEAD: Officer Suspended After Fatally Shooting Unarmed Teen
DOC.TEXT: A police officer who shot an unarmed teen-ager to death was suspended without pay, authorities said. Officer Hyda Hernandez, 25, was suspended Sunday while authorities investigate the shooting of Louis Liranso, 17, in the New York City borough of Brooklyn, police said. Patrick Clark, a spokesman for Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, said the case would be brought before a grand jury this week. Police shootings are routinely taken before grand juries. The shooting occurred early Saturday evening, when police responded to a report that four men with guns were in a dispute in front of a Chinese restaurant. Officers found Liranso and a man with an injured knee, Hector Lopez, 25, at the scene. When they began to search Liranso, the youth made a quick jerking motion and Hernandez, thinking he was pulling out a weapon, shot him once in the back, according to Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. However, several witnesses said Hernandez was taking Liranso into the restaurant when he tripped and she shot him. ``The cops said `freeze,' and he put his hands up,'' said 13-year-old Mark Facul, a cousin of Larinso. ``He tripped on a step and she shot him.'' Liranso was not armed, and was dead on arrival at Woodhull Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Safety Analyst Says 707 Fuel Gauges Aren't Highly Accurate
With PM-Jetliner Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A pilot of older jetliners says fuel gauges on airplanes like the Boeing 707 that crashed on New York's Long Island are not highly accurate, especially when tanks are low and fuel is sloshing around. ``You could not trust them below 10,000 pounds (of fuel),'' said John Nance, a former Braniff pilot. Nance, who lives in Tacoma, is an airline safety analyst. The National Transportation Safety Board, which is investigating the crash, has said gauges recovered from the wreckage of the 23-year-old plane indicate the plane had about 10,000 pounds of fuel, perhaps enough to keep it aloft the 15 miles from the crash site to its destination, John F. Kennedy International Airport. Investigators caution, however, that the fuel estimate could be wrong. The Avianca airliner crashed Thursday night in the affluent community of Cove Neck, N.Y., killing 73 people and injuring 85. Because of the absence of engine noise before the crash, the lack of fuel odor and the lack of fire after the crash, investigators focused from the start on the possibility the airliner ran out of fuel. Nance said that with small amounts of fuel on older jetliners, including the 707 and the McDonnell Douglas DC-8, gauges reading the fuel splashing around in the several tanks were ``all over the map. You really don't know what you've got.'' He said that ``to burn under 10,000 pounds is a dangerous procedure. To burn below 5,000 is an emergency.'' Boeing officials have said they don't know of any problems with fuel gauges on 707 airliners, few of which are still in use by United States airlines. Spokesman Jack Gamble said Sunday that each airline provides its own flight manuals to pilots for instruction on methods to check fuel levels. Airplane manufacturers are required to calibrate gauges before delivering planes, he said. After that, however, the worthiness of the gauges is up to the airlines and federal regulators. Nance, who still flies as a heavy jet commander with the Air Force Reserve, said he never flew in Boeing 707s but did pilot DC-8's, which have similar fuel gauges. While the gauges lack accuracy, he said, the equipment represented the known technology at the time the planes were built, beginning in the 1950s. Newer-generation jetliners, he said, have much more accurate fuel gauges. ``On the older DC-8's, the gauges were so unreliable that we were directed by Braniff to disregard them totally and keep a fuel-burn chart,'' he said. Jetliners are equipped with fuel-flow gauges that measure the amount of fuel being burned at any given time, he said, and a flight engineer's job includes keeping track of fuel flow and fuel used. ``I would always want to make sure that I started (a flight) with a known quantity, and keep track of the fuel burn. I would never depend just on the fuel gauges,'' he said. He said 707 flight crews are aware of the system's limitations, and become familiar with each airplane's idiosyncrasies. He noted that Avianca has been flying the 707 for some time, and its staff would presumably know the aircraft. He said any number of scenarios could have taken place Thursday evening, but that the crew might not have looked at the instruments, might have seen the wrong indications on the gauges and believed them, or might have misinterpreted the gauges. The crew told controllers the plane was low on fuel but did not formally declare a fuel emergency. Nance cited the case of a United Air Lines flight into Portland, Ore., in December 1978. The DC-8 ran out of fuel and crashed, though the gauges indicated the plane had 4,000 pounds of fuel left. Fewer than a dozen died.

DOC.HEAD: New Allegation of Mayor's Drug Use Raised
DOC.TEXT: A former business associate of Hazel Diane ``Rasheeda'' Moore, central figure in the drug case against Washington Mayor Marion Barry, says she and others snorted cocaine with Barry at a party in 1986. Carole Bland Jackson said in weekend interviews that she snorted the drug with Ms. Moore and Barry at the party in August 1986, two days before the two women received a no-bid a contract to work with the city's summer youth employment program. Moore, 38, lured Barry to a downtown hotel of Jan. 18, where he was arrested on a misdemeanor drug-possession charge after allegedly smoking crack cocaine. Jackson told The Washington Post that ``everybody was using'' the drug at the party at a Washington condominium with the exception of Moore's sister. She said Moore and Barry eventually went into the bedroom, and that Barry tried to get her to join them in their sexual activity. The story was first reported on Sunday night by television stations WJLA and WRC. Barry entered a substance abuse clinic, the Hanley-Hazelden Center in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Jan. 22 and is to undergo weekly court-ordered urine tests there, according to court records. Barry was scheduled for a Feb. 5 hearing before U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson, but prosecutors have said they do not oppose postponement of that session while the mayor is at a treatment center. No new date has been set. In another development, a key witness in the probe of alleged cocaine use by Barry and his friend, Charles Lewis, has been subpoenaed to testify before a federal grand jury, federal officials said. James P. McWilliams, a former federal prosecutor in the U.S. Virgin Islands and now an official of the District of Columbia Department of Public Works, could testify by midweek, officials told The Washington Times. McWilliams is expected to be asked about whether Barry and Lewis used drugs at a Washington hotel in December 1988 and on whether Barry used drugs during visits to the Virgin Islands, the newspaper said. Barry reportedly has denied under oath jury that he ever used drugs, but Lewis has testified that McWilliams paid $140 for the crack smoked by Lewis and Barry. McWilliams' attorney, Daniel Masur, has denied charges that his client supplied the money for the crack and said McWilliams was never involved in any drug transactions.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: BAMAKO
Pope Tells Burkina Faso Catholics to Resist Contraception
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with pope's remarks in Burkina Faso; picks up 9th pvs: I rejoice ... ^By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II told Roman Catholics today to resist abortion and contraception as they try to improve living conditions in this impoverished West African country. Celebrating Mass outside the capital at a national pilgrimage site, the pope said the church and its members should work to build up the country ``on the basis of respect for the human person and the family. ``Human life is inviolable, the right to life should be defended ceaselessly,'' John Paul said. He said life should be protected ``from conception until natural death'' and that couples should live ``a responsible fatherhood and motherhood.'' He said couples must resist ``invasion of methods which go against the dignity of the woman and do not honor the man. I appeal to all lay people to fight for the sanctification of the family.'' The Roman Catholic Church rejects artificial birth control and the church here has resisted government birth control plans. The pope arrived here from Mali on the fourth leg of an eight-day tour of five African nations. About 9 percent of Burkina Faso's 8.5 million people are Roman Catholics, more than a third are Moslems and most of the rest are animist. On his way from the airport to the Mass site, the pope's motorcade passed tens of thousands of people gathered by the roadside in front of thatched huts and concrete hovels. A steady wind from the Sahara desert blew sand and dust. The country has been blighted by drought and expanding desert and the average per capita income is around $200. John Paul was greeted upon arrival from Mali by President Blaise Compaore, who took power in a 1987 coup in which his predecessor, Thomas Sankara, was killed. Africa is Catholicism's fastest growing church, with more 75 million adherents. The Vatican expects to count 100 million African faithful by the year 2000. However, Islam is a major challenger for converts, and the Catholic church is increasingly worried by the spread of Islamic fundamentalism in some areas of Africa. In Mali, the pope celebrated a Mass attended by 15,000 Christians and 10,000 Moslems. ``I rejoice that a climate of understanding reigns between the Moslem and Catholic communities in Mali,'' the pope said in his homily during the Mass at Bamako's soccer stadium. ``Dialogue between Moslems and Christians is more necessary than ever.'' As the pope toured the stadium in an open Mercedes, both Moslems and Catholics stood, waved and cheered. About 1 percent of Mali's 8 million people are Catholics, while Moslems account for 70 percent. Most of the rest are animists. ``I hope that the dialogue between Moslems and Catholics improves even more and favors constructive cooperation,'' John Paul said. Earlier in the day, the pope spoke of the church's concern over intolerance toward Catholics in some other countries in Africa without naming any individual nations. He also urged Catholics to recognize and respect ``the authentic religious values'' of Moslems. ``Dialogue with them is not always easy or desired by everyone, and it is sometimes difficult to find a common language or representatives to talk to each other,'' he said in a speech to Mali's bishops.

DOC.HEAD: Police Charge Man in Pedestrian Death
DOC.TEXT: A Colorado man was charged with murder in a hit-and-run driving case in which he allegedly made a U-turn across a road divider so he could chase down a pedestrian and kill him. George Thomas Kohoutek, 38, of Aspen, Colo., was being held without bail today in a Dallas jail. Kahoutek was arrested Sunday after police concluded that his rented red Jeep was the car used to kill Rafael Caracheo, 26, who police believe was struck intentionally by a hit-and-run driver on a Dallas street Saturday morning. Witnesses said the driver of a late-model red Jeep Cherokee made a U-turn after passing Caracheo on a street, then drove over the median into oncoming traffic, sped up and ran him down. Caracheo was dragged on the Jeep's hood more than 100 feet before being thrown into a street sign, police said. Lt. William Craven of the department's hit-and-run division said a phone tip led police to Kohoutek, who has been convicted twice of driving while intoxicated. Police said they don't know if Kohoutek knew Caracheo.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Budget Will Keep Congress Busy All Year _ Despite Deadlines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs new with budget release; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Deadlines will.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's unveiling of his 1991 budget proposal today sets off a legislative process that is outlined in law but still allows for months of delay, finger-pointing and confusion. Bush's $1.23 trillion spending blueprint lays out the president's priorities for the coming year. He wants to increase federal efforts on space, science, environmental and anti-drug efforts while trying to shrink the deficit without a broad tax increase. N Now Congress gets its chance to make the changes it wants, and the process slows to a crawl. Deadlines will be missed, and lawmakers and the White House will blame each other for it. Virtually every committee in Congress will get involved, often working in opposing directions. Each side will accuse the other of using unrealistic numbers, and at year's end a growing dynamic will be everybody's desire to simply go home. The budget year is already getting off to a late start with today's presentation of the spending plan. It is supposed to be released on the first Monday after Jan. 3, but the White House and Congress agreed to an extension. Between now and the Oct. 1 start of fiscal 1991, a host of other deadlines will be missed as well. The reason: the budget is an extremely important political document, and lawmakers see the fiscal choices they must make as primary. There are no consequences for missing the deadlines anyway. ``This is one of the most difficult budget years we've had in terms of trying to make ends meet with this process,'' Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said late last week. Domenici's prediction was founded on the expectation that there will be several time-consuming, partisan budget battles this year. Should easing tensions with the Soviet Union translate into Pentagon spending cuts, and where should those savings go? How will the Republicans thwart Sen. Daniel Moynihan's efforts to cut Social Security taxes? Will Bush finally get his capital gains tax cut, and if so what will the Democrats demand in return? And where will Congress and the administration find the $36.5 billion in savings they need to pare the deficit to $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law? The law calls for the House and Senate to approve a budget blueprint by April 15, a document that does not require the president's signature. A measure imposing new taxes and fees and spending cuts must be completed by June 15. Thirteen separate spending bills, providing money for federal agencies and programs, are supposed to be enacted by Oct. 1, an event that has occurred only once since 1976. While all this is going on, Congress will be grumbling about the administration's economic forecast, which by law is used in the budget process. Those projections _ prepared by the Office of Management and Budget _ are generally believed by lawmakers to be too rosy. The healthier the economy, the more revenue the government can estimate it will collect, and the easier its deficit-reduction job seems. But by Aug. 15 the administration will update its forecast, and if the economy is souring Congress would suddenly be faced with finding even more savings than it thought were needed. If by Oct. 15 legislators and the president have not agreed to enough reductions to meet the Gramm-Rudman shortfall target, the law automatically triggers enough spending cuts to satisfy the target. This mix will be confused further by one more event: the expiration of the government's legal authority to borrow money, which should occur sometime in September. The law extending the government's $3.1 trillion debt limit will likely attract all sorts of controversial items because of its must-pass nature. Congressional leaders hope to complete the year's work by early October, this being an election year. Whether they succeed, or whether a special post-election session is needed, is likely to depend on whether budget business is completed in time.

DOC.HEAD: FDA OKs Alternative Treatment for Fungal Infections
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the drug fluconazole as an alternative treatment for two fungal infections that afflict patients with AIDS, cancer and other diseases that weaken the immune system. The drug can be used for treating cryptococcal meningitis, an inflammation of the brain and nervous system that can be fatal. It also was approved for treating candidiasis, an infection that causes sores in the mouth and throat. The infection is present in 80 percent to 90 percent of AIDS patients in advanced stages of the disease. Other drugs are available to treat these infections, but they can cause serious adverse reactions, the FDA said. Fluconazole can also cause side effects, including abdominal discomfort, nausea and, less commonly, signs of liver damage. In rare cases, the drug has been associated with severe skin rashes and fatal hepatic necrosis, a form of liver failure, the FDA said. The drug will be marketed by Pfizer Inc. under the trade name Diflucan.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Release May Be Delayed Because of Unrest:Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with report de Klerk opposes legalizing ANC, ANC leader's comments on obstacles to Mandela's freedom; picks up 10th pvs, ``If and...
DOC.TEXT: The government is considering delaying Nelson Mandela's release from prison and slowing reforms because of concerns about current unrest, newspapers said today. An aide to Mandela said the black leader will continue his anti-apartheid fight if substantial reforms are not made, even if it means spending more time in custody. Mandela has been in prison since 1962 and is serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. The South African media have been swamped with reports and speculation on when Mandela might be released. The government has said it intends to free him but has not said when. Several newspapers said today the white-led government is thinking of keeping Mandela in jail at least until March because of renewed unrest, such as demonstrations against a tour by English cricket players defying a ban on sports contacts with South Africa. Government leaders are concerned that releasing Mandela and introducing other reforms would spur unrest, and they want to hold off on changes to be sure they retain control of developments, the reports said, citing unidentified sources. In addition, The Star newspaper said President F.W. de Klerk does not want to legalize Mandela's African National Congress movement _ a condition set by Mandela for accepting freedom. De Klerk is expected to outline government reforms Friday in a speech at the opening of the new session of Parliament. He has said he wants to dismantle apartheid. Winnie Mandela, wife of the jailed nationalist leader, said Saturday that her 71-year-old husband would refuse release until the government ends a state of emergency imposed in 1986, legalizes the ANC and allows exiled ANC leaders to return to South Africa. A veteran ANC leader, Walter Sisulu, said today that problems have cropped in up plans for Mandela's release, but he said it did not know exactly what they were. Sisulu made his comments in Oslo, Norway, where he and five other ANC leaders arrived to begin their first visit outside Africa since being released from more than 25 years in South Africa prisons. The Scandinavian countries have been strong supporters of the ANC and were among the first countries to impose economic sanctions against South Africa. Dullah Omar, a close friend of the Mandela family, told The Associated Press today that Mandela has made it clear the government must enact basic reforms to clear the way for talks between whites and blacks. ``If and when he is released and there have been no major changes, then he will report back to his organization (the ANC) that three years of talks (with the government) have been a waste of time,'' Omar said. In an allusion to resuming armed struggle, Omar said, Mandela ``will go back to where he left off, before he went to prison, and will probably find himself back in prison in a month.'' Mandela has been having talks with government leaders on ways to resolve South Africa's political problems, which stem from the country's apartheid system. Under apartheid, South Africa's 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The country's 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews Become Focus of West Bank Controversy
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 10-12, `Criticism also...Khalil wrote' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment today from Iraqi president criticizing U.S. policies and Arab League saying Soviet Jews' rights violated; picks up 13th pvs, `The protests...
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Only a few score Soviet Jews have settled in the occupied West Bank since the new immigration wave began, but their presence has drawn an outcry from the Arab world and aroused U.S. concern. New arrivals say they fled anti-Semitism and did not come here to make a political statement. ``I did not find any difference between the (occupied) territories and Tel Aviv,'' said Kira Nefyodova, a short, bespectacled Leningrad chemist. ``I'm very far from politics. I don't want anybody to think that I'm making a political move.'' Alex Yankevitch, a construction engineer, and his wife Liuba, recalled finding a big yellow Star of David painted on their door in Leningrad one morning, the work of an anti-Semite. ``And what can I do in Leningrad when the pogrom starts? I can stand near my door and wait for the killers,'' he recalled, his lips trembling. ``Here the Jewish army will defend me and my family.'' Even so, Palestinians view the presence of such Soviet emigres in Ariel, a hilltop settlement 25 miles north of Jerusalem, as a potential threat. In a protest to Western consulates, 25 prominent Palestinians said up to 1 million Soviet Jews could come to Israel and that their settlement in the occupied lands could undermine the peace process and further strain limited housing and jobs, forcing Palestinians to leave. Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat asked the Soviet Union not to allow Soviet Jews to emigrate if they are going to settle in occupied territories. Jordan's King Hussein told The Jordan Times that settlement in the territories was ``a serious and pending danger'' to stability in the region. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today blamed the problem mainly on U.S. immigration quotas. Criticism also has come from Egypt, the only Arab state to have a peace treaty with Israel. Writing in the English-language Daily Mail, Cairo's former chief U.N. delegate, Ahmed Tewfik Khalil, accused the Americans and Soviets of colluding against Palestinians by failing to stop Jewish immigrants from settling in the disputed lands. The Arab League took a different tact. Secretary-General Chedli Klibi said today that the Soviet Jews' rights also are being violated because he said they are being forced to go to Israel and settle ``in a territory they have never seen before.'' The protests followed Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's statement that suggested Israel needed the land it captured in the 1967 Middle East war to accommodate the new wave of immigrants. U.S. State Department officials objected to Shamir's remarks as ``not helpful.'' The United States views the settlements as an obstacle to peace, and Washington has said it would not provide any aid to house immigrants there. In Ariel, officials are not concealing their desire to increase the Jewish population in the West Bank and Gaza, which now is about 70,000 in more than 120 settlements. Ariel Mayor Ron Nachman said that even if Soviet Jews settle in Tel Aviv the ``demographic reality will change'' and strengthen Israel's claim to the land. His statement alluded to the position of the center-left Labor Party, which opposes further settling of the occupied lands. It argues the Jewish character of the state would be threatened by the absorption of 1.7 million Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza and that this is the strongest argument for giving up the land. There are 3.7 million Jews and 810,000 Arabs in the pre-1967 boundaries. But few new arrivals have come to the occupied territories, and the overall immigration to Israel has a long way to go before realizing official predictions of 300,000 over the next three years. Absorption Ministry officials said about 1 percent, or less than 200, of the 16,000 Soviet Jews who arrived in the past 13 months have moved to the occupied lands. ``The number of immigrants going there is not meaningful at all, and it's only a matter of headlines,'' said Uri Gordon, head of immigration at the Jewish Agency, which funds immigrant resettlement programs. Many of those who do come to the West Bank do so on the advice of friends or earlier immigrants and fail to grasp the complexity of living in the West Bank. Only one of those interviewed said he was motivated by political ideology. Ariel provides friendly volunteers to help with official paperwork, is encouraging veteran residents to ``adopt'' new Soviet arrivals and is sponsoring Hebrew classes. The warm welcome is important. ``We just felt welcome and needed here,'' said Yankevitch, 38. ``We were so nicely treated by everybody ... and this is so important after we left so much behind.'' Last week, Yankevitch rented a two-floor apartment from an Israeli who left Ariel. As with any new immigrant, his rent and most other expenses are covered in the first year by the government. Ariel officials say they receive virtually no other direct government support for their absorption program, which brought 45 Soviet families to Ariel in the last four months. Ms. Nefyodova, 36, interviewed in her small kitchen surrounded by a donated refrigerator, electric heater and gas stove, appeared to be content. ``I never expected to find myself in the territories, and I did not expect to find such quiet cities here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Savings Incentive, Capital Gains Tax Breaks in Budget
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress today to cut taxes on capital gains and create a new tax break to encourage savings. Bush's 1991 budget calls for tax increases of $15.7 billion, although there is no proposed general increase in personal income taxes. The budget recommends $5.6 billion increases in user and service fees and $1.8 billion worth of targeted tax cuts, including a special credit of up to $1,000 a year for each child under the age of 4 in lower-income families. Although the most sensitive revenue proposal in the budget is the tax cut on capital gains, the one with the potential for affecting the greatest number of taxpayers is the call for a reward for increased savings. Under this proposal, a couple could avoid tax on the interest earned on special ``family savings accounts'' held for seven years or longer. While interest would be tax-exmept, deposits to such accounts would have no tax advantage. Most couples would be allowed to invest up to $5,000 a year in these accounts; a single person could invest $2,500. The tax break would be limited to couples with incomes below $120,000 and single people under $60,000. Bush also recommended that a first-time homebuyer be allowed to withdraw up to $10,000 penalty-free from an Individual Retirement Account in order to make a down payment on the home. The proposed capital-gains tax cut is more sweeping than the one Bush failed to win from Congress last year. Democratic leaders have fought any such reduction on grounds that 80 percent of the benefit would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. ``A reduction in the capital-gains rate would help United States businesses in the face of increasing global competition,'' Bush said in a written message to Congress. He also repeated the administration's insistence that cutting taxes on capital gains _ which are profits from the sale of stock, real estate and other investments _ would increase revenues. Under Bush's plan, capital gains from property owned more than one year would be taxed at lower rates than apply to wages and other income. When fully phased in, the provision would exempt from taxation 30 percent of profits from the sale of property owned at least three years; 20 percent of gains from property owned more than two but less than three years would be exempt; 10 percent of gain from assets held more than one year would be exempt. Thus, a person whose regular income is taxed at 28 percent would pay an effective rate of 19.6 percent on capital gains from long-held property. Other revenue proposals include: _Making permanent the 3-percent tax on local and long-distance telephone service, which is due to expire Dec. 31. _Raising the 8-percent tax on airline tickets to 10 percent. _Increasing more than three times the fee on waterway shippers, from 0.04 percent of value to 0.125 percent. _Requiring the 3.8 million state and local government workers who are not covered by a retirement plan to pay Social Security taxes. Also, state and local workers hired before April 1, 1986, would be required to pay the 1.45 percent Medicare tax; most state and local workers already pay. _Cutting oil industry taxes by creating four incentives for drilling in old fields. _Imposing fees for a variety of government services, including those provided by the Coast Guard and the Food and Drug Administration. _Requiring veterans, except those with low incomes, to pay part of their medical bills relating to non-service-connected ailments. Many veterans wold have to pay a 1.75 percent fee on new VA housing loan guarantees.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Seeks Details On Debts, Economic Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Communist leadership today promised to provide the opposition with details on Bulgaria's economic crisis but rejected a call for an independent commission to look into the staggering foreign debt. The debt, estimated at more than $11 billion, is a major issue of contention between the Communists and the Union of Democratic Forces, a loose grouping of 12 independent movements and parties. In addition to a halt on new loans to Bulgaria, the opposition has demanded the dismissal of the directors of the National Bank and the Foreign Trade Bank, apparently for their role in the mismanagement of Western credits during years of hard-line Communist rule. Ventseslav Dimitrov, an economic adviser for the independent trade union Podkrepa, said a halt on loans is necessary because ``we don't know what the previous credits have been used for.'' The leader of the Communist delegation, Andrei Lukanov, reacted sharply to the opposition's stance, saying: ``There is no example in world history where the opposition negotiates with creditors of a country to stop credits.'' He said it was inappropriate for the opposition to object to new credits deemed badly needed to help economic recovery. The Communists agreed to provide the opposition with information it wants on the national economy when the talks convene again Feb. 6. The opposition-Communist talks emerged from the peaceful pro-democracy revolution that ended more than three decades of rule by Todor Zhivkov. A Communist Party congress opens Tuesday and is expected to result in a showdown between conservatives and reformers, who favor a clean break with the past to shed the image associated with Zhivkov's hard-line leadership.

DOC.HEAD: More Drug War, Head Start Money; Another Attempt At Tenant-Ownership
DOC.TEXT: The budget President Bush sent Congress today includes a new attempt to encourage family savings and a significant boost for Head Start while making a fresh effort to dramatically shift the focus of federal housing programs. The $1.23 trillion fiscal 1991 budget proposal also includes a major cash infusion for the war on drugs and new initiatives _ in the form of higher spending _ for space and biotechnology programs. Other programs slated for significant spending increases are the Federal Aviation Administration, a proposal that relies heavily on dipping into an aviation trust fund, and efforts to clean up hazardous materials at nuclear plants and other facilities run by the federal government. Some of the ``initiatives'' offered in the spending blueprint are indeed new; others, like the president's child-care and capital-gains proposals, are simply new attempts to win congressional approval of Bush proposals that did not survive Congress last year. And for all its new and reworked initiatives, the budget proposal also includes an attempt to head off one of the biggest initiatives likely to emerge on Capitol Hill: an attempt to take advantage of the so-called ``peace dividend'' created by declining world tensions by spending money now earmarked for the military on domestic programs. ``The sum of all such planned expenditures totals about 10 times the over-estimated dividend, which is itself perhaps five times the actual dividend,'' Budget Director Richard Darman said in a message accompanying the budget. ``Thus, Washington entertains the notion of spending 50 times a dividend that has not definitively materialized _ a true Wonderland phenomenon.'' The battle over the real or imagined ``peace dividend'' is likely to be the biggest budget skirmish. Several of the president's other initiatives also appear certain to alienate Congress' majority Democrats, while others likely will be accepted quickly, perhaps with tinkering. Here are brief summaries of several Bush policy initiatives. The numbers are for proposed fiscal 1991 spending unless labeled as ``spending authority,'' meaning that the amount shown is what the administration is asking to spend spent over several years. _FAMILY SAVINGS ACCOUNTS. In a bid to improve the nation's anemic savings rate, Bush proposes exempting from income tax the interest paid on family savings accounts that are held for seven years. The limit would be $5,000 for those filing a joint tax return; $2,500 for individual returns. Withdrawals taken after the seven years would be tax free and a 10 percent excise penalty would be assessed on early withdrawals. _HEAD START. Bush proposes adding $500 million in spending authority to the pre-school education program in fiscal 1991, for a total of $1.9 billion. The 36 percent increase should allow the program, a favorite of Democrats and Republicans alike, to enroll 180,000 more 4-year-olds from low-income families, according to the administration. About 450,000 children now participate in Head Start programs. _HOUSING. The president's $23 billion Department of Housing and Urban Development budget includes expansion of two of the pet projects of HUD Secretary Jack Kemp _ urban enterprise zones and tenant ownership. Bush's proposal to shift nearly $60 million from low-income rental programs to a certificate program that allows tenants of housing projects and other federally subsidized housing programs to buy their units likely will face stiff opposition in Congress from liberal Democrats who do not believe tenant ownership will work on a large scale in many areas of the country. _THE DRUG WAR. Bush unveiled this part of his budget last week, proposing to boost federal spending authority for the drug war by $1.1 billion to $10.6 billion. _SPACE. Bush proposes increasing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's spending from $12 billion to $14.1 billion. The budget projects a record 10 space shuttle flights next fiscal year at a cost of more than $8 billion and also proposes budget authority of $2.6 billion for development of the manned space station and $1.2 billion for exploration activities to support the planned Moon-Mars mission. _AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL. Bush proposed an increase in overall FAA spending that would see a reduction in the amount of direct federal spending for air safety while the amount taken from an aviation trust fund financed by user fees would increase sharply. Bush proposed outlays of $1.2 billion in federal funds for the FAA next year, down from about $3 billion in the current fiscal year, while spending $6 billion from the trust fund, up from $3.4 billion this year. Bush said his proposed increase for the FAA would allow for the hiring of 495 more air traffic controllers and 300 safety specialists. The administration said those increases were needed because of increasing number of commercial flights and the aging of the nation's aircraft fleet. Bush proposed increased user fees to help pay for the increase. _HAZARDOUS CLEANUP. Bush proposes spending $4.2 billion to clean up hazardous materials at Department of Energy nuclear plants and other facilities run by NASA and the departments of Defense, Interior, Agriculture and Transportation. That would be an increase $642 million over the current fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Government Supporters Converge On Capital After Huge Anti-Regime Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with protest outside opposition party, allegation that opposition supporters were bribed to rally Sunday; picks up 11th pvs, `The National...
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people shouting support for the provisional government converged on Bucharest today and urged leaders to stand firm against opposition demands that they resign. It was the biggest pro-government rally in weeks and came one day after thousands massed in the largest anti-government protest since the December revolution. Demonstrators marched down major city streets shouting support for President Ion Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, which has been accused of supporting the same totalitarian tactics as the ousted Communist regime. Another crowd of several thousand gathered outside massed outside the offices of opposition National Peasant Party, which organized Sunday's anti-government protest. ``We won't leave until you dissolve the party!'' the crowd chanted. ``Iliescu, don't give up! The country is your army!'' demonstrators shouted as they marched past cheering shopkeepers and pedestrians. Iliescu told the crowd the Front would not resign. ``The Front stands soundly on its own feet. The Front is not in danger ... We remain open to dialogue with the whole country (and) we stretch out our hands to all those who want to talk, to work and to rebuild the country,'' he said. By late morning, more than 10,000 pro-Front forces had gathered in Victory Square, and thousands more were marching and even running toward the plaza where the Front's governing council has its headquarters. It appeared the protest would attract more people than Sunday's anti-government rally, which drew about 15,000 people. It was the biggest such rally since the revolution that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The national news agency Rompres said ``tens of thousands'' of people, many of them just off night shifts in Bucharest factories, massed outside government headquarters and that many people had come to the capital from other areas of the country. Many groups of protesters arrived in trucks, and how the crowd came together indicated workers may have been instructed to attend _ a tactic often used by Communist leaders. A smaller pro-Front rally also was held Sunday, and one participant said he had been directed by superiors at work to attend. A woman at today's pro-government rally alleged that people were bribed to attend the opposition protest Sunday. ``They were given dollars, cigarettes, and lei,'' she said, referring to Romania's currency. She refused to give her name. The National Salvation Front, a loose grouping of intellectuals and former Communists and dissidents, has been governing by decree since Ceausescu fled the capital Dec. 22. He was executed Dec. 25. The trial of four men who were close Ceausescu associates resumed today before a military tribunal in Bucharest. The four went on trial Saturday on charges of complicity in the murder of anti-government protesters who were killed by security forces during the revolution. The defendants are former Communist Party secretary Emil Bobu, considered the No. 3 figure in the Ceausescu leadership; former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu; and former Politburo members Manea Manescu and Ion Dinca. Only Dinca has testified. When he took the stand Saturday, he said he had done nothing to stop the shooting of protesters in December. Demands for the Front's resignation erupted Tuesday when the leadership announced plans to compete in national elections in May. Critics say the Front cannot fairly compete in an election that it also administers. Some accuse it of being a front for Communist rule, noting that it includes some former ranking Communists. The protesters Sunday broke through a line of soldiers and rallied outside Front headquarters. Many demanded the opposition be given positions in the provisional government. They booed Iliescu when he appeared on an upper floor of the building and chanted ``Resign! Resign!'' and ``Get out, or we'll come get you out!'' as he tried to speak. Iliescu pledged later to renew dialogue with the more than 20 political parties hoping to compete in the May election, a promise he repeated today. Like the protest Sunday, today's demonstration violated a ban imposed by the Front on rallies without advance police permission. Authorities made no attempt to disperse the pro-Front demonstrators, but there was a cordon of soldiers, tanks and armored cars outside the Foreign Ministry building that houses the government headquarters. Some demonstrators commandeered heavy construction equipment and trucks to join in the processions. ``The Front is representing us,'' shopkeeper Viorica Mustareata told The Associated Press as she yelled support from the sidelines. ``The Front is with the peasants, the workers, with everyone.'' The anti-government protest was called by the largest opposition party, the National Peasant Party, as well as the National Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party which joined the Peasant Party in calling for a broad coalition government until the elections in May. After nightfall, truckloads of pro-government demonstrators were brought to the square, some shouting that the opposition protesters were ``provocateurs'' and ``gypsies.''

DOC.HEAD: Flood, Landslide Death Toll Reaches 160
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains years caused floods and landslides that have killed at least 160 people in the past week, officials said today. Eighty were dead and at least two dozen were missing in the Central Java provincial capital of Semarang, about 310 miles east of Jakarta, said a provincial police officer on condition of anonymity. The officer said there also were casualties in floods in Kendal and Demak and landslides in Batang and Temgangung regencies. He declined to elaborate. But the newspaper Suara Pembaruan said the death toll has risen to 28 from a landslide Thursday night in Temanggung, about 30 miles south of Semarang. At least one other person still was missing in the landslide, which destroyed dozens of houses as villagers slept, it said. In Batang, at least 34 people were found dead after floods swept over two villages Saturday and Sunday and caused a landslide that destroyed more than 40 houses, the newspaper added. In Indonesia's easternmost province, Irian Jaya, rescuers have found 16 bodies buried in a landslide that struck Saturday in the district of Gurabesi on the outskirts of the provincial capital of Jayapura, a spokesman for the governor's office said. He said rescuers still were looking for one women believed buried in the landslide. Jayapura is about 1,900 miles northeast of Jakarta. In West Java, heavy rains last week caused a landslide Wednesday that killed two people in a village in Cianjur regency. On Sunday, heavy rain also caused some rivers to overflow and inundated most of the eastern part of Jakarta. More than 21,000 people were affected, but no casualties were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Controllers' Communication Gap Investigated in Avianca Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with investigators back on site; SUBS 18th-20th grafs, bgng `Many pilots...', with 5 grafs to ADD background on fuel emergency declarations, amount of fuel. Picks up 21st graf pvs, `Benson said...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4, NY10
DOC.TEXT: Regional air controllers knew a Colombian jetliner was low on fuel and needed priority landing clearance 50 minutes before it crashed, but local controllers never got the information, investigators said. The investigation into Avianca Flight 52's crash, which killed 73 people and injured 85, is focusing on the communication gap between the high-altitude air traffic controllers and those handling landings at three local airports, said Lee Dickinson, of the National Transportation Safety Board. Dickinson said investigators planned to interview the regional controllers today. Investigators also returned this morning to the crash site in Cove Neck on Long Island. They were expected to end the on-site investigation later today or Tuesday. Records indicated the Boeing 707 had more than enough fuel for the flight from Bogota and Medellin, Colombia, to New York, but the jet flew in three holding patterns totaling nearly 90 minutes along the East Coast because of weather-related congestion before it crashed Thursday night, investigators said. As the plane neared the end of its final, 46-minute holding pattern south of Kennedy International Airport, the crew told controllers in the regional New York Center about the fuel shortage and requested priority clearance to land, Dickinson said. At that point, controllers asked pilot Laureano Caviedes what his alternate landing site was, and, according to Federal Aviation Administration tapes, he replied, ``Boston. I can't make it.'' Shortly afterward, the regional controllers turned the aircraft over to the local controllers. But, after interviewing six local controllers who either handled or tracked the flight, investigators determined they were unaware of the shortage. ``For whatever reasons, we don't know, the controllers (handling landings at Kennedy) did not know that,'' Dickinson told reporters late Sunday. ``I don't know why it wasn't passed on. It may have been passed on in a different style, if you will,'' he said without elaborating. He said the regional and local controllers had spoken to each other by telephone when transferring control of the plane. At 9:24 p.m. the plane aborted an attempted landing at Kennedy, apparently because of bad weather, and the pilot immediately said he wanted to try again, saying twice to one of the controllers that he was low on fuel, Dickinson said. That was the first time the local controller knew anything about a fuel problem, Dickinson said. Less than 10 minutes later the plane crashed. The pilot and the other two members of the cockpit crew were among those killed. A federal official close to the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity said information obtained by investigators indicates the error appeared to lie with the regional controllers. Dickinson emphasized that when the pilot told the regional controllers he needed a priority landing, the word ``emergency'' was never used and for that reason the severity of the situation may not have been relayed. Asked what procedures would have mandated an emergency, he replied without elaboration: ``There are certain phrases that the cockpit should tell the controller. The word `emergency' was never used. The word `priority' was.'' Dickinson noted that an American Airlines flight that landed right before Avianca's aborted attempt had 14 minutes of fuel when it landed. The American pilot had told controllers he would declare a fuel emergency if he was not immediately cleared for landing. Many pilots are reluctant to declare a fuel emergency because the FAA strictly monitors those cases, according to aviation officials. Should the agency determine a pilot was not justified in declaring an emergency, the pilot's license can be suspended. ``Pilots are not anxious to declare an emergency,'' he said, ``because they then have to explain it to the FAA. The FAA comes in and says, `OK, what's the emergency here?''' ``It's embarrassing,'' The New York Times quoted an unidentified pilot as saying. ``Plus you have to write a lot of reports.'' Investigators determined during the weekend that none of the Avianca's four engines was running when it slammed into a wooded hillside. Investigators earlier said the plane may have had up to 10,000 pounds, or nearly 1,500 gallons, of fuel upon impact. But NTSB spokesman Mike Benson said Sunday that figure could be wrong because the fuel gauges may have given inaccurate readings. Boeing spokesman Jack Gamble in Seattle has said that 1,500 gallons of fuel could have been enough to get the plane from the crash site to the airport 15 miles away, ``but not much more.'' Benson said the NTSB planned to calibrate and test the gauges. The Boeing 707 fuel gauges cannot be trusted when the level goes below 10,000 pounds, said John Nance, a former Braniff pilot who is an airline safety analyst. Officials changed survivor totals twice during the weekend. After officials compared Avianca's passenger list and hospital records, they revised the tally of people on board from 161 to 159; officials could not immediately explain the second change, to 158. More than 20 survivors remained in critical condition, hospitals reported.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Earthquake Shakes Central New Mexico
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake jolted central New Mexico strongly enough to rattle furniture this morning, but no injuries were reported. ``We felt the whole house shake,'' said Albert Miranda of Veguita, a few miles from the quake's epicenter south of Albuquerque. ``It didn't last very long. The chandelier shook, but nothing was broken. It was a fast shake.'' ``The dog went wild barking in the house,'' said Albino Salas Jr. of Bernardo. ``He was running all over the room.'' Pat Jorgenson of the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., said the survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., measured the tremor at 4.5 on the Richter scale. The epicenter of the 6:16 a.m. quake was 40 miles south of Albuquerque, almost exactly the same spot as one of the same magnitude on Nov. 28, 1989, she said. Both quakes occurred along the Rio Grande Rift, which splits New Mexico north to south, paralleling the Rio Grande from Colorado to El Paso, Texas, Ms. Jorgenson said. The last time before November that an earthquake struck the same area was July 1906, she said. Allan Sanford, a professor of geophysics at the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology in Socorro, said earthquakes are relatively rare in the state. California, he said, has 100 times as much quake activity as New Mexico. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs.An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage in the local area, and 5 can cause considerable damage. The earthquake that caused heavy damage in the San Francisco-Oakland area on Oct. 17 measured 7.1 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide Explains Budget in Child's Terms
With PM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: How do you explain a $1.23 trillion federal budget with a deficit in the billions of dollars tucked away in nearly 190,000 accounts and recorded in a book that runs to 1,569 intimidating pages? Budget director Richard G. Darman used child's terms today to tell readers what it all means. In an introduction to President Bush's fiscal 1991 budget plan, Darman spoke solemnly of PACMEN, the Cookie Monster and Wonderland. To Darman, the federal budget might be seen as ``the Ultimate Cookie Monster,'' a reference to the gruff character on the ``Sesame Street'' children's TV show who ``cannot resist gobbling up anything and everything that might be consumed _ especially cookies.'' The budget's ``excessive tendencies toward consumption are not exactly ennobling,'' Darman wrote. ``But at the same time, its underlying motivation is clearly not malevolent. ``What harm it may cause is largely unintended. Its massive presence might be understood as little more than a compilation of cookies received, cookies crumbled and crumbs spewed forth.'' Darman says the Cookie Monster analogy isn't fair to the Cookie Monster or the budget. ``In reality, a budget is not just a monstrous mass of cookies and crumbs,'' he says. ``It is more: an implicit statement of values and expectations for the future.'' Using the imagery of the PACMAN video game, Darman warns of rising costs of such federal liabilities as health care, pensions, mandatory benefit programs, insurance coverage and environmental cleanup obligations. ``Each is like a hidden PACMAN, waiting to spring forward and consume another line of resource dots in the budget maze,'' the budget chief wrote. Then it's off to ``Wonderland,'' Darman's name for a political fairyland where he believes Congress is heading when it starts tinkering with the budget. Darman says a new game on Capitol Hill is finding ways to spend the ``peace dividend,'' the supposed savings in defense spending resulting from the recent easing of East-West tensions. ``It starts by overestimating the dividend,'' he wrote. ``Then each player plans to spend the dividend in his or her preferred way. The sum of all such planned expenditures totals about 10 times the overestimated dividend, which is itself perhaps five times the actual dividend. ``Thus, Washington entertains the notion of spending 50 times a dividend that has not yet definitively materialized _ a true Wonderland phenomenon,'' Darman says. He also characterizes as a ``very dangerous game politically'' the recent congressional demands for a cut in Social Security taxes. ``Indeed, Wonderland seems to be running wild with attractive fantasies, but without yet having established coherent direction,'' he wrote. In a footnote, Darman observed that the budget document was published this year in a single volume, rather than the seven separate budget books issued in previous years. The aim, he said, was to make the federal budget easier _ and perhaps more informative _ to read. ``There is no formal record of the number of individuals who may have read, cover-to-cover, the previous seven-volume editions of the budget,'' Darman wrote. ``Nor are there epidemiological studies of their fate.''

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Leader Predicts an End to the Angolan War in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi today said pressure from the superpowers and Angola's weariness with bloodshed would bring an end to the 15-year-old civil war this year. Savimbi made the comments on his first visit to Lisbon since Portugal granted independence to the African nation in 1975, when fighting began between his U.S.-backed guerrillas and the Marxist government supported by the Soviet Union and Cuba. Portugal recognizes the existing government and Savimbi had been banned until this year from coming to the country. ``The pressure for peace from inside and outside Angola will be so great, I don't see how either side will be able to continue fighting in 1990,'' he said. ``We are going to launch an enormous effort to end the war this year.'' Savimbi's remarks came against a background of increased diplomatic efforts to break a deadlock in the Angolan peace process as U.S. envoy Herman Cohen traveled from Angola to London, where he was reportedly to hold talks with Soviet officials on the war in Angola. A cease-fire agreement was signed in June in Gbadolite, Zaire, but it collapsed within days. Since December, the guerrillas have been holding off what they describe as the biggest government offensive ever mounted against their strongholds. Savimbi also said the guerrilla group was involved in direct contacts with Cuba to provide guarantees that his forces would not attack Cuban soldiers. Cuba suspended the withdrawal of its troops from Angola after four Cubans where killed in a guerrilla raid Jan. 21. Savimbi described the attack as ``involuntary'' and said the guerrilla group would provide Cuba with assurances such incidents would not be repeated. Cuba began withdrawing its troops after South Africa pledged in December 1988 to halt aid to the guerrillas and grant independence to neighboring Nambia. Savimbi said the next step in the peace process should be a halt in the government offensive followed by moves to bring about direct talks between himself and Eduardo dos Santos. ``The Americans and the Portuguese can play a more active role in the search for peace by establishing where the common ground between the two sides lies and using that to bring us together,'' Savimbi said. He said Washington and Lisbon should act in support of peace efforts by President Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire. Savimbi said the guerrillas backed Mobuto as a mediator and Cohen, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for African Affairs, had told him by telephone today that Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos shared the same position. The guerrilla leader was on the third day of a visit that marked the end of a 15-year ban on his travel to Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Says Country May Collapse; Early Elections Called
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with Honecker, three aides to be tried in March; picks up 7th pvs, `In Bonn...' ^By CAROL J. WILLIAMS
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communists agreed to share power with the opposition and move up elections by nearly two months because of growing civil unrest that threatens the country's existence, Premier Hans Modrow said today. The government said it would hold elections on March 18 instead of May 6, and form a governing coalition with the opposition until a freely elected leadership takes office. Also today, authorities arrested former hard-line leader Erich Honecker, and a prosecutor said he would be tried for high treason in March. Chief Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph told Parliament that Honecker and former Politburo members Erich Mielke, Guenter Mittag and Joachim Herrmann would be tried by the Supreme Court. All four have been expelled from the party. If convicted, Honecker, who was ousted Nov. 10 in East Germany's peaceful revolt against his 18-year Stalinist regime, could face life in prison. Honecker, 77, was taken to prison after being released from a hospital where he had undergone surgery for kidney cancer, the official ADN news agency said. His lawyer, Wolfgang Vogel, asked prosecutors to free Honecker from custody because he is too ill to stay in jail, ADN said. In Bonn, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl today said he plans to make campaign appearances for conservatives running in the East German elections. Kohl, a Christian Democrat, said he will be talking this week with pro-democracy opposition forces and East Germany's Christian Democratic leaders to decide which party to back. Opposition activists initially had resisted overtures by the still-dominant Communists to join an interim government but apparently felt the situation had become so dire that they had no other choice. East Germany's economy is on the brink of disaster and many of its most promising young workers have joined a destabilizing exodus to the West. As many as 2,500 East Germans have been fleeing daily. Modrow urged parliament today to support the agreement with the opposition. The premier said strikes and the exodus of workers have worsened the economy and set off a chain reaction of economic breakdowns, ``threatening the existence of East Germany.'' Modrow said bomb threats and vandalism have spread. ``Protection of citizens can no longer be fully guaranteed,'' Modrow told the 500-member People's Chamber. ``The current government coalition is proving increasingly fragile,'' Modrow said. ``Economic and social tensions have increased. The economic situation is deteriorating in a worrying way.'' Opposition forces had wanted to stay out of the government until the elections to avoid sharing blame for the country's economic catastrophe. But Modrow's transition government, a collection of relatively reformist Communists who are trying to salvage their standing among the citizenry, was beginning to unravel. Reforms to encourage Western investment have been held up by disputes between Communists and various opposition groups. As a result, a decline in production and living standards has hastened. Seeking to draw opposition leaders into a grand coalition to govern until the elections, Modrow opened talks Sunday with representatives of nine reform movements and a handful of minor parties long aligned with the Communists. The Communists suffered the defections of some leading reformers a week ago and the crisis deepened Thursday when three ministers from the Christian Democratic Union _ a party traditionally allied with the Communists _ pulled out of the 27-member Cabinet. Modrow and more than 40 representatives of rival political forces agreed that a new Cabinet will be submitted by Wednesday to Parliament. The decisions were announced by Martin Ziegler, a Lutheran Church official, who said the new leadership would include one member from each of the nine opposition groups represented at weekly talks with government. He said the ministers would be named without portfolio, and it was not immediately clear if the Cabinet would be expanded or if some current ministers would give up seats. The government currently has 16 Communist ministers. Wolfgang Schnur of the opposition Democratic Awakening said the Cabinet members will decide later how to distribute ministerial responsibilities. All the political groups are vying for voter support in this country of 16 million. Many opposition parties held weekend congresses to chart election strategy, but the meetings served more to highlight differences dividing the groups and preventing the emergence of a united force to challenge the Communists. New Forum, the largest of the pro-democracy groups, previously claimed 200,000 members. But a moderate faction split off from the movement to form the German Forum Party over the weekend. Meanwhile, Christian Democratic Union leader Lothar de Maiziere announced he was prepared to seek an election coalition with Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union, two East German opposition groups that support market-oriented reforms and closer ties with West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Proposes Independence on March 21
By HEIDI VON EGIDY
DOC.TEXT: The new Nambian legislature today proposed that the territory declare independence March 21 and bring to an end 75 years of South African rule.
