The Constituent Assembly submitted the date to Namibia's South African administrator, Louis Pienaar, who is expected to approve. The assembly plans to vote on the proposal at a session Tuesday. South Africa has agreed to grant independence to Namibia, Africa's last colony, under a regional peace treaty. More than 6,000 United Nations military and civilian personnel have been supervising the process since last April. The 72-member Constituent Assembly, elected in November, also is debating a democratic, Western-style constitution and is to begin voting on the document Tuesday article-by-article. All leading parties represented in the assembly have expressed support for the proposed constitution and no major disagreements are expected. The document has a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech, and a free press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and an executive president limited to two five-year terms. One potentially contentious provision would allow for detention without trial at times of war and during a state of emergency. At such times, the government could detain a person without charge if he was considered ``a clear and present danger to the security of the state.'' The leftist South-West Africa People's Organization, which waged a 23-year bush war against South African rule, captured 41 seats in the assembly and will form the first government. The group's leader, Sam Nujoma, is expected to become the country's first president. However, at least 48 assembly members, or two-thirds, must approve each article of the constitution. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a multiracial coalition that favors a free enterprise economy, has 21 seats. The 10 remaining assembly seats are divided among five parties.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Praises Promised Panama Bank Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 12th graf, Quayle was, to update with arrival in Jamaica
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle today praised Panama's U.S-installed government for its plans to change its banking system to curtail the laundering of drug money. ``I'm impressed with (Panamanian President Guillermo) Endara's willingness to move in a different direction in dealing with important issues like the laundering of drug money,'' Quayle told a news conference as he ended an overnight visit here before heading for Jamaica. ``Changes will make it easier to detect this type of activity,'' he said. Endara, appearing with Quayle, did not detail what changes are being contemplated in the banking system but said he knows some must be made. ``Panama's bankers want reasonable changes which don't unduly change the banking environment,'' Endara said through an interpreter. ``They know Panama cannot continue to be the center for ... drug dollars. We have to participate in the fight against drug trafficking.'' Alluding to the former Panamanian government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, which was toppled in December after a U.S. military invasion, Quayle said: ``We now have a government here that will join the United States in the war on drugs, where before we had a government that was cooperating in the transportation and production of illegal drugs. ``A tremendous change has occurred in Panama with the war against drugs and our campaign to get to the bottom of this taking a significant step forward with the commitment of President Endara,'' he added. Panama's system of confidential bank accounts similar to that in Switzerland has attracted more than 100 international banks, employing nearly 8,000 people. Coded banking accounts can be opened in Panama under government orders if the account holder is under investigation. ``We do not know what they will be yet,'' Endara said of the changes. ``Bankers are not opposed to reasonable changes that do not affect the banking environment. But they also know that Panama cannot continue to be a center for narcodollars.'' ``But we are opposed to fishing expeditions which is what the U.S. officials want,'' Edgardo Lasso, president of Panama's banking association, said recently. Following the news conference with Endara, Quayle flew to Jamaica for the last leg of his three-day damage-control mission in the wake of the Dec. 20 Panama invasion that offended leaders of many Latin American countries. In Kingston, Quayle expected to hear complaints about a cutback of $25 million in economic aid to the Caribbean country. Prime Minister Michael Manley has said President Bush is sending new aid to help with economic reform in Poland and Hungary at the expense of small countries like Jamaica. Bush's newly announced plan to provide Panama with $1 billion to help recover from the invasion adds to the sting. Manley said the cutback means his country will not have adequate resources for its war on drugs, which he estimated at $29 million for its initial phase. The new leaders in Panama, and the congregation of a pro-American church Quayle attended Sunday, were in favor of the U.S. military action. ``At this moment the police forces are not quite capable of protecting the lives, property and public order as the Panamanian people want,'' said Endara after attending mass with Quayle. ``That's why we need the U.S. forces in Panama at this moment, but we hope that in a very short time this will not be necessary.'' Quayle, a day after being pressed by other Latin heads of state to get the occupying troops out of Panama, insisted they will be withdrawn within a matter of weeks. He and the leaders of Costa Rica, Venezuela, Guatemala, El Salvador and Belize attended the presidential inauguration in Honduras on Saturday. ``Certainly there is concern about the security and the future of Panama,'' Quayle said, adding he had discussed with Endara how to help build Panama's police into a viable force. Bush, he said, ``wants to see the troops withdrawn and to obtain a level that we had prior to Operation Just Cause as soon as possible,'' Quayle said. One administration official predicted the troop level could be down from the current 17,000 to the pre-invasion 13,000 within two weeks. The vice president spent part of Sunday in meetings with government leaders. But he also visited a popular tourist viewing site on the Panama Canal, bought bananas at an outdoor market, stopped at a T-shirt stand to buy shirts for his three children and watched part of the Super Bowl with U.S. soldiers at Fort Clayton. He also said in a television interview on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' that he understands the reasoning of Mexico and Venezuela in not wanting him to visit their countries at this time. They told him a visit would be inopportune due to anti-invasion sentiment, ``but I will be visiting those countries later on,'' Quayle said. Offering a new rationale for the invasion, Quayle said that if Manuel Antonio Noriega had stayed in power, U.S. adherence to the Panama Canal treaty would have been jeopardized. ``Implementing the treaty as ratified by the Senate would have been a very difficult proposition,'' he said on the Brinkley show. The agreement, signed under President Carter, calls for the United States to cede control of the canal to Panama at the end of this century. Quayle was warmly received by Panamanians at Cristo Rey Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Javier Villanueva, who was renowned for his anti-Noriega sermons in pre-invasion days, said the U.S. military intervention had helped end Panamanian suffering.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted East German Leader Arrested And Jailed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Honecker to be tried in March, four associates also to be tried; picks up 11th pvs, `East Germany...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker was arrested and taken to prison today, and a prosecutor said he will tried for high treason in March. Honecker, 77, was detained after his release from East Berlin's Charite hospital, where he had undergone surgery for a malignant kidney tumor, the official ADN news agency said. Chief Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph told Parliament that Honecker and former Politburo members Erich Mielke, Guenter Mittag and Joachim Herrmann would be tried by the Supreme Court on treason charges in March. All four have been expelled from the party. Mielke was Honecker's security chief, Mittag oversaw the economy and Herrmann headed the party's propaganda department. Eleven members of Honecker's ousted Politburo already are in prison awaiting trial. Honecker's lawyer, Wolfgang Vogel, asked the chief prosecutor to free the former leader from Rummelburg prison based on a doctor's statement that he is too ill to stay in jail, ADN said. Vogel is East Germany's most prominent lawyer. One of Honecker's doctors, Horst Vogler, said the former leader was ``very depressed'' and his mental state ``impaired'' following two major surgical operations since August. West German television showed an impassive Honecker being led out of the hospital by his wife, Margot, in pre-dawn darkness. She kissed him goodbye before he was taken away in a large limousine. Honecker's daughter, son-in-law and youngest grandchild also came to see him off at the hospital, ADN quoted Vogler as saying. The charge of high treason carries a maximum life imprisonment. The conviction used to carry the death penalty, but that was abolished in reforms that followed Honecker's ouster Oct. 18. East Germany has been caught up in a virtual frenzy to root out corruption and abuse of office. Honecker, the aging hard-line Stalinist leader who ruled East Germany for 18 years, had previously been declared too ill to withstand imprisonment. ADN said the director of Charite urology clinic, Dr. Peter Althaus, repeated today that in his opinion Honecker is still not well enough to be jailed. On Sunday, West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper said Honecker would be arrested but that he would be held at a prison hospital because of his condition. ADN did not say whether Rummelsburg prison is equipped with a medical facility. Earlier this month, East Germany's Luthern Church had offered to put Honecker up in a home for the aged upon his release from the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuation of Foreigners From Southern Sudan Begins
DOC.TEXT: Two U.N. planes flew to the rebel-held city of Juba today to evacuate foreign relief workers who had been trapped by a civil war. Some of the foreigners apparently couldn't wait for the U.N. jets and left on a plane belonging to a relief organization, U.N. spokeswoman Pat Banks said. Those who waited included the United Nations' sole representative in Juba, an American named Bob Brandstetter, she said. It was unclear how many foreigners were taken out of the southern city, which has been shelled twice in the last 10 days and become the focus of an increasingly turbulent war. The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army promised in a radio broadcast to hold fire today from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. to allow the evacuation of foreigners. The only foreigners believed to be in Juba are relief workers and missionaries, and estimates of their numbers range from 80 to 120. A British Embassy official said he understood that about 30 people, more than a dozen of them Britons, opted to be airlifted out. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Embassy put the number at about 20 and said they included four Americans. The United Nations sent two Canadian-built Twin Otter aircraft to Juba from the Sudan capital of Khartoum, 750 miles away, and from Lokichokio, in Kenya. But Ms. Banks said that by the time the planes arrived in Juba, all but four of the people planning to leave had already left aboard a special plane of the Lutheran World Federation, which has been operating a small relief airflift to Juba. That group flew to Nairobi, Kenya. The four who waited for the U.N. plane were to fly to Khartoum, Ms. Banks said. The Sudan People's Liberation Army, mainly black African Christians and animists, began fighting in 1983 to wrest concessions for the south from the Arab Moslem-dominated central government. Juba has about 250,000 people and is the largest city in southern Sudan. The rebels have cut off almost all approaches by road to Juba, and at least three civilian aircraft have been shot down in the area. The only food trickling in has been via the Lutheran World Federation airlift. The city is believed to have only a month's worth of food supplies left.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first graf to correct garble
DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: Here are the U.S. domestic and overseas military bases that are candidates for possible closure. They are listed by service or defense agency: U.S. Army: Detroit Army Tank Plant, Mich.; Fort Ord, Calif.; Fort McClellan, Ala.; Lima Army Tank Plant, Ohio; Sacramento Army Depot, Calif.; Troop Support Command, St. Louis, Mo.; and Army ammunition plants at Charlestown, Ind., Parsons, Kan., Karnack, Tex., Minden, La., Picayune, Miss., Scranton, Pa., and Desoto, Kan. U.S. Navy: Alameda Naval Aviation Depot and Alameda Naval Air Station, Calif.; Chase Field Naval Air Station, Tex., Detroit Naval Air Facility, Mich., El Centro Naval Air Station Facility, Calif.; Long Beach Naval Shipyard, Calif.; Louisville Naval Ordnance Station, Ky., Moffett Field Naval Air Station, Calif.; Oakland Naval Hospital, Claif., Oakland Naval Supply Center, Calif.; Philadelphia Naval Staion and Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, Pa.,; South Weymouth Naval Air Station, Mass. and Treasure Island Naval Station, Calif. U.S. Air Force: Bergstrom Air Force Base, Texas; Eaker Air Force Base, Ark.; Los Angeles Air Force Base, Calif.; and Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C. Defense Logistics Agency: The four Defense Contract Adminsitration regional offices at Cleveland, Ohio; Dallas, Texas; New York, N.Y.; and St. Louis, Mo. Overseas: U.S. Navy: Nea Makri Naval Communications Station, Greece. U.S. Air Force: Comiso Air Base, Italy; Erhac Air Base, Turkey; Eskisehir Munitions Storage Site, Turkey; Hellenikon Air Base, Greece; Kwang Ju Air Base, Suwon Air Base, Taegu Air Base, all in South Korea; RAF Fairford, RAF Greenham Common, and RAf Wethersfield, all in the United Kingdom; and Zweibrucken Air Base in West Germany. In addition, the Navy would partially draw its forces down at Bermuda Naval Air Station and would realign its forces at San Miguel Naval Communications Station in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Strict Measures For Gun Ownership in Czechoslovakia
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Legislation strictly controlling gun ownership will be submitted to parliament and two commissions will be set up to supervise the police, the interior minister said Monday. The security forces have been reorganized since the formation of a non-Communist-led government and the commissions will determine if new directives issued from Prague are being followed nationwide, said Interior Minister Richard Sacher. ``There are still people in the security forces who understand the recent events only as a transitory period,'' he said. There are 130,000 valid gun permits in the country allowing the legal ownership of 143,000 firearms, 135,000 shotguns that can be used by hunters, and another 135,000 firearms held by registered collectors, he said. ``When you sum this up, you have quite a nice army,'' the minister said. Sacher said last week he was suspending all valid permits starting Friday to force registration of firearms in private hands. He said not only high ranking Communist Party leaders have been entitled to hold firearms but many lower ranking officials too. The draft law on firearms and ammunition to be sent to parliament would much more strictly limit permits. The minister, the first non-Communist in Eastern Europe to be put in charge of a nation's police, indicated there could be an unknown number of weapons in circulation illegally, describing a ``leak of firearms due to losses by their legal holders.'' Asked about rumors concerning a possible coup attempt, Sacher said: ``I'm convinced there is no such possibility, because there is no support among the people for such forces. It could be perhaps only a local affair.'' ``These reports can, however, be qualified as a criminal act of `spreading alarming reports,''' Sacher added. He said security forces in Bohemia would be reinforced by the troops of the Interior Ministry, while the Slovak security forces would be reinforced by regular army troops.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany to Allow Its Side of Wall to Become Gallery
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany will allow artists to turn part of the Berlin Wall's bare eastern face into an outdoor gallery, a West Berlin art promoter said Monday. David Monty said plans call for a nearly one-mile stretch in East Berlin to be set aside for painting and sculpture by 120 artists. An East German border guard official, at a news conference with Monty, said authorities expect to leave that wall segment standing and indicated the Defense Ministry has no objections to the project. Monty said he hoped to enlist famous names to work on 20 percent of the 33-foot-tall concrete panels making up the wall. The artworks, to be encased in clear plastic, would be opened to the public in May, he said. All topics would be permitted except campaign slogans for East Germany's elections and ``racism,'' Monty added. Contrary to the blank East German side, the West Berlin face of the wall in most places is covered with colorful graffiti. East Germany's Communist authorities opened the wall Nov. 9. Interim President Manfred Gerlach later said it would be torn down and replaced with a less imposing installation. Officials say the wall panels will be sold abroad for hard currency, with the revenue to be used for social causes. Last week, border guards and soldiers removed a first 320-yard stretch and carted the piece to a depot for storage.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
`Robin HUD' Pleads Guilty in HUD Thefts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to UPDATE with prosecutor now putting amount stolen at $6.6 million sted $5.6 million, further detail from hearing, and to recast. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: A Maryland real estate agent, dubbed ``Robin HUD'' after admitting she stolemillions of dollars in federal housing funds and gave some of it to the poor, pleaded guilty today and said she felt ``terrific.'' Marilyn Louise Harrell smiled throughout the hearing in U.S. District Court in pleading guilty to charges that she stole at least $4.75 million and lied on her tax returns and to federal officials. Her trial was to have begun today. The 46-year-old Ms. Harrell said she had decided to plead guilty as part of a plea agreement because she did not want to spend taxpayers' money in a court proceeding. She pleaded guilty to stealing government property and failing to report income for taxes. As part of the plea bargain, prosecutors dropped two other tax counts, two counts of lying to officials from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, and one count of lying to a bank on a loan application. But prosecutors said the still do not believe her story that she gave most of the money to charity because she is a born-again Christian. ``My assertion that she has been her own biggest charity will be fact'' by April 20, the date she is to be sentenced, U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox said at the hearing. Prosecutors recommended a sentence ranging from 37 months to 46 months, roughly three to four years, in prison. The two charges to which she pleaded guilty carry a maximum sentence of 13 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. Willcox said prosecutors would also recommend a fine but had not yet determined how large a one they would recommend. If convicted on all counts, she would have faced a maximum of 31 years in prison and more than $1 million in fines. Asked by U.S. District Judge Herbert F. Murray how she felt, Harrell replied, ``Terrific, your honor.'' Harrell, who confessed to government officials in December 1988, became a symbol of mismanagement at HUD when scandal erupted there last summer. After her indictment last November, U.S. Attorney General Richard L. Thornburgh said the case was the single largest involving the theft of federal funds by an individual. Harrell went against the advice of her attorney and freely discussed taking the money in testimony before Congress and in several nationally televised interviews. Prosecutors say Harrell took at least $6.6 million from HUD, money generated by sales of HUD properties that Harrell handled as a private escrow agent for the agency. Harrell said she has documents to prove that she took only $4.75 million in HUD funds. And she said that, contrary to the prosecutor's assertion that only a little went to charity, in fact less than 6 percent of the money benefited her family. Harrell said she hopes to be sentenced to perform community service, but regards prison as a chance to get a college degree. ``I told the kids (her son, John, and his wife, Vicki), just think of it as Mom going away a few years for college,'' said Harrell, who will become a grandmother sometime next month. Harrell, who lives in Waldorf, a small town in southern Maryland, said she has prepared herself for imprisonment since 1985, when she started diverting HUD funds. ``I never did have a problem with pleading guilty on No. 1, the embezzlement charge,'' Harrell said last week. ``Obviously, that's something that's known nationwide. ``I really truthfully consider it an honor to give up years of my life to help some of the people I've helped,'' she said. Prosecutors had said earlier that she had taken at least $5.6 million, but they revised the figure today after identifying six more properties for which she allegedly did not turn settlement proceeds over to the government. A handful of supporters who said they had benefited from her charitable contributions attended the hearing. One held up a large card that said, ``Marilyn, we are remembering you.'' ``I thought I'd get caught a long time ago,'' Harrell said after the hearing. ``I figured I was history and would help as many as I could before I went down.'' Asked if she was sorry, she said, ``Of course I'm sorry. It was not a good thing to do.'' She has said in the past that she was a born-again Christian who took the money to help people in the name of Christ.

DOC.HEAD: World Earthquakes, Deaths Down in 1989
DOC.TEXT: The number of significant earthquakes was down last year despite the World Series quake in California, and total deaths were well below average, the U.S. Geological Survey reports. Earthquake fatalities worldwide totaled 526 last year, well below the long-term average of 10,000 deaths per year. The Oct. 17 California quake, which has been named the Loma Prieta quake, killed 62 people, injured an estimated 3,500 and caused damage totaling at least $5.6 billion. In 1988, tremors claimed some 28,000 lives, most in the earthquake that struck Soviet Armenia on Dec. 7 of that year. Overall there were 55 significant earthquakes last year, six fewer than in 1988. On average the world had about 60 significant quake a year. A significant quake is defined as one that registers at least 6.5 on the Richter scale, or one that has a lower reading but which causes casualties or significant damage. In addition to the World Series quake there were five other significant quakes in the United States last year, including one in the Los Angeles area on Aug. 8 that claimed one life. The others were felt in Hawaii on June 26, Southern California on Jan. 19, Alaska on Sept. 4 and the Aleutian Islands on Oct. 7. Last year's deadliest quake occurred Jan. 22, killing 274 persons in the Tajik region of the Soviet Union. Ninety died in Iran in a quake that struck on Aug. 1. The strongest tremor of the year occurred May 23 in the South Pacific. It was a so-called Great quake, measuring 8.3 on the Richter scale. That scale measures the strength of earthquakes as shown by ground motion. Each increase of one whole number indicates 10 times more ground motion. Thus a quake of 6.3 is 10 times more powerful than one of 5.3.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Poor Leadership Caused Labor Day Violence
Ed: SUBS 4-5th grafs, `According to...', with 5 grafs to UPDATE with NAACP reaction. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The report...'.
DOC.TEXT: Poor leadership, not racism, was the main cause of a riot during a Labor Day weekend gathering of black college students, an independent panel has concluded. The panel concluded that race became a factor only after violence began between students and police, according to a report published Sunday by The Virginian-Pilot and Ledger-Star newspaper of Norfolk. Two days of looting during a gathering of 100,000 students from predominantly black universities and other young people last September cost taxpayers more than $1 million. The violence during ``Greekfest'' damaged 124 stores in Virginia Beach, and 50 people were injured in clashes with police and National Guardsmen. Jack Gravely, president of the state National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that his group supports the basic findings and conclusion of the report. Gravely, however, said there were some holes in the report concerning the arrest and detention policies of the various law enforcement agencies involved. ``I think the police departments were let off the hook. ... We're not finished with Virginia Beach,'' he said. According to the Norfolk newspaper, the Labor Day Review Commission determined that poor preparation, failure of communication and criminal actions by a small percentage of the crowd were responsible for the violence. The commission's report was to be formally presented to Virginia Beach officials this afternoon. City officials have said they won't comment until the report is released officially at that time. The report said most police officers acted responsibly and professionally, but it urged officials to review films of the violence and consider disciplining officers who violated procedures. ``We believe some arrests were mistakenly made, a few officers used inappropriate force, and some subjected residents and visitors alike to abusive language,'' the newspaper quoted the commission report as saying. Once the violence began, the report said, ``Race then became ... a way to differentiate potential friends and foes.'' Better preparations by city officials could have helped head off problems during the gathering, the commission said. ``We believe that City Council and the mayor should have been more active and should have exerted greater leadership,'' the report said. ``That sounds like a pretty fair assessment,'' L. Victor Collins, who was director of minority student affairs at Old Dominion University in Norfolk at the time of the riots, said Sunday. The report recommended ways to promote a peaceful gathering as thousands of students are expected to return to the beach this September. ``It must be understood that a repeat of Labor Day 1989 would, without doubt, strike a major blow to race relations in the city, the region and the commonwealth'' of Virginia, the report said. Mayor Meyera E. Oberndorf said city officials want to make this year's Greekfest a success. ``We want to make September 1990 a win-win situation,'' she said. The report said city officials were out of touch with the gathering's practical problems and racial implications, but it also condemned the looting and violence. ``No amount of rationalization can excuse the behavior of those individuals who destroyed, looted, and generally violated the bounds of decency that circumscribe the actions of all who live in a civilized society,'' it said. The report urged appointment of an interracial committee _ including representatives of the city, area colleges and universities, and student, civil rights, business and religious groups _ to plan this year's festival.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Communists Dissolve Party, Elect New Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to ADD quote from new party leader; restores dropped word in lead and ADDS name of breakaway party in 3rd graf. Pickup 8th pvs, `Kwasniewski, who...' Kwasniewski is pronounced Kfahsh-NYEV-skee.
DOC.TEXT: The Communists dissolved their 41-year-old party today and split into two pro-reform groups that will try to find a place in the East bloc's first democracy. Former Communists today chose Aleksander Kwasniewski, a 35-year-old sports official, to lead the new ``Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland.'' Most of the former Communist Party members joined the party. But a more radical reformer backed by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, former Gdansk party chief Tadeusz Fiszbach, broke away from the larger group and created a smaller party, called the Social-Democratic Union, that he said would not be tainted by the Old Guard. Poland has led the past year's whirlwind of democratic reform in the East bloc, and its Communist Party became the second in the Warsaw Pact after Hungary to disband in an attempt to distance itself from a repressive past. Hungary's Communists dissolved their party in October, a month after the Solidarity movement took control of Poland's government and ended 40 years of Communist rule. Hungary is to hold free elections on March 25. Poland held elections in June, when Solidarity-backed candidates won all but one of the seats they contested. The Social Democrats elected Kwasniewski, who is close to the former Communist leadership, as their first chairman. Leszek Miller, a former Communist Party secretary, was chosen as general secretary. Kwasniewski received 1,049 votes and Miller 926 votes out of 1,196 votes cast. There were three candidates for each position. ``We feel very moved by this election, and also terrified, because we are aware of the immense tasks,'' Kwasniewski told the delegates. ``I hope we can do together what we have to.'' Kwasniewski, who directs the government's sports committee, has said he wants a party capable of rallying leftist opinions and winning popular backing following the demise of the Communist Party. ``The most important thing is votes, not members. The better party is one with 100,000 members and (capable of getting) 1 million votes than a party with 1 million members and only 100,000 votes,'' he said before the vote. The latter case described the old Communist Party, he said. On Sunday, the main body of Communists voted 1,228-32 to create a new party with a platform calling for a multiparty system, respect for human rights and a market economy with some state ownership of capital. In a resolution, it called for ``further strengthening of ties'' with all the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and endorsed the idea of a ``common European home.'' However, it also said unemployment should not be accepted as a permanent part of the economy and that work is ``a natural right of man'' _ a clear attack on the Solidarity-led government's crash transformation of a centrally planned economy to free market capitalism. The platform's final resolution accepted responsibility for a legacy of failures during the four decades the party held absolute power in Poland, from the crimes of the Stalinist era to the country's current economic crisis. The Communists' last stronghold in Poland is on the local level, where elections are slated for April, and their leaders acknowledged a fresh start was needed if they are to have any chance. The new party inherits the disputed property and employees of its predecessor, formally known as the Polish United Workers Party. Walesa today accused the party of ``political arrogance'' for taking over the holdings of the Communist Party. In a statement issued in Gdansk, Walesa said, ``The illegally acquired property of the former (Communist Party) belongs to the whole society. That is why none of the newly created parties has the right to take possession.'' Young demonstrators forced their way into the provincial Communist Party headquarters in Gdansk _ the northern port where Solidarity was born in 1980 labor unrest _ on Sunday and occupied the building, demanding it be turned over for public use. In the southern city of Krakow, an attack on a party building shattered ground-floor windows, the official news agency PAP reported. Anti-communist demonstrators have briefly occupied party buildings in cities nationwide over the last month, demanding that party property be returned to the national treasury. The Solidarity-led government has formed a commission to review the legal status of the buildings, businesses and other Communist holdings. At the party congress, Fiszbach and about 100 followers declared formation of their own Social Democratic Union based on ``completely different organizational and financial principles.'' Fiszbach, a parliamentary deputy who quit his regional party chief job after the 1981 martial law crackdown on Solidarity, denounced what he called ``artificial unity'' and said it was impossible that all the old Communists had instantly become believers in democracy. The Social Democratic Union's founders included about two doze formerly Communist members of parliament. In a statement, the breakaway party said it would call a nationwide congress in coming months and likely field candidates in the local elections. In his outgoing speech, the old Communist Party's first secretary, Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski, said the party ``played a great historical role in the Polish state.'' ``We are not putting it into a coffin but are closing a chapter of the Polish revolutionary movement,'' Rakowski said just before the party's red-and-gold flag was carried out of the congress hall for the last time.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Offers To Mediate Israel and Palestinians, Invites Arafat
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel today offered to mediate peace talks between Israeli and Palestinian leaders, and his spokesman said PLO leader Yasser Arafat has been invited to visit. Havel said his intention was to help make up for the decades of Czechoslovak passivity regarding the Middle East. ``We are all responsible for the situation in the world,'' said the leader of Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist government. ``For years we have been doing nothing. We were a mere passive colony.'' Israeli Vice Premier Shimon Peres visited Prague on Jan. 21 to discuss restoration of diplomatic ties, which were severed in 1967 over the Middle East War. On Thursday, Havel met with the Palestine Liberation Organization's envoy to Prague, Samil Abdul Fattah. Havel's spokesman, Michael Zantovsky, said the offer to mediate Israeli-Palestinian talks was contingent on approval from both sides. Zantovsky said Havel invited Arafat to visit Czechoslovakia but gave no date. Israel has refused to meet with the PLO, claiming it is a terrorist organization. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been trying to get Israeli and Palestinian leaders to meet to discuss Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's plan for elections in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Last week, Havel offered Prague as the site of the next superpower summit, but U.S. and Soviet officials at a meeting in December decided to hold the next summit in the United States. Also today, Interior Minister Richard Sacher said legislation strictly controlling gun ownership is to be submitted to Parliament and two commissions will be established to supervise the police.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of North African Jews Calls For Talks With PLO
DOC.TEXT: A charismatic spiritual leader who has wide support among Israel's predominantly hard-line North African Jews on Monday called for a Palestinian state and talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``We've had enough wars and bloodshed. We are ready to talk even with those who murdered some of our sons,'' said Rabbi Baruch Abu-Hatzera, known as Baba Baruch. The rabbi, who had made similar comments earlier this month, spoke in an interview before joining thousands of pilgrims for the annual ``Hilula,'' a county fair-style memorial for his father and revered holy man, Rabbi Israel Abu-Hatzera, who was known as ``Baba Sali.'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc and a past ally, was so angered by the rabbi's statements that he canceled his visit to the Hilula at the last minute. The rift opened the door for the left-of-center Labor Party that could improve its elections chances with the support of the traditionally conservative North Africans, particularly those from Abu-Hatzera's Moroccan community. Vice Premier Shimon Peres, the Labor Party boss and Shamir's rival, attended the memorial for the elder Abu-Hatzera and delivered a speech. ``This has great importance for the next elections,'' said Rabbi Benjamin Chen, an aide to Baba Baruch. ``There are about 800,000 North Africans in Israel. They will remember that Shamir didn't come to honor the memory of Baba Sali.'' The North Africans constitute a large segment of the Sephardim, or Jews from Middle East countries, who in recent years have become a majority among the nation's 3.5 million Jews. Ashkenazim, or European Jews, have been more supportive of the Labor Party. Reactions to Baba Baruch's new politics were mixed among the thousands of North African pilgrims who flocked to a white-domed mausoleum on a muddy hilltop in this Negev Desert town to mark the sixth anniversary of Baba Sali's death. ``We should talk to the PLO if that brings peace. My youngest son will be drafted in two years, and I'm already sick with worry,'' said Rina, a 55-year-old mother of six from the nearby town of Beersheba, touching the white marble grave. Rina, who like the other pilgrims ascribes miraculous powers to Baba Sali and Baba Baruch, said she prayed for peace at the grave. She then placed a soft-drink bottle filled with water on the grave, saying it would become holy and rinse away ailments. Pilgrim David Daninu criticized Baba Baruch, saying he should not mix religion and politics. ``If we are good Jews, God will help us. Baba Baruch should not try to be a politician. Many people think it's not good what he did,'' said Daninu, 63, a retired turkey farmer from Moshav Bnosh, an agricultural settlement. Daninu, clutching a green plastic basket with sandwiches, shouted over the Arabic music blaring from booths where vendors who sold everything from Baba Sali pictures, prayer caps and holy books to perfume, detergent and sweaters. Baba Baruch retained several hard-line elements in his peace plan. He wants Israel to annex the West Bank, considered by right-wingers part of the biblical land of Israel, and establish a Palestinian state in the Gaza Strip and adjoining parts of Egypt. West Bank Palestinians would be urged to resettle in the new Palestinian state, a proposal most would likely reject. ``They should build cities in Gaza, in Al Arish and other areas under Egyptian control,'' said the black-robed rabbi, speaking in his home overlooking the mausoleum. Housing Minister David Levy, a hawkish member of Shamir's Likud, attended the memorial and said Shamir ``erred in attributing too much to what (Baruch) said.'' ``It is not he (Baruch) who will dictate to the government of Israel with whom to speak or determine the future of the land of Israel,'' said Levy, an immigrant from Morocco.

DOC.HEAD: Super Bowl `Overnights' Low
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary ratings showed that the San Francisco 49ers' record 55-10 trouncing Sunday of the Denver Broncos averaged a 38.9 rating in 23 cities, A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates showed Monday. Michael Eisenberg, a CBS vice president for research, said his network anticipated the ratings to rise to 43.5 when national estimates are available Tuesday. Each national ratings point represents 921,000 homes. However, if the national ratings don't appreciably rise from the 23-city ``overnight'' figures, Sunday's contest could prove the lowest-rated Super Bowl since 1971, when Baltimore beat Dallas 16-13. That game averaged a 39.9 national rating. It was broadcast when each national ratings point represented 601,000 homes. Last year's San Francisco-Cincinnati Super Bowl, won by the 49ers 20-16, was seen in nearly 40 million homes, according to Nielsen estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Hill Democrats See Brutal Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th graf pvs, The House, to CORRECT Gray's title to majority whip.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's $1.23 trillion budget drew a skeptical response from several Democrats in Congress today with one senator describing it as ``another fraud'' and a House leadthe United States to scale back its military presence. Bush's budget for fiscal year 1991 slows growth in military spending and dictates no general tax increase as part of a plan to cut the federal budget deficit in half. The defense budget is a suggested $303.3 billion, a rise of 2.3 percent from this year's $296.3 billion but a decrease of 2 percent after inflation, figured at 4.3 percent, is taken into account. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said the budget is a ``listen-to-what-I-say-and-forget-what-I-do budget.'' He said the figures translate into ``huge fiscal problems ahead'' without a change in course. ``The low aspirations of this document may put a very low ceiling on what we can expect to accomplish with the deficit this year,'' he said. Bush's budget projects a 1991 deficit of $63.1 billion, far below this year's estimated $123.8 billion deficit. Bush said his plan would balance the budget by 1993, the same year the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law requires a balanced budget. Hollings said the administration's 1991 figures have a ``starting line some $20 billion ahead of where they really are.'' He was skeptical about the White House proposal of adding to federal revenues with items such as ``asset sales.'' The House Democratic whip, Rep. William Gray of Pennsylvania, said he wouldn't call the budget ``dead on arrival, but we've got to take a closer look at the specifics. ... It's got to be looked at; it's got to be examined.'' He questioned Bush's underlying economic assumptions, saying they were ``quite rosy,'' at a time when ``all the indicators indicate that we're not going to have that kind of growth, interest, inflation that the administration is saying.'' Moreover, Gray said some of the ways Bush plans to raise money _ such as collecting user fees from boaters _ are simply ``taxes on working-class Americans'' that have been rejected by Congress in the past. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., who recently generated intense controversy in Congress by proposing a $62 billion cut in Social Security taxes this year and next, noted that Bush wants to balance the budget in 1993, the year after the next presidential election. ``It is well known that the federal budget is always in balance three years from now, never now,'' Moynihan said. Rep. Bob Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, said the Democrats obviously have ``a little bit different idea of where the priorities ought to be.'' ``We'll have the usual kind of argument throughout the year and hopefully we'll just get done in time,'' Michel said. House members all face re-election this year.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov to Play Computer at Harvard
DOC.TEXT: No. 2 ranked chess champ Anatoly Karpov is planning a match at Harvard University with Deep Thought, a computer program defeated last October by world chess champ Garri Kasparov. ``The computer is out for revenge now,'' Danny Edelman, president of the Harvard University Chess Club said Monday. Kasparov beat Deep Thought 2-0 in New York three months ago. Since then, the program has been improved and has defeated international grandmaster David Levy as well as Maxim Dlugy and Tony Miles, both grandmasters. Friday's match against Karpov will be the first for Deep Thought, Edelman said. Saturday, Karpov will play a simultaneous match against 40 opponents, including many junior champions.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmen Say Wrong Man Jailed Eight Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add that sentence was 55 years.
DOC.TEXT: New information appears to clear a man who has spent almost eight years in prison for a grocery store robbery, and prosecutors will ask the state parole board to pardon him, a district attorney said today. Dallas County District Attorney John Vance said police will be giving his office new information that will enable prosecutors to seek Michael Anthony Woten's release. Woten had been sentenced to 55 years. ``We will ask for it just as soon as the Dallas Police Department furnishes us information on the case, if they haven't already,'' said Vance. ``Then, we will be in the process of doing that in the next day or two. ``I believe my prosecutor has already confirmed it with the police. We are just waiting for the police to physically give it to us so that we will be knowledgeable enough to ask the governor and Board of Pardons and Paroles to pardon him.'' The Dallas Times Herald reported Sunday that new evidence places Woten with a truck driver on the outskirts of Oklahoma City at the time a Dallas Safeway supermarket was robbed on April 16, 1982. Vance said prosecutors will send a letter to the parole board ``setting out the facts as we know them'' and asking it to recommend to Gov. Bill Clements that Woten be given a full pardon. ``I wish that somebody in the process had found that evidence in 1982 and convinced us not to file the case in the first place,'' Deputy Police Chief Ray Hawkins told the Times Herald. Woten, 36, expressed disbelief when told by the newspaper that he might soon be a free man. ``Is this for sure?'' he asked. ``In all honesty, this has happened so fast, you know ... They're not going to change their minds, are they?'' The Times Herald's two-month investigation began after Woten wrote to the newspaper, claiming his innocence. He enclosed an affidavit from fellow inmate Russell Everett Chamberlain, which said Chamberlain committed the robbery. Earlier this month, Hawkins ordered a detective to reinvestigate the case. But he told the Times Herald that Chamberlain's confession would not be enough to win Woten's freedom. Then, last week a Times Herald reporter interviewed a crucial witness _ in the presence of a Dallas police detective. Former trucker Don ``Kangaroo'' Fainter remembered picking up Woten in Oklahoma City and confirmed much of Woten's alibi that he was hitchhiking to St. Louis the day two gunmen took $5,200 from the Safeway. Fainter, who now runs a gift shop in Claycomo, Mo., recalls details of the nine-hour trip with Woten. ``I gave him a ride. I'd swear to that,'' he said. During his trial, Woten testified that at the time of the robbery he was hitchhiking with a truck driver who introduced himself as Don and used the CB handle ``Kangaroo.'' However, Woten's attorney couldn't find the truck driver. Fainter came forward after hearing of an ad the Times Herald placed this month in a truckers' publication, searching for ``Kangaroo.'' He said he doesn't understand why he wasn't found and asked to testify in 1982. ``I don't know why they couldn't find me. I was right here,'' Fainter said. Evidence of the trip was found in the Centerville, Ky., office where Fainter's former employer stored company records. The Woten case is latest in a string of dubious convictions in Dallas County. Randall Dale Adams, subject of the film ``The Thin Blue Line,'' was freed last year after spending 13 years in prison after he was convicted of killing a Dallas police officer. He came within three days of the death penalty, and his conviction was finally overturned after his case gained publicity from the documentary. Lenell Geter was cleared of armed robbery charges in 1984 after he spent 16 months behind bars. And Joyce Ann Brown was freed in November after spending nine years in prison on an aggravated robbery conviction. After her conviction was overturned by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, prosecutors said they may try her again.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks 2 Percent Defense Spending Cut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, a0598,a0603,a0518,a0519
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress today to trim defense spending next year by 2 percent after inflation because of what the Defense Department called ``phenomenal changes'' sweeping the Soviet bloc and diminished chances of a major land war in Europe. ``The likelihood of a Warsaw Pact attack on NATO at this point is obviously very remote,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said at a briefing on the Pentagon's proposed $292.1 billion budget for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Cheney said some changes in U.S. defense spending are in order because of budget constraints. But he cautioned against wholesale cuts in major weapons programs given the ``enormous uncertainty'' surrounding political developments in the Soviet Union. In his budget proposals to Congress, Bush and Cheney outlined a smaller U.S. military force, paring 38,000 men and women from the 2 million in uniform and calling for elimination of several weapons systems, as well as the shutdown or reduction of 55 military bases at home and 14 overseas. At the same time, the Bush administration called for five costly new B-2 stealth bombers, another $1 billion Trident submarine and funds for two controversial intercontinental nuclear missile systems. The president also proposed an additional $900 million for the Strategic Defense Initiative. ``We've seen phenomenal changes,'' Cheney said, noting that many of the Warsaw Pact's leadership has been swept from power in a pro-democracy tidal wave in the past year. He also noted reductions in Soviet military spending. But Cheney said any attempt to reduce U.S. military strength because of the budget squeeze ``has to be done carefully, cautiously, it has to be done deliberately.'' Bush's budget plan is certain to provoke a blistering battle on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers cut Bush's request for SDI funds last year, and are unlikely to embrace military base closings in their own districts. ``We cannot responsibly reduce the defense budget without looking at bases and production lines,'' Cheney said in a statement released with a list of targeted installations that ranged from the Army's Fort Ord near Monterey, Calif., to the sprawling repair docks at the Philadelphia naval shipyard. The Pentagon gave no estimate of eventual cost savings from the base closings, which require congressional appropriations for the initial expense of shutting them down. Cheney said in a statement that the Pentagon budget ``represents the first steps in responding to changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, as well as tighter budget constraints. Our response includes reducing force levels, closing military bases and ending weapons programs.'' To help reduce spending, Cheney planned to announce later today a sweeping list of bases to be closed or reduced over the next five years, from Philadelphia to Long Beach, Calif., and overseas. The base closing proposals, some already publicized, have drawn angry protests from lawmakers whose congressional districts would be affected. The Pentagon's fiscal 1991 budget plan for the 12 months starting Oct. 1 shows an increase in current outlays of $286.8 billion in outlays _ a 2 percent reduction after adjusting for anticpated inflation. The administration projects a 4.3 percent inflation rate for the coming year. The Pentagon is seeking overall budget authority of $295.1 billion, up from this year's $291.4 billion. That figure does not include $11.1 million in spending for the nuclear weapons programs administered by the Energy Department. Looking ahead, Cheney projected a 2 percent decline in defense spending over the next five years. ``By 1995, defense spending will be at its lowest level, measured either as a share of (the total economy) or as a portion of total federal spending, since before World War II,'' Cheney said. The fiscal 1991 plan calls for cutting active-duty armed forces by 38,000 men and women, trimming civilian Defense Department employees by 5,000 and reducing reserve forces by 3,000. Two Army divisions would be disbanded by the end of the year. They are the 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood, Texas, and the 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Wash. Production of the Army's M-1 tank would end after 225 are turned out this year. The Navy would lose two of its four battleships from the World War II era, the USS Iowa and USS New Jersey, for an estimated savings of $75 million. Eight older attack submarines would be deactivated and two nuclear cruisers would be retired. Fourteen B-52s also would be withdrawn from service. Overall, Cheney said he wanted to terminate 20 weapons programs in an attempt to save $2.9 billion. Among them are the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft, the Navy's F-14D jet fighter, the Phoenix and Maverick missiles, the Apache helicopter, the Army Helicopter Improvement Program and the F-15E fighter. Congress last year rejected the administration's attempt to eliminate the Osprey and ordered F-14D production to end after several years. The administration's move to protect several big-ticket weapons programs from the budget ax faces opposition in Congress. The budget plan includes five B-2 stealth bombers costing a total of $5.5 billion. The batwinged, radar-evading plane has given lawmakers ``sticker shock'' with its $530 million price tag. Congress approved two of the three stealth bombers requested last year, but the addition of five more is certain to be resisted. Funds for SDI, a space-based anti-missile system, would be increased by $900 million to $4.5 billion. Together with about $300 million in Energy Department money, the program would get $4.8 billion under the budget plan, $1 billion more than Congress approved last year. Another controversial administration request is $202 million in continued financing of two land-based ICBMs, the rail-based, multiple-warhead MX missile and the truck-based, single-warhead Midgetman. Another costly budget request is $1.5 billion for one Trident submarine and $1.7 billion for 52 Trident II nuclear missiles. The budget includes $1.2 billion to involve the U.S. military more deeply in Bush's anti-drug war and a 3.5 percent military pay raise. Many legislators are expected to demand more drastic cuts in defense spending in anticipation of a supposed ``peace dividend.'' Cheney has been accused of lacking a strategic plan for responding to recent political upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. But Cheney defended his budget plan as providing ``careful, orderly, prudent'' reductions at a time of international uncertainty. He has said this is ``the worst possible time to contemplate changes in defense strategy.''

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Captain's Trial in Nation's Worst Oil Spill Gets Under Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with trial under way, judge briefing media, other detail. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `I'd like...'. DELETES now-redundant 9th graf, `Hazelwood faces...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: The trial of Joseph Hazelwood got under way today with the judge predicting it would take a ``fairly long time'' to select a jury to weigh the charges against the former tanker captain in the nation's worst oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone spent much of the morning briefing reporters on courtroom rules in the highly publicized case. Hazelwood, 43, faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. He was the captain of the Exxon Valdez when the tanker ran aground March 24, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil. Johnstone said jury selection in the case would not begin until Tuesday, and that he would spend the rest of today on pretrial motions. In motions similar to ones that have been rejected in the past, Hazelwood's lawyers are seeking again to have his failed sobriety test prohibited as evidence and challenging the state's jurisdiction in the case. ``I expect jury selection will take a fairly long time,'' Johnstone said, estimating it could take two weeks. About 90 prospective jurors have been given standard, three-page questionnaires and about 30 a day will be questioned, the judge said. A larger number will be screened if a panel of 12 plus alternates cannot be found from the pool of 90 people. Johnstone said he expects each side in the case to spend about three weeks presenting arguments. Largely for reasons of fairness, the trial was moved here from Valdez, the port where the Exxon Valdez took on its cargo of North Slope crude hours before the tanker struck charted Bligh Reef. Before he left his home state of New York to come here to face trial, Hazelwood said said he looked forward to arguing that the spill was a ``tragic accident,'' not a criminal act. ``I'd like to get rid of the misconception that I got drunk, ran the ship aground, and just shrugged my shoulders and walked away _ because that's just not what happened,'' Hazelwood said in an interview with The Associated Press last week in his New York lawyer's office. Hazelwood, who was not on the bridge when the accident occurred, failed a blood-alcohol test 10 hours after the Exxon Valdez struck Bligh Reef in Prince William Sound. The spill killed thousands of animals and disrupted commercial fishing seasons. Exxon says the cleanup has cost $2 billion. The charges carry combined penalties of up to seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Defense attorney Dick Madson planned to argue that Hazelwood left clear instructions for the crew and cannot be held criminally responsible for their actions. Third Mate Gregory Cousins was at the wheel of the 987-foot vessel when it ran aground after leaving designated shipping lanes. Cousins was expected to testify. He was served with a subpoena in Tampa, Fla., on Friday at the request of Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, the Hazelwood prosecutor. Cole alleged that Cousins was not licensed to navigate in Prince William Sound. Cousins declined to comment before the trial. In an affidavit, Cole also alleged that Hazelwood was seen drinking at two bars within three hours before his ship left the port of Valdez. Other witnesses Madson said he will call include other crew members and an expert who will describe a computer simulation of the ship's course and testify that the Exxon Valdez would have cleared Bligh Reef had the crew followed Hazelwood's instructions. The trial, originally scheduled for October in Valdez, was delayed as courts dealt with reassigning judges, processing thick legal motions and other matters. The trial was moved to Anchorage on grounds a fair proceeding could not be obtained in Valdez, and because Alaska's largest city has a substantial jury pool and facilities for news media. Hazelwood was expected to be in the courtroom throughout the trial. Since being fired, the seaman from Huntington, N.Y., has been working as a lobsterman. Before his tanker ran aground, the longest he had been ashore since he was an adolescent was two or three months. ``I get stark crazy when I am too far from the salt water,'' he said, chain-smoking during the interview. Hazelwood said he was confident that once Alaskans heard the case against him ``they will agree that this was a tragic accident, nothing more.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Cheney Announces Proposed Base Closings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 3 grafs new with Cheney announcing proposal; picks up 3rd graf apvs, bgng: ``Among the.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed closing or realigning more than 60 military bases in the United States and 12 installations overseas today as part of a cost-saving effort. ``These proposed actions are part of an ongoing effort to streamline Defense Department operations in keeping with changing requirements and future budget realities,'' Cheney told Capitol Hill lawmakers in a letter that accompanied his list. Cheney released the list of suggested targeted military sites at a Pentagon briefing, in which he also discussed his $292.1 billion fiscal 1991 spending plan. Among the domestic bases affected are several in California, including Fort Ord, which played a major role in the recent invasion of Panama; Alameda Naval Aviation Depot, Oakland's Naval Supply Center, Moffett Field Naval Air Station and Long Beach Naval Shipyard. The overseas bases include seven in Europe, four in Asia and a Naval Air Station in Bermuda. The European bases include two in Greece _ Hellenikon Air Base and NAVCOMMSTA in Makri; one in West Germany _ Zweibrucken Air Base; three in England _ RAF Fairford, Greenham Common and Wethersfield; and one in Italy _ Comiso Air Base. Comiso and Greenham Common are home to Air Force cruise missile installations that are being dismantled under the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty with the Soviet Union, signed in December 1987. The Asian bases on Cheney's list are a Navy base in San Miguel, Philippines and three in South Korea _ Kwang Ju, Suwon and Taeguak. ``No final decision has been made regarding closure, reduction or realignment of installations,'' the Navy documents on the closings said. The Army cuts also apply to a number of reserve units, including some in Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, Kentucky, Maryland and Michigan. Reports of Cheney's proposed closures have circulated for several days on Capitol Hill, where they set off heated protests from lawmakers and prompted a warning from Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, that the shutdowns must not be partisan if the Pentagon hopes to achieve any cuts. However, to discourage leaks, Pentagon officials waited until the weekend to print the entire base closure list, and the secretary was to discuss his reasoning behind the base erasures at a two-hour press conference today. Cheney's list is only a suggestion, however. Since it costs money to shut bases down and legislation is necessary to accomplish the complex feat, the savings are not usually accrued until years later. In actuality, Cheney's list is a proposal to study which bases should be eliminated. Closing a base also requires a lengthy series of environmental impact statements which often lead to delays.

DOC.HEAD: CBS To Make TV Movie About Lucille Ball
DOC.TEXT: CBS said Monday it has commissioned production of a TV movie about the late Lucille Ball, whose ``I Love Lucy'' series in the '50s helped boost the network to high ratings. No actress has been chosen to play Ball, a spokesman said. The film, covering the period when Ball was married to bandleader Desi Arnaz, will air during the 1990-91 season. Ball died last April at the age of 77.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrat Leader Endorses Lafontaine as Top Opposition Canidate
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Opposition politician Oskar Lafontaine won a key endorsement Monday in his bid to be the main challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in December's elections. Lafontaine, the governor of Saarland state, led the Social Democrats to a lopsided victory over Kohl's conservative party in state elections. On Monday, Social Democratic Party chairman Hans-Jochen Vogel announced he was backing Lafontaine as the party's choice to challenge Kohl. He said Lafontaine is a politician ``who can speak to the people and who can convince them.'' Vogel said the party's board will discuss Lafontaine's candidacy in March. A final decision will be made at a special national party congress in autumn, but Vogel's endorsement along with those from other influential Social Democrats is likely to assure Lafontaine of the candidacy. The independent-minded, leftist Lafontaine is the party's deputy chairman. The Saarland governor told reporters he would take a three-week vacation to consider whether he would accept the party's nomination. But in recent weeks, Lafontaine has clearly stated he was willing to try to unseat Kohl. Lafontaine's already good prospects of becoming the Social Democrats' standard bearer received a major boost after he led the party to a resounding victory in Sunday's local elections. Nationally known and respected as a tough career politician, Lafontaine is expected to be a strong challenger to Kohl's bid for a third four-year term as the West German leader. Lafontaine, 46, handed Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Union the latest in a string of local setbacks. The Free Democrats, Kohl's centrist partner in the governing Bonn coalition, also lost seats. Sunday's vote in Saarland was an unexpectedly strong endorsement for Lafontaine's entry into national politics, as the Social Democrats widened its absolute majority in the state parliament. The Social Democrats polled 54.4 percent, compared with 33.4 percent for the Christian Democrats and 5.6 percent for the Free Democrats. According to preliminary official results, the Social Democrats won 30 of the state parliament's 51 seats, a gain of four. The Christian Democrats won 18, down two, while the Free Democrats dropped from five to three seats. For Kohl, it was a damper after last fall's sudden democratic changes in East Germany stirred hopes for German reunification and boosted the chancellor's standing. Lafontaine's campaign focused on the economic and social impacts of the wave of East Germans resettling in West Germany. The election outcome illustrates the public's growing resentment of the influx. Lafontaine has urged that generous federal and state benefits for East German immigrants be cut to encourage them to stay at home and work for democratic change. He said Sunday night that the Saarland vote was a warning to Bonn. ``A majority of the population does not tolerate that one talks about future forms of statehood but not about current social problems,'' he told West German TV. ``It is nonsensical to offer bounties for leaving (East Germany).'' About 47,000 East Germans have fled political and economic uncertainty in their Communist-dominated homeland since Jan. 1, and as many as 2,000 arrive daily. Nearly 344,000 migrated to West Germany last year, putting great strain on social services and housing markets. Lafontaine recently called himself a ``German patriot in the tradition of enlightenment and tolerance.'' Vogel has predicted ``outstanding achievements'' for Lafontaine, who began a meteoric political career at age 21 in the party youth organization. In Saarbruecken, he became the youngest mayor of any West German city at age 32. When he was voted deputy chairman of the Social Democrats in 1987, he had become known as a gadfly opposed particularly to the party's conservative wing led by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt. Lafontaine vocally opposed plans to station U.S. medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany, pushed by Schmidt in the late 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Praises East German Elections Action; Cautions Romanians
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Monday praised East Germany's decision to move up national elections to March and cautioned the interim rulers of Romania against backsliding from the country's revolution. Privately, U.S. officials were relieved that the East German government had decided not to wait until May 6 to hold the elections. They had rated the Communist goverment's chances of surviving until then as no better than 50-50. Those chances may have been improved by the parallel decision in East Berlin to form a coalition government until the March 18 elections with opposition elements, a move that effectively ends the Communists' domination. ``They seem to have accelerated the schedule in order to move quickly to a more stable, more long-term regime that's based on the popular will. That's something that we support,'' Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III visited Potsdam last month to demonstrate U.S. support for the new governnet. He held separate talks with Premier Hans Modrow and Lutheran clergymen, many of whom were critics of the ousted hard-line regime. Baker is planning to go to Czechoslvakia next week to show support for the relatively calm transition in that Central European country. But chances that he might also go to Romania appear to be slipping in light of unsettled conditions there. A final decision is expected shortly. The stop in Prague is part of a trip dominated by talks Baker will hold in Moscow Feb. 7-8 on arms control issues, Afghanistan and other topics with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Spokesman Boucher reiterated U.S. support for trends in East Germany in his statement. ``The United States has, I think, clearly and consistently favored the process of democratic reform in East Germany,'' he said. ``We think that only by meeting the desire of the East German population for reform can stability be maintained.'' Boucher addes that ``it remains critical that the elections be genuinely democratic, free and secret.'' He said the decision to move up the elections was designed to promote stability in East Germany by establishing a government based on popular will. ``We agree that the installation of a legitimate government based on free elections is the best guarantee of long-term stability,'' Boucher said. Turning to Romania, where an interim government has imposed restrictions on freedom of assembly, the State Department spokesman took a cautious stance. ``We are carefully watching the almost daily demonstrations in Bucharest which have protested the predominance of Communists in the National Salvation Front, and the Front's recent decision to run candidates in the election scheduled for May 20th,'' he said. ``The composition and policies of the Salvation Front will obviously be important issues in those elections. We call upon all Romanians both inside and outside the government to conduct themselves peacefully and in the true spirit of democracy to which they say they are dedicated,'' Boucher said, reading from a prepared statement. It concluded with this warning: ``There should be no backsliding on the part of transitional officials as Romania moves from revolution to democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Kim Dae-Jung Urges Resistance to Merger of Three Conservative Parties
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Kim Dae-jung urged ``democratic'' forces Monday to join him in opposing the merger of the governing Democratic Justice Party and two conservative opposition groups. The leftist leader called the proposed merger ``a coup d'etat.'' ``There is no precedent in our nation's political history for such an infamous and traitorous action,'' he said. ``In a single day, the ruling party, which had not even a majority, suddenly became three-quarters of the National Assembly. This is a situation which makes possible total dictatorship.'' Changes in the constitution can be made with a two-thirds vote in the legislature. President Roh Tae-woo's party holds 127 of the 299 seats in the unicameral parliament, compared with 71 for Kim's leftist Party for Peace and Prosperity. The merged party, to be formed in a month, would have about 220 seats. In a statement he read at a meeting of the Seoul Foreign Correspondents Club, Kim said his party ``will welcome all moderate, democratic political forces and will try to be the people's party.'' He said the proposed new ruling party was ``controlled by the forces of the extreme right.'' Roh's party intends to join with the Reunification Demcoratic Party of Kim Young-sam and the New Demcoratic Republican Party, led by Kim Jong-pil. They are the second- and third-ranked opposition parties after Kim Dae-jung's. During a television appearance a week ago with the two other Party leaders, Roh said they had agreed to form a new conservative political group with the aim of bringing stability to South Korea's faction-ridden politics. Kim Dae-jung said Monday that, if the three parties ``insist on the ... merger, and forcibly change the consitution to allow for a cabinet system'' to replace the existing presidential system, the present National Assembly ``must be dissolved'' and the people's decision sought through elections. He claimed the merger was designed to keep him from winning the next presidential election. Roh's term ends in 1993. Kim Dae-jung says he lost the last presidential election in 1987 because the two other Kims also ran as opposition candidates, splitting the vote. Earlier Monday, the Rev. Park Hyung-kyoo and nine other dissident Protestant ministers issued a declaration describing the merger as an attempt ``to block the masses from advancing into political circles.'' They said they planned a rally Feb. 13 to oppose the merger, and predicted 2,000 Christian clerics would attend. There have been reports of plans by some junior lawmakers in Kim Young-sam's party to form a new independent opposition group.

DOC.HEAD: Faulty Air Conditioning Fan to Blame for Cabin Smoke
DOC.TEXT: A faulty air-conditioning fan was blamed Monday for sending smoke into the cabin of a Delta Air Lines jet as the pilot tried for a third time to make the trip to New York. The fan overheated Sunday, spreading smoke in the cabin of Flight 606 through air-conditioning ducts and forcing an evacuation, said Sam K. Murphy, district marketing manager for Delta. There was no fire. The flight, bound for LaGuardia Airport, carried 114 passengers and a crew of eight. Four people suffered minor injuries when the passengers and crew used slides to evacuate the Boeing 727. The plane was taxiing at about 1:15 p.m. when the smoke was detected in the passenger cabin, Murphy said. At that point, he said, the plane's engines were shut down and the emergency chutes used. ``People were grabbing at the oxygen masks,'' said Christen Cashman, 21, a student at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. ``I wasn't really that nervous because there was a businessman next to us and he told us it was no big deal and these things happen all the time. Then we lined up and went down the evacuation chute.'' The aborted takeoff was the plane's third attempt that day. The plane had first tried to depart on schedule at 11 a.m., but returned to the gate before liftoff because of an oil warning light on engine No. 1, Murphy said. Maintenance workers fixed the problem and the plane took off about a half hour later, he said. After about 20 minutes in the air, the same warning light flashed on for engine No. 3 and the aircraft returned to Tampa International Airport. ``That indicates a potential problem and as a precautionary measure, (the pilot) returned to have our maintenance people take a look at it,'' Murphy said. As he returned for landing, the pilot _ using standard procedures _ shut off the engine and dumped a ``significant'' amount of fuel over the Gulf of Mexico, said Paul MacAlester, an airport spokesman. He says the fuel is dumped to lessen the chances of fire from landing difficulties. ``It would have been enough (fuel) to get from here to La Guardia and some to spare,'' MacAlester said. ``You do this so you don't have any more fuel on board than you have to.'' The jet landed safely and maintenance workers changed the oil filters in the two other engines. As the plane prepared for take off an hour later, the smoke was detected and the flight was grounded.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Seek More Air Traffic Controllers, Safety Inspectors
With AM-Budget Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush proposed Monday to trim federal transportation outlays next year to $7.8 billion, but to hire more employees to handle growing air traffic congestion and detect safety problems in aging airliners. Bush's proposed budget for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1, calls for a $264 million increase in funds for the Federal Aviation Administration, a 7 percent boost to $4.1 billion for the agency. The higher funds would enable the FAA to hire nearly 500 new air traffic controllers, 300 new safety inspectors and additional security specialists. There were 16,921 controllers on the federal payroll as of Dec. 31. ``Additional staff are needed because of projected increases in aviation activity and because of the aging of the aircraft fleet,'' the FAA said. ``The staffing increases will result in the largest air traffic control work force in the history of the FAA and more than double the staff devoted to detecting the problems of aging aircraft,'' the agency said. The announcement came as federal investigators were exploring an apparent communications mixup between regional and local New York air traffic controllers in the crash of a Colombian Avianca jetliner on Long Island last Thursday, killing 73 people and injuring 85 others. The plane, which was low on fuel, was trying to land at Kennedy International Airport. Overall, Bush urged reducing Transportation Department outlays from the current $9.2 million to $7.8 billion next year, and putting greater reliance on tax-supported highway and aviation trust funds and public-private enterprises to finance major transportation improvements. The trust funds are supported by a variety of user fees and excise taxes on such items as gasoline. When they are taken into account, total transportation spending would rise to $28.7 billion in fiscal 1991, compared with $28.2 billion this year. Other Bush proposals included: _A ticket tax or surcharge on departing air passengers to help finance airport construction and improvements. _A fivefold increase in research spending on developing so-called smart cars and smart highways using ``state-of-the art electronics, communications and computer technology to improve traffic control systems (that) warn drivers of dangerous situations and make more efficient use of the existing road system.'' _$10 million to assess the potential of a public-private system of non-polluting, high-speed trains guided by magnets and achieving maximum speeds of 300 miles per hour. The administration proposed a 12 percent increase _ from $6.5 billion to $7.2 billion _ in programs to benefit air travelers, as part of a long-term plan to modernize aviation facilities, expand airport capacity and bolster aviation research and development. The request for $190 million earmarked for research and development _ a 12 percent boost in current spending _ would finance a study of metal fatigue and corrosion in older aircraft and a new laboratory to perfect airport detection of explosive devices in luggage. It also would pay for development of new ways to prevent aircraft fires and minimize fire injuries. Bush proposed cutting off operating subsidies to mass transit systems in cities with populations of 1 million or more, saying the federal contribution represents less than 6 percent of those budgets.

DOC.HEAD: Increases Reported in Personal Income, Spending
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending posted its largest increase in three years in 1989, the government reported Monday, and analysts said robust incomes should result in continued purchasing strength in the first quarter of 1990. The Commerce Department said spending totaled $3.47 trillion, a 7.3 percent gain over 1988 and the sharpest advance since a 6.1 percent increase in 1986. At the same time, it said personal incomes rose 9 percent to $4.43 trillion last year, up from 7.6 percent in 1988 and the fastest advance since rising 9.5 percent in 1984. ``You look at those numbers and you kind of wonder why everybody was talking about recession,'' remarked Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting organization. ``Those were pretty good numbers, especially the growth in income, which was quite robust.'' The difference between 1989 earnings and purchases helped boost Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ to 5.5 percent from 4.2 percent in 1988. It was the highest rate since 1984's 6.1 percent.
