Despite the increases in 1989 incomes and consumption, the year ended on a sluggish note, with economic growth held back by high interest rates resulting from Federal Reserve efforts to slow inflation by keeping a tight grip on credit. The Commerce Department reported last Friday that the gross national product grew only 0.5 percent in the October-December quarter, down from a 3 percent advance in the third quarter. The report on the GNP _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ included a rare decline of 0.1 percent in spending in the fourth quarter. The year-end economic sluggishness was further reflected in Monday's report of a 0.5 percent increase in personal income in December, down from the 0.9 percent gains in both October and November. The December figure was the smallest advance since a 0.2 percent rise last September and reflected a seasonally adjusted annual spending rate of $4.57 trillion. ``The December increase was boosted by a return to work following strikes in the aircraft and telephone industries and was reduced by decreases in retroactive Social Security benefit payments and in subsidy payments to farm proprietors,'' the Commerce Department said. But at the same time, consumers increased their spending in December by 1 percent, up from 0.3 percent in both October and November and the largest increase since a 1 percent gain in August. Spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.58 trillion. Much of the December increase, Commerce said, was spent on fuel oil, electricity and natural gas because of unusually cold weather. Nevertheless, Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group here, said consumers still were spending as the year ended, although cautiously. ``We'll see an improvement in consumer spending in the first quarter'' of 1990, she said. ``We already see an increase in car sales which made the whole (fourth) quarter look so bad.'' Purchases of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ rose $6.7 billion in December after declining $2.8 billion the previous month. Non-durable purchases gained $6.2 billion after a $3.4 billion November increase. Spending on services increased $24.1 billion following a $9.6 billion advance the previous month. Americans' incomes after taxes rose 0.4 percent last month, after a 1 percent gain in November. The key component of the income category _ wages and salaries _ increased $16.9 billion in December, reflecting in part the end of the Boeing Co. aircraft strike. Wages and salaries rose $2 billion in November. Payrolls at manufacturing companies increased $2.3 billion after dropping $5.9 billion in November. The December savings rate was 5.6 percent, down from 6.2 percent in November.

DOC.HEAD: Falcons Once Near Extinction Come Back to Illinois
DOC.TEXT: A program aimed at bringing the peregrine falcon back from the brink of extinction in Illinois has reached its goal a decade earlier than expected, the project director said Monday. When the Chicago Peregrine Release program ends this summer, 46 of the crow-sized birds of prey will have been reintroduced into Illinois, said director Vicki Byre. Before the program began in 1986, peregrines had not been seen in Illinois for 35 years, wiped out by pesticides that damaged their ability to reproduce, Ms. Byre said in a telephone interview. ``By the end of 1960s, peregrines were entirely extinct east of the Rocky Mountains,'' she said. But with the help of projects nationwide, there are now likely more than 100 breeding pairs east of the Rockies _ and probably more than that west of the Rockies, she said. Peregrines in the western United States have fared better because there is less cropland _ and thus less pesticide use, Ms. Byre said. ``It's because of man that they have disappeared so I think we owe it to our fellow living creatures to help them back,'' she said. Changes have been made since the near-demise of the peregrine, nature's fastest bird and known for making spectacular swoops at 200 mph to catch its prey _ smaller birds _ in flight. The pesticide DDT was banned in this country in 1972, and the federal government declared the falcon an endangered species the following year. The peregrine's natural habitat _ mostly wide open cliffs _ also has changed. Places where it once roosted have been populated with homes, trees, and the falcon's most deadly predator _ the great horned owl, said Carl Becker, chief of the Illinois Department of Conservation's Division of Natural Heritage. So most projects like Chicago's release the birds into urban ``wilds.'' Ornithologists have discovered the lofty ledges of skyscrapers make ideal homes. Under the Chicago program, coordinated by the Chicago Academy of Sciences and the conservation department, 5-week-old peregrine chicks raised in captivity are released in groups of about five and provided with food until they can thrive on their own. Each bird costs $1,750. ``The whole thing that we measure the success of the program by is not just if you can get them released in the wild but if they can mate on their own,'' Ms. Byre said. So far, peregrines in Illinois have produced at least six young, she said. ``Our goal was to try to get three breeding pairs into Illinois by the year 2000. The program has reached that goal already because we do have three pairs,'' Ms. Byre said. Once the Chicago program ends, the conservation department will evaluate whether to attempt peregrine release elsewhere in the state, Becker said.

DOC.HEAD: Nature Conservancy Makes Its Biggest Land Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: The Nature Conservancy closed a deal Monday to acquire the biologically diverse 321,703-acre Gray Ranch in New Mexico's southwestern boot heel, the environmental organization said. It is the largest land acquisition in the nearly 40-year history of the non-profit Conservancy, which has protected more than 4 million acres of ecologically significant land across the United States. ``We acted as we did because we were concerned that it (the ranch) may be sold to another purchaser that may not share the kind of conservation goals that The Nature Conservancy had,'' said Bill Waldman of Santa Fe, director of the Conservancy's operations in New Mexico. ``More separate species and subspecies of mammals are found on the Gray Ranch than on any existing national wildlife refuge or national park in the continental United States,'' Waldman said from the group's national headquarters in Arlington, Va. The ranch supports an estimated 75 species and subspecies of mammals, 150 species of birds and 52 kinds of reptiles and amphibians, said Michele Merola, operations and communications coordinator for the Conservancy in Santa Fe. The animals include three federally endangered species _ Sanborn's long-nosed bat, the bald eagle and the ridge-nosed rattlesnake. The state also has an endangered species list, Ms. Merola said, and 21 plants and animals from that list are represented at the ranch, including the white-eared hummingbird, the bunchgrass lizard, night-blooming cereus, green-flowered fishhook cactus and the white butterfly cactus. In the middle of the ranch south of Lordsburg sit the Animas Mountains, covered with conifer trees like Douglas fir, pinon and juniper. The flanks of the mountains give way to oak and shrub oak that is surrounded by semi-desert grassland, which makes up the bulk of the ranch. Last year, Congress postponed appropriations to buy the ranch and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. placed an indefinite freeze on a proposed federal purchase of the ranch for use as a wildlife refuge. Lujan's decision came after he and Gov. Garrey Carruthers toured the ranch last September. At the time, Lujan expressed concern about its high cost. ``The owners want $23 million, but the appraisal is $16 million and, by the time they buy surrounding ranches, we're looking at $50 to $60 million instead,'' Lujan said. The Nature Conservancy bought the ranch from Gray Land and Cattle Co., which Waldman said has owned the land for seven or eight years. The price was not revealed, but Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., said last year that the group planned to buy the ranch for an estimated $18.25 million. ``We've been actively involved in pursuit of protecting it for several years, and we've been negotiating for two years,'' Waldman said. The Nature Conservancy is acquiring 226,664 acres of deeded land, and will lease the remaining state, private and U.S. Bureau of Land Management land, Waldman said. The ranch was once the property of George Hearst, a California mining and livestock baron and father of publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst, the Conservancy said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Says Angolan War May End This Year
DOC.TEXT: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, said Monday the civil war may end this year because of superpower pressure and his country's weariness with bloodshed. ``The pressure for peace from inside and outside Angola will be so great, I don't see how either side will be able to continue fighting in 1990,'' said Savimbi, who has U.S. support. ``We are going to launch an enormous effort to end the war this year.'' He spoke to reporters during a tour of Europe that also will take him to Belgium, Switzerland, West Germany and possibly France, in search of support for his UNITA guerrilla movement. Savimbi has fought the Soviet-backed government since Angola independence from Portugal in 1975. He said UNITA, whose formal name is the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, had been in direct contact with Cuba to give assurances the rebels would not attack Cuban soldiers stationed in Angola. Last week, Cuba suspended the withdrawal of its troops after four Cubans where killed in a UNITA raid. Reports on Monday from Luanda, the Angolan capital, said Cuban soldiers killed 33 guerrillas in apparent reprisal for the Jan. 21 rebel attack. Cuban soldiers had not been involved in fighting since the withdrawal began after South Africa pledged in December 1988 to stop aid to UNITA and grant independence to neighboring Namibia. Cuba originally had 50,000 soldiers in Angola and an estimated 19,000 remain. Savimbi said better superpower relations meant the Kremlin would support a more active role for the United States in seeking peace. U.S. envoy Herman Cohen was in London on Monday and reports said he intended to meet with Soviet officials about Angola. A cease-fire signed in June at Gbadolite, Zaire, collapsed within days. Since December, UNITA has fought off what the rebels describe as the largest government offensive ever launched against their strongholds. Halting that offensive and arranging talks between Savimbi and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos should be the next steps, the rebel leader said. ``The Americans and the Portuguese can play a more active role in the search for peace by establishing where the common ground between the two sides lies and using that to bring us together,'' he said. Savimbi said the United States and Portugal should support peace efforts by President Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire, who has mediated between the government and rebels. He said Portugal could serve as a channel of communication between the sides. President Mario Soares and Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal met with Savimbi separately over the weekend. Jose Durao Barroso, secretary of state for foreign affairs, flew to London on Monday for talks with Cohen. Savimbi met with Roman Catholic Church leaders and labor union officials Monday.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Commission Meeting Opens With Tribute to Sakharov
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Human Rights Commission began its annual session on Monday with a tribute to the late Andrei Sakharov, who was hailed as a champion of freedom and human rights. All members of the 43-nation commission rose after the incumbent chairman, Marc Bossuyt, asked for a minute of silence in Sakharov's ``memory and as a gesture of gratitutde for all those who courageously fought for human rights.'' Bossuyt, a Belgian international law expert, also hailed ``the courage, clearsightedness and self-sacrifice of political leaders who dared to abandon the methods of the past to confront realities ... in order to better respond to the needs of the peoples which they govern.'' He said the past year had brought success for some human rights movements, while others ``were drowned in blood.'' ``In any case, it is clear that the thirst for freedom can move masses throughout the world,'' he said. ``The last decade of the 20th century has begun with that message.'' Bossuyt said he believed the commission remained silent on many past abuses too often. ``Every time a repressive regime collapses and human rights violations are revealed, there is a certain embarrassment which some people try to hide in vain by feigning irgnorance,'' he said. ``The commission should concern itself less with the risk of displeasing some governments which violate human rights and should be more concerned by the fate of the victims of those violations,'' he said. Jan Martenson, U.N. Undersecretary-General for Human Rights, joined Bossuyt in eulogizing Sakharov. ``We best honor his memory by maintaining the fight for justice and human dignity in the face of indifference and intolerance,'' he said . The crowded opening meeting was also attended by observers from many other U.N. member nations and by representatives of more than 100 non-governmental organizations monitoring human rights. Purificacion Quisumbing, a senior legal official in the Philippine government, was elected to chair the 1989 session, succeeding Bossuyt. The commission's agenda covers a wide range of issues, from such ``traditional'' subjects as South Africa and Israel to special reports on a number of countries, including Iran and Romania, both non-members. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar has been asked to submit a ``note'' on the situation in China, a member. The note is to come in response to a cautious resolution adopted by a panel of the commission last August following the brutal repression of pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. The United States has said it will make a new effort to have the commission launch a special inquiry into the human rights situation in Cuba, also a member of the commission.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Declines to Call LaRouche to Witness Stand
DOC.TEXT: Lyndon LaRouche was transported nearly 1,000 miles to testify in the loan-fraud trial of an associate, but the defense Monday decided against calling the imprisoned political extremist to the stand. ``I didn't need his testimony because there was no dispute on the evidence I wanted him for,'' said Pat Monaghan, the attorney representing Donald Phau. Monaghan refused to say what evidence he was referring to. LaRouche will be taken back to a federal prison in Rochester, Minn. Roanoke County Sheriff's Department spokesman James Robertson would not give a cost estimate for flying LaRouche from Minnesota and keeping him in the county jail for nearly a week. But he said the county expects to be reimbursed by either LaRouche or the defendant. Phau is one of 16 members of the LaRouche organization who were charged three years ago with violating the Virginia Securities Act by selling and issuing promissory notes for five LaRouche-affiliated organizations. All of the cases involved telephone solicitations for loans. LaRouche was convicted 13 months ago on federal charges of mail fraud, conspiracy to commit mail fraud and conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Carry N.H. Artist's McAuliffe Poster to Space
DOC.TEXT: Artist Mel Bolden figured his portrait of space shuttle Challenger victim Christa McAuliffe would circulate around the world, but he didn't expect it to go into orbit. He learned Monday that a photograph released by the Soviet news agency Tass shows a copy of his McAuliffe poster on the wall in the Soviet MIR space station. Orbiting Soviet cosmonauts featured the poster and an official NASA photograph of the Challenger crew to commemorate their deaths four years ago Sunday when the shuttle exploded shortly after launch. ``I'm just trying to figure out how they got a copy of the poster,'' Bolden said. ``It's beyond my wildest dream or imagination.'' ``It's an honor,'' he said. ``I'm flabbergasted.'' Cosmonauts Alexander Serebrv and Alexander Viktorenko conducted a lesson for children from space Sunday to commemorate the Challenger anniversary. McAuliffe, a Concord High School social studies teacher, was chosen in 1985 from among 11,000 teachers to be the first ordinary American to travel in space. Her main mission on the flight was to have been to conduct classes from orbit to rekindle interest in space travel. Bolden's poster shows a smiling McAuliffe in her blue NASA flight suit, the shuttle headed for space in the background. It also incorporates a classroom scene painted in her Concord High classroom. On the blackboard is a simple message: ``Any dream can come true if you have the courage to work at it.'' Bolden, who turned 71 on Sunday, the blast anniversary, figures NASA may have given the Soviets a copy of the poster. Bolden said he and McAuliffe worked together to design the poster, which was intended to be distributed to help raise money for science scholarships. ``We were trying to get across the idea of education, particularly science education, and trying to inspire kids into getting into science and math,'' Bolden said. After McAuliffe died, Bolden took his idea to Pepsi-Cola Co., which bought the portrait and donated it to the Smithsonian Institution's Air and Space Museum in Washington. The MIR station was launched Feb. 20, 1986. The current crew is the seventh to visit the station. Serebrv and Viktorenko were launched into space in June for a planned six-month stay in MIR.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ships Enter Soviet-Dominated Black Sea
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Navy warships on Monday sailed through the Bosporus Strait into the Black Sea _ waters dominated by the Soviet fleet, an Istanbul port source said. The vessels were the destroyer Thorn and frigate Capodanno, both attached to the Mediterranean-based 6th Fleet, said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Ocean, a Soviet navy intelligence and support ship, also passed through the Bosporus into the Black Sea together with the U.S. warships, the source said. The U.S. ships will spend four days in the international zones of the Black Sea, the source said. The United States dispatches ships to the area from time to time to reaffirm its commitment to the vital Turkish straits and place a stake in navigational rights in the Black Sea.

DOC.HEAD: British Envoy Urges U.S. Passports For Hong Kong Residents
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Monday he had urged the Bush administration to grant American passports to residents of Hong Kong working for American firms in order to help the island's transition from British to Chinese rule in 1997. The idea is to reassure islanders that they can stay in Hong Kong while having a secure fallback of an American passport should they wish to leave, Hurd told reporters after lunching with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Hurd was meeting President Bush and other leaders on his first trip to Washington since assuming office last October. His talks were focused on upcoming changes within the NATO alliance in light of the changes sweeping away the old order in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Hurd said that if Hong Kong residents holding key positions leave the territory, stability could not be maintained during the complicated transition period. He said he told Baker that ``it would be enormously helpful'' if the United States provided passports to islanders working for American firms. Britain and other countries would also be providing passports to Hong Kong residents under this scheme. The subject will come up again Tuesday when Hurd holds talks in Congress, where legislation on the matter is pending. Hurd said he had appealed to Baker for U.S. understanding of his government's handling of more than 40,000 Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong. The British want to send most of the Vietnamese back, but the United States wants a one-year suspension of the forced repatriation to Vietnam. Hurd said the problem will become more accute with the anticipated arrival of 30,000 to 40,000 more Vietnamese in Hong Kong this spring and summer. He said British efforts were concentrated on explaining to residents of Vietnam the realities of life in overcrowded camps in Hong Kong and other Asian nations. Too many Vietnamese are taken in by smugglers who tell them they are assured of resettlement in the West, Hurd said. Only about 1 percent of those leaving fit Britain's definition of refugees, or people fleeing persecution. The rest are viewed as economic migrants seeking a better life. Hurd said he had told Baker that the British government is under pressure to launch an aid program for the Communist government of Vietnam to improve conditions in the impoverished country. The United States has imposed economic sanctions on Vietnam, defying critics who argue that U.S. economic help could do much to stem the flow of boat people. Hurd said the decision announced earlier in the day by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to shut down dozens of military bases at home and abroad, including pulling out of three Royal Air Force bases in Britain, was compatible with NATO's objectives. ``We're satisfied that the decision is reasonable and compatible'' with the Vienna talks between NATO and the Warsaw Pact on reducing their conventional forces in Europe, as well, he said. Hurd said he and Baker generally agreed that ``although problems are clearly accumulating in the Soviet Union, we don't see any reason to suppose they put a question mark over the leadership'' of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Base Closings, Foreign Aid, Personal Savings Highlight Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs, Acknowledging that, to note 2 per cent cut is after inflation, removes attribution which now redundant in 3rd graf, adds graf on Water Projects
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress on Monday to close military bases while spending more money on the Strategic Defense Initiative, establish a new foreign aid program to encourage democracy in Eastern Europe, and give families with long-term savings a tax break. Here are some of the highlights of the president`s $1.23 trillion spending plan for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. DEFENSE: The budget would raise spending from $296.3 billion this year to $303.3 billion in fiscal 1991 _ a 2.3 percent increase. The Defense Department said that after inflation of 4.3 percent is figured in, the change amounts to a 2 percent reduction. The Pentagon would cut 38,000 men and women from the 2 million now in uniform. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney proposed closing or realigning more than 60 military bases in the United States and 12 installations overseas. Two Army divisions would be disbanded by the end of the year. They are the 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood, Texas, and the 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Wash. The Pentagon would also terminate 20 weapons programs in an attempt to save $2.9 billion. The budget calls, however, for five new B-2 stealth bombers, at a cost of $5.5 billion, and $900 million for the SDI program, often dubbed Star Wars. Both proposals, as well as the base closings, are expected to encounter stiff congressional resistance. ``There'll be a debate about defense, there's no question about that,'' said Speaker of the House Thomas Foley of Washington. Also in the defense budget are $1.5 billion for another Trident submarine and $202 million in continued financing of two land-based missile systems -the rail-based, multiple-warhead MX and the truck-based, single-warhead Midgetman. Another $1.7 billion would be spent for 52 submarine-based Trident II missiles. FOREIGN AID: Provides $300 million for democracies in Eastern Europe, and calls for a nearly 80 percent increase to combat drugs, including $175 million to help drug-producing Andean countries attack the narcotics problem. Proposes to begin the repayment, over a five-year period, of $620 million in back dues owed to the United Nations, on top of $794 million in current payments. Another $279 million would be earmarked for overdue bills from multilateral development banks. The two largest recipients of U.S. military and economic aid would continue at their current levels: $3 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt. TAXES: Recommends $15.7 billion worth of tax increases but no general boost in income taxes. There would be a $5.6 billion increase in user and service fees. Also included is a capital-gains tax cut and $1.8 billion in other tax reductions including a credit of up to $1,000 a year for each child under age 4 in poor families. Social Security tax receipts would be used only to pay off government debt, beginning in 1993. The interest paid on family savings accounts held for seven years would be exempt from income tax up to a limit of $5,000 per joint tax return or $2,500 per individual return. After the seven years withdrawals would be tax free. Before that, there would be a 10 percent excise. FARM: The budget provides $23.4 billion for nutrition, the largest general program in the Agriculture Department budget, including an increase of $600 million for food stamps to cover higher food costs and increased monthly allocations to families. The food stamp budget would be $15.4 billion. There would be less than $5.2 billion for child nutrition, however, down $156 million from 1990. Despite the decrease, children from the poorest families would continue to get meals free and those in middle-level poverty would pay 20 cents a meal instead of 40 cents as at present. Children from affluent families, now entitled to have meals subsidized by the government, would have to pay full price, adding about 29 cents per meal to their outlay. The budget also provides more money for farm price support programs. Nevertheless, guaranteed prices for farmers, as well as the direct payments they receive for major crops, would probably be reduced if Congress goes along with $1.5 billion in commodity program cuts being proposed separately. The budget could increase farm spending by about 4.1 per cent, pushing it from the current $48.2 billion to about $50.2 billion. On the other hand the increase could be held to 1 percent if the lawmakers approve the unspecified commodity cuts. SPACE: Increases the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's spending from $12 billion to $14.1 billion, or 24 percent, the largest increase for any major agency of the government. Calls for a record 10 space shuttle flights next fiscal year at a cost of more than $8 billion. The spending blueprint proposes budget authority of $2.6 billion for development of a manned space station and $1.2 billion for exploration activities to support a mission to the moon and, later, to Mars. TRANSPORTATION: Shifts much of the cost of air traffic control from direct federal spending to an aviation trust fund financed by user fees. Currently $3 billion comes from direct spending and $3.4 billion from the trust fund. Bush would cut the direct federal share to $1.2 billion and raise the trust fund portion to $6 billion by increasing the user fees. He said this would pay for 495 more air traffic controllers and 300 air safety specialists. HEAD START: Adds $500 million of spending authority for the pre-school education program, for a total of $1.9 billion. The administration said the 36 percent increase should allow the program to enroll 180,000 more 4-year-olds from low-income families. About 450,000 children now participate. HOUSING: Shifts nearly $60 million from low-income rental programs to a certificate program designed to allow tenants of federally subsidized housing to buy their units. The $23 billion Housing and Urban Development budget also provides more money for urban enterprise zones designed to encourage self-help in the inner cities. DRUGS: Boosts over-all federal spending authority for the drug war by $1.1 billion to $10.6 billion. ENVIRONMENT: Calls for $4.2 billion to clean up hazardous materials at Department of Energy nuclear plants and other facilities run by NASA and the departments of Defense, Interior, Agriculture and Transportation. This would be an increase $642 million over the current fiscal year. Requests $175 million for the first year of a reforestation program aimed at planting 1 billion trees a year on private land. ARTS: Increases spending for arts and humanities programs, such as the national endowments and the National Gallery of Art and Smithsonian Institution, from $694 million to $757 million. The money includes $2 million for an exhibit at the national gallery celebrating the 500th anniversary of Columbus' voyage to America. WATER PROJECTS: No money is provided for new Army Corps of Engineers projects. The $3.2 billion budget for the agency is about the same as that for the current year. The corps said the budget reflects ``the new emphasis placed by the administration on maintaining and restoring the environment.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Calls for States to be Innovative in Providing Public Services
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's budget message Monday suggested state and local governments build more toll roads to meet highway needs and charge air passenger fees to finance new airport construction. A chapter of the fiscal 1991 budget document the administration sent to Congress highlights efforts by states to come up with ideas to provide public services in the face of a shrinking federal ability to provide money. It said local governments should encourage car pools, including use of restricted lanes, and turn to privately run city bus systems as an alternative to higher-cost public transit systems. It recommends broader use of some of those state and local innovations, and describes others as experiments worth watching in health care, education, the environment, welfare and child care. ``It is a picture of creative experimentation _ not social engineering, but the natural flowering of variety inherent in a healthy federal system,'' the budget report says of state and local efforts. ``It is a picture that merits highlighting _ and federal government support.'' The budget said states and local airport authorities are looking for alternatives to federal funding for expansion or construction, and that a ``passenger facility charge'' is one prominent alternative. Congress prohibited such fees in 1973, but the administration will recommend Congress pass legislation abolishing the ban, the budget said. A Transportation Department estimate said that by imposing a fee of $3 per passenger, nearly 60 major airports would collect more than twice what they receive in federal airport formula grants. Toll roads, while not a new idea, have enjoyed a resurgence in popularity as federal highway money becomes more scarce. Federal law has prohibited use of federal money for construction of new toll roads, but the government allowed several experimental projects in 1987. The administration pointed to northern Virginia, where the state last year gave permission for investors to build a 14-mile toll road, the longest private toll road in the country. ``For toll road users, transportation costs will be higher, but travel should be safer and quicker,'' the budget said. ``The administration will look favorably upon innovative means of financing highways, including toll roads.'' Rae Bond, spokeswoman for the National Governors' Association, said that in highlighting state actions the administration did not address the governors' call for the federal government to release some of the more than $16 billion accumulated in the highway trust fund. The governors last summer asked the administration to release the money, which is accumulating through federal excise taxes and, the association contends, could be used to pay for transportation needs in the states. ``They appreciate the flexibility to do toll roads if that's appropriate, and private-sector construction if that's appropriate, but they have a concern about trying to force states to use toll roads or private-sector construction,'' Bond said. ``The trust fund should be used first.'' The budget said some cities have scaled back plans for rail rapid transit because of high construction costs and are substituting improved bus service. Private bus service has been successful, sometimes for a portion of the total transit network, the budget said, adding that federal studies show private companies can operate 20 percent to 50 percent less expensively than public agencies, largely because of lower labor costs. It said carpools and use of buses should be encouraged as alternatives to mass transit, and cited the approach in the Virginia suburbs of Washington, where designated lanes of a primary commuter artery _ and an entire highway, during rush hours _ are reserved for buses or carpools. The budget cited a number of state programs aimed at encouraging poor youths to continue with their education, including young welfare mothers and fathers. Among those it highlighted without endorsing was Wisconsin's controversial ``Learnfare'' program, which cuts welfare benefits if the family's children drop out of school. It cited an Oregan plan, which will require a federal waiver of Medicaid rules, to expand health coverage to cover all whose incomes are below the poverty line. While including more people, Oregon would limit cost by assuring only a ``basic'' package of medical services, with additional medical services provided only if money is available. The administration said the plan ``clearly breaks new ground in seeking to deal with a major problem,'' and it is studying the idea.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Budget Recognizes ``Remarkable Changes'' Abroad
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday sent Congress a $1.23 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 that keeps new spending below inflation and recognizes ``remarkable changes'' in the world by scaling back defense and rewarding emerging democracies. Bush called the spending plan an ``investment in the future.'' But Democratic leaders in Congress pounced on it as a ``standpat budget'' and challenged its claim to halve the federal deficit, to $63.1 billion. Fights loomed with the Democratic-controlled Congress on a range of fronts: Bush's desire to cut Medicare and capital gains taxes, to close military bases he considers outmoded and, on the other hand, to preserve some expensive weapons. Bush would increase spending on space, education, the environment and the war on drugs. Losers, this year, are Medicare, college student loans, farm subsidies, energy conservation grants and mass transit. The president's budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 calls for $36.5 billion in spending cuts and other deficit-reduction measures. It projects a 7 percent increase in revenues, to $1.17 trillion, without a general tax increase and just a 3 percent boost in overall spending - more than a percentage point below the current rate of inflation. Bush proposed defense spending of $292.1 billion, a cut of 2 percent measured against inflation; while boosting foreign aid to Eastern Europe, the Philippines and Latin America. On the domestic front, his budget would leave in place the Social Security tax increase that took effect earlier this month. But it honors Bush's 1988 campaign pledge to propose no general tax increase. Still, the budget recommends $15.6 billion in lesser tax increases and a $5.6 billion increase in user and service fees _ most of them recycled from Reagan budgets and previously defeated in Congress. The budget calls for ``family savings'' accounts under which families could bank up to $5,000 a year and pay no tax on interest on deposits held for seven or more years. ``With an eye toward future growth, and expansion of the human frontier, the budget's chief emphasis is on investment in the future,'' Bush said in a brief message to Congress accompanying the 1,569-page document. But Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., called it a document of ``low aspirations. ... It predicts huge fiscal problems ahead and then goes on to propose no change in course.'' And House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said, ``I think it's a standpat budget'' but he said lawmakers would ``take it very seriously'' rather than pronouncing it ``dead on arrival'' as Democrats had done with several Reagan budgets. Bush's budget direction, Richard G. Darman, opened the annual budget battle by proposing a truce. ``We fully expect to negotiate with Congress over priorities,'' he told a briefing. Bush's budget asserted it was meeting the $64 billion deficit target for fiscal 1991, under the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law, ``with specific and defensible measures _ and without gimmicks.'' However, critics claimed the administration's prescription for getting the budget deficit down to $63.1 billion _ from a projected $123.8 billion this year _ does rely on accounting gimmicks. ``They continue to jimmy the figures,'' said Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C. ``It's another fraud.'' For one thing, Bush's budget uses an optimistic set of economic projections that assume both declining interest rates and falling inflation. The budget also calls for overall growth this year of 2.4 percent this year _ compared to the 1.7 percent forecast by private forecasters and the Congressional Budget Office. The government's most recent figures showed economic growth slowed to an annual rate of 0.5 percent during the last three months of 1989. ``Obviously, the slowdown in the fourth quarter makes everybody nervous,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady conceded. Bush recycled many proposals which did not reach enactment in 1989 _ a tightening of the Clean Air Act, a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, a $3,000 tax credit for adoptions, tax breaks for child care and more money for fighting crime and drugs. The most dramatic element of the budget was the scaleback in defense. Propelled by relaxed East-West tensions, the Pentagon budget calls for a reduction of 38,000 troops and closing dozens of military bases. It was the most restrained defense budget submitted by the White House in more than a decade. ``Remarkable changes have occurred during the past year. The Berlin Wall has been opened and democratic forces are on the move in Eastern Europe,'' Bush said. ``As a result, savings in the defense budget are now possible.'' Bush said defense and international policy ``must take advantage of the opportunities provided'' by these changes. However, claiming Soviet military capability ``will remain formidable, even after announced reductions,'' Bush said he was proposing a military budget that would allow the nation ``to hedge against an uncertain future.'' His plan calls for five costly new B-2 stealth bombers, another $1 billion Trident submarine and funds for two controversial intercontinental nuclear missile systems. He also called for an additional $900 million for the Strategic Defense Initiative, known as Star Wars. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said defense spending will be a crucial battleground and predicted Congress would make ``larger reducitons'' that Bush proposed. The president's budget calls for a $3 billion increase in outlays for foreign aid, to $14.2 billion. It calls for $300 million in special assistance ``for those countries in Eastern Europe that are moving toward democracy'' and another $200 million for the Philippine government of Corazon Aquino. It also requests $270 million in outlays for the Andean countries of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to help stem the international flow of drugs. The administration renewed its call for a lower capital gains tax, proposing that 30 percent of assets held for more than three years be exempt from the tax. The measure was similar to a proposal that passed the House but was blocked by filibuster in the Senate last year that would lower the effective rate of the tax _ on real estate, stocks and other assets _ to 19.6 percent. Currently, capital gains are taxed at the same rate as other income _ 15 percent, 28 percent or 33 percent. The administration did not embrace a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to provide a $62 billion cut in Social Security taxes this year and next. However, it proposed that after 1993 _ when the budget is supposed to be balanced under the Gramm-Rudman law _ any surpluses in the Social Security trust fund be used to pay off the national debt. As in past budgets, the Social Security surplus masked the size of the deficit. The 1991 deficit would be $70 billion higher without this surplus. The various domestic cuts totalled $13.9 billion, with $5.5 billion coming from trims in doctor and hospitals payments in the Medicare health care program. Other major program cuts included $1.8 billion in farm price supports and crop insurance and savings of $2.9 billion by limiting pension increases to federal civilian retirees and by restraining cost of living increases to civilian and military government workers. Aid to urban mass transit systems would be cut sharply and low-income energy assistance would be trimmed by $340 million, to less than $1.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: 35-Year-Old Leader Chosen For New Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kwasniewski is pronounced Kfahsh-NYEV-skee.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Communists on Monday elected a 35-year-old sports official to lead a new party in its quest for popularity in the East bloc's first democracy. But one day after its founding, the new Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland was accused of ``political arrogance'' by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa for taking over the holdings amassed by the Communists during their rule. It also contended with a breakaway group of reformers, whose were organizing a rival Social-Democratic Union that would have nothing to do with the old party's leadership or assets. Parliamentarians for the Communist Party, which was officially disbanded early Monday, reflected the confusion among the remnants of their party. Twenty Communist deputies lined up behind the Social Democracy Party, 25 joined the Social-Democratic Union, and the remaining 125 members _ including caucus leader Marian Orzechowski _ withheld support from either side, state TV reported. In lopsided votes, Aleksander Kwasniewski became the Social Democracy Party's chairman and Leszek Miller, a 43-year-old former Communist Party secretary, its general secretary. Kwasniewski, who has close ties to the former Communist leadership, will lead the new party's Supreme Council, while Miller will be the administrator overseeing party bureaucracy. Kwasniewski received 1,049 votes for chairman and Miller 926 votes for general secretary out of about 1,200 votes cast. The two men immediately were embraced and congratulated by Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski, the first secretary of the dissolved Communist Party. ``We feel very moved by this election, and also terrified, because we are aware of the immense tasks,'' Kwasniewski told the delegates. Kwasniewski, who leads the state sports and youth committee, said he wanted a party capable of rallying leftist opinions and winning popular backing after the demise of the Communist Party. TV reported that red flags were removed from party buildings nationwide. ``The most important thing is votes, not members. The better party is one with 100,000 members and (capable of getting) 1 million votes, than a party with 1 million members and only 100,000 votes,'' he said. He said the latter case described the old Communist Party, which was in disarray after ceding power to a Solidarity-led government in August. His party, in a resolution adopted Monday, called for ``further strengthening of ties'' with the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. In Gdansk, Walesa criticized the party for taking over the Communist holdings, which he said belong to the ``whole society.'' Taking the property would be ``an act of political arrogance,'' Walesa said. ``In the conditions of revised political pluralism, none of the parties can start from a privileged position.'' There has been a public clamor for the state to confiscate the property acquired by the Communists, and Walesa said he hoped a special government commission reviewing the issue would ``not disappoint social expectations.'' The breakaway Social-Democratic Union formed under reformer Tadeusz Fiszbach, a onetime Gdansk party chief who is close to Walesa, rejected any remnants of the old party. Fiszbach proclaimed the separate party on Sunday and continued to sign up followers Monday _ meeting in the same sprawling building where the Social Democracy Party was in congress. ``In our opinion, what the (Social Democracy Party) congress was incapable of doing was saying `We are sorry' to the society for all the abuses'' of the Communist years, said Marek Krol, a newspaper editor who joined Fiszbach's party. ``This is one of the basic differences.'' Fiszbach said his party intends to participate in local elections in April. The old Communist Party claimed to have 1.9 million members, only a portion of which were expected to join either the Social Democracy Party or the Social-Democratic Union.

DOC.HEAD: Zhivkov Moved From House Arrest to Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 15-18, ``Zhelev appeared ...'' with 6 grafs to ADD predictions on outcome of Communist Party congress. Restores first reference to Zhelev.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: SOFIA, Bulgaria _ Todor Zhivkov, whose word was law in Bulgaria for 35 years, has been moved from house arrest to a prison for people accused of murder and other major crimes, the chief prosecutor's office said Monday. A statement carried by the official news agency BTA said Zhivkov, ousted as Communist Party chief Nov. 10, was being questioned. The 78-year-old former leader already has been charged with misappropriating state property, inciting ethnic hostility and abuse of power. Misuse of state property, the most serious charge, carries a maximum penalty of 30 years. The ethnic hostility count arose from discriminatory policies against the ethnic Turkish minority in Bulgaria. Zhivkov is one of two former Eastern European leaders charged with crimes. In East Berlin, the chief East German prosecutor said Erich Honecker was arrested and imprisoned after leaving a hospital Monday and will be tried for treason in March. Honecker, 77, had been recovering from surgery to remove a malignant kidney tumor. Authorities detained Zhivkov on Jan. 19 and placed him in investigative custody. News reports said he was kept in a villa adapted for the purpose. Monday's statement from the prosecutor did not say when Zhivkov was moved to the Remand Prison of the Criminal Investigation Department, which houses people suspected of, or charged with, serious crimes. Several relatives and close associates of Zhivkov also have been accused of crimes. The prosecutor's statement announced indictments of his son-in-law, Ivan Slavkov, and an investigation of Milko Balev, a former Zhivkov aide. Slavkov, president of the Bulgarian Olympic Committee and a member of the International Olympic Committee, was charged with illegal posession of ``a large quantity of firearms ... receiving considerable remunerations on questionable legal grounds, and with malfeasance in office,'' it said. Balev, a former Politburo member, faces charges of ``malfeasance in office and misappropriation of public property,'' the statement said. It did not say whether the two were in custody. Negotiations began Monday between the Communist Party and opposition. The foreign debt of about $11 billion and growing economic problems were the main items of discussion by party delegates and the Union of Democratic Forces, a loose alliance of 12 independent groups and parties. Union spokesman Georgi Spassov said Sunday the opposition would not join any coalition government before elections, scheduled for May, because it does not want to be a scapegoat for past economic failures or have reforms blocked by the Communist-controlled parliament. But Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the opposition delegation, appeared to modify this view Monday when he said, ``We are no demagogues; we can change our opinion.'' However, leaders of some groups within the alliance virtually ruled out any cooperation with the Communists. ``One must not strike compromises with compromised personalities,'' said Rumen Vodenicharov, who leads the Independent Committee for Human Rights. The Communist Party convenes a congress Tuesday at which reformers are expected to try to break with policies associated with Zhivkov's tenure. Old guard Communists likely will try to slow reform moves, fearing the collapse of the party and the loss of their privileges. Spassov predicted conservatives would force out reformers if they tried to go too far. Other opposition leaders were less pessimistic. ``The old guard will mount a strong challenge, but I do not think it will be strong enough to topple the reformers,'' said Deyan Kyuranov, a senior member of the Ecoglasnost enviromentalist organization.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Workers Held for 20 Days in Chad Back in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Three Lockheed engineers detained in the North African country of Chad for 20 days have returned home to Georgia, the company said. Lockheed officials said the three employees arrived by private plane Saturday and were met by relatives. ``As far as Lockheed is concerned, the book is closed and we will have no further comment on the situation,'' spokesman Dick Martin said in a statement Monday from Lockheed's Marietta plant. The three engineers _ Irving Thrash, Marvin Gambill and Ernest Ruse _ were held at police barracks in N'Djamena from Jan. 5-15 for destroying a technical manual for two C-130 aircraft the Chad government purchased from Lockheed. The men said they were not licensed to export the manual. Lockheed arranged with the State Department for an export license and brought a new copy of the manual to give to Chad authorities. The men were confined at a hotel until they left the country Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Soviet Prisoners Call for Emergency Exodus of Soviet Jews
With AM-Arabs-Jews
DOC.TEXT: Leading Soviet immigration activists on Monday called for emergency evacuation of Soviet Jews, who they said are endangered by anti-Semitism and possible pogroms. ``Our Soviet Jewish brethren are in danger,'' the activists said in a statement. ``The government, the army and the police are unable to restore order. The realities of civil war threaten all citizens of the Soviet Union, especially the Jews. ``Unbounded anti-Semitic propaganda, the strenghtening of anti-Semitic groups, murders and the threat of pogrom have become the norm of life for Soviet Jewry,'' they said. The group, which included former Soviet ``refuseniks'' Ida Nudel, Yosef Begun, Vladimir Slepak and Yosef Mendelevitch, called on the Soviet Union to fulfill its promise to allow direct flights from Moscow to Israel. The Soviets, facing strong protests from the Arab world over the influx to Israel, have refused to approve the direct flights agreement between Aeroflot and Israel's El Al airlines. On Monday, the Kremlin summoned Israel's ambassador to Moscow and condemned the settlement of some of the Soviet emigres in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Alexander Zinchuk, the Soviet ambassador to Jordan, was quoted in an interview with the English-language Jordan Times as saying that the Kremlin was talking to the PLO about the issue, but there was little Moscow could do to stop the flow. ``We are in a difficult position over this (immigration) issue,'' he said, blaming the United States for putting quotas on the number of Soviet refugees that it would accept. Last year, 12,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel, and the government expects up to 100,000 to arrive in the next year. Begun, who had waged a 17-year battle for emigration before coming to Israel in 1988, called for Western pressure on Moscow to implement the agreement. In addition, the group called for an increase in the existing flights through Romania and Hungary and the opening of all other means of transportation such as ships, buses and railroads. As one example of the dangers faced by the Jews, the activists cited a Soviet TV report broadcast on Saturday that said members of the Russian nationalist group Pamyat, at a recent rally in Moscow, openly called for a Jewish pogrom May 5. ``What else do we need?'' asked Vladimir Lifshitz, a member of the activist group. The activists blamed Israel's government for failing to understand the urgency and for the delays in issuing emigration invitations, which are needed to start emigration procedures. They said some Soviet Jews had to wait for five to eight months for an invitation from Israel. ``I accuse my government of not being willing to understand the seriousness of today's situation in Russia,'' Ms. Nudel said. ``If it will permit a new tragedy to happen, all the blame will be fully upon us.''

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Officials Find Eagle Dead in Oil Pit
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state wildlife officers investigating a report of dead birds in an oil pit found the remains of a bald eagle, a great blue heron and a duck, an agent said Monday. Since Oct. 1, the federal government has had the authority to prosecute the owners of uncovered oil tanks and oil pits in the deaths of migratory birds. Kash Schriefer, an agent with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Services, said the eagle was found last week in the pit in a rural area east of Duncan in southwestern Oklahoma. The bird will be tested to determine if the oiling was the cause of death, Schriefer said. He said the department plans to prosecute the owner of the pit if charges are warranted. The birds are protected by the migratory bird act, and the eagle is also protected by the eagle protection law and as an endangered species.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil Fined Maximum $4,500, Gets Probation, for Crude Oil Spills
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Oil Corp. was fined $4,500 on Monday and placed on two years' probation for two pipeline ruptures that poured more than 130,000 gallons of crude oil into the Los Angeles River and city sewers. The fine imposed by Municipal Court Commissioner Joseph Spada was the maximum permitted for two misdemeanor charges, to which Mobil pleaded no contest in December. A restitution hearing was scheduled March 6. The first pipeline break occurred Sept. 10, 1988, in the suburban Encino area and sent 90,000 gallons of crude oil onto city streets. The oil eventually flowed into sewers and the Los Angeles River. The second break occurred 17 days later as the pipeline was being repaired. The line carries 2.6 million gallons of oil daily from Kern County oil fields to Mobil's Torrance refinery. Temperature changes in the oil caused the pipeline to corrode and rupture the first time, said Deputy City Attorney Vincent B. Sato, adding there was no indication of negligence. Mobil attorney Ernest J. Getto said at the time of the no contest pleas that the company had revised its monitoring procedures and had begun replacing older sections of the pipeline. City Attorney James Hahn wants Mobil to pay for the cleanup. Only two restitution claims were filed by Monday _ a Fire Department bill for more than $200,000 and a $17,000 state Department of Fish and Game bill. The police, city Department of Animal Control and county Flood Control District have yet to complete claims, said Mike Qualls, a spokesman for the City Attorney's Office.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Is Grumpy; Ate Too Much Barbecue
DOC.TEXT: ``I'm in a grumpy mood today,'' President Bush groused Monday, complaining he had eaten too much Texas barbecue at a Superbowl party. ``No answers today. I'm trying to think of answers and (I'm getting) too many questions,'' he said as reporters asked him about the $1.23 trillion budget plan he unveiled for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Bush talked about his bad mood during a picture-taking ceremony in the Oval Office with visiting British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Brushing off the press as he normally does at photo opportunities, Bush said, ``I ate too much yesterday and I just don't feel like answering any questions. And besides that, it violates the groundrules to answer any questions.'' He allowed as how he sometimes does answer, but ``only when we want to answer questions.'' Bush and his wife Barbara had about a dozen people in Sunday to watch the Superbowl, and served barbecue from Ft. Worth. While saying he had overindulged, Bush quickly added, ``I don't want to get any rumors started about my physical condition. ``I'm just grumpy. I don't want to talk about it. ``It was good,'' he concluded, talking about the food.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Budget Seeks $14 Billion _ at Least _ in Spending Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The 1991 budget President Bush released Monday relies on spending cuts in defense and domestic programs for at least $14.2 billion in deficit reduction, but the precise total depends on who is doing the calculations. By all accounts, however, the president's $1.23 trillion budget was relying on spending cuts for less than half the $36.5 billion in savings it sought in its quest to slice the federal deficit to $63.1 billion. The president's own budget documents claim to reduce spending next year on programs ranging from Medicare to military pay by a total of $16.9 billion below the rate at which they would otherwise grow. But an analysis by Senate Budget Committee Republicans put the total at $14.2 billion. The Democratic staff of the House Budget Committee decided that all told, Bush has proposed $16.1 billion in spending reductions. At any rate, those totals are net spending cuts. In fact, Bush proposed many billions more in reductions _ the number was not available Monday _ that are offset by spending increases he wants in other areas. It's all part of the confusion that results every year the day the president's spending plan is unveiled as budget technicians pore through the thick document, often not finding the figures they hoped to locate. Everyone agreed that the biggest chunk of the savings _ $5.5 billion _ would come from the Medicare program that helps the poor and handicapped pay their medical bills. Of the total, $3.35 billion of the cuts would come from reimbursements made to hospitals, while payments to doctors and for other outpatient services would be reduced by $2.15 billion. Such proposals have had a hard time making it through Congress in the past. Another $3.6 billion in savings would be earned by reducing various health and retirement benefits for federal employees. That would include a freeze on annual cost-of-living increases for government civilian and military retirees and a separate proposal to have the Postal Service _ which is off-budget _ pay health benefits for retirees. Bush's call for a $303.3 billion defense budget _ including some nuclear weapons work by the Department of Energy _ shrinks the military budget by 2 percent below the rate of inflation. As the budget is calculated, this counts for $3.2 billion in savings. Subsidies to farmers paid by the Commodity Credit Corp. would be reduced by $1.5 billion. Other spending cuts the budget lists include nearly $500 million by reducing payments for school lunch programs and for meals provided by day-care centers; $100 million by limiting the government's costs of administering its foster care efforts; and $157 million by limiting the ability of distant relatives to inherit a deceased veteran's benefits. The balance of Bush's proposed savings come from minor tax increases, new fees for federal services and sales of federal assets.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Budget Increase Would Mean More Tax Audits
AM-Budget Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP)_ The Internal Revenue Service's $6.1 billion budget request for next year would enable the tax-collecting agency to start auditing more income tax returns. The IRS expects to audit only 97 of every 10,000 tax returns for 1989, an all-time low. Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. told reporters that with improvements expected under the fiscal 1991 spending plan that President Bush sent Congress on Monday, that number should rise to 102 per 10,000 for 1990 returns and 103 per 10,000 for 1991 returns. Those figures do not include IRS computer checks of the returns of the 40 million taxpayers who file returns based principally on income from wages, interest and dividends, Goldberg said. IRS computers automatically check those returns to make sure they include all income reported by employers, banks and brokers. While those computer checks are not audits, Goldberg said, they are very thorough. ``The fact remains that there has been a continuing decline in audit coverage for a number of years, but now we are seeing a reversal of the trend,'' he said. The proposed IRS budget increase to $6.1 billion next year represents an 11.6 percent increase in its current spending of $5.5 billion. Goldberg also said the IRS expects to spend as much as $6 billion to replace its obsolete computer system over the next decade. He said this will give agency employees faster access to taxpayer data, so that taxpayers can get immediate telephone answers to questions about their accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Let Customers Block Caller I.D. Service
DOC.TEXT: A Senate bill was introduced Monday that would require telephone companies to allow customers to block Caller I.D., a new service that displays a caller's phone number before the receiver is picked up. Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., said he was in favor of the new technology, but that customers also should have the option of not giving out their phone numbers. ``A privacy balance must be struck,'' Kohl said in introducing the Telephone Privacy Act of 1990. ``Who decides whether the caller will reveal his or her number?'' Kohl said. ``I think the decision must rest with the caller.'' Caller I.D., which has been available in New Jersey for more than a year and is just beginning to be offered in Tennessee, West Virginia, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Maryland, uses a small terminal that displays the numbers of incoming calls. The device costs $50 or more to purchase, and the Caller I.D. service costs about $7 a month. Privacy rights advocates claim it is an Orwellian intrusion on individual privacy unless a blocking option is offered. Phone companies such as Bell Atlantic, which is phasing in Caller I.D. in the mid-Atlantic states but not offering blocking, say a blocking provision would defeat the purpose of the service. California has passed legislation requiring blocking be offered with Caller I.D., and Pennsylvania allows police and domestic violence agencies to block it. Some phone companies have said privacy concerns have delayed their plans to introduce the service. Kohl sits on the Senate Judiciary Committee, which, according to congressional sources, will consider Caller I.D. as part of hearings on a number of privacy issues this year. Kohl said he planned to sign up for the service whenever it is offered in his home district of Milwaukee or in Washington. ``But there is a down side,'' he said. ``Caller I.D. will diminish our privacy as callers.'' ``People with unlisted phone numbers are forced to divulge their numbers every time they contact someone who has Caller I.D.,'' he said, noting that a woman in a battered women's shelter may not want to reveal her number while calling her family. Under Kohl's bill, calls to 911 emergency lines would not be blocked. His bill does not specify, however, whether blocking should be offered on a per-call or a subscription basis, or whether it should be free. David Barasch, consumer advocate of Pennsylvania, said he supported Kohl's bill and endorsed it on behalf of the National Association of State Utility Consumer Advocates, Kohl's office said. President Bush's special adviser for consumer affairs, Bonnie Guiton, also backed the idea of blocking, she said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Over Peace Dividend Anything But Peaceful
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The battle between Congress and the Bush administration over how to divvy up the ``peace dividend'' could make the Cold War look like a Sunday school picnic. The sniping began in earnest Monday with delivery of President Bush's 1991 budget request to Congress and will likely continue for several years as U.S. policy makers try to adjust to a new world symbolized by the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. The central questions revolve around the magnitude of defense savings made possible from lessened East-West tensions _ and which programs will receive additional funds as a result. At present, there is nothing approaching a consensus on the answers to either of those questions. The apectations about the peace dividend in the first place. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney announced last November that he was searching for Pentagon cuts totaling $180 billion over the next six years. However, Cheney was calculating his savings against an administration plan projecting a buildup in defense forces that Congress had already rejected. Thus, the actual savings will be far less. No one disputes that there will savings, but the scale of the windfall will be much more modest, especially in the next few years. In 1991, for example, the administration's new budget puts the ``peace dividend'' at $3.2 billion. That figure is arrived at by comparing what the administration is seeking in total military outlays, $303.3 billion, compared to the $306.4 billion that would be required to let the Pentagon keep pace with inflation. The $3.2 billion figure left Democrats definitely unimpressed, with many accusing Darman of playing his own political game by proposing steep cuts in military personnel, coupled with a whole new round of base closings, while protecting the administration's pet multibillion-dollar weapons programs. Democratic leaders left no doubt that they would be looking for deeper cuts in some of the weapons programs favored by Bush. ``There will be a debate about defense, no question about that,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. But after all the arguing over how much money can be wrung out of the Pentagon, a new battle will commence over where the extra funds should be spent. A whole array of advocates for domestic programs have begun lining up, seeking extra money for everything from cleaning up the environment to taking care of the disadvantaged and rebuilding America's crumbling road and bridge system. Social advocates sense a golden opportunity after having to endure a long dry spell of austere budgets in the Reagan era of large Pentagon buildups. Takes together, the proposals for increased domestic spending exceed $200 billion a year, far dwarfing any windfall from defense. But there is another worry. With everyone looking for the newfound pot of gold, what will that do to the discipline needed to reach a consensus for cutting the federal budget deficit. ``We have to keep reminding people that even if we get new money (from a peace dividend), we still have a budget deficit, which means we still have to find places to cut spending,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M. and senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Martin Crutsinger has covered econmomics in Washington for The AP since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Visit North Carolina, Tennessee Colleges
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to Raleigh, N.C., and Knoxville, Tenn., on Friday to visit research laboratories at two major state universities, the White House announced Monday. Bush will visit North Carolina State University to tour electrical engineering laboratories and hold a roundtable discussion with research scientists and graduate students. He then will fly on to Knoxville to visit the campus of the University of Tennessee for a demonstration and group discussion on microbiological ways to clean up environmental damage. Bush will deliver an address afterwards to the University of Tennessee community. The White House press office said further details of the trip will be released later in the week.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Boy Killed for Ransom from Drug-Dealing Brother
DOC.TEXT: A kidnapped 12-year-old boy whose finger was cut off to persuade his drug-dealing brother to pay ransom was found dead in a pile of plastic bags just days after the brother was killed, police said Monday. A man collecting cans on a bike path Sunday discovered the body of William Porter, who was abducted Dec. 5 as he walked to school. The boy's 25-year-old brother, Richard Thomas Porter, had refused to cooperate with the police investigation of the kidnapping. Detectives speculated he may have been negotiating his brother's release before he turned up fatally shot Jan. 4, not far from where William was found in the New York borough of the Bronx. A police spokesman, Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, said William's body was identified Monday by family members. An autopsy report on the cause of death was not complete, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner, said Monday. Detectives believe the boy was kidnapped for up to $500,000 in ransom from Richard Porter, reputed by police to be a mid-level drug distributor who controlled several street dealers in Harlem. A police source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said William's right index finger was severed and left Dec. 6 with a short taped message from him in the bathroom of a Manhattan restaurant. ``They cutted my finger off,'' the sixth-grader cried on the tape, the Daily News said in Jan. 5 editions. ``Please help. ... I love you mommy.'' Richard Porter was found shot in the head and chest. His wallet, with more than $2,000 in it, was found on his body. At the time his slaying, police refused to comment on the kidnapping because the 12-year-old had not been found. The kidnappers demanded ransom money in a series of telephone calls, notes and the taped message from William, all on Dec. 5 and 6. The kidnappers had told Richard Porter in a telephone call to go to the restaurant bathroom, but he sent another family member instead. The last contact with the kidnappers came Dec. 10, when a woman handed a note to a child in Manhattan and told him to deliver it to William's aunt, who lived in the area. The note said the boy was in pain and needed medical attention.

DOC.HEAD: Sexual Mutilation Trial Begins 8 Months After Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old boy identified photographs of a man and the man's bicycle as those of the person who raped and sexually mutilated him and left him for dead, a prosecutor said Monday in his opening statement. ``His eyes got very wide ... he was sure,'' Pierce County deputy prosecutor James Roche said of the boy's identification of Earl Kenneth Shriner. ``He was sure that was the man who had attacked him.'' Shriner, 40, who has a history of sexual attacks, is charged with first-degree attempted murder, first-degree assault and two counts of first-degree rape. The savageness of this case, in which the boy's penis was cut off, has sparked major proposals in the current Legislature for dealing with predatory sex offenders. Proposals range from civil commitment to castration. Immediately after the attack, the boy was incoherent and afraid he'd done something bad, Roche told the jury. But the child, who has turned 8 since the May 20 attack, recovered and identified his attacker. He is scheduled to testify. The jury was selected last week in Bellingham, 120 miles north of Tacoma, because of extensive pre-trial news coverage. Jurors are being sequestered in Tacoma during the trial. Roche said testimony from the boy, as well as microscopic analysis of hair and blood recovered from Shriner's clothing and other personal effects, would tie Shriner to the crime. But Dino Sepe, one of Shriner's defense lawyers, said Shriner ``is the wrong man, and the evidence is going to show that man is the wrong man.'' Immediately after the attack the boy ``pretty much rambled incoherently ... at one point he said, `I've been bad,''' the prosecutor said. But by the next day, the boy was able to identify Shriner from a photo montage that included the pictures of five other men, Roche said. The boy also identified a picture of the bicycle Shriner allegedly used to lure him into woods near the child's home. Blood taken from Shriner's jacket matched the boy's blood type, and 15 hairs found on a yellow braided cord recovered from the pocket of Shriner's jacket also match, Roche said. Seven of those 15 hairs showed root damage ``as if they had been pulled out of the head,'' said the prosecutor. Sepe cautioned jurors that they had to find ``evidence for every element of every crime beyond a reasonable doubt'' to convict Shriner. Shriner willingly let police in his house when they arrived at his door on the morning of May 21, Sepe said. ``He told them he had nothing to hide. He knew he had nothing to hide. He fully cooperated with the officers,'' Sepe said. ``He told them he had no contact with any children that night.'' Sepe said the blood and hair samples were not conclusive. ``There's millions of people (with) that similar type of blood,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Contains Promises, Promises, Promises and Threats, Too
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Moves pvs 18th graf bgng: Those steps, to last graf, fixing sequence.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's budget promises to save your family $114,000 in taxes over the next 25 years if you can set aside $5,000 a year. It makes enticing promises, too, if you love trees, have a houseful of tots or are fascinated by magnetic levitation. But in budgetry, an exercise somewhat removed from reality, the budget that giveth also taketh away. The taking would come from people who ride Amtrak or the airlines, go boating on weekends or work for the federal government. Don't bank on the $114,000 windfall or get rid of your boat. By August, when Congress usually focuses on budgets, January's proposals have a habit of changing or vanishing altogether. Bush's proposal to require a $25 decal on any recreational or commercial boat using waterways patrolled by the Coast Guard revived an idea originally floated by President Reagan. Congress balked, and the idea sank. So, too, did Reagan's proposal to drop the federal subsidy received by the Amtrak rail passenger system. Reagan said it would be cheaper to hand an airline or bus ticket to every Amtrak passenger than to pay a subsidy averaging $30 for every Amtrak rider. Bush's fiscal 1991 budget plan drops that argument, but retains the proposal. His budget director, Richard Darman, told reporters Monday that ``the federal government's responsibility is not to run the railroads.'' Magnetic levitation is something else again. The budget document describes it as ``a new transportation technology that relies on the use of magnets for propulsion and levitation rather than conventional steel-wheel-on-rail technology.'' Bush proposed spending $9.7 million to check it out. In the meantime, Bush proposed eliminating subsidies to keep big-city mass transit systems operating. Darman said that's a local responsibility. Air passengers would pay more _ a boost in the 8 percent ticket tax to 10 percent _ but would get more, for airport construction and hiring 495 more air traffic controllers to help the 17,000 now scanning the skies. The $3 tax on international flights would double. Here's how that $114,000 windfall would work for families able to save: Families with incomes under $120,000 would be able to open two savings accounts in which husband and wife would deposit a total of $5,000. If the accounts were left untouched for more than seven years, the interest earned would escape taxation. Early withdrawal, in less than three years, would carry a 10 percent penalty on top of the regular tax on interest. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady figures that in 25 years a family would save $395,000 of which $114,000 would otherwise have been paid in taxes. He assumed the family pays income tax at a 28 percent rate and can find a bank paying 8 percent interest. Poor families would get a tax credit of $1,000 _ subtracted from taxes owed _ for every youngster under age 4. And parents who adopt children with special needs could deduct $3,000. To start those tots on the road to school, Bush proposed making room for 180,000 more Head Start youngsters in a program that now enrolls 450,000 needy preschoolers. For investors who hold onto their stocks for three years or more, 30 percent of the profits when they finally sell the stocks would be tax-exempt. That's more generous than the capital gains tax proposal that, with Bush's backing, passed the House but stalled in the Senate last year. Federal workers would be among the losers in the budgetary game of winners and losers. Bush's budget proposes a three-month delay in a federal pay raise that is scheduled to take effect Oct. 31. And the 30 percent of state and local government workers who are exempt from Social Security taxes _ and benefits _ would lose that status. What the president proposed for trees was to plant more of them _ one billion a year through a $175 million reforestation program plus another 30 million through a community ``plant a tree'' initiative. His budget message said growing more trees across America would fight the threat of climatic warming known as the greenhouse effect. An acre of trees removes up to 9 million tons of carbon dioxide from the air, but the country is losing 700,000 acres of trees annually, it said. Finally, grim prospects for tax sharpies. The budget proposes more money for enforcement of the tax laws, specifically for collecting delinquent taxes, checking out fake dependent claims, auditing mortgage interest deductions, and matching what the taxpayer says he received in interest against what interest payers say they paid. Those steps, said the budget, should ``close the gap between taxes owed and taxes paid.''

DOC.HEAD: Strike Eases in Baku, But Red Army Can't Leave Yet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to ADD background on politicians calling for troop withdrawal, count of arrested Azerbaijani activists and Azerbaijani activist blaming militants for bloodshed; pickup 12th, `Soviet TV...'
DOC.TEXT: Many Azerbaijanis heeded their leaders' call to ``put our grief aside'' and return to work in their capital Monday, but the defense minister said Soviet troops could not be withdrawn yet from the Caucasus. ``The situation is not the best,'' Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov told the government daily Izvestia about the ethnic turmoil in the southern Soviet Union. He cited attempts by extremists to keep workers from their jobs in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital on the Caspian Sea, weapons still held by those insurgents and their attacks on government buildings. Yazov did not provide details. Asked by Izvestia when Soviet troops, who stormed the oil center of Baku more than a week ago, would be pulled out, Yazov responded: ``Troops will remain until the required order is restored.'' Azerbaijan's top politicians and political activists have been demanding for days that the troops be withdrawn, saying they are not needed to keep order and are infringing on the republic's sovereignty. The official news agency Tass said most of Baku's businesses resumed work Monday and mass transit was operating on most routes.
