Baku Radio broadcast an appeal by the republic's Communist Party and government leaders for citizens to return to work. ``We have to put our grief aside for the sake of all those who continue to live and for the sake of the welfare of the children, the women, the elderly and each and every family,'' said the appeal, monitored by the BBC in London. ``We call on you to report to work to give a new life to each and every house, town, district and city,'' it said. Tass said leaflets circulated in the city urged the strikes to continue, and Izvestia reported that extremists went to apartments and threatened to attack people if they went to work. Soviet media reported more arrests of nationalist leaders in Azerbaijan's capital. ``The extremist strongholds with stocks of food and ammunition are being detected,'' Radio Moscow said Monday. A Moscow spokesman for the Azerbaijani People's Front, a group that has organized anti-Armenian protests, reported that as of Monday, more than 200 members had been arrested in Baku. One of those arrested blamed militant People's Front leaders for the bloodshed, saying they had ignored official warnings to halt attempts to seize power and prevent Soviet troops from entering Baku. Heibulla Balash Agayev made the remarks on Azerbaijani television Sunday and Tass reported them Monday. Yazov has said troops moved into Baku to destroy the People's Front and other smaller groups that were about to seize power. Soviet TV showed empty seats in Baku classrooms and said many students and teachers were staying away from school because they feared attack. In another development, the mainly Christian Armenians and predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis on Sunday began pulling back from the border between Armenia and Nakhichevan, an Azerbaijani territory bounded by Armenia, Iran and Turkey. Tass said there were no new ethnic clashes in Nakhichevan. The withdrawals went without incident Sunday, according to Yusif Samedugli, a leader of the nationalist Azerbaijani People's Front, and Armenian activist Rafael Popoyan. Last week, activists agreed to a truce at that border, one of the most bitterly contested areas. Armenians are demanding control of Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of Azerbaijan populated largely by Armenians. The two Soviet republics have feuded intermittently over Nagorno-Karabakh for two years. The conflict exploded into anti-Armenian riots on Jan. 13 in Baku and led to battles between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the countryside. Soviet troops stormed Baku on Jan. 20. At least 197 people have been killed in the neighboring republics since Jan. 13, by official count, with 125 of the deaths following the arrival of Soviet troops. Signs in Baku blame President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the deaths, labeling him a killer with blood on his hands, the British television company ITN reported from Baku. Peace talks between representatives of the Armenian National Movement and the Azerbaijani People's Front are scheduled for Thursday in Riga, Latvia. Both sides say they will discuss troop withdrawals, refugees and other humanitarian concerns. Some reports said the territorial dispute will not be on the agenda. ``The goal is to stop senseless bloodletting,'' said Dainis Ivans, a Latvian People's Front leader and one of three mediators. The Baltic nationalist movements' initiative to sponsor the talks between Armenians and Azerbaijanis reflected how much clout the burgeoning movements have gained in the past year and their concern over Kremlin intervention. Another Latvian People's Front mediator, Romas Razukas, said the Baltic groups have experience in achieving change peacefully and this could be a lesson to Armenians and Azerbaijanis. ``We would like to persuade them of the value of diplomacy and the use of parliamentary means to resolve disputes. We want them to understand how much we have achieved through those means,'' Razukas said. Tass reported Monday that three leaders of the Azerbaijan People's Front, the most powerful nationalist group in the republic, had been detained by the KGB. The news agency also said about 10,000 leaflets calling for civil disobedience were seized at a Baku factory. In the Armenian capital of Yerevan, a sniper exchanged gunfire with Soviet soldiers trying to recapture armored vehicles and other military equipment seized by extremists, Tass said. One man was killed and several wounded. In another attack, militants armed with submachine guns broke into police headquarters in Yerevan on Monday and took 135 pistols, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: More Foreign Aid Sought for East Europe and International Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress on Monday for $300 million in fiscal 1991 to reward emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and proposed major aid increases to Andean countries to help stem drug production. But the president's overall $18.2 billion foreign affairs budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 was largely devoid of details, including specific requests for most U.S. aid recipients around the world and a description of exactly what Bush wants to do in Eastern Europe. Also missing from the budget is any mention of Panama. The administration will seek a special appropriation this year to send about $500 million in cash and a like amount in non-cash benefits to help the Panamanian economy recover from U.S. sanctions and invasion. However, the administration apparently has not decided what it wants to do for Panama in fiscal 1991. The $300 million for countries behind the crumbling Iron Curtain was billed as ``a special assistance initiative,'' but appeared to some to be primarily the second installment of a three-year aid package Congress approved last year for Poland and Hungary. A Senate Budget Committee Analysis called the proposal a cut from last year. ``I don't see much for Eastern Europe, to be frank,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., was poised to introduce his own package of aid to the Eastern European countries Tuesday, including easing trade restrictions and some direct aid. It appeared likely that last year's criticisms of Bush as too timid toward Eastern Europe were likely to be replayed. The budget document promised that legislation will be sent to Capitol Hill spelling out more clearly how the money would be used to encourage free-market economic reform and development of democracy. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who is still struggling with aid allocations for the current year, is likely to be questioned about the administration's intentions when he testifies Thursday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Acknowledging that the ``bipolar superpower era'' is over, the budget puts a new emphasis on international organizations that contrasts with the skepticism showed such groups by Bush's predecessor, Ronald Reagan. Bush's budget promises to pay off past-due debts to the United Nations and multilateral development banks left by Reagan _ $620 million in back dues to the U.N. plus $794 million for the regularly scheduled payment, and $279 million to clear a backlog for the banks. A nearly 80 percent boost is proposed in aid for the war on drugs, including $175 million in what the budget terms new aid ``for the economies of those countries that evidence a determination to attack seriously the narcotics problem.'' Under pressure from Capitol Hill, the administration apparently is seeking some of that aid to help coca farmers switch to other crops. Coca is used to produce cocaine. In addition, law enforcement aid of $20 million is sought for Colombia, where a crackdown on cocaine cartels has brought violent retaliation; $19 million for Peru, the world's largest coca leaf producer; and $15.7 million for Bolivia. The estimated outlays for all international affairs categories _ foreign aid, maintaining embassies and running the State Department _ would be $18.2 billion in 1991, an effective increase of nearly 12 percent. The 1990 figure is estimated at $14.6 billion, but has been artificially reduced by one-time income of $1.7 billion from early repayment of past military aid loans. The budget proposal would continue the two largest recipients of U.S. military and economic aid at their current levels: $3 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt. It asks, as well, for $200 million to pay the second installment of a five-year, $1 billion pledge to an international aid effort for the Philippines. In addition, $2.1 billion is requested to make payments to NATO countries and the Philippines in return for rights to maintain U.S. military bases on their soil. There also is a request for a long-term appropriation of $270 million to rebuild the new U.S. Embassy in Moscow, which was penetrated by Soviet listening devices. Of that amount, only about $10 million is estimated to be spent in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 March on Parliament to Protest Steep Price Increases
DOC.TEXT: More than 20,000 demonstrators chanting ``We're fed up!'' rallied in front of the Parliament Monday to demand pay raises and to protest price hikes in foodstuffs and public transport. ``We do not want to use our final weapon, the general strike, but we are not ruling it out either,'' said Sandor Nagy, general secretary of the official central trade union federation, which helped organize the protest. About 4,000 demonstrators later marched to the television headquarters to demand their views be broadcast, the official MTI news agency reported. The demonstration followed a series of price increases earlier this month, part of a government plan to cut the budget deficit and let the market set prices. Meat prices rose 32 percent, dairy products 42 percent, bread 20 percent and cigarettes and liquor more than 20 percent. On Thursday, public transport fares will go up 55 percent. The austerity program is designed to prove to the International Monetary Fund that the government is serious about cutting subsidies, a condition for receiving Western credits. The official unions said the program will push almost a third of Hungary's 10.6 million people below the proverty line, set at $83 a month. Protesters carried banners with the slogans ``European Wages for European Prices!'' and ``We always sacrifice, but to what result?'' One protester, Amalia Kis, living on $56 a month, said she bought no fuel during the winter and spent her days in the public library ``because they have heat there.'' The demonstration was called by the Iron Workers Union and endorsed by the National Council of Trade Unions to press for an increase in the minimum montly wage to $85 and an $8 wage increase. Premier Miklos Nemeth has rejected higher wages without corresponding increases in productivity. Members of the League of Independent Trade Unions did not attend the rally, and a spokesman said workers should talk with company managers instead of the government, which will turn over power following elections in March. ``We understand the people's anger, it is fully justified, but this demonstration is unnecessary and harmful,'' said Csaba Oery, the league's spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Tiny Increase for USDA
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday proposed an ``austere'' 1 percent budget increase for the Agriculture Department for fiscal 1991, with nearly one-third of the $48.7 billion he requested targeted for food stamps. As part of the overall department budget, the president proposed a $1.5 billion cut in commodity programs. The cuts, which were not detailed, would likely mean that farmers would get lower guarantee prices and reduced direct payments for major crops such as wheat, feed grains and cotton. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter called the proposed budget ``austere, but ... by no means dracronian.'' The Bush administration projects inflation this fiscal year at 4.1 percent. If Congress does not go along with the commodity cutback, the USDA budget could balloon by 4.2 percent next fiscal year, from $48.2 billion to $50.2 billion. Details of the proposed $1.5 billion in commodity program cuts were left to negotiations between the Bush administraton and Congress. Initial Democratic response was not enthusiastic. Nutrition programs would account for $23 billion of the USDA budget _ with about $15.4 billion going for the food stamp program. That is up about $600 million from this year, mostly because of higher food costs and upward adjustments in monthly allocation to needy families. State child nutrition programs, at $4.8 billion, would be down about $150 million from this year but would allow for an increase in school lunch subsidies for middle-poverty children who now pay a reduced rate for meals. Children from the lowest-income categories get meals free. Under the proposal, the reduced-rate meals would cost a child 20 cents instead of the current 40 cents. The women, infants and children (WIC) program would account for $2.2 billion, up from $2.1 billion this year and a reflection of rising participation. The Bush budget for the year beginning Oct. 1 calls for scaling back the Federal Crop Insurance Corp., which provides subsidies to farmers who carry all-risk protection for crop loss. The agency's budget _ $1.2 million this fiscal year _ would fall to $430,000. In place of the crop insurance program, a new disaster assistance program would be worked out with Congress. Net outlays for USDA commodity programs _ a wide range of subsidies for crops, dairy products, honey and wool _ were projected at more than $10.2 billion in 1991. But that assumes Congress will approve the $1.5 billion in cuts. If lawmakers reject the plan, commodity subsidies would rise to about $11.7 billion in 1991 from $8.4 billion this year. That would still be far less than the record level of $25.8 billion in 1986. The subsidy programs, provided by the department's Commodity Credit Corp., dropped to $22.4 billion in 1987 and to $12.5 billion in 1988. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said in a statement that ``efforts to balance the federal budget cannot be allowed to destroy one of our greatest accomplishments, which is to provide `safety net' levels of support'' for farmers. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said the administration's budget ``suggests they will continue to cut target prices and (price support) loan rates until the farm programs are effectively abolished.'' Under the system, the CCC payments mostly run a year behind the events, meaning that the 1991 budget proposed by Bush will be for crops grown in 1990, and so on. The sharp drops in net outlays the last two years reflect the 1988 and 1989 droughts, which reduced production and drove up commodity prices. That meant less need for payments to farmers, thus reducing CCC outlays. With farmers planting larger acreages this year and a probable continuation of normal yields for the major field crops, total spending on commidity programs is expected to jump in 1991. The budget also proposes a sharp reduction in Farmers Home Administration spending to about $5.8 billion in 1991 from $7.1 billion this year. Most of the FmHA savings would be in farm loan programs, rural housing and the elimination of ``business and industrial'' programs to help improve local communities. The budget calls for a further shift from direct loans by the agency to guarantees for private lenders.

DOC.HEAD: Namibian Assembly Proposes March 21 as Independence Date
By HEIDI VON EGIDY
DOC.TEXT: The Constituent Assembly proposed Monday that this southwest African territory declare independence on March 21, ending 75 years of rule by South Africa. Namibia is Africa's last colony. The 72-member assembly, elected in November, submitted the date to Louis Pienaar, Namibia's South African administrator, who is expected to approve. An assembly vote on the proposal is planned on Tuesday. South Africa captured Namibia from the Germans in 1915. In December 1988, it agreed to grant independence as part of a regional treaty that also calls for phased withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, Namibia's northern neighbor. More than 6,000 U.N. military and civilian personnel have been supervising the transition process since last April. The constituent assembly also has been debating a democratic, Western-style constitution and is to begin voting on the document Tuesday article-by-article. No major disagreements are expected, because all leading parties represented in the assembly say they support the proposed constitution. The draft constitution contains a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, freedom of speech and freedom of the press. It foresees a multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and an executive president limited to two five-year terms. One provision that may lead to dissension allows for detention without trial during a state of emergency or in time of war. An individual could be detained without charge if that person was deemed ``a clear and present danger to the security of the state.'' SWAPO, the leftist South West Africa People's Organization which had fought a bush war for independence from South Africa since 1966, won 41 seats in the assembly and will form the first government. SWAPO leader Sam Nujoma is expected to become Namibia's president. The multiracial Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, which wants Namibia to have a free enterprise economy, has 21 seats. Five parties share the 10 remaining seats. Two-thirds of the assembly, or 48 members, must approve each article of the constitution. The South African Defense Force, South-West Africa Territorial Force and the South-West African Police fought SWAPO in the northern part of the territory in a war that killed 20,000 people, mostly guerrillas, over 23 years. The last fighting in the country of about 1.5 million occurred in April 1989 at the outset of the U.N.-supervised independence process that resulted in elections in November for the constituent assembly. The territory is composed of sparsely populated areas. The territory, as large as France and West Germany combined, contains 11 main ethnic groups, including two mixed-race groups, eight black groups and about 75,000 whites. The Ovambo people, who inhabit the relatively fertile northern region, make up about half the population.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Seeking Pardon for Man Jailed for Eight Years
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said Monday they'll seek a pardon for a man who has spent almost eight years in prison for robbery because of new evidence supporting the man's alibi. Michael Anthony Woten, 36, was found guilty of robbing a grocery store of $5,200 on April 16, 1982. He was arrested May 7, 1982, convicted of aggravated robbery with a deadly weapon and sentenced to 55 years in prison. During his trial, Woten testified that he was hitchhiking to St. Louis on the day of the robbery. But Woten could only identify the truck driver who picked him up with his citizens' band radio handle of ``Kangaroo,'' said Deputy Police Chief Ray Hawkins. ``We had what we thought then was a pretty strong case,'' said Hawkins. ``Five witnesses were pointing the finger at'' Woten. The Dallas Times Herald recently tracked down the truck driver through an ad in a trucker's publication. Former trucker Don ``Kangaroo'' Fainter told the newspaper he remembered picking up Woten in Oklahoma City and confirmed much of Woten's alibi that he was hitchhiking on the day of the robbery. Evidence of the trip was found in the Centerville, Ky., office where Fainter's former employer stored company records. Dallas County District Attorney John Vance said prosecutors are awaiting written information from the police before proceeding with a pardon request. ``We are just waiting for the police to physically give it to us so that we will be knowledgeable enough to ask the governor and Board of Pardons and Paroles to pardon him,'' Vance said. Hawkins said Woten had written several news agencies claiming his innocence, after which the Times Herald interviewed him and brought police a written outline of what Woten said had occurred. ``We investigated it and were able to find some written documentation that substantiated what he had to say,'' Hawkins said. ``While there is a modicum of evidence that he still might be guilty, there is now a reasonable doubt and that is all that is required to turn him loose.'' Woten had enclosed an affidavit from a fellow inmate, which said the inmate committed the robbery. Authorities have not said what, if any, action will be taken against the inmate. ``Is this for sure?'' Woten told the Times Herald when informed he might be freed. ``In all honesty, this has happened so fast, you know ... They're not going to change their minds, are they?'' It could not be determined Monday when Woten would have been eligible for parole. Calls by The Associated Press to various state officials were not returned. The Woten case is latest in a string of dubious convictions in Dallas County. The most publicized was that of Randall Dale Adams, subject of the film ``The Thin Blue Line,'' who was freed last year after spending 13 years in prison after he was convicted of killing a Dallas police officer.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Seeks Down Payments on VA Loans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Though it's now the Veterans Department, the short form is still the familiar ``VA.''
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's proposed 1991 budget requests more spending on the health-care needs of the nation's 27 million veterans but would require down payments on on its home loans for the first time. The proposed budget also asks for Congress to approve legislation ending the mobile home loan program. The Veterans Department cited high foreclosure losses, particularly among active duty military personnel, as the reason for ending that Vietnam-era program. In another area, the administration proposes nominal fees for middle-income veterans who seek treatment for non-service connected disabilities at VA facilities. None of the individual fees for such services as prescriptions and outpatient visits would exceed $10 a day. The measure is supposed to bring in $112 million. The proposed $30.1 billion budget for the department calls for spending of $12.4 billion for health care, compared with the $10.8 billion sought last year by the administration. After an increase by Congress and a slight cut to meet Gramm-Rudman targets, spending this year is estimated at $11.4 billion. The total budget request would exceed current spending by $1.4 billion. This is the first VA budget proposal since the VA achieved cabinet status. Secretary Edward J. Derwinski attributed the increased funds to his agency's greater public visibility. ``I think the president understood early on that they can't shortchange us,'' Derwinski said. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee praised Derwinski, a former Republican congressman from Illinois, saying the health care budget is ``the best VA medical care budget request by a president in more than a decade.'' ``Secretary Derwinski took his case directly to President Bush and did a tremendous job in convincing im that the downward spiral in VA health care must be halted,'' he said. ``This is a fair and realistic budget coming from the White House and one of the best we've seen in years for veterans,'' said Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., chairman of the House Veterans' Affairs Committee. Lawmakers and veterans groups have complained that VA's ability to care for an increasingly aging veterans population was eroded by the Reagan administration. The VA does substantial work with AIDS victims and those suffering from drug abuse, and cares for a growing number of elderly patients. The budget shifts more funds in those directions. The budget gives more than $500 million in pay increases to the current staff and adds $100 million to hire more than 2,300 people, including 800 nursing positions. The hirings would bring the total staff to close to the 194,720 mandated by Congress. The House and Senate are currently working on legislation to increase nurses' pay, and both veterans committees in both houses have promised legislation this year to raise salaries and benefits for doctors and dentists. Amvets, Disabled American Veterans, Paralyzed Veterans of America and Veterans of Foreign Wars say $13.4 billion is needed just to return basic services to the level available in 1988. The Bush proposal also proposes a 4 percent down payment for VA loans and an increase to 1.75 percent in the in the fee borrowers must pay to a VA mortgage insurance fund. Down payments have never been required by the government in the history of the program, and the insurance fee had already increased from 1 percent to 1.25 percent in January. Raymond H. Avent, the acting chief benefits director, defended the proposal, saying the impact would be minimal and is necessary to save the program from huge loan losses. He said that since the first $25,000 of a loan would be exempt from the fee and the usual home costs $80,000, the home loan would require only a $2,200 to $2,300 down payment. ``The potential is much greater'' that the borrower will not walk away from a mortgage with that much money invested in it, Avent said. Veterans organizations complain that VA is constantly blaming veterans for problems in the loan system instead of its own mismanagement of the program. Cranston called the down payment feature ``the most objectionable'' feature of the budget proposal. ``Congress created the program in 1944 precisely to allow hundreds of thousands of veterans to purchase homes even though they could not come up with a downpayment,'' he said. ``The same need is here today.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Money for NASA to Return to the Moon and Head to Mars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruhout with science proposals, detail on NASA science missions.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress on Monday to increase NASA's 1991 budget by 17.5 percent, including money for a start on his plan to send astronauts back to the moon and, later, to Mars. NASA would be authorized to spend $14.1 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, an increase of $2.1 billion over this fiscal year. The space agency's spending authority _ different from the one-year budget in that authority includes money for projects that wouldn't be completed and paid off until later years _ would rise by 24 percent, from $12.3 billion to $15.1 billion. Bush also was generous to other fields of scientific research, adding $895 million for basic non-defense research, for a total of $10.9 billion, and a $2.1 billion increase for applied research and development, for a total of $14.4 billion. Among the areas proposed for a boost was the National Science Foundation, $2.2 billion, a 13 percent increase; AIDS research, increasing by $749 million to $3.2 billion, and the superconducting Super Collider, budgeted for $293 million, a 56 percent increase. Bush also asked for a 20 percent rise in financing science and engineering education, proposing to bring federal investment in that area to $871 million. The president's request to Congress ``demonstrates the administration's continued strong support for NASA and the civil space station,'' NASA administrator Richard H. Truly told a news conference. ``It reflects the president's belief that investment in space yields substantial benefits _ vastly expanding scientific knowledge, developing valuable new technology and, especially important, lifting the dreams, imagination and spirit of our nation.'' A major beneficiary would be the manned space station, which the United States hopes to have in orbit late in the decade. Authority for the station would increase from $1.7 billion to $2.4 billion as the project moves from design to the fabrication stage. The first construction flight is scheduled for the spring of 1995. If approved by Congress, the space budget would pay for starting the so-called ``Mission to Planet Earth,'' an ambitious program to study the Earth's environment using satellites and instruments. The budget request includes $661 million in spending authority to study the Earth, including money to start two polar-orbiting platforms, the first of which would be launched in 1998. It also would initiate the development of Earth probes, a series of smaller instruments focused on specific, high-priority data needs, including ozone depletion. The first would be launched in 1994. The budget proposes a total of $3.3 billion for space science and $101 million for programs to promote the commercial use of space. Space science includes such major flight projects as the Galileo mission to Jupiter and the Magellan mission to venus, both underway, plus the Hubble Space Telescope, set for an April launch. Proposed funds ``directly relatable to exploration are a little bit less than $1 billion,'' Truly said. When exploration expenditures included in the budgets of the Defense Department and other agencies are added in, he said, the amount will be more than $1.3 billion. Last July, on the 20th anniversary of man's first landing on the moon, the president set a goal of having the United States return to the moon and then to begin manned exploration of Mars early in the next century. The budget request reflects the first steps toward that goal in a $179 million authority item for ``exploration technology,'' which includes $4.5 million for lunar and Mars science, and $11 million for nuclear propulsion studies. Bush's proposal also envisions development of two new robotic missions, the Lunar Observer and Lifesat. The latter would be a series of reuseable satellites designed to carry living speciments into orbit and be returned to Earth for analysis of the effects of long-term exposure. The National Aero-Space Plane, a joint NASA and Air Force project, would receive a total $277 million in spending authority. An additional $129 million in joint funds is proposed for develping a new family of launch vehicles. NASA had planned a record 10 flights in calendar 1990 but had to postpone one, because of delays in flying the recent satellite retrieval mission and a delay in the anticipated spring launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. The budget calls for 10 flights in each of the next two fiscal years, leading up to a planned flight rate of 12 a year. The budget would also enable NASA to increase employment from 23,735 to 24,466. ``With more than 85 percent of NASA's appropriation going to the private sector, we simply must have the in-house expertise to manage contract performance,'' Truly said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Targets More Money for Renewing, Cleaning up Nuclear Arms Plants
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday proposed a nearly $1 billion increase in spending authority to modernize decrepit U.S. nuclear weapons plants and clean up their environmental messes. Bush's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 includes $9.95 billion for nuclear weapons development and production, as well as environmental cleanup at the 17 major weapons facilities owned by the Energy Department. That compares with slightly more than $9 billion currently allocated to the Energy Department for those purposes. All the figures are for budget authority, which represents ceilings on actual outlays to be determined separately. The department used budget authority figures for the plant modernization project because funds are spent over several years under long-term contracts. About two-thirds of the proposed $1 billion increase is for Energy Secretary James D. Watkins' new plan to clean up radioactive contamination and toxic wastes at the weapons plants and bring the facilities into compliance with environmental laws. Bush called for $2.75 billion in spending authority for cleanup and waste management for fiscal 1991, an increase of about $600 million over current levels. Estimates of the total cleanup costs range from $65 billion to $100 billion in spending over 30 years. Watkins said most of the rest of the increase would go toward making nuclear weapons plants safer and more modern. Bush also proposed a 20 percent boost in spending on development of two new nuclear reactors to produce tritium, a critical ingredient in nuclear warheads. The new reactors would replace damaged facilities at the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C. Watkins said it's possible that only one new reactor would suffice, but he stressed his view that no such cutback should be made until more is known about how reforms under way in the Soviet Union will affect Western security interests. Watkins also confirmed that he decided to halt plans for building a high-technology plutonium refinery in Idaho. The $1.2 billion project, known as the Special Isotope Separation plant, will be phased out starting April 1, he said. The energy secretary said the department had determined that the Idaho refinery was not needed to meet plutonium requirements for weapons production, but that overall spending on the weapons complex must increase to meet defense needs. ``Until arms control is a fait accompli, we have to demonstrate that we have the will to keep our strategic stockpile'' adequate, Watkins told a news conference. He said a viable weapons production complex was as important as the warheads themselves in deterring a Soviet attack. Watkins said the government had failed for years to invest adequately in nuclear weapons plants, thus leaving them vulnerable to breakdowns and unsafe operation. Many key facilities are closed for safety and management improvements. ``We're trying to put the investment back in here to ensure that this doesn't become the Achilles heel at the (arms control) bargaining table for the United States,'' he said. Watkins also announced that a facility at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, near Richland, Wash., that had been designed to provide plutonium for the space program would be shut down over four years, beginning this year. He said the department decided it would be cheaper for the Savannah River plant to provide the plutonium.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees World Increasingly `On the Side of God'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, hailing moves toward democracy throughout Eastern Europe, said Monday that ``the world, increasingly, is on the side of God.'' Bush, in a speech to the annual convention of the National Religious Broadcasters, also said ``I believe with all my heart that one cannot be America's president without a belief in God, without the strength that your faith gives to you.'' He got a rousing response from the crowd of about 2,000, particularly when he expressed opposition to abortion, saying, ``I support the sanctity of life,'' and when he reiterated his support for a constitutional amendment permitting voluntary prayer in public schools. Bush has been a regular speaker at the broadcasters' conventions. Monday's address marked his fourth appearance before the group. ``We believe that political values without moral values, a moral underpinning, cannot sustain a people,'' Bush said. He recalled his comment in his inaugural address that ``the day of the dictator is over,'' and said, ``Indeed, the last year has been a victory for the freedoms with which God has blessed the United States of America. We have seen the rights of man move mountains or _ as in East Berlin _ even move a wall. Bush said the changes in Eastern Europe ``were propelled by many things, faith not the least of them.'' He said that as pro-democracy demonstrations spread across Europe, ``the day of the dictator did end.'' The president praised the role of religious figures in democratic revolutions, and singled out a Romanian Orthodox priest, Gheorghe Calciu, who spent 21 of his 64 years in jail and was spared at the last minute from a death sentence. Addressing the priest, who was in the audience, Bush said, ``Father, it's an honor to salute you. ... I know, too, you hope to return to your native land.'' ``And in this season of miracles, who can doubt you will?,'' Bush said. ``For today, the times are on the side of peace, because the world, increasingly, is on the side of God.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Release Reportedly Delayed Because of Unrest
DOC.TEXT: News reports Monday indicated the release of Nelson Mandela may be delayed because of unrest, and an aide said the black leader will resume his political struggle even if it means going back to jail. The government is considering delaying Mandela's release until March because of renewed unrest, including protests against a touring English cricket team that has defied a ban on sports contacts with South Africa, according to several newspapers. On Monday, police fired tear gas at a Roman Catholic church to break up about 1,000 people who gathered to plan a protest rally against the cricket team. Organizer Paul Ntuli said dozens of people suffered minor injuries at the Pax Nova church near the central city of Bloemfontein. Police confirmed the incident but declined to give any details. In downtown Johannesburg, police used batons and tear gas to disperse more than 1,000 black railway workers following a union meeting. No injuries or arrests were reported. Government leaders were concerned that releasing Mandela and other pending reforms would inflame unrest and officials want to slow down reforms to ensure they retain control of developments, said reports citing unidentified sources. The Star reported Monday that no decision had been made on when to release Mandela and the decision would be left to President F.W. de Klerk. De Klerk had not set a date for release because he did not want to meet demands that the government also legalize the African National Congress, the main black group fighting the white-led government, the paper said. Mandela, 71, has been imprisoned since 1962, and is serving a life term for helping plan the start of the ANC's anti-government sabotage campaign. The South African media has been swamped with reports and speculation on when Mandela might be released and the issue is dominating political life. The government has said it intends to free Mandela but has not given any date. De Klerk is expected to outline government reforms Friday in an opening address to new session of Parliament. De Klerk, who says he wants to end discrimination, could announce Mandela's release. However, the Rev. Allan Boesak, a leading anti-apartheid figure, said Mandela's release must be accompanied by reforms such as lifting the state of emergency and legalizing the ANC and other banned organizations. ``It has not yet been shown that Mr. de Klerk has either the vision or the courage to make this moment a moment of historic importance,'' Boesak said. An anti-government demonstration is planned outside Parliament to coincide with de Klerk's speech. Winnie Mandela, wife of the jailed nationalist leader, said after seeing her husband in prison Saturday that problems had arisen and his release could be delayed. In Oslo, Norway, veteran ANC leader Walter Sisulu said Mandela ``is ready for release at any time. I know that Mandela would be making certain demands, but I do not know if they are conditions.'' Dullah Omar, a close friend of the Mandela family, said Mandela has made it clear the government must make basic reforms to clear the way for talks between whites and blacks. ``If and when he is released and there have been no major changes, then he will report back to his organization (the ANC) that three years of talks (with the government) have been a waste of time,'' Omar said. In an allusion to resuming armed struggle, Omar said, Mandela ``will go back to where he left off, before he went to prison, and will probably find himself back in prison in a month.''

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather In The North
DOC.TEXT: A new storm headed for the northern Pacific Coast on Monday with a threat of wind and rain, snow scattered over the Northeast closed schools, and rain fell along the East Coast. High wind warnings were issued along the Oregon coast and inland, and over sections of Washington. A winter storm watch was posted for the Oregon Cascades and the mountains of northeastern Oregon. Snow fell during the early afternoon from southern Maine to central New England, much of New York state, the northern and western two-thirds of Pennsylvania, much of Ohio, eastern Indiana, southeastern Lower Michigan and north-central Kentucky. The snow forced scores of New York schools to close as a precaution and was blamed for at least one death in weather-related road accidents in that state. Binghamton, N.Y., reported 5 inches of snow by afternoon. Two to 4 inches fell at Albany, Glens Falls and Poughkeepsie, the National Weather Service reported. ``A lot of areas will end up with 6 to 12 inches before it's all over,'' said Ken LaPenta, a weather service meteorologist in Albany. Rockingham, Vt., got 1{ inches of snow in 2 hours. Accumulations over north-central Pennsylvania included about 7 inches across Lycoming County, 6 inches at Laporte, 5 inches over Clinton County, and 2{ inches to 5 inches over Tioga County. Eight inches fell at Laurel Mountain Park. To the south of that area, rain fell from southeastern Pennsylvania to Maryland, much of Virginia, West Virginia, southeastern Ohio, eastern Kentucky, eastern Tennessee, North Carolina, western South Carolina, northwestern Georgia, southeastern Alabama and the Florida Panhandle. A few thunderstorms were scattered over Georgia and northern Florida. Elsewhere, snow fell from the Idaho Panhandle to northwestern and north-central Montana. Strong winds blew across Wyoming, with morning gusts to 58 mph in Cheyenne and 55 mph in Casper. Winds gusted to 60 mph in Scottsbluff, Neb., and in Colorado at Fort Colllins, Boulder, Longmont, and the Air Force Academy. A winter storm watch was in effect into Tuesday morning across northwestern and north-central Minnesota. A cold front moved into Montana during the morning, lowering temperatures by as much as 20 and 25 degrees. At noon, the wind chill at Cut Bank was 50 degrees below zero. Marquette, Mich., posted a record high of 34 during the afternoon. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 4 below zero at Cut Bank, Mont., to 84 at both Fort Myers and Vero Beach, Fla. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 9 below zero at Warroad, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Lambast Bush Budget on All Fronts
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats attacked President Bush's 1991 budget on all fronts Monday, calling the $1.23 trillion spending plan too soft on the Pentagon, too harsh on domestic programs and too reliant on rosy economic projections. Republicans leaped to Bush's defense, even though many of them had to concede that parts of the president's proposal would never be enacted and that the budget year likely would be a tough one. ``I wouldn't be surprised if we were unable to reach agreement up here this year,'' Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the Senate Budget Committee's ranking Republican, conceded to reporters. In a preview of a theme likely to dominate the year's Capitol Hill fiscal wars, majority Democrats pounced on Bush's call to spend $303.3 billion for overall defense spending. That figure _ a 2 percent cut from this year's $296.3 billion when compared to the costs of inflation _ was derided by many Democrats as being too generous to the military at a time of easing tensions with the Soviet bloc. ``It is becoming apparent that if there is to be a peace dividend that amounts to anything, this Congress is going to have to carve it out,'' complained Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``You'd think Joe Stalin had come back and entrenched himself in the Kremlin.'' ``It is a Rip Van Winkle budget that has not yet awakened to the changes in the world or the major challenges at homes,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. Yet noticeably lacking was the phrase that became the reflexive reaction among Democrats to many of the budgets that President Reagan sent the lawmakers: ``Dead on arrival.'' ``I think we'll take it very seriously,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. But like other members of his party, Gephardt called the spending blueprint a ``stand-pat budget'' that fails to seriously address many of the nation's problems. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., lauded Bush's proposals to boost spending on the Head Start preschool program for low-income children by $500 million to $1.9 billion. But he chided the president for offering overall education increases _ to $24.6 billion _ that fail to keep abreast of inflation, and for cutting heating bill subsidies to the poor. ``A budget should make a statement about a nation's priorities and aspirations,'' Byrd said. ``The only clear statement made by this first Bush budget is, `Read my lips, not my actions.''' Also criticized were Bush's projections for an economy growing 2.6 percent this year _ well below the rate that congressional economists and many private analysts expect. More optimistic forecasts allow the White House to boost its projections for revenue collections, thus making the deficit appear smaller. ``The return of the rsy scenario,'' said Rep. William H. Gray III, the House's No. 3 Democratic leader, referring to the name adopted for the economic estimates Reagan used. ``Dancing all over the American economic landscape when all the indicators indicate that we're not going to have that kind of growth.'' Commenting on what he said was a lack of a bold attack on the deficit _ which the administration thinks it will cut from an estimated $123.8 billion this year to $63.1 billion in 1991 _ House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said, ``This is a take two aspirin and call me in the morning budget.'' The Democratic barrage prompted some Republicans to retort that if Democrats don't want to adopt the Bush proposal, it is up to them to produce an alternative. ``Congress always feels the need to be different, no matter what the president suggests,'' said the House Budget Committee's ranking Republican, Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota. ``But Congress is obliged to produce a budget resolution of its own _ or to signify a willingness to negotiate with the president right off the bat.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of 2nd item to CORRECT name of bird to `Canada geese,' sted `Canadian geese.'
DOC.TEXT: Most of the record number of Canada geese that wintered in Reno have flown back home, avoiding a planned ``taste-aversion'' program to make them literally sick of roosting here.
DOC.HEAD: Steve Fairaizl, 2nd graf
Seven Dozen Military Sites Here and Abroad Slated For Closure or Cuts
With AM-Base Cuts-List
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 15th graf to CORRECT spelling of Taegu; INSERTS 4 grafs after 18th graf pvs, bgng, `Cheney's list,' to show that some bases were on last year's list and adds comment from Sen. Pete Wilson.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recommended Monday closing or scaling back more than 72 U.S. military installations and ending operations at 12 overseas facilities, a plan that immediately drew congressional fire. ``I understand the problem they're faced with, but it's absolutely vital that Congress have the guts to make the right decisions as we go through this period of time,'' Cheney said as he released his $292.1 billion fiscal 1991 spending plan _ with the base closing proposal _ and signaled lawmakers that the battle has begun. Cheney said he had no figures yet for the potential savings from the moves. He said the numbers were still being analyzed. But because it costs money to shut bases down and legislation is needed to do so, the savings are not usually accrued until years later. The plan, far less extensive than the 86 closings and five realignments that Congress adopted last year from a federally mandated commission, calls for closing a significant number of facilities in California. Among the candidates for closure there are Fort Ord, Alameda Naval Aviation Depot and Naval Air Station, Long Beach Naval Shipyard, Moffett Field Naval Air Station and Oakland Naval Supply Center in California. Asked whether politics influenced the choices on the closing list, which largely targets bases in the districts of liberal Democrats on Capitol Hill, Cheney said the charge ``wasn't a valid one.'' ``I did not assemble this list,'' said the former Republican congressman from Wyoming. The list was complied by the services, said Cheney, who smiled at suggestions that the services may have been political in their choices. Other Cheney proposals include deactivation of the 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood, which would involve the loss of 12,000 troops. A Republican, Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, rushed into action to try to work out a deal to save the division. ``We worked out an agreement that if we are able to successfully negotiate round one of the conventional disarmament agreement with the Soviets, that would bring home 21,600 Army personnel from Europe, and the first 12,000 of those would go to Fort Hood,'' Gramm said in Texas. But he added, ``The Army is looking at a reduction of 135,000 men in uniform. There's no way you can do that without affecting us. We want to minimize that effect.'' The overseas bases where the United States would end its operations or realign forces include seven in Europe, six in Asia and a Naval Air Station in Bermuda. Of the 14, all would be closed except the Bermuda air station and naval communications station in the Philippines, which would have some forces shifted. The European bases include two in Greece _ Hellenikon Air Base and the Naval Communications Station in Makri; one in West Germany _ Zweibrucken Air Base; three in England _ RAF Fairford, Greenham Common and Wethersfield; and one in Italy _ Comiso Air Base. Comiso and Greenham Common are home to Air Force cruise missile installations that are being dismantled under the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty with the Soviet Union, signed in December 1987. The Asia bases on Cheney's list are a Navy base in San Miguel, Philippines; two bases in Turkey _ Eskisehir Munitions Storage Site and Erhac Air Base; and three in South Korea _ Kwang Ju, Suwon and Taegu. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said in a statement that the base closure proposals ``will be controversial.'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said her military installations subcommittee will be taking a close look to ensure that the closings are not partisan. Cheney's list actually is a proposal to study which bases should be eliminated. Closing a base also requires a lengthy series of environmental impact statements which often lead to delays. A handful of bases on Cheney's proposed list were part of the closure and realignment list Congress approved last year, including Fort Sheridan in Illinois, Fort Meade in Maryland, Letterkenny Depot in Pennsylvania. The recommendations from the defense secretary would effectively cancel or completely realign the remaining work at some of those facilities. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a gubernatorial candidate whose state is particularly hard-hit by the base closings, said he didn't ``think some of them make sense,'' particularly the Long Beach shipyard which has met target dates on spending and repairs. Wilson said the closings will have to be examined thoroughly because of the previous shutdowns, ``the savings were peanuts.'' In Long Beach, the area's chamber of commerce president, Bob Creighton, said the closing of the shipyard could mean as much as $100 million a year to the local economy. ``The chamber plans to work quite closely with our city officials, our congressional delegation and the shipyard employees themselves to do everything we can to convince Congress that the closing of our shipyard would be a mistake,'' Creighton said. Meanwhile, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the U.S. decision to withdraw its forces from three Royal Air Force bases was compatible with NATO's objectives. ``We're satisfied that the decision is reasonable and compatible'' with the current conventional arms talks in Vienna.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Spending Plan Intended to Cope With Wave of Soviet Immigants
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli government Monday outlined a $31.3 billion budget for 1990-91 that is intended to cope with a growing number of Soviet Jewish immigrants and hold the line on defense spending. ``Immigration and what it encompasses is determining the fate of this year's budget,'' Finance Minister Shimon Peres said in presenting the spending plan to the Knesset, or parliament, for approval. Peres later told army radio Israel ``has to think of other possible sources of money for absorbing immigrants.'' The budget would increase the value-added tax by one percentage point to 16 percent and hike taxes on fuel and cigarettes. But Peres rejected any other taxes or special assessments, saying they ``could slow the pace of getting out of the recession and increase the rise in inflation.'' Parliament is expected to approve the budget with little debate or change. The Finance Ministry said the proposed budget takes into account ``two main events, the expected growth in the immigration from the Soviet Union and the stagnation in economic activity in 1989.'' The economy grew just 1 percent each of the last two years, and Israeli officials have largely blamed the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Under the proposed budget, spending would grow by $5.3 billion, or about 19 percent, over the 1989-90 budget. However, when adjusted for inflation _ about 20 percent in 1989 _ there would be little change in real value. The deficit is projected at $2.11 billion. Last year's budget provided for a $900 million deficit, but it wound up at $2.34 billion. The Finance Ministry said the budget would provide $600 million to cover immigration costs for 40,000 Soviet Jews in the new fiscal year, or double the amount spent in 1989-90. It said another $200 million would be provided by the Jewish Agency from donations abroad. But the ministry said revised estimates indicate as many as 100,000 Soviets could come this year and that an additional $500 million would be needed to resettle that number of immigrants. The defense budget anticipates the Palestinian uprising, now in its 26th month, will continue in 1990-91. At total of $6.27 billion is budgeted for defense, up from $5.3 billion in the previous year. But the increase of 18 percent does not make up for inflation, military experts said. The Defense Ministry estimates its uprising-related expenses at about $225 million. But it has budgeted only $75 million, so it will have to cover the balance by cutting spending in other areas, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: A Billion New Trees and Tougher Pollution Law Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's 1991 budget would spend at least $1 billion more to protect the environment in programs ranging from planting a billion new trees to tougher enforcement of pollution laws. The Environmental Protection Agency would be given an additional $332 million to spend on an array of programs including cleaning up toxic waste dumps, tougher enforcement of existing laws and implementation of stricter air pollution requirements now being considered by Congress. The agency's overall proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning in October is $5.8 billion, 6 percent more than this year's estimated expenditures. The administration projects inflation this year to be 4.1 percent. ``Today, a consensus is emerging ... (that) investments in maintaining and restoring the health of the environment can now be seen as a responsible investment in the future,'' said the president's budget document sent to Capitol Hill. Under a broad category of activities that encompasses more than a half dozen agencies and departments, the administration said it wants to spend $7.6 billion for major programs to protect the environment, including a number of initiatives under an umbrella program entitled ``America the Beautiful.'' The spending would reflect an increase of about $1.2 billion for the various programs, officials said. Reflecting the heightened concern about global environmental issues such as the effect of pollution on the earth's warming and on the destruction of the ozone layer, the budget calls for authorizing $1 billion in spending for research into global changes, 50 percent more than now is being given such efforts. In another initiative aimed at dealing with global warming, Bush proposed spending $175 million next year to begin a long-term program aimed at planting a billion trees a year on private land across the country. The program also would help local communities begin tree planting efforts. Trees absorb carbon dioxide, a leading pollutant linked to global warming. Scientists suggested the tree-planting effort would have only marginal effect on overall global warming, however. Bush, who has vowed to end the dramatic decline in recent years of environmentally vital marshlands, called for spending $460 million next year on wetland protection under programs administered by a half dozen agencies, an increase of $88 million over this year. The president also proposed buying additional lands for national parks and said the Forest Service would eliminate ``below cost'' timber sales at nine national forests located near urban centers and make those forests more accessible for recreation. The budget provides $10 million for additional recreational facilities at the nine forests. ``The budget shows a marked departure from nearly a decade of decline and destruction of America's environmetnal programs,'' said Paul Prichard, president of the the private National Parks and Conservation Association. But some environmentalists were not as enthusiastic. ``It falls far short of what is necessary to restore environmental protection in the United States and around the world,'' said Brent Blackwelder, a vice president of Friends of the Earth. He said many environmentalists believe ``at least $5 billion in new environmental spending is called for.'' EPA Administrator William Reilly said at a news conference that the president's budget ``at a time when new money is very hard to come by ... represents a significant commitment ... to assure that the public is protected from the most serious environmental threats now and in the future.'' Reilly noted that the budget calls for hiring 245 additional people to help administer the Clean Air Act, which he expects to be approved by Congress later this year, and for hiring 292 additional people in the agency's enforcement program.

DOC.HEAD: Envoy Says Cuba Plans to Jam U.S. TV Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's U.N. envoy said Monday his nation will jam planned U.S. television transmissions to Cuba and warned broadcasters face serious disruptions in ``this so-called radio war or TV war.'' Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, who assumed his post last week, said the U.S. government's plan to transmit TV broadcasts into Cuba violates international telecommunications agreements. ``It is the same as taking from us part of our land, our sea, our air space,'' he told reporters. ``We are not creating this so-called radio war or TV war. They are the ones who did that,'' he said of U.S. broadcasters. Alarcon said Cuba has previously disrupted transmissions from the United States and warned further interruptions ``will have serious consequences'' for U.S. stations. ``We have given them some examples just to remind their technicians that it is perfectly possible,'' Alarcon said. ``You can disrupt our TV services or our radio services but they can also suffer the same consequences if you do the same from the South to the North.'' The United States has been broadcasting radio transmissions to Cuba via Radio Marti _ named for Cuban patriot Jose Marti _ for about five years. Last year, Congress provided money for television broadcasts to Cuba. On another matter, Alarcon said Cuba will not resume the withdrawal of its troops from Angola until it is assured that U.S.-backed rebels in the African nation will not attack Cuban soldiers. An estimated 50,000 Cuban troops supporting the Angolan government in a 15-year-old civil war with the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) began a phased pullout a year ago under an accord signed by Angola, Cuba and South Africa. UNITA was not party to the accords but pledged not to attack the Cubans as they withdrew. News reports from Havana said Cuba and Angola temporarily suspended the withdrawal pending an investigation into a UNITA guerrilla raid Jan. 21 on a water pumping station guarded by Cuban troops. Four Cubans were killed and seven wounded, U.N. officials said. The rebels have said they didn't know Cubans were in the area at the time. ``As long as we don't receive a satisfactory explanation of what happened and also the necessary assurances that such a thing cannot ever be repeated ... the withdrawal continues to be suspended,'' Alarcon said. He also said his nation is pleased it will have an opportunity to play a heightened role in U.N. negotiations next month as president of the 15-member Security Council. The rotating presidency will give Cuba reponsibility for setting the council's agenda and more involvement in negotiations between member nations. Cuba was elected to the council last year as representative of the Latin American nations, the first time since the Cuban revolution in 1959 that it has served in that capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Government Accuses Opposition of Coup Attempt
LaserPhoto XBUC2
DOC.TEXT: The government accused opponents Monday of attempting a coup and supporters rallied behind it, occupying the offices of one opposition party and forcing another's leader to flee in an armored car. More than 15,000 people rallied in Bucharest to support the self-appointed government that took over when Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was deposed and executed last month. News media reported similar demonstrations in several other cities, but gave no details. On Sunday, about 15,000 people protested in the capital, demanding the resignation of the Council of the National Salvation Front, the name adopted by the government that is running the country until elections planned for May 20. After initially declaring its only purpose was to guide Romania through the immediate post-revolutionary period, the Front recently said it would enter candidates in the elections. That decision angered the fledgling opposition, which says the Front _ 150 intellectuals, technocrats and former Communists _ has an unfair advantage. Many opposition politicians have pointed to the Communist pasts of leading Front members and suggested it really is the Communist Party in disguise. As the thousands of pro-government demonstrators gathered Monday outside Front headquarters in Victory Square, three of Ceausescu's henchmen pleaded guilty in court to complicity in genocide. Former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, former Central Committee secretary Emil Bobu, and former Politburo member Manea Manescu, along with Ion Dinca, a former Politburo member who pleaded guilty Saturday, admitted supporting Ceausescu's order to shoot demonstrators at the revolution's outset. About the Sunday protest, Front member Silviu Brucan said it was organized by the Peasants Party, which was a dominant presence in Parliament before World War II and is thought to be the strongest opposition party now. Brucan, a ranking Communist who fell out with Ceausescu after criticizing his dictatorial methods, told reporters the rally was an attempt to overthrow the Front. ``Their shock troops came close to the main entrance of the building,'' he said. ``The whole event amounted to a putsch, a coup d'etat.'' Peasants Party spokesman Ion Ratiu said of Brucan's allegations: ``The whole thing was turned around to justify their actions today.'' He spoke at a news conference called in the hotel room he has called home since returning last week from decades of self-exile in Britain. Ratiu, a wealthy shipbuilder and real estate investor, accused the Front of staging Monday's demonstrations. Many protesters arrived at Victory Square in buses and trucks. Another pro-government rally formed around the building that houses Peasants Party headquarters, about two miles from the Front building, and at the nearby Liberal Party headquarters. ``We won't leave until you dissolve the party!'' demonstrators chanted as they forced their way into Liberal headquarters. Peasants Party leader Corneliu Coposu was evacuated building by soldiers in an armored car. No injuries were reported at either headquarters. Brucan said three people suffered stab wounds to the back during Sunday's protest, but that none was in serious condition. Brucan denied Ratiu's claim that the Front staged and paid for the demonstrations Monday, but several people outside the Peasants Party building indirectly suggested they had been under pressure to demonstrate. They said they worked in state factories and had joined their bosses at the pro-government rallies. A woman who would not give her name claimed the Sunday demonstration also was less than spontaneous. ``They were given dollars, cigarettes and lei,'' she said, referring to the Romanian currency. Both days of demonstrations violated a ban the Front has put on rallies that lack advance authorization from the police. The Front has decreed that rallies should not take place during working hours, but made no attempt to disperse Monday's pro-government demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Employees Start Back to Work While Union Dissidence Continues
DOC.TEXT: About one-third of the workers at a Ford Motor Co. plant outside Mexico City returned to their jobs Monday after a dispute between factions of a labor union sparked a 22-day shutdown, a Ford spokesman said. ``We expect to resume full operation probably by the end of this week,'' said the spokesman, Carlos Bandela. At least 150 thugs entered the plant Jan. 8, killing one worker and injuring nine following a dispute between union leader Hector Uriarte and workers who considered him pro-management. After the flareup, protesting unionists took over Ford installations and demanded Uriarte's ouster. Authorities issued an arrest warrant charging Uriarte with masterminding the violence. The company closed the plant, saying it could not guarantee the safety of its workers. The confrontation was the latest in a series of struggles between old-guard Mexican union bosses and employees who want more democratically run unions. The dissidents refused an offer of a referendum because union officials wouldn't agree to provisions for ensuring a fair vote, dissident leader Salvador Fuentes Reyes. Newspaper reports Monday said dissident union members were maintaining a picket outside the company installations in Cuautitlan, 15 miles north of Mexico City. ``It's an intra-union problem,'' said Bandala. ``It's almost resolved.'' Bandala said 1,200 union employees went back to work Monday and another 1,200 were expected to rejoin the labor force on Tuesday. The 3,800-member work force normally produces 450 cars and trucks a day. ``We lost 450 units a day for 22 days,'' Bandala said. He did not have an estimate how much the shutdown cost the company. He said the company is negotiating with Fidel Velazquez, head of the Mexican Workers Federation to which the Ford union belongs. Negotiations will determine whether union members will receive back pay for work time lost when the company closed the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Head Start, Education Department Would Each Get $500 Million More
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs for story listed on News Digest as AM-Budget-Education
DOC.TEXT: Head Start, the highly touted preschool program, would receive $500 million more under the 1991 budget proposal President Bush sent Congress on Monday. The 36 percent increase would be the largest one-time jump for the program since it began 24 years ago. Bush is asking Congress for $1.9 billion budget in multi-year spending authority for Head Start for fiscal 1991, enough to raise enrollment from 450,000 to 667,000 _ 70 percent of children aged 3 through 5 from low-income families. Bush's budget message to Congress called the program ``a key component in achieving the readiness of all children to start school.'' Besides giving preschoolers the social and learning skills to help them thrive in grade school, Head Start _ an agency of the Health and Human Services Department _ screens children for medical and dental problems and gives them two meals a day. The president seeks an identical $500 million in budget authority for the Education Department _ $24.6 billion compared to $24.1 billion this year. For fiscal 1991 alone, Bush asked Congress to approve a budget of $23.7 billion, a 6.2 percent increase over this year's $22.3 billion budget. The administration expects inflation this year to be 4.1 percent. The education budget targets $1.8 billion for initiatives and priority areas, including preschool, elementary and secondary education; mathematics and science education; dropout prevention; adult literacy, and drug education. For the Chapter One program, which provides special educational services for low-achieving elementary and secondary students, Bush requests a a $600 million increase to $5.1 billion. And for the Even Start program, which provides basic education srvices to parents together with their children aged 1 through 7, Bush seeks to double the multi-year budget authority to $48 million. In the area of education for the handicapped, the budget proposes spending $2.2 billion in fiscal 1991, a $500 million increase that would provide more services to 355,000 preschool children and would enhance the state programs that serve all infants up to the age of 2, and their families. ``The 1991 budget proposes the highest spending levels ever for programs to prepare children for school and for discretionary education programs,'' said the budget. However, Bush's budget requests cuts in certain student loan programs for college students, including a $600 million decrease in the Guaranteed Student Loan program, to $3.2 billion from $3.8 billion. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said that the student loan expenditures would fall in 1991 because of a projected decrease in interest rates. While Bush requests a $473 million increase in the Pell Grants program, which provides money to college student, over the current $4.8 billion, the budget seeks to cut the program next fall by $66.5 million. As a result, about 14,000 students receiving awards averaging $200 would lose their grants, and 1.3 million other students will have their stipends cut by $50. The budget also seeks budget authority of $230 million for math and science education, a 70 percent increase over what Congress provided in 1990; $239 million for adult literary, an increase of more than 25 percent; and a $50 million increase to $590 million for drug prevention and anti-abuse programs.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, 20 Injured in Kosovo Riots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with at least two killed, details; picks up 8th `Tensions were'
DOC.TEXT: At least two ethnic Albanians were killed and 20 seriously injured Monday in battles with police on the sixth day of unrest in troubled Kosovo province. Eight deaths have been confirmed since last Wednesday in the latest wave of violence between police and ethnic Albanians who demand free elections and the lifting of a 12-month-old state of emergency. The official news agency Tanjug said one protester was killed in Urosevac, 30 miles south of Pristina, capital of Kosovo, and the second died in Gnjilane, 6 miles south of the city. Tanjug said, without elaboration, that ``several policemen'' were injured in clashes with demonstrators throughout the province. Yugoslavia's collective state presidency and the government issued separate statements, both describing the Kosovo situation as ``extremely grave'' and promising ``resolute action'' against ethnic ``Albanian extremists and separatists.'' Riots began last year after the Serbian republic, of which Kosovo is an autonomous province, made constitutional changes to take tighter control. About 90 percent of the people in the impoverished southern province are ethnic Albanians, predominantly Moslem. The minority Christian Serbs say the Moslems in Kosovo, which is adjacent to Albania, want to force them out. Tensions were heightened Monday by the resumption of trial proceedings against 14 ethnic Albanians, including the province's former Communist leader, charged with inciting a wave of unrest last year that left at least 25 people dead. After a brief court session, the trial was rescheduled for Feb. 5, apparently because of the tense situation, the state Tanjug news agency said. In the city of Podujevo, about 30 miles north of Pristina, riot police lobbed tear gas and used a water cannon to disperse about 2,000 demonstrators. Tanjug said 8,000 people assembled at Drenica, 25 miles northwest of Pristina, for ``peaceful demonstrations.'' Hundreds of people lined up on the sidewalk of Pristina's main street to sign a petition calling for democratic elections, the lifting of martial law, and the release of all ethnic Albanian political prisoners. ``Only a democratic dialogue can solve the present problems of Kosovo, this is our contibution to its start'' said Yusuf Berisha, head of the Association of Sociologists and Philosophers. His group is part of the opposition coalition that drew up the petition. Berisha said 2,000 people had signed the petition in the first two hours. ``We expect more than one million people to sign it,'' said Zekeria Cana, secretary of the Kosovo human rights committee, another coalition member. Bogdan Kecman, a leader of Kosovo's minority Serbs, rejected any dialogue with the ethnic Albanian movements, however, describing them as ``terrorists and separatists.'' ``We demand that the state give us weapons to protect lives from the Albanians,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: FBI To Lose 400 Agents Under Bush Budget
DOC.TEXT: The FBI would lose 400 agents under President Bush's proposed 1991 fiscal-year budget, largely because of a new overtime law that will cost the bureau an extra $42 million, officials said Monday. Congress, never eager to cut the FBI budget, must approve the proposal. If Congress agrees, the reduction will be absorbed by the resignation or retirement of agents, usually between 450 and 480 each year, Deputy FBI Director Floyd Clarke said. But ``right now, our hiring program will have to be almost stopped in 1991'' if the budget is not changed, Clarke told reporters at a budget briefing. ``We just have to work harder,'' he added. ``We will get the job done.'' The cuts at the FBI contrast with proposed increase in the number of Drug Enforcement Administration agents from the current level of 3,167 to 3,547 in the next fiscal year. ``There is no question the drug war is receiving a very high priority,'' said Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer. ``It is the highest priority in the department.'' At the FBI, the manpower cut would mark only the second time in 11 years the bureau has reduced the number of agents on its payroll. The 1981 fiscal year budget cut 93 agents from the FBI's workforce. Proposed increases for such high-priority FBI efforts as organized crime and white-collar criminal investigations will partially offset the reductions in the bureau's workforce, which includes more than 10,000 agents. But even these sections of the FBI will experience net cuts in manpower despite Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's repeated vow to attack ``crime in the suites'' that has spawned fraud in the savings-and-loan and securities industries. ``Those priorities remain the attorney general's priorities,'' said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. But the FBI's ``job is to manage the operation within the budget provided them. We will be working with the bureau's management ... to ensure ... there will be no diminution of effort in the priority areas.'' The proposed $1.54 billion budget calls for a net loss of 41 agents assigned to white-collar investigations and six agents investigating organized crime, Clarke said. To meet deficit-reduction targets, $25.7 million will be cut from the FBI's budget, eliminating 227 agents. In addition, the FBI plans to cut 559 agents from its payroll to finance the higher costs of overtime under a new law enacted by Congress. Budget increases for such high-priority enforcement programs as white-collar and organized crime would add 388 agents to the FBI's authorized workforce, a net loss of 400 agents, according to budget documents. Paying FBI agents at higher overtime rates will cost the bureau an estimated $41.9 million in the 1991 fiscal year, according to budget documents. Under the new law, agents' overtime is paid at a rate pegged to their actual pay grade. Previously, all agents over Grade 10 earned overtime pegged to that salary grade. The change means that a senior agent will earn up to $15,000 in overtime each year instead of $6,000 or $7,000, Runkel said. Virtually every FBI agent earns overtime, and Runkel suggested that the bureau could better manage the time of agents to reduce this expense. The new overtime law, sponsored by Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, will cost the Justice Department more than $66 million. The figure includes overtime increases for Border Patrol, immigration and DEA agents. The Office of Management and Budget originally agreed to finance the additional overtime expenses but later forced the department to absorb that cost through program cuts, said a department source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls Aerostar Minivans
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Monday recalled about 116,000 of its 1986 and 1987 Aerostar minivans with optional captain's chairs because of possible seat-belt damage. Ford said webbing on the right front passenger seat belt may have become worn and, if so, would be replaced by dealers. In instances where webbing has not been worn, Ford will send consumers protective sleeves for the seat belts. The optional captain's chairs recline, have heavier arm rests and a higher back than standard seats. About 60 percent of all Aerostars made for those two years contained the optional seats and are subject to the recall, Ford spokesman Jim Trainor said.

DOC.HEAD: American University Officials Meet on Moslem-Christian Issue
DOC.TEXT: The president of Lebanon's American University of Beirut said Monday that a three-day meeting had eased tensions between campuses in Moslem west Beirut and the city's Christian sector. Students at the branch campus in Christian east Beirut have refused to attend classes for two weeks, alleging the university administration, based in the Moslem sector, was discriminating against them. University President Frederic P. Herter flew from New York to the port of Larnaca on the south coast of Cyprus to attend the meeting of administrators and faculty from both campuses. He denied reports that the east Beirut branch wanted to become an autonomous university, but conceded it had ``inadequate representation of ... interests on the main campus.'' Herter said faculty at the east Beirut branch want more students admitted, charging the administrators in west Beirut who review applications had discriminated against Christians. ``There have been no irregularities or prejudicial activities in the admissions on the part of the main campus,'' he said.
