Enrollment at the Christian branch dropped this year from about 1,000 to about 900. About one-fifth of the 5,100 students at the main campus also are Christian. Herter said it will ``take a lot of good will'' to resolve problems, with faculty ``on both sides willing to go back and forth'' between the two sectors of Beirut. The extension was set up in 1977 when continued fighting made it more and more hazardous to cross the Green Line that divides the city into sectarian zones. The U.S.-affiliated university has suffered heavily in Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war. Fighting last year forced the campus to close for six months. It reopened Oct. 9. Herter has not been to Beirut since 1985, when Moslem extremists began kidnappings of Westerners, including several faculty members at American University. Three have been killed. Two are still being held: acting dean of agriculture Thomas Sutherland, a Scottish-born U.S. citizen, and Brian Keenan, an English language professor who holds dual Irish and British nationality. Herter said it was ``good news'' that Sutherland, kidnapped in Beirut on June 9, 1985, had been reported alive and well by a London newspaper. The Sunday Correspondent said Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem sources in Beirut confirmed Sutherland was being held with Briton John McCarthy, a television journalist kidnapped on April 17, 1986. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants to Curb Farm Abuses
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pledged Monday to work with Congress to prevent some individual farm operations from collecting excessively large federal subsidies. ``Failure to do so will result in a loss of public confidence and support for the farm program,'' Bush said in his proposed budget for fiscal 1991. ``The taxpayers rightly expect these abuses to be curbed.'' The 1985 farm law limits the amount of income-support payments under various crop programs to $50,000 per person each year. The limit on total federal subsidies is $250,000 per year for each person. Those ceilings ``have been routinely exceeded'' because a ``person'' is defined as an individual or business entity, such as a corporation or trust, the budget document said. The report included diagrams of how illegal joint ventures using family members and other entities were set up to evade the $50,000 limit in 1988 and collect $912,089 in federal subsidies. Another example showed payments of $801,619. Both examples were included last year in reports by the Agriculture Department's inspector general. The budget document said that while reducing farm program costs is important, the Bush administration ``also is concerned about the distribution of those subsidy payments.'' ``A significant portion of benefits goes to larger, wealthy farmers,'' it said. ``In an era of limited resources, this is hard to justify. In 1987, for example, 30 percent of the $22.4 billion in commodity related subsidies went to 4 percent of the farmers who had average net cash incomes of more than $100,000 per year and net worths of nearly $850,000. ``This should be changed,'' Congress was told. ``One option for achieving savings of approximately one-half billion dollars would be to eliminate direct payments to farm operators with adjusted gross incomes of over $100,000 per year.'' The budget document added: ``This income level, after all, represents three times the average for an American family of four. Up to a billion dollars could be saved by withholding direct payments to farm entities with gross sales of $500,000 per year or more.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain Shelves Identity-Card Plan for Reducing Soccer Violence
DOC.TEXT: The government reversed itself Monday and shelved plans to use identity cards as a means of reducing violence at soccer games. The decision was announced after publication of a report on the overcrowding that led to 95 spectators being crushed to death last April at Hillsborough Stadium in Sheffield, northern England. Judge Peter Taylor of the Appeal Court prepared the report, which said using identity cards could cause crowding at turnstiles and more deaths by crushing. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had supported the card idea against a host of critics in politics and the soccer world. She indicated last week, however, that she would back down. The reversal was confirmed Monday when Home Secretary David Waddington told Parliament: ``The government have decided not to proceed with the establishment of a Football Membership Authority.'' The authority was supposed to control hooliganism by issuing cards to fans that would admit them through computerized turnstiles. The cards of known hooligans would have been invalidated. Among problems with the plan was the unresolved question of whether the courts or soccer authorities should decide who was a hooligan. Also, the entire system would have had to operate through a central computer register whose ability to handle up to 400,000 fans a week never was established. Waddington said the legislation would stay on the books for possible activation if other methods failed. Abandonment of the card plan removes the cornerstone of the government anti-hooliganism strategy while Britain is preparing to send teams from England and Scotland to the World Cup tournament in Italy this summer. Hooliganism devastated English soccer in the 1980s with riots, field invasions and street battles involving English fans abroad. In the worst incident, at a Brussels stadium in 1985, 39 people were killed when Liverpool fans went on a rampage. Judge Taylor recommended legislation to outlaw running onto soccer fields, throwing objects from the stands or shouting obscene or racist remarks. He also supported experimenting with surveillance of suspected hooligans by attaching electronic tracers to their legs, but expressed ``grave doubts about the feasibility of the national membership scheme and serious misgivings about its likely impact on safety.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Try to Recruit Troops, Kill 12
DOC.TEXT: The rebels killed 12 men from the southern region of Equatoria for refusing to join their ranks, an official newspaper reported Monday. There was no immediate comment from the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, and the report could not be independently verified. The daily Al-Inkaz Al-Watani also quoted the leader of the military government, Lt. Gen. Omar el-Bashir, as promising to defeat the southern rebels in the battlefield. The reported comments mark a change in strategy for el-Bashir and follow intense fighting in the 6-year-old civil war. After he overthrew the civilian government of Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi last summer, el-Bashir promised to end the civil war through peace negotiations. Al-Inkaz Al-Watani, quoting an unidentified official, said the rebels had tried to force the young men to join their ranks to replace troops lost in fighting. The paper said the men were killed between the towns of Yei and Tambura. The mainly Christian and animist rebels began their civil war in 1983, demanding economic reforms and greater autonomy from the Moslem-dominated government in the southern provinces of Bahr el-Ghazal, Upper Nile and Equatoria.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 25 Dead After Ferry Capsizes
DOC.TEXT: Salvage crews on Monday recovered a sunken ferry that collided with another vessel in heavy fog and capsized, killing at least 25 passengers and leaving another 75 missing, officials said. The accident Sunday was the fourth major river accident this month. Officials said 150 people were on board the ferry when the collision occurred on the River Lohali near Patuakhali, 90 miles south of Dhaka. Officials in Patuakhali said by telephone that a salvage ship using two cranes pulled three large portions of the ferry from the river. Police and fire brigade divers found 25 bodies floating in the river but none was found in the vessel, the officials said. The officials said that about 50 people on the roof of the ferry jumped into the river after the collision and swam ashore. They said most of the other passengers were inside the hull, however, and had shut the windows because of the thick fog. At least 33 other people have drowned and another 122 are missing and presumed dead in three similar accidents in the country earlier this month. Boats and ferries are the most popular means of transport in Bangladesh, a low-lying nation crisscrossed by hundreds of rivers. Accidents are common because many vessels frequently travel without lights at night.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Parliament Approves Five-Year Economy Plan
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran thanked Parliament and its oversight committee on Monday for reviewing and approving his $112 billion, five-year plan, Tehran television reported. The ambitious plan is designed to revive Iran's war-shattered economy. The Islamic Republic News Agency reported earlier this week that the 12-member Guardian Council, which screens legislation for conformity with Islam and the constitution, sent parts of the plan back to Parliament for amendment. IRNA did not say what portions of the plan were found objectionable, nor has it reported on its subsequent approval. Monday's broadcast quoted Rafsanjani as saying, ``I thank the Guardian Council and the Parliament for approving the five-year plan, and express the government's readiness to implement it in its entirety.'' Both the telecast and IRNA were monitored in Nicosia. It was not clear whether Rafsanjani was thanking the council for giving the go-ahead to parts of his plan, or whether the blocked portions of the plan had also been approved. He was speaking at an unusual meeting of Iran's top leadership that the broadcast said was called to plan celebrations for the upcoming 11th anniversary of the 1979 revolution that brought the clergy to power. The anniversary is Feb. 1-11. The 270-member Majlis, or parliament, passed Rafsanjani's plan after leading radicals blocking the plan bowed to a stern warning by Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The radicals, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, objected to Rafsanjani's call for foreign investment in reconstruction projects, and his plan to privatize inefficient government projects. Mohtashemi said this month he opposed any direct foreign investment in Iran. But Deputy Finance Minister Mandi Navvab said Saturday Iran welcomed foreign investment, and that Tehran's policies provided grounds for mutual cooperation with foreign companies, IRNA reported earlier. It quoted Navvab as saying foreigners were legally free to invest in joint ventures with Iranian partners as long as the foreign stake in each project did not exceed 49 percent. The Rafsanjani plan aims to triple non-oil exports in 1990-95 to $9 billion a year. Iran now relies on oil and gas exports for about 95 percent of its foreign exchange. The program would rebuild industries following the eight-year war with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Two for Navy Posts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate Gerald A. Cann to be assistant secretary of the Navy for research, development and acquisition, and Jacqueline E. Schafer to be assistant secretary of the Navy for installations and environment. Cann has been vice president of the undersea warfare center of General Dynamics Corp. since 1988. He was a deputy assistant secretary of the Navy from 1977 to 1985. Ms. Schafer has been a member of the President's Council on Environmental Quality since last year, and earlier was a regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

DOC.HEAD: There's Something Fishy About Advertisements in Takeover Battle
DOC.TEXT: A wood products giant has been promoting a takeover attempt involving 2.1 million acres in Maine with newspaper advertisements showing a smiling sportsman with a big fish. There's just one little problem: It's the wrong fish. Georgia-Pacific Corp. has been running the full-page ad for weeks in state newspapers to win the favor of residents in its battle to buy Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. for $3.8 billion. At least two experts say the fish held by the fisherman in the ad appears to be a striped bass, which lives in coastal waters and not in northern Maine, the location of the 2.1 million acres at stake in the takeover. ``I think it was a poor choice,'' state fisheries biologist Paul Johnson said Monday. ``If they're going to show somebody with a fish, they should show a fish from northern Maine.'' The advertisement is headlined ``The Maine Facts About Georgia-Pacific.'' At the state Department of Marine Resources in Augusta, the ad caught the attention of another fish expert. ``They're nowhere near the land that they're trying to acquire,'' said Lewis Flagg, director of the department's anadromous fish division. Anadromous fish, such as salmon and striped bass, return from the sea to rivers and streams to spawn. Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman Gail Smith, reached at her office at the company's Atlanta headquarters, said she had little information about the fish picture. ``It was taken somewhere in New England,'' Ms. Smith said. ``It's intended to be a representation of sporting activities.'' Johnson said from the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife office in Greenville that workers in his office began laughing at the ad when it first began running. He said he was surprised when it kept appearing over and over. ``It just finally grated on my nerves,'' said Johnson, who wrote a letter to the editor of the Maine Sunday Telegram. ``The striped bass is hardly an appropriate species to choose in promoting its quest to take over management responsibility for more than 2 million acres of inland forest and water resources,'' Johnson's letter said. ``Wouldn't a picture of a trout, togue or salmon provide a more persuasive demonstration of Georgia-Pacific's commitment to Maine?'' the letter said. The striped bass has been introduced in some freshwater bodies, particularly in the South, and Flagg said the state is trying to develop a population in the Kennebec River. Johnson said the fish will probably never swim in the waters of Great Northern's land. ``We're a long way from the coast,'' he said. ``They should just change that damn picture in their advertisement.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain Will Not Prosecute Moslem Leader on Incitement Charge
DOC.TEXT: The government will not prosecute a British Moslem leader who addressed a rally in October where crowds reportedly supported a death threat against writer Salman Rushdie, the lord chancellor said Monday. Rushdie's book ``The Satanic Verses'' is considered blasphemous by many Moslems and the author has been in hiding since last Feb. 14, when the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for Rushdie's death. At a rally Oct. 21 in Manchester in northern England, Dr. Kalim Siddiqui was quoted as asking participants to raise their hands in agreement with Khomeini's death sentence. In its report on the meeting, the Daily Telegraph said nearly all of the 250 Moslems present raised their hands. The director of public prosecutions, Allan Green, decided there was insufficient evidence to prosecute Siddiqui on charges of incitement to murder, said Lord McKay, the lord chancellor, who is the country's chief legal officer. Lord McKay made the announcement in answer to a legislator's question in the House of Commons. ``The Satanic Verses'' caused worldwide protests last year and the publisher has delayed plans for a paperback version because of continued Moslem death threats, The Observer newspaper reported Sunday. It said Rushdie was angered by the decision and ``is now claiming that his life will never be safe until the publishing cycle is completed.'' In a statement later Sunday, publisher Viking Penguin said: ``No firm date has been established, but even if it had it would not be the company's policy to reveal such information for obvious security reasons.'' A Viking Penguin spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, denied there was animosity between the publisher and Rushdie. The Observer, quoting an unidentified company source, said the publishers will not produce the paperback as long as there is risk to its staff, bookshops or the public. The hardcover edition of ``The Satanic Verses'' has become an international bestseller, with sales of more than 1 million copies, despite being banned in more than 20 countries. It was published in fall 1988.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Says Fuel Problems For Colombia Jet Were Relayed
DOC.TEXT: Avianca Flight 52's declaration of a fuel shortage was relayed from regional traffic controllers to controllers handling its approach, but the urgency of the warning wasn't clear, authorities said Monday. The controllers were not told by the pilot that there was an emergency, Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Fred Farrar said from Washington. Farrar said the word used was ``priority,'' which ``has no particular meaning in air traffic control. If there is an emergency, you use the `word emergency.''' The FAA report conflicts with information provided Sunday night by the National Transportation Safety Board, which said the regional controllers had not relayed word of the fuel shortage to the local controllers. The Boeing 707 fell powerless into a secluded neighborhood of Cove Neck on New York's Long Island on Thursday night, killing 73 of 159 people aboard, including the cockpit crew. More than 20 survivors remained hospitalized in critical condition Monday. Inspection of the crash site on a wooded hillside was nearly complete Monday, and investigators focused on conversations of the crew and controllers. The investigators said tapes show the crew warned a regional control center that it was low on fuel about 45 minutes before the crash, as it was circling over New Jersey in a holding pattern. The jet flew in three weather-related holding patterns totaling nearly 90 minutes along the East Coast as it flew from Colombia to New York City's John F. Kennedy Airport. ``We think we may need priority,'' a crew member told the control center about 8:45 p.m., according to preliminary transcripts, Farrar said Monday. A regional controller replied, ``How long can you hold before you have to go to your alternate?'' The alternate landing site was Boston. ``Wait a minute,'' the cockpit replied, pausing apparently to check, the FAA said. ``We can hold five minutes.'' Shortly thereafter, the cockpit said its alternate site was ``Boston. I can't make it.'' At that time, the FAA said, the regional controller telephoned the control center that handles approaches and departures for Kennedy. The regional controller said Avianca 52 had just come out of the holding area ``and can only do five more minutes of hold. Can you take him now?'' The local control replied, ``Slow him to 180 knots and I will take him.'' After the call, the plane was released to Kennedy airport and it made a landing attempt 37 minutes later through rain and fog, but aborted the approach because it was coming in too steeply, authorities said. Investigators say the Avianca crew agreed to a controller's suggestion that the plane loop back over Long Island and come in for a second attempt. It did so, the cockpit saying twice it was low on fuel, but the engines soon quit and the plane crashed. Investigators are looking at the fuel shortage as a cause. NTSB investigators Monday were interviewing regional controllers and Kennedy tower controllers to determine the extent of their knowledge of the fuel problems, and what was done about it. Asked about the conflicting reports of what information was relayed between controllers, NTSB spokesman Mike Benson said the phone message from the regional center ``may not fully reflect what went on. There may be more to that conversation. It may need to be judged in a fuller context.'' The FAA's duties include the nation's air traffic controllers. The NTSB investigates transporation accidents. The FAA and the NTSB, as well as the controllers' association, stressed Monday that Avianca's message was not urgent and did not use the word ``emergency,'' which would have brought the plane quickly back to Kennedy and cleared the way for a second landing attempt. FAA standards for flight emergencies spell out instructions to pilots. ``Common sense and good judgment will determine the extent of assistance to be given in minimum fuel situations,'' the FAA instructions say. ``If, at any time, the remaining usable fuel supply suggests the need for traffic priority to ensure a safe landing, the pilot should declare an emergency and report fuel remaining in minutes.'' The words ``emergency'' or ``minimum fuel,'' according to R. Steve Bell, president of the Air Traffic Controllers Association, ``would have triggered an emergency response by controllers. Stating that you are low on fuel does not imply an immediate problem.'' In Washington, Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner said that while he could not predict the outcome of the investigation, he does not believe a lack of a sufficient number of air traffic controllers was to blame. ``You should not prejudge an investigation before all of the people are interviewed and all of the facts are in. But I believe that when the evidence is all in, staffing will not be a factor,'' Skinner said, declining to answer further questions.

DOC.HEAD: Some Journalists Say Panama's Press Still Not Free
DOC.TEXT: Veteran journalists in Panama are only half joking when they say Panama still has no opposition news media, even after the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Noriega had suppressed virtually all opposition outlets. Last week, officials of the Inter American Press Association said freedom of expression had ``improved very much'' since the U.S. invasion in December. Also, however, the IAPA officials expressed concern about 10 radio and two television stations taken over by the government and the arrests of journalists connected with the old regime. Members of the committee, led by Ed Seaton of Seaton Group, said the government assured them the cases ``would be dealt with in accordance with Panamanian law.'' In a country where the concept of freedom of the press has been subjective, the old regime's collapse resulted in public recriminations and confusing legal situations regarding old and new media. There was little opposition to Noriega, and not one media outlet now criticizes the U.S. invasion. La Estrella, owned by a close friend of Noriega, now supports President Guillermo Endara's government as strongly as it did the dictator. La Prensa, which Noriega closed, resumed publication earlier this month and supports the new government. El Siglo reopened and attacked everyone and everything connected with the old regime, especially La Estrella. It called Maj. Gen. Henry Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army South, the most popular man in Panama. Another publishing company, Panama America, was taken over 21 years ago when the government moved in during disputes between minority and majority stockholders. After the invasion, the old majority owners returned, took over the modernized facilities and started publishing two papers, Critica Libre and Panama America. The immediate losers were 68 journalists who worked for the pro-Noriega newspapers Critica, Matutino and La Republica. They seek either reinstatment or severance pay, but the publishers say the workers are not and never have been employees of Panama America. ``We are professional journalists,'' said Eva Montillo, former assistant editor of La Republica. ``We did our job as journalists. The newspaper's policy or ideology is something else.'' Aristides Calvo, editor in chief of Editora Renovacion, as the company was called in the Noriega years, is the only journalist still detained by the new government. Complaints have been filed against him that include extortion and ``apology for crime.'' Endara's government has taken custody of at least 10 radio stations and two television stations owned by people believed to have been connected with Noriega. Most continue operating. Government officials say they were taken over so investigations could determine whether public funds were used to buy them. Some may have to be returned, including the largest television station, Channel 2. Its owners include former pro-Noriega presidential candidate Carlos Duque and Eduardo Diaz Herrera, former second-in-command of the Panamanian Defense Forces. Diaz Herrera broke with Noriega in mid-1987, accusing the general of electoral fraud, drug trafficking and other crimes. Less clear is the case of Channel 5, which seemed to belong to whoever was president. It first was owned by former President Ricardo De La Espriella, whom Noriega forced to resign. When Noriega made Eric Arturo Delvalle president, Delvalle also got control of Channel 5. When Noriega had Delvalle dumped, the television station became the property of the government agency that had financed its purchase. Panama America may become a serious headache for the new government, both in ownership and labor problems. ``We will have to face it sooner or later,'' a government official said privately. ``The old group left, scared by the U.S. Army. It was a de facto situation. There are no legal documents involved.'' Majority stockholders sued the government when their facilities were taken over and they kept the case open 21 years. They told IAPA they will go to the Supreme Court to clear up the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges Against Exxon Valdez Skipper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT quote to reflect that it partial quote; SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT that prospective jurors will be considered, sted questioned.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AG2,AG3
DOC.TEXT: Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood's attorneys on Monday lost another bid to have charges against him dismissed on the opening day of his trial in the nation's worst oil spill. ``... I feel that this show should not go on, at least not here,'' Hazelwood attorney Dick Madson said in arguing that the New York seaman should have been charged under federal rather than state law. Hazelwood, 43, was the captain of the Exxon Valdez when the tanker ran aground March 24, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. He faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted on all counts, he faces up to seven years and three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone denied Madson's motion for dismissal of the charges, saying it lacked substance. Earlier defense efforts to get the indictment against Hazelwood dismissed also failed. Madson said federal law prevails to guarantee consistent rules from port to port regardless of which state a vessel is in. ``Federal laws and regulations have covered this field for 200 years and there's a good reason for it,'' he said. Hazelwood sat in the courtroom as Johnstone dealt with preliminary matters for 90 minutes before instructing attorneys to spend the rest of the day examining standard, three-page questionnaires completed by prospective jurors. Johnstone said he expects jury selection to take less than the two weeks attorneys in the case predicted. Still pending is a defense motion to keep from evidence the results of a blood-alcohol test that Hazelwood failed about 10 hours after the tanker struck Bligh Reef and began spilling oil in early-morning darkness. The spill blackened shores and killed wildlife, resulting in what Exxon Corp. calculated was a $2 billion cleanup. Some state officials and others say the work is not over and should continue this spring and summer. About 90 people have been summoned as candidates for the 12-member jury. The questionnaire for jurors includes questions about experience with vessels, work in the oil and fishing industries, familiarity with the oil spill and personal economic loss or gain tied to the spill. The trial is expected to last more than six weeks. Defense attorneys and prosecutors have said each side will need about three weeks to present its case. Hazelwood originally was scheduled for an October trial in Valdez, the port from which the tanker sailed a few hours before the crash. But the trial for the Huntington, N.Y., seaman was moved to Anchorage to increase the chance of a fair proceeding and to take advantage of a larger jury pool and facilities. About 30 prospective jurors a day will be considered, the judge said. A larger number will be screened if a panel of 12 plus alternates cannot be found from the pool of 90. Nearly all of the people in the courtroom Monday were from the news media. Johnstone's first business of the day was a briefing for reporters, photographers and camera crews concerning courtroom rules.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Gets Assurances of Panamanian Drug-Money Reform
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf pvs, bgng: Quayle said, to UPDATE with phone call to Bush, more details
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle won assurances Monday that Panama will reform its banking practices to deter drug-money laundering, but public details were few and Panama's president suggested any changes would be ``not that profound.'' Quayle later flew to Jamaica as he wound up a three-country tour to Latin America and the Caribbean, during which leaders in the region criticized the U.S. invasion of Panama and pressed for withdrawal of American troops. Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley said his government is not ready to agree to U.S. urging to recognize the Panamanian government of Guillermo Endara. Manley also complained that potential U.S. cuts in aid will hinder his nation's ability to fight illegal drugs. In Panama City, Endara stood beside Quayle at a news conference and declared that Panama ``cannot continue to be a center for narco dollars.'' But Endara, facing opposition from Panama's bankers, also said, ``We don't know yet what exact changes will have to be made in our banking laws. We're working on that now.'' Endara, who was installed as president at the start of the U.S. military strike that ousted Manuel Antonio Noriega, said that some of what the Bush administration wants can be accomplished simply by enforcing current laws. During Noriega's rule, Panamanian banks were accused by U.S. authorities of serving as centers helping traffickers ``launder'' drug money _ sanctioning transactions that made it difficult to track the money. Quayle said he was impressed with Endara's willingness ``to move in a different direction ... where we will be able to detect this type of activity much easier than before.'' Quayle, who arrived back in Washington on Monday night, told reporters en route from Jamaica that he had telephoned President Bush with a ``very upbeat'' report on the trip. He said that while Venezuela and Jamaica both insist on some sort of election in Panama before they're willing to recognize the Endara government, ``as far as we're concerned he's legitimized now.'' Quayle said the election last May 7 that was invalidated by Noriega was won fairly by Endara. ``It was a free and fair election.'' However, he said it's up to the new Panama government to decide whether it will hold new elections. The vice president's talks with the Endara government produced agreement on a need for stricter enforcement, for stronger requirements for banks to report large deposits, and for negotiations on exchanging tax information concerning people under investigation in drug cases, said a senior official traveling with Quayle. ``I don't think that the bankers are opposing just any changes,'' Endara told reporters. ``The bankers want changes that are reasonable and will not duly change the banking environment. They know that Panama cannot continue to be a center for narco dollars.'' Jamaica was the last stop of Quayle's three-day trip that focused on regional ramifications of the Dec. 20 U.S. military invasion of Panama. Manley said the vice president's visit did not change his government's opposition to the military action. Although Jamaica strongly opposed Noriega, Manley said, ``We also feel very strongly about the principles of sovereignty that are involved in the invasion of any country by another.'' ``Although we have an understanding of what led to the action, we could not agree with it,'' he told reporters in a joint news conference with Quayle. ``We are good friends but friends do not always agree,'' he said of U.S.-Jamaica relations. Jamaica is worried about pending cuts in U.S. economic support because ``if there is a cut at all it makes it that much harder to fight the war on drugs,'' Manley said. He previously has complained that the United States planned to cut all of Jamaica's $25 million in economic support money, which was part of a total $124 million aid package in 1989. Quayle assured him, ``We simply are not going to stand by and allow a zeroing out of the economic support funds. ``We take that very seriously,'' he said about the potential impact on anti-drug efforts. Quayle noted that a majority of the foreign aid money is earmarked for a handful of countries. He said the administration wants Congress to provide more flexibility in distributing the remaining money. After his talks with six heads of state at Saturday's presidential inauguration in Honduras and with the Panamanian leaders, Quayle was receptive to the idea of more aid to the beleaguered countries of the region, one aide said. Panama had sought $2 billion to help it recover from the invasion and the economic stranglehold of two years of U.S. sanctions against Noriega's regime. President Bush last week said he was prepared to supply Panama with half that amount. Before leaving Panama City, Quayle took a driving tour of the impoverished Chorrillo neighborhood. Several blocks were leveled by fire and bombing during the U.S. attack, including the headquarters of Noriega's Panamanian Defense Force. As his motorcade slowly drove by the area, onlookers gathered in groups and peered out windows, watching in stony silence. Their reaction was in stark contrast to the enthusiastic cheering Sunday from a well-dressed congregation at a Roman Catholic church Quayle attended in another neighborhood.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Step Up Protests of Soviet Jewish Emigration to Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 6 grafs after 4th, ``We strongly ... UPDATING with Israeli reaction. Picks up 5th, `Israeli officials ... with minor editing to trim and conform.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein blamed the United States on Monday for an influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, an increase that Arab officials fear will drive Palestinians out of the Israeli-occupied territories. The Soviet Union also drew Arab fire, as newspapers echoed PLO chief Yasser Arafat's call Saturday for Moscow to reverse itself and curtail migration of its Jews to Israel. The Kremlin on Monday blasted the Israeli government's decision to settle Soviet emigres in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and said the move complicates plans to allow even more Soviet Jews to emigrate. ``We strongly condemn endangering Soviet emigres by using them to crowd Palestinians out of their own land,'' said the Soviet statement, which was reported by the official Tass news agency. ``This policy reveals plans to create a `Greater Israel' above all at the expense of the Palestinian people.'' In Jerusalem, spokesman Yosef Amihud of the Israeli Foreign Ministry attacked the Soviet statement as having ``many irregularities concerning the Israeli position'' and added: ``As for the insinuations that Israel was using the Jews coming out of the Soviet Union to crowd Palestinians out of their own land, this has no base. ``The government of Israel has no policy that determines where an immigrant will live and every immigrant is free to choose where he will live.'' Amihud said Moscow had not followed up an agreement reached with Israel a year ago in Cairo that teams of experts from the two countries meet. He said ``Israel hopes that the Soviet Union will use its influence on Arab nations ... (to) answer the Israel peace plan'' and that the Soviets pursue ``freedom of entrance and exit.'' Immigration activists in Jerusalem asked Monday for an emergency evacuation of more Soviet Jews, who they said are endangered by anti-Semitism and possible pogroms. Israeli officials have predicted 300,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in Israel within three years under relaxed Soviet emigration procedures. Speaking in Cairo, Saddam said the influx is causing ``plain and serious harm'' to the Palestinians. ``We regard the United States as a participant in this immigration because of its policies,'' said Saddam, standing beside President Hosni Mubarak, whose Egypt is the only Arab country at peace with Israel and is among Washington's closest Arab friends. ``If the United States were preventing nationals of other countries from settling in it, we would say that this is a general practice,'' he said. ``But for the United States to let in all kinds of immigrants and prevent only Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union and East European countries, this can only mean that it is opening only one door to them. Namely, Israel's door.'' The United States has a country-by-country quota for immigrants, with an annual global total of 270,000. Until the Soviet Union removed many of the restrictions on potential emigrants, the U.S. quota never was filled. Its 50,000 quota for the fiscal year ending in June, much higher than previously, was filled by a backlog from last year and as many as 400,000 more are expected to apply for refugee status in the coming year. In Tunisia, the Arab League's secretary-general, Chedli Klibi, on Monday discussed Jewish immigration with Robert H. Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunis and Washington's designated channel for dialogue with the PLO. Details were not revealed. Arafat and other Arab leaders say settling Soviet and other immigrants in the Israeli-occupied lands would make a Middle East peace settlement more difficult, if not impossible. Israel took the two territories from Egypt and Jordan following the 1967 Middle East War. If hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants settled there, the Arabs fear Israel would be reluctant to relinquish any part of the territories the PLO want as a Palestinian state in confederation with Jordan. About 70,000 Jews live in the West Bank and Gaza, home to about 1.7 million Palestinians. The United Arab Emirates' newspaper Al-Bayan quoted Farouk Kaddoumi, head of the PLO's political department, as saying Arab foreign ministers will meet Feb. 5 in Tunisia. He said their subject will be whether to approach Soviet and East European officials to stop their Jews from going to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Urge Prosecutors to Keep Molestation Case Alive
DOC.TEXT: Parents who refuse to accept a jury's innocent verdicts in the McMartin preschool child molestation trial urged prosecutors Monday to keep the case alive. Parent Robert Currie failed as promised to produce new evidence during two news conferences that drew about 50 reporters to this beachside community that was the focal point of the nation's longest, most expensive criminal trial. Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted Jan. 18 of 52 child molestation charges in connection with the now-defunct McMartin Pre-School. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other counts against Raymond Buckey. In announcing the news conferences, Currie sent out notices stating, among other things, that he would display hundreds of police reports. Instead, he appeared at the first news conference outside the Manhattan Beach Police Department and read a child's graphic descriptions of a molestation that allegedly occurred in 1985 _ claims similar to those rejected by the jury during the trial. As he stood on the street surrounded by news cameras, a driver passing by shouted ``Kill Buckey!'' Asked why he had called the news conference, Currie said, ``To show the people and to show the jury they have made a mistake.'' He said he wanted to bring pressure on District Attorney Ira Reiner to refile the 13 undecided molestation charges against Raymond Buckey. A decision on that matter is to be announced Wednesday. Currie's child was not a complaining witness in the trial, although he alleges the boy was molested. At the second news conference, a mother, Leslie Floberg, told reporters she believes her son was molested six years ago at a preschool at St. Cross Episcopal Church in nearby Hermosa Beach. That preschool is now closed. Church officials were questioned during the McMartin investigation because one of the alleged victims said he was taken to a church, where animal sacrifices were held. No charges, however, were ever filed against church officials or workers, though three of the church's priests have since resigned. The church's volunteer youth minister was arrested recently on sex abuse charges. The youth minister has since been fired by St. Cross. ``I came because the media was depicting St. Cross as a victim of the McMartin case,'' Mrs. Floberg said. ``There are things going on here that need to be questioned. We have a moral responsibility.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Offers to Mediate Israel, Palestinians; Invites Arafat, Dalai
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel on Monday offered to mediate peace talks between Israel and Palestinian leaders, and invited PLO chief Yasser Arafat to visit Prague, his spokesman said. Israeli vice premier Shimon Peres visited Prague Jan. 21 to discuss restoration of diplomatic ties broken off in the 1967 Mideast War, and a future visit by Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. Last Thursday, Havel received the PLO ambassador to Prague, Samil Abdul Fattah, and spoke of Czechoslovaks seeking peace in the Middle East. ``Czechoslovakia could play the role of a mediator in the Israeli-Palestinian dialogue, should the two sides so wish,'' Havel's spokesman Michael Zantovsky quoted the president as saying. Havel received the Palestine Liberation Organization's ambassador to Prague, Samil Abdul Fattah, last week. Zantovsky said the president ``supported the right of the Palestinian people to their own home,'' while expressing ``understanding for Israeli anxiety based on thousands of years of painful experience of the Jewish nation.'' After Zantovsky spoke to a news conference, Havel himself appeared. One reporter asked whether his latest diplomatic initiative was not of a ``messianic nature.'' Havel said he hoped to make up for decades of Czechoslovak passivity in the Middle East. Czechoslovakia was an active early supporter of Israel, but the past two decades adopted a foreign policy style that Havel and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier, close friends and former dissidents, are now activating. ``If somebody makes an offer to two countries involved in years of tragic war, to help, and yet makes the impression of a Messiah, than you can call it that,'' Havel commented. ``We are all responsible for the situation in the world. For years we (Czechoslovakia) have been doing nothing. We were a mere passive colony,'' he commented. Zantovsky said Havel invited Arafat to visit Czechoslovakia, but gave no date. The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, is due to visit Czechoslovakia Feb. 2-6 at Havel's personal invitation, a move that drew strong Chinese reaction. ``I have explained to the Chinese ambassador that the Dalai Lama's visit to Czechoslovakia is of a private nature, I wanted to invite him a long time ago when I was not yet a president,'' Havel said. ``I want to meditate with him.'' ``If the Chinese republic is not satisfied with this explanation, I am sorry. The Dalai Lama is coming,'' Havel added.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes During Cruise Missile Test; Report Says Pilot Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 3rd graf `The crash' to UPDATE with completion of missile test. Picks up 4th, The Canadian ... with minor editing to conform
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian Forces fighter jet that was to intercept a U.S. cruise missile crashed shortly after takeoff on Monday, military officials said. CBC-TV reported the single-seat CF-18 plane exploded in flight and the pilot was killed. However, Maj. Jan Martinsen, spokesman for the Cold Lake base, said the pilot's fate was unknown. The crash occurred near Inuvik, Northwest Territories, shortly after the plane took off at 8:02 a.m., Martinsen said. The cruise flight was not affected and the cigar-shaped missile, about the length of a full-size car, landed on schedule almost four hours later on the Primrose Lake air weapons range surrounding Cold Lake. It traveled 1,365 miles from the Beaufort Sea, over the Mackenzie Valley, British Columbia and Alberta to Primrose, Martinsen said. She said the cause of the CF-18 crash is not known. ``That's for a board of inquiry to determine,'' she added. The Canadian Press identified the pilot as Capt. Richard Corver of Toronto, quoting Martinsen as saying Corver had flown CF-18 fighter planes for three years. Searchers at the site found no sign of the pilot near the fuselage, which was scattered over a snow-covered area 3 miles east of the airport runway at Inuvik, in the Northwest Territories. ``This investigation will be very difficult because it's dark, it's very cold and it's a very difficult area to reach,'' said Martinsen. The only access to the area is by helicopter or snowmobile. The CF-18 was part of the Canadian Forces team participating in the 15th test of the cruise missile over Canada. The aircraft and other planes were to hunt down and simulate shooting the missile. This was the first time a fighter plane had crashed in testing of the cruise missile. The unarmed U.S. cruise missile was released from a B-52 bomber over the Canadian Arctic. The test was the 15th over Canada's northwest since the Canadian and U.S. governments signed an agreement in 1983. The CF-18s were included in the military exercises for the first time last year. Residents of Inuvik said the crash area is dotted with lakes and lightly wooded with spruce and pine trees. Temperatures in the area hover around 30 degrees below zero.

DOC.HEAD: Sports Brightens Often Grim Year for Northern Californians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Led by ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with parade, color; picks up 5th graf, `The 49ers ...' A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Back-to-back Super Bowl victories and a San Francisco Bay area World Series provide bright but bittersweet highlights for Northern Californians bowed under by a deadly earthquake and string of ghastly crimes. Names in the news in the past year included a teamload of sports stars and a busload of bad guys and alleged bad guys who share Page One in local papers. While the San Francisco 49ers football team returned from New Orleans on Monday after destroying the Denver Broncos 55-10, Mayor Art Agnos awaited receipt of a dead fish. The Rocky Mountain trout isn't a threat, it's the centerpiece of a dinner Agnos won in a Super Bowl bet with the mayor of Denver. Led by quarterback Joe Montana, San Francisco took the Super Bowl trophy home for the fourth time as the National Football League's first repeat champion in a decade. The team made a triumphant return to the city Monday in a downtown victory parade attended by 75,000 fans. Fans cheered ``Go Niners!'' and sounded red plastic horns as Montana, coach George Seifert, team owner Eddie DeBartolo and other players rode by in flashy convertibles. The 49ers are being hailed as the ``team of the decades'' _ the '80s and the '90s _ and the symbol of the region's resilience after a year of disasters left it rattled but not ruined. ``It helped tremendously,'' Leo Bigley, 30, said of the 49ers victory. ``The quake happened right during the football and baseball seasons and took the spirit out of it. When the Niners came back, it wasn't hysteria but all felt a commitment to this as a way to show we can rebuild.'' Or as San Francisco Examiner columnist Rob Morse wrote, ``The 49ers once again showed kinky San Francisco that dominance can be thrilling.'' Not far from the parade route, crews worked to repair damage on Marina Boulevard caused by the Oct. 17 earthquake that destroyed stylish homes, sparked fires and knocked out utility service for weeks. Thousands were left homeless and 67 people died in the 7.1 shudder centered in the Santa Cruz Mountains. Three months later, families still live in shelters from the farming community of Watsonville to San Francisco. Alternative routes of transportation had to be found for those attending the remaining World Series baseball games between the San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics in October. The quake struck as Game 3 was about to begin at San Francisco's Candlestick Park. The Athletics won the series, 4-0. Giants' pitcher Dave Dravecky became a hero without even playing. Dravecky returned to baseball last year after surgery to remove a malignant tumor from his left arm. After a dramatic first-game-back victory, the weakened bone snapped as he won his second post-operation start. Northern California children were the focus of other news in 1989. Last January a man clad in military fatigues and armed with an Chinese assault rifle killed five children and wounded 30 other students and one teacher when he opened fire at Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton, 75 miles east of San Francisco. He then shot and killed himself. Authorities said Patrick Purdy, 24, had acted out a hatred for minorities and chose children because of their vulnerability. Children also were among the alleged victims of Ramon Salcido, charged with the slayings of his wife, two daughters and four others during a bloody rampage last April in the scenic wine country north of San Francisco. A widespread manhunt ended with Salcido's arrest in Mexico. Death also was the fate of former Black Panther leader Huey Newton, shot in East Oakland in August by a man police say was trying to win favor with a drug-dealing street gang.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Promises to Free All Political Prisoners
LaserPhoto MGA-1
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega Monday promised to free more than 1,000 political and rebel prisoners before next month's national elections. ``Tomorrow I will ask the National Assembly to release all these prisoners,'' Ortega said. His announcement was widely seen as a move to upstage his main opponent in the presidential race, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the candidate of the 14-party United National Opposition coalition, or UNO. She has drawn enthusiastic responses at rallies for promising to free all political prisoners if she wins the election, viewed as a referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule. The Permanent Commission on Human Rights, a private Nicaraguan organization, says there are currently more than 4,000 political prisoners. Ortega announced his plans after meeting with Nicaragua's 11 Roman Catholic bishops, and he said he was releasing the prisoners at the request of Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the archbishop of Managua. ``We, as pastors, are interested in reconciliating men with God and reconciliating men among each other,'' said Obando y Bravo, a leading critic of Ortega's leftist Sandinista government. ``We are happy, therefore, that we are advancing along these lines, creating a climate of peace.'' Ortega, who is seeking a second six-year term in the Feb. 25 elections, also urged the U.S.-supported Contra rebels to release hundreds of people the government claims they have kidnapped. ``I think this would be a good time for those kidnapped to be set free, because the mothers of those abducted suffer as much as the mothers of those imprisoned,'' Ortega said. He said the political and rebel prisoners he has agreed to free include 39 former members of the National Guard of dictator Anastasio Somoza, who was overthrown by the Sandinistas in 1979, and about 1,000 others imprisoned on charges of being Contras. The Sandinista-dominated National Assembly is expected to give rubber-stamp approval to Ortega's request. Last March, the government released 1,984 former National Guardsmen who had been jailed since the Sandinistas took power. The government kept 39 guardsmen it considered ``highly dangerous'' in prison, a decision that has been the source of repeated complaints by human rights groups and the men's families. Ortega, who has lately been courting the religious community, also said he will speak with his brother, Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, and Interior Minister Tomas Borge about allowing priests to hold religious services at prisons and in military barracks. ``The idea is that the priests can go to the barracks and that the soldiers and everyone else who would like to can receive ministrations from the priests,'' Ortega said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Notified on Arms Sales
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf pvs, bgng: In a, to CORRECT TWO to TOW
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has told Congress it intends to sell Egypt some $488 million _ and Israel some $285 million _ in AH-64 Apache attack helicopters, missiles and support equipment, the Pentagon announced on Monday. The Egyptian purchase includes 26 gunships, 492 Hellfire missiles, other ammunition, spare equipment, training and support services, the statement said. The Israeli purchase includes 19 gunships, 539 missiles, spare and repair parts, training and other support services, the statement said. The choppers are designed primarily as anti-tank weapons, and are produced by McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co., Mesa, Ariz. The sales will not affect ``the basic military balance in the region,'' the statement said. In a separate statement, the Pentagon said the administration has also informed Congress it intends to sell Pakistan 10 AF-1F Cobra attack helicopters including the TOW missile system at a cost of $89 million. The sale also includes spare engines and logistics support, the statement said. The choppers provide ``a modest increase in the Pakistan Army's air mobile anti-tank capability,'' the statement said. The prime contractor is Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc., of Fort Worth, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in Multi-Vehicle Crash on Lagos Expressway
DOC.TEXT: A gravel truck attempting to pass a bus collided head-on with a car coming from the other direction, causing a multi-vehicle accident that left 20 people dead, police said Monday. Jewelry, money and bodies littered the scene of Sunday's accident on a busy expressway on the outskirts of Lagos, the authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel, East Germany Open Talks on Diplomatic Ties
DOC.TEXT: Israeli and East German diplomats began talks Monday on opening diplomatic relations, prevented for 40 years by the shadow of the Nazi Holocaust, said Amos Ganor, the Israeli ambassador in Denmark. Neither side would say where the talks were being held in the Danish capital or how long they would go on. Ganor said the talks touched on Israel's insistence that East Germany accept part of the moral responsibility for the murder of 6 million Jews by the Nazis during World War II, an issue that blocked building of formal relations. ``But the talks are about more than just diplomatic relations and reparations' for survivors of the Holocaust,'' Ganor said, without elaborating. An East German spokesman, reading a brief statement following the talks, said the meeting ``was conducted in a businesslike atmosphere'' and would resume Tuesday. East Germany was the only Soviet bloc country not to establish ties with Israel after the Jewish state gained its independence in 1948. All except Romania severed the ties after the 1967 Middle East war. West Germany accepted blame for the Holocaust and paid billions of dollars in reparations to Israel and to individual survivors. East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow said Friday that, following the ouster of the previous Communist regime, his country was ready to discuss relations with Israel and open up the issue of reparations. Ganor said East Germany's movement toward democracy gave impetus to the talks. Michael Shiloh headed the Israeli delegation and Reiner Neumann represented East Germany. Both are Foreign Ministry officials. Hungary renewed ties with Israel last September. The Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland have moved recently toward repairing relations with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony: Ceausescu Ordered Defense Minister Killed
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dictator Nicolae Ceausescu ordered the defense minister killed for opposing his order to shoot protesters during last month's revolution, a top member of the deposed Communist government told a military tribunal Monday. Emil Bobu's disclosure came as he, former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu and Manea Manescu _ vice president of the State Council under Ceausescu _ pleaded guilty to charges of complicity to genocide. They face up to 30 years at hard labor if convicted in the first of a series of trials of top Ceausescu henchmen. Ceausescu told an emergency Politburo meeting on Dec. 22 that Defense Minister Vasile Milea was a traitor and had committed suicide. Hours later, he and his wife fled Bucharest when the army sided with protesters in the popular uprising. The Ceausescus were executed Christmas Day after they were convicted at a secret military trial of genocide and ruining the national economy. That tribunal also blamed the Ceausescus for about about 60,000 deaths during the dictator's 24-year rule. Recalling the final Politburo meeting, Bobu said: ``My intimate opinion is that the organization of the assassination of Gen. Milea was made by the traitor Ceausescu.'' Bobu said Ceausescu earlier had threatened to put Milea ``in front of a firing squad'' because he tried to oppose an order to shoot demonstrators in the western city of Timisoara, where the revolution began Dec. 15. Milea was ``extremely outraged'' at the order, said Bobu, No. 3 in Ceausescu's government and the former secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee. On Saturday, former Politburo member Ion Dinca, the fourth person on trial, testified that Milea told Ceausescu on Dec. 17 that he had reviewed military regulations and ``didn't find anywhere that the armed forces should shoot the people.'' The testimony did not indicate who would have killed Milea. Dinca said Monday that he believed all four defendants agreed with Ceausescu's orders to shoot because they wanted to save their positions. Postelnicu denied he had control over the hated Securitate secret police force, which he said was personally commanded by Mrs. Ceausescu ``and partially by Ceausescu.'' Postelnicu, speaking forcefully, said Ceausescu wanted to get rid of him and Milea because the armed forces had not used tanks and ammunition against the Timisoara demonstrators. He said four Politburo members opposed the dismissals, however, and Ceausescu threatened to resign as leader of the government. Bobu and several others then insisted Ceausescu stay, Postelnicu said. Asked by the tribunal president, Col. Andrei Nitoiu, whether that was a moment that could have ended Ceausescu's dictatorship, Postelnicu replied: ``I think this could have been the unique moment in the last 20 years. In my five years as a non-voting member of the Politburo, this was the first time that anyone contradicted him. ... I could have done it, but I didn't do it.'' Nitoiu read off the inventory of goods found at Postelnicu's home, including 22 pounds of jewels, $27,500 in Romanian currency, extensive video equipment and 440 pounds of meat, which was severely rationed by Ceausescu's government. Nitoiu said investigators found more than $444,500 in Romanian's lei currency at Manescu's home, along with gold and jewelry.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Usually Declare `Emergency' Before Given Traffic Priority
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 2-4, bgng: Fred Farrar, to CORRECT name of FAA and UPDATE with FAA saying nature of emergency wasn't clearly relayed; DELETES 14th graf pvs, And regional, now redundant; SUBS 16th graf pvs, Lee Dickinson, to include Sunday time element. Picks up 17th graf pvs, As the
DOC.TEXT: Fuel shortages like the one that may have occured before last week's Avianca crash are not routinely given emergency treatment unless the pilot actually declares a ``fuel emergency,'' under federal rules for air traffic controllers. Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said Monday that it is not the responsibility of the controllers to relay information other than the flight's route and number unless the pilot specifically calls an emergency. ``Air traffic controllers have have one primary job _ to keep aircraft from getting too close,'' Farrar said. ``It's the captain's job to fly the airplane. It's not the controllers' job to make judgments for him.'' However, FAA investigators said the regional controllers did relay information, by telephone, to the control center that handles approaches and departures at Kennedy International Airport, but the urgency of the matter wasn't clear. That conflicts with information provided Sunday night by the National Transportation Safety Board, which said the regional controllers had not relayed word of the fuel shortage to the local controllers. The regional controller said Avianca 52 had just come out of the holding area ``and can only do five more minutes of hold. Can you take him now?'' The local control replied, ``Slow him to 180 knots and I will take him.'' Under standards set by the FAA, if a pilot tells air traffic controllers he has ``minimum fuel,'' both he and controllers know that no undue delay can be accepted. But according to the FAA`s air traffic control manual, ``this is not an emergency situation but merely an advisory that indicates an emergency situation is possible should any undue delay occur.'' A minimum fuel advisory does not imply a need for the aircraft to be given a traffic priority, the FAA rules state. But if the pilot takes the next step and declares a fuel emergency, the entire controller system is geared to help. The FAA manual puts it this way: ``If at any time, the remaining useable fuel supply suggests the need for traffic priority to ensure a safe landing, the pilot should declare an emergency and report fuel remaining in minutes.'' As he circled over the seaboard in holding patterns before crashing on Long Island, the captain of Avianca Flight 52 never declared he had an actual fuel emergency. The crash killed 73 people and injured 85 others. On Sunday, Lee Dickinson of the National Transportation Safety Board told a news conference in Melville, N.Y., there was an apparent communications gap between high-altitude regional controllers and those handling landings. As the plane neared the end of its final, 46-minute holding pattern south of Kennedy International Airport, the crew told controllers in the regional New York Center about the fuel shortage and requested priority clearance to land, Dickinson said. Shortly afterward, the regional controllers turned the aircraft over to the local controllers. But, after interviewing six local controllers who either handled or tracked the flight, investigators determined they were unaware of the shortage, Dickinson said. R. Steve Bell, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, AFL-CIO, called the safety board's assrtions ``highly misleading and premature.'' The Avianca pilot never declared a ``fuel emergency,'' he said. ``No one knew how perilous was his situation until it was far too late,'' Bell said. ``The air traffic controllers would have moved heaven and earth to make for a safe approach for the crippled aircraft but the pilot never sent out the key words that he was in mortal danger.''

DOC.HEAD: Honecker to Face Trial on Treason Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Modrow arrival in Moscow, details. Picks up 5th pvs, `More than...' Minor editing thereafter
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ADN4,7
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker, who ruled East Germany for 18 years until his downfall in October, was arrested immediately after his release from a hospital Monday and will be tried for treason, the national prosecutor said. Plans to put the former Communist Party chief and three members of his Politburo on trial in March were announced by Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph at a session of Parliament, where Premier Hans Modrow offered a grim account of the state of the nation. The swift action against Honecker, 77, indicates the strength of a nationwide backlash against corruption in his Stalinist regime. Economic problems and widespread unrest have forced Modrow, the embattled Communist premier, to move the country's first free elections up from May to March 18 and bring the opposition into a coalition that will govern until then. In Washington, State Department Richard Boucher said: ``They seem to have accelerated the schedule in order to move quickly to a more stable, more long-term regime that's based on the popular will. That's something that we support.'' The Soviet news agency Tass later announced that Modrow had arrived on a 24-hour working visit in Moscow at the Kremlin's invitation and noted it was his first trip there since being elected prime minister last November. Tass said Modrow is expected to meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and to have talks on a wide range of subjects, including the processes under way in the two countries and Eastern Europe. More than 100,000 people demonstrated in Leipzig and other cities Monday night. Many called for the election defeat of the Communists and reunification with prosperous West Germany. ADN, the official news agency, said Communist Party chief Gregor Gysi postponed a trip to the United States planned for this week so he could help prepare for the elections. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said in Bonn he would campaign for any East German Christian conservatives who wanted his help, and put off a visit Chile and Brazil planned for early March. He said negotiations on an agreement to strengthen ties between the two Germanys should be conducted with the government chosen in March. Honecker had recuperated at Charite hospital from the surgical removal Jan. 8 of a malignant kidney tumor. He was arrested as he left the hospital and taken to Rummelsburg prison in East Berlin, ADN reported. It said Dr. Peter Althaus, director of the hospital's urology clinic, considered Honecker too ill to be imprisoned. Bild, a mass-circulation West German newspaper published in Hamburg, reported last week that Honecker would be arrested and kept at a prison medical facility. ADN did not say whether Rummelsburg had a hospital. A dozen once-mighty Politburo members have been swept up in the anti-corruption campaign. In Parliament, Joseph said 23 officials from the former government were in jail. Honecker, ousted Oct. 18, is accused of leading the nation to the brink of economic collapse through mismanagement and the misuse of power for personal enrichment. Joseph said Erich Mielke, Guenter Mittag and Joachim Herrmann, former Politburo members, also faced trial for treason. Mielke was Honecker's security chief, Mittag oversaw the economy and Hermann was in charge of propaganda. Treason previously carried a maximum penalty of death, but East Germany abolished capital punishment last year. Modrow's speech to Parliament explaining the decision to hold earlier elections and govern with the opposition painted a bleak picture of conditions in East Germany. He said mounting challenges to authority threatened the government's existence. ``The current government coalition is proving increasingly fragile,'' Modrow said. ``Economic and social tensions have increased. The economic sitution is deteriorating in a worrying way.'' Strikes, work slowdowns and the flight to the west of up to 2,500 people a day have worsened the already stagnant economy, and demands for higher wages and benefits are ``threatening the existence of East Germany,'' he declared. ``These failures have had a chain reaction of consequences for many other facilities and for provision and care of the population.'' New wage demands would cost East Germany $23.5 billion, and the budget already is $10 billion in the red, he said. Bomb threats, unruly demonstrations and vandalism have increased and the government no longer is able to ensure public safety, Modrow told the lawmakers. ``The emigration wave continues unhindered,'' Modrow said. More than 340,000 East Germans left in 1989, most of them skilled workers. Under a coalition plan agreed upon Sunday, each of the nine reform groups participating in weekly meetings with the Communists will name a minister without portfolio to join Modrow's 27-member Cabinet. The new Cabinet is to be announced Wednesday. At its Monday session, Parliament approved the March 18 election date and gave the first reading to a law establishing democratic voting procedures. In the weekly meeting with the opposition, where reforms are drafted, Environment Minister Peter Diederich gave a depressing report on the ecology. He said East Germans breathe air contaminated by four times the volume of pollutants emitted in West Germany, which has its own smog problems. More than 44 percent of the forests are dead or dying and at least 10 percent of the people drink water that does not meet public health standards, he said. Sulfur dioxide emissions are nearly nine times higher those in West Germany and considerably worse than in Czechoslovakia and Poland, which along with East Germany are the most polluted nations in Europe, Diederich said. The minister said he would press the government to give the environment equal rank with economic performance.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Rich to Help Poor African Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to ADD Mali to countries visited. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Monday exhorted developed nations to help poor African countries by treating them as equals and sharing the resources and knowledge needed to escape poverty. ``How would history judge a generation that, having all the means to feed the Earth's population, refused to do so in fratricidal indifference?'' the pope asked in what the Vatican described as the major speech of his five-country African trip. This sub-Saharan country, whose name means Land of the Upright Men, symbolizes the chronic problems of drought, hunger, disease, and expanding deserts that afflict much of the continent. The average per capita income in Burkina Faso is about $200 a year. ``I must point out the gravity of the ills that wound the peoples of Africa so much,'' the pope said in a speech at the headquarters of the West African Economic Community. ``If we want to help Africa overcome its handicaps, a public awakening is needed more than ever,'' he said. The pope spoke at a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of an appeal he made on behalf of the sub-Sahara region, or Sahel, during his first visit to Ouagadougou. That appeal led to the creation in 1984 of the John Paul II Foundation for the Sahel, funded primarily by West German Catholics. The organization has invested more than $3 billion to combat desertification and finance health, agriculture and other development projects. But the Sahel, and all of Africa, still needs help, John Paul said. ``Once again, I must launch a solemn appeal to humanity, in the name of humanity itself ... in the name of justice, I beg my brothers and sisters in humanity not to scorn the starving of this continent, not to deny them the universal right to human dignity and the security of life,'' he said. ``The world must know that Africa suffers deep poverty,'' he said, speaking in French. ``Available resources are declining, the Earth is becoming sterile over immense areas, malnutrition is chronic for 10 of millions of humans, death claims too many children. Can not such destitution be considered a wound in the side of all of humanity?'' John Paul said developed nations must view poor nations as partners and share scientific knowledge to help promote progress. ``They should not see the poorest countries only as clients or more or less solvent debtors,'' he said. ``This attitude, conscious or not, has led to too many dead ends.'' He also emphasized the responsibility of public officials in the needy natons. ``It is the moral quality of the people which must be respected, and all forms of intolerance, corruption, resentment and debasement must be abolished,'' he said. Earlier, the pope told Roman Catholics to build a society in Burkina Faso ``based on respect of the human person and the family.'' ``Human life is inviolable,'' he said at Mass at a national pilgrimage site outside the capital. ``The right to life should be defended ceaselessly'' from conception to natural death. John Paul said couples must resist ``invasion of methods which go against the dignity of the woman and don't honor man.'' The local church has resisted the government's birth control programs, and there is similar opposition from Moslems. A survey last year found only 4 percent to 6 percent of women using modern birth control methods. The birthrate in this country of 8.5 million people is 2.9 percent, one of the highest in the world. Catholics make up about 9 percent of the population. International aid agencies, including the World Bank, and African governments themselves, have identified population growth as a key factor in the poverty that afflicts the Sahel. The pope's African tour began Jan. 25. He returns to Rome on Thursday after a stop in Chad. The pope has also visited Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau and Mali.

DOC.HEAD: Super Bowl `Overnights' Low
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS throughout to RECAST, CORRECT rating to 39.6, sted 38.9, ADD share; ADD half-hour breakdown for prime time. No pickup. A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco 49ers' 55-10 victory over the Denver Broncos on Sunday would be one of the lowest-rated Super Bowls in history if overnight ratings released Monday are an indication. The game averaged a 39.6 rating in 23 cities, and the ratings dropped during the game as it became clear the 49ers had the National Football League championship in the bag, according to the figures from the A.C. Nielsen Co. Michael Eisenberg, a CBS vice president for research, said his network anticipated the ratings to rise to 40.0 when national ratings are released Tuesday. Each national ratings point now represents 921,000 homes. If the national ratings don't appreciably rise from the overnight figures, Sunday's game would be the lowest-rated Super Bowl since 1971, when Baltimore's victory over Dallas got a 39.9 rating. The rating represents the percentage of televisions tuned in to a program. Last year's San Francisco-Cincinnati Super Bowl, won by the 49ers 20-16, got a 43.5 rating and was seen in nearly 40 million homes, according to Nielsen estimates. The ratings for this year's game dropped off during the second half as San Francisco's margin of victory increased. From 7 p.m. EST to 7:30, the game got a 37.0 rating. It dropped to 37.3 rating from 7:30 to 8, to 34.8 from 8 to 8:30 and 32.0 for the final half hour, which included postgame interviews.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Nuclear Protesters Hail U.S. Foreign Base Closings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with South Korean reaction.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Base Closings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western European governments reacted calmly Monday to plans announced in Washington to shut seven U.S. military bases in Europe, but at one base due to be closed, British anti-nuclear protesters expressed delight. Women who have maintained ``peace camps'' for nearly a decade around the muddy perimeter at Greenham Common said they helped send the Americans home. The U.S. cruise nuclear missile base, west of London, is probably the best-known of the bases slated for closure. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said of the proposed 2 percent cut in the U.S. defense budget, ``Both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. have agreed the cold war is over. Any vestige of that should be relegated to history.'' In Italy, where the U.S. cruise missile base at Comiso is scheduled to close, Premier Giulio Andreotti's spokesman, Pio Mastrobuoni, declared, ``The announcement is a sign of the times. ``The news expresses the new reality of the climate of cooperation between East and West.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a firm opponent of any significant disarmament by the West despite the crumbling of communist governments in the East bloc, had ``no objections,'' said a spokeswoman at her 10 Downing St. office. ``We've discussed the proposals with the United States. We have no objections,'' the spokeswoman said. She spoke on condition of anonymity. The Greek Parliament was due to vote Monday on a six-month extension of the 1983 agreement covering U.S. bases, but postponed the vote for two days. Instead, Defense Minister Tzannis Tzannetakis announced two of the four major military installations in Greece are to go _ Hellinikon base outside Athens, used by reconnaissance aircraft that shadow the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean, and Nea Makri, a U.S. naval communications base 22 miles from the capital. The bases are among 14 U.S. foreign military installations and more than 60 in the United States that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced he wants to close or realign to save money. Community leaders and business people in several areas near bases expressed concern at what will amount to losses of millions of dollars annually. Besides Greenham Common, two other of the 66 U.S. military installations in Britain were being closed _ Fairford, a base for 18 KC-135 air-to-air refuelling tankers in south-central England, 25 miles from Oxford, and Wethersfield, eastern England, base for a civil engineering unit. The other proposed base closures in European NATO countries were two in Turkey _ Eskisehir Munitions Storage Site and Erhac Air Base _ and one in West Germany, Zweibrucken Air Base. In addition, the British Defense Ministry said a squadron of American F-16 fighters based at Bentwaters in eastern England was to be disbanded. ``We have to make our operations cost just a little bit less. . .. We feel this is the way to do it in the United Kingdom,'' said Lt. Col. Sam Giammo, director of public affairs for the 3rd U.S. Air Force, based at Mildenhall, in the eastern England county of Norfolk. Jean Hutchison, 54, a longtime member of a ramshackle camp on the Greenham Common base perimeter, said, ``The Americans will leave Greenham rather than other bases thanks to the work of thousands of women.'' Said Evelyn Parker, another Greenahm anti-nuclear campaigner, ``It's stunning news. This has been an amazing thing to live through.'' Missiles are being removed from Greenham, Comiso and other U.S. cruise and Pershing II nuclear missile bases under the 1987 agreement between the superpowers to eliminate their medium-range nuclear missiles. Giammo said Greenham Common and Fairford will be put on a standby basis. He said the United States will maintain a small presence at each site in case it needed to reactivate the base. The last cruise missiles are to be removed from Greenham Common next year. Wethersfield will be handed back to Britain's Royal Air Force. About 3,000 American personnel will be withdrawn from Britain, or about 7.5 percent of the total, under the proposals announced Monday, he added.
