DOC.TEXT: From time to time a suspect under the strain of questioning will confess to a crime he didn't commit. Here's a strange case in West Virginia in which two men confessed to the same murders. The first was freed and the second was tried and convicted. Now he's going to be tried a second time.

A decade ago Paul Reggettz III spent 11 months behind bars after confessing that he murdered his wife and their two children. He was freed after a former neighbor confessed to the same crime. Reggettz has spent the past 10 years struggling to rebuild his life, painfully aware of the stares and whispers of those who still think he's guilty. Now the second man who confessed, John Moss Jr., is to stand trial again, in March. His previous conviction on three first-degree murder counts was overturned because of a judge's mistakes. ``I don't want to keep reliving that nightmare,'' Reggettz says. ``Every five years will I have to because of the state Supreme Court? Where are my rights? I'd like to have the right to get on with my life.'' The nightmare began on Dec. 13, 1979, the cold, rainy day Reggettzrushed into a restaurant a block up the narrow dirt street from his family's one-story house in nearby St. Albans. He called police and said: ``You've got to help me. My wife's dead.'' Police found Vanessa Reggettz, 26, lying on the bedroom floor, beaten, strangled and stabbed with a pair of scissors. Their 7-year-old son, Paul Eric, was found in the bathtub, apparently choked with an electrical cord before being drowned. Their 4-year-old daughter, Bernadette, had been strangled and was hanging from a cord strung over a door. As the bodies were carried from the white frame house, Reggettz, then a 36-year-old United Parcel Service worker, was taken to state police headquarters for questioning. He was interrogated for 21 straight hours, with no food or sleep. Police deny any improprieties, but Reggettz says he was bullied, threatened, knocked to the floor and had a gun held to his head. Finally, he says, the shock of seeing his family murdered, combined with the terror of the interrogation, overwhelmed him, broke his will. He confessed. ``The children were screaming and crying,'' he told investigators. ``My head felt like it was going to explode and I had to put a stop to the noise.'' Reggettz was taken back to the house where his family had been slaughtered and re-enacted the slayings for police and Kanawha County Prosecutor Mike Roark. ``I was put under so much pressure, tremendous pressure,'' Reggettz says. ``Now, what's pressure to me might not be pressure to you. You might stand 10 times the pressure. I was put in a pressure situation where I would have told them I was anybody or anything doing anything they wanted. Anything. ``And people say, `You mean to tell me you would lie and say that?' ... I didn't want to lie. Why would I want to say something I didn't do? ``But lying got to where it didn't mean anything out of fear. Fear won over the lying ... I would have told them anything _ anything _ to get them to leave me alone and not put pressure on me.'' An autopsy report estimated the time of death at midnight, well before Reggettz left for work at 1:45 a.m. The case seemed cut-and-dried, and Circuit Judge John Hey sent Reggettz to jail without bond. Charges against Reggettz were dropped before he went to trial, but he lost his job while behind bars. ``Three times _ and I'm not trying to get dramatic _ three times I planned suicide in there,' Reggettz says. ``I came to the very end of my rope three different occasions. ``I thought dying would have to be better than living.'' Ten months after the slayings, and the day after Hey refused to throw out Reggettz's confession, Moss told police he committed the murders. In jail in Cleveland on other charges at the time, Moss was a former neighbor of the Reggettz family. He had been named in Reggettz's indictment as a participant in the slayings, but he wasn't indicted then because he was 17. Tests showed that some of the blood found in the Reggettz home didn't come from the victims or from Reggettz, but did match Moss' blood type.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$adv11
DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
DOC.NOTE: For Release Sun., Feb. 11
DOC.HEAD: CHARLESTON, W.Va.: blood type.
DOC.TEXT: Moss also was linked to several items reported stolen from the Reggettz home. The medical examiner changed the estimated time of death, which he had based on Reggettz's confession, to sometime in the early morning after Reggettz had left for work. Roark finally conceded he believed Reggettz was at work 25 miles away in Rand when the murders occurred, and Hey dropped the charges against him. Moss contended he also was forced into a false confession by the state trooper who interrogated Reggettz, but Hey refused to throw out his tape-recorded statement. His defense lawyer argued that Reggettz committed the murders, picturing him as a volatile father with no affection for his family, and as a former motorcycle gang member who worshipped Satan. A jury deliberated 14 hours before convicting Moss in 1984, five years after the slayings. But the state Supreme Court in December 1988 ordered a new trial for Moss on three grounds. The court said the judge erred when he refused to poll each juror about possible exposure to prejudicial comments made by the prosecutor and broadcast on local radio and television stations during the trial. The court also said the judge allowed the prosecutor to make prejudicial comments during his closing arguments, including statements that Moss has ``a ruthless, vicious, diseased criminal mind'' and should never be released ``to slaughter women and children in Kanawha County.'' The court also said Hey failed to allow admission of evidence regarding a polygraph test Reggettz took. Despite Moss' widely publicized trial, Reggettz still runs across people who assume he was guilty. ``All this many years later they act like I was the one who was tried, and I'm out running around when I ought to be locked up,'' he says. ``I have a problem understanding that ... ``If you liked me before this stuff happened you'll probably say I didn't do it. And if you didn't like me, you'll probably say I did it. I've seen it with my own eyes.'' During a recent shopping trip, for example, Reggettz says he waited outside a discount store while his wife _ he remarried seven years ago _ went through the checkout line. ``I was standing outside looking through the window waiting for her, and the woman checking her out said: `You know who that is? That's Paul Reggettz. That's the guy who killed his family.' And my wife said, `That's my husband.' The woman didn't know what to say.'' Reggettz, 46, now lives in South Charleston and earns his living doing odd jobs. A self-described born-again Christian who refound his faith in jail, he and his wife have no children, but he said they're considering adoption. A member of a Pentecostal church, Reggettz struggles to explain his concept of good and evil when asked why his family died. ``I believe there's a God in heaven,'' he said. ``I believe there's a Satan _ a real, live living devil ... ``He's an evil thing out to destroy, kill. And I think he was the instigator. He used somebody to destroy my family. He'll use anybody that's open to his influence. ``Explain to me why a guy suddenly, one day he walks off the job and goes home and gets three or four guns and a thousand rounds of ammunition and goes to a school and starts shooting up kids. I don't believe that one day the man says, `I think I'm going to kill a bunch of kids today.' I'm sure a lot of them have thought that. But they may have help thinking of it.'' Ten years later, Reggettz says he's not bitter about what happened to him. ``I used to be,'' he says. ``It took me a long time to get to where I'm at today. ``The state of West Virginia, the state police, some of them made mistakes. Fine. Everybody's going to make mistakes. The state's not perfect. The state police are not perfect. Mike Roark's not perfect. The judges aren't perfect. ``I know a lot of people made big mistakes in my case. But the mistake would be even worse if I let it eat me alive.''

DOC.TEXT: When an ordinary man leading an ordinary life wakes up one morning to discover that he can fly, his life is transformed. Right? Not in the fantasy world of Randy Cohen, where people seldom have their feet on the ground.

Randy Cohen isn't able to fly or live in a tree but he likes to think about it. So, Cohen does the next best thing: He writes about people who do. His strangely talented people appear as a series of comic pieces in his book, ``Diary of a Flying Man,'' published by Knopf. Cohen, a soft-spoken, amiable 41-year-old, occupies an office in midtown Manhattan that looks out on a building he regards as ``an architectural inconvience, full of hard-working people _ no crimes being committed, no affairs blossoming, nothing.'' The wall above his desk houses a large collection of pictures. All of children. A closer look reveals they are all of the same child. ``It's my daughter, Sophie, 2. I took a lot of pictures of her so people would think I have a big family.'' While in the office, Cohen works as a writer for the ``Late Night With David Letterman'' television show. He and nine other staff writers are responsible for ``generating amusing things _ the ongoing task that awaits weekly.'' During his six years with the show, Cohen has come up with ideas as varied as attaching a miniature camera to a monkey's head and having him shoot the show that night as well as a ``musical piece trivializing glasnost.'' The pieces in his book are not from the TV show. ``The book is a lot darker and bleaker than the show, but I like to think it is very, very funny,'' Cohen says. The title piece tells of an ``ordinary man leading an ordinary life'' who wakes up one morning and finds he can fly. He exults: ``Mankind's oldest dream has become my reality: I can fly. This morning, running after a $5 bill blowing along the pavement, I simply lifted into the air. What profound transformation will my life undergo? Unfortunately, the five turned out to be a torn page from Sunday's fashion supplement.'' Which pretty well sums up Cohen's way of looking at things. As he says, ``The man believes the ability to fly will transform his life. It doesn't. Instead of walking to the cash machine and finding it doesn't work, now you can fly there and find it doesn't work. I think that if all your dreams come true things would still be the same. Say you get super-strength. So you lift up the phone book and order in a pizza, then you tear the phone book in half. Big deal, the pizza will still be cold when you get it, assuming it arrives at all.'' As for the men who live in trees, the thesis is, says Cohen, that ``men lead crude, primitive lives and should be pathetically grateful that women invite them indoors. Left to their own devices, men will revert to barbarism. But the guys in the trees are happy. They can eat food without sauces and throw their clothes on the floor _ in this case on the branches.'' As one tree dweller puts it: ``I don't have framed prints on the wall. I don't give little dinner parties. I haven't ironed anything since 1973. What kind of life is that? It's my life.'' Here is an excerpt from one of the pieces in the diary. It's called ``Sleep Problems'': ``Connie's postal obsessions keep her up for hours. `I worry how long the lines will be at the post office tomorrow. Did I put enough postage on the letters I mailed today? Did I casually apply a stamp that will be worth thousands to collectors in 30 years? Is it unethical to use the Rutherford B. Hayes commemorative when I disapprove of so many policies of his administration, particularly his use of federal troops against striking railroad workers? It's all so trivial, but my mind grinds on. Then I panic: if I don't fall asleep right now, tomorrow I'll be too tired to get anything done. At that point I'm doomed. I get up, put on my robe, go into the living room, phone someone I loathe, and threaten them in a disguised voice, usually this high-pitched nasal twang.''' Cohen came to humor writing in a funny way. ``I used to play drums in a rock 'n' roll band. And I could introduce a song with funny banter. Since I was a flamboyantly inadequate drummer, it was suggested to me that I give up drums and become a stand-up comic. So I became a free-lance writer. I sold my pieces and I made enough to eat modestly. Free-lance writers are famous for low cholesterol.'' He says he applied for a job with the Letterman show when he found his wife planned to work at home ``and it terrified us that both of us would be at home. I turned in a sample of my work _ sort of a comedy writing test _ and I was hired. I'm sure it was a clerical error. The piece I submitted can still conjure up visceral embarrassment at its inadequacies.''

DOC.TEXT: Robert Urich believes there's more to the story of convicted wife-killer Rob Marshall than is revealed in his portrayal of Marshall in the TV miniseries ``Blind Faith.'' The two-part NBC series on Sunday and Monday is based on the Joe McGinniss book about Marshall, who was sentenced to death on a charge of arranging for the murder of his wife in Toms River, N.J., in 1984. ``I think this might be described as one scenario of what happened,'' says Urich. ``It's based on the book, which is based on interviews. I'm convinced there's more to it than comes out in the book or the miniseries. ``But it's not an actor's job to make moral judgments about the character. This is the first time I've played in a real documented story. It bothered me that we might take license with the real story. ``I play a man who says he's innocent. The story is told from other people's points of view. If they say he looked suspicious or broke down and cried, that's what I had to do. Overall, I had problems of accurately nailing down his mood and tone.'' Urich has returned to California after ending his Boston-based role as the tough private detective in ABC's ``Spenser: For Hire.'' He has sold his 20-room, 15-acre home near Boston and bought a smaller house in the San Fernando Valley. Last spring Urich was seen as Jake Spoon, a former law officer who also worked as an outlaw, in the hit CBS miniseries ``Lonesome Dove.'' He is now preparing for his first situation comedy since his brief appearance in ``Soap'' 12 years ago. ``It was knowing I was going to do a comedy that allowed me to do something as different and as dark as `Blind Faith,''' he says. Urich says he felt fortunate that Roby Marshall, one of Marshall's three sons, acted as an adviser and was available on the set of ``Blind Faith.'' ``This was a man who presented the picture of a perfect father,'' Urich says. ``There was something compelling about this guy. I did have the benefit of having his son, Roby, by my side. I felt I could believe him when he said his father's hand shook or he lost his composure.'' ``Blind Faith'' was adapted by John Gay and directed by Paul Wendkos. It also stars Joanna Kerns as Rob's wife, Maria, David Gray as Roby, Jay Underwood as son Jay, Johnny Galecki as son John, Dennis Farina as prosecutor Kevin Kelly, Robin Strasser as Marshall's mistress, Felice Richmond, Joe Spano as Marshall's best friend, Sal Coccaro, Doris Roberts as a friend of Marshall's mother and William Forsythe as the man who testified he arranged for Maria's murder. ``As much as anything, it's a story of the survival of these boys and how this catastrophe affected their lives,'' Urich says. After completing ``Spenser: For Hire,'' Urich went to Texas for his role in ``Lonesome Dove.'' Then he did movies for Disney, USA Network and CBS. ``Spenser'' was based on Robert Parker's books about the tough Boston detective. ``The problem with `Spenser' or any detective on a network is you can't really pinpoint the audience,'' Urich says. ``You can't do the violence or the language or the elements necessary for the story. Spenser in the books was probably more ruthless, but I felt America didn't need another hero who broke the law and all the rules.'' In his new comedy, ``American Dreamer,'' created by Gary David Goldberg (``Family Ties'') for NBC, Urich plays a former broadcast journalist named Tom Nash who returns to his hometown with his children after his wife is killed in a terrorist bombing. He writes a column for a Chicago newspaper. ``I call it a version of `Our Town' for television,'' he says. ``It's one man's reflection on life. He brings along all his emotional baggage. He stands in a spot of life and travels back and forth in time. Then a scene lights up and he steps into the action. I play the role at all ages.'' Urich's last appearance in a theatrical film was in ``Turk 182'' in 1985, although people remember him most for ``Ice Pirates'' in 1984. ``I'd like to do more features, but I've managed to stay unavailable because of my work for television,'' he says. He's also acquired a small publishing company, Beaver Dam Press in Nashville, Tenn., and plans to re-issue the outdoor books by Nash Buckingham.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian TV Network _ Many Hate It But Everybody Watches It
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On any given night in prime time, 85 million of Brazil's 150 million people stare into their television screens, eagerly consuming the fare offered up by 85-year-old Roberto Marinho and his TV Globo network. That's an astounding share of Brazil's potential viewing public of 100 million. Even those who say they hate what Marinho stands for and want his network broken up can't resist the magnetic pull. Not only is it Brazil's largest network, it is the largest in the Third World and, on a global basis, is generally considered to rank fourth after NBC, ABC and CBS in the United States. An average of 96.6 million Americans watch TV each night, according to A.C. Nielsen Co., with the three major networks attracting 60 million of them. Thus Roberto Marinho and TV Globo _ with a whopping 85 percent share of the Brazilian audience _ soars into the ratings stratosphere. The network has 15,000 employees and 70 stations reaching nearly all of Brazil's 4,000 cities and towns. All of that, however, leaves some Brazilians deeply worried that Marinho has far too much influence for Brazil's good. None of the three other Brazilian networks, independents or educational TV come near to competing with TV Globo's recognized quality or popularity. President Fidel Castro of Cuba is a fan, although he would place himself at the opposite end of the ideological field from Marinho. Castro's addiction is a TV Globo soap-opera sold throughout Latin America titled ``A Escrava Isaura'' (``Isaura the Slave''). TV Globo's soaps _ called ``novelas'' _ draw the largest number of viewers. The network also attracts an audience with first-run movies, dubbed into Portuguese, such as ``Raiders of the Lost Ark.'' It offers sophisticated, far-ranging news coverage _ first on the scene of fires, floods, bus crashes and Cabinet resignations. Yet the cries often go up: ``Break up TV Globo!'' Books, magazine articles and politicians charge that so vast a TV network is simply too powerful _ most particularly in a country where millions barely can read and turn to television for information as well as entertainment. The direct target of the criticism is the iconoclastic billionaire Marinho, who also has his hand in newspapers, radio, book and magazine publishing and communications systems. Critics charge that Marinho uses his conglomerate to push a right-wing, pro-business, anti-populist political message. Marinho, whose physical bearing belies his age by 15 or 20 years, doesn't deny it. ``We openly supported the candidacy of Fernando Collor de Mello,'' Marinho unabashedly told a group of reporters in Rio de Janeiro recently. He was referring to the victor in Brazilian elections in December _ the first free presidential vote in almost 30 years. Conservative, pro-free enterprise Collor de Mello defeated a Marxist-oriented opponent in a final runoff by a slim margin and is to take office March 15. But when Marinho asserted that his media conglomerate also gave time and space to competing candidates, skeptics _ sharing a widely held belief that Marinho ordered slanted coverage to favor Collor de Mello _ laughed aloud; some walked out. The silver-haired magnate envisions his media might with a proselytizing mission: ``This is not the United States. We have an obligation to reach not only the cultured people but also those of the lowest classes.'' And indeed, the first signs of modern progress in Brazil's wretched ``favelas,'' or hillside slums, often are TV aerials sprouting from the roofs of miserable shacks. ``Brazil cannot be governed with Roberto Marinho having the power he does,'' says the leftist-populist Leonel Brizola, former governor of Rio de Janeiro and one of 21 candidates who ran for the presidency. During his unsuccessful campaign, Brizola promised: ``On the first morning of my first day in office I will re-examine the monopoly of the `TV Globo Party,' the biggest party in Brazil. That network must be taken off the air.'' Brizola finished third and was eliminated from the deciding runoff. ``TV Globo is agile and efficient, with a level of quality that makes it the leader in the ratings,'' said Professor Jose Marques de Melo, the head of the School of Communications and Arts at the University of Sao Paulo, the nation's largest and most prestigious learning center. ``But its professional conduct during the elections left a lot to be desired.'' ``Brazil needs a code of ethics for news media,'' Marques de Melo added. Ricardo Kotscho, the press spokesman for the losing presidential candidate in the finals, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, said Marinho's extremely successful newspaper O Globo of Rio de Janeiro, which openly endorsed Color de Mello, ``lost all its credibility in the campaign and also its morals.'' In his session with the newsmen, Marinho said, ``A newspaper can support whomever it wants.'' He added that O Globo gave coverage to the other candidates even though he personally didn't like them. ``I have been called a fascist,'' Marinho said. ``But when I was young, I boxed and practiced jiu-jitsu and karate. I know how to hit as well as get hit.'' Marinho inherited the newspaper O Globo (The World) after his father, Irineu Marinho, died just three weeks after founding the paper in 1925. He expanded into radio in the 1940s and now runs a money-making nationwide radio network. TV Globo went on the air in 1965. Time-Life Broadcasting of the United States once held a minority interest in it, leading to charges that TV Globo was a mouthpiece for ``American imperialism.'' But now the Globo empire belongs exclusively to Marinho, his brothers and his sons. TV Globo spends lavishly to produce its prime-time novelas, which draw ratings of over 90 percent at home. Translated from the Portuguese, they are exported to the rest of Latin America, Western Europe, Scandinavia, the Middle East, the Orient and U.S. Spanish-language stations. Marinho lives in the best mogul style, in a fabulous estate high in the hills overlooking Rio, near the famous Christ the Redeemer statue on Corcovado peak. The Roberto Marinho Foundation finances free art exhibits and open-air concerts and operas for Brazil's poor masses and also a televised adult-education course that has given some 4 million Brazilian dropouts a chance to acquire high school-equivalency diplomas. In 1964, when a right-wing military regime seized power and ruled for 21 years, Marinho and his media voices were solidly behind it. Brizola, exiled during the military dictatorship but later granted amnesty, says, ``I am not against Roberto Marinho personally, but in Brazil an essential public service such as radio and television must be made more democratic.'' Marinho's response: ``Mr. Brizola can provoke me all he wants. It won't do him any good.'' Married twice and recently estranged from his second wife, Marinho did not flinch when a reporter asked him about his current relationship with a Rio society figure, Lily de Carvalho, an old flame from his younger days. ``She is a widow and a free woman,'' he said. ``Age does not interfere with companionship. I don't drink. I don't smoke. I exercise. I go underwater fishing without an aqualung. I don't spend any sleepless nights.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Feb. 4

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `For All Mankind'
DOC.TEXT: Do you remember that day in 1969 when you and your family huddled around the television set for an unbelievable sight: Neil Armstrong stepping down to the powdery surface of the moon and and saying, ``One small step for man, one giant leap for mankind?'' If you were a parent, you probably took photographs of your children watching this milestone of human history. Our memories are linked to flickering images on the 17-inch screen. Now the moon-exploration experience can be viewed on the big screen in the way that the astronauts saw it. A new feature documentary, ``For All Mankind,'' takes you inside the space capsule and onto the surface of the moon in color and with absolute clarity. A magazine writer named Al Steinert is responsible for the film. Ten years ago, he began wondering about all the movies that the 13 astronauts took during their flights and lunar explorations. The film _ 6 million feet of it _ remained in the NASA vaults, available for public view. Nobody had ever thought of reviewing all of it. Al Steinert did. The most dramatic sequences were selected, then painstakingly expanded from 16mm to 35mm film. As a result, the film is remarkably clear, even on huge screens. Only the shots at the Johnson Space Center betray graininess. Despite the familiarity of all the moon adventures, ``For All Mankind'' seems entirely new. It is far more exhilarating than a ``Star Trek'' movie, and it evokes renewed awe at the courage of the astronauts. Steinert wisely allows the astronauts themselves to relate the story, in their communications with Earth and in reminiscences he recorded in recent times. He tells the story linearly, starting with the suiting up at Cape Canaveral, the awesome liftoff and the silent, dream-like soar through the outer limits. The moon sequences are blissfully lyrical, aided by the other-worldly music by Brian Eno, Roger Eno and Dan Lanois. The understated comments by the astronauts add immeasurably to the storytelling. ``For All Mankind,'' which was produced by Reinert and Betsy Broyles Brier, has been appearing in test engagements around the country, having acquired no distributor. The film is unrated, but it offers a profound experience for all ages, particularly youngsters to whom space travel seems unremarkable. Running time: 80 minutes.

DOC.TEXT:
``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' (Orion Home Video. VHS-Beta, $79.98. Rated R.)
``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' is a hilarious, dark farce of the trouble men cause women. Full of improbable relationships and impossible coincidences, this subtitled film from Spain has been a big hit in the United States. And for many good reasons. Among them is Carmen Maura, who plays the passionate, beautiful Pepa, the central character of director Pedro Almodovar's movie. Pepa and Ivan (Fernando Guillen) share a penthouse apartment in Madrid and when Ivan abruptly leaves her, Pepa sets off on a desperate course to get him back. Along the way, she encounters her friend Candela, who is involved with a man who turns out to be a Shiite terrorist; Ivan's wife, who spent 20 years in a mental hospital; a feminist lawyer who is her successor as Ivan's lover; and a taxi driver who supplies his fares with music, magazines and drinks. There is melodrama galore _ a suicide attempt, a nearly hijacked jetliner, an unplanned pregnancy, barbiturate-spiked gazpacho and stakeouts. But ``Women on the Verge'' never resorts to slapstick. Pepa and Ivan are actors, Pepa playing the mother of a murderer in a television show. They also both dub films, and in one she plays a bride. At the altar, the priest whispers that she must not trust any man, not even her husband and then hands her a condom. Throughout there is a sense of loss of control, a frantic pace. Everything is just out of wack. And that is the part of the wonderful charm of ``Women on the Verge.''

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Feel'' (RCA) _ Human Drama
Sometimes you can judge a record by its cover. Johnny Indovina, the singer-leader of Human Drama, poses on ``Feel'' with bare chest, beads and necklaces, black nail polish and crucifix earring, his face darkened by shadows, his hair hanging in front of his eyes like a mask. This is music for the white makeup, black leather and big moussed hair set. It's gloom and doom rock with plenty of angst thrown in. ``Feel'' is this Los Angeles-based group's first album. It's similar in tone to The Smiths, Joy Division or The Cure _ but on the Despair-o-Meter, Human Drama comes out on top. Indovina yelps, favors a sobby vibrato, and uses the Pained Hiccup Effect in his vocals. His alienated voice is alienating. His songs may have arisen from genuinely deep pain, but it's difficult to share that pain with him. His lyrics are mostly obscure and cryptic. Send in the undertakers _ or maybe a psychiatrist. ``So deep it burns, I burn until I cry, I die,'' Indovina sings on ``Death of an Angel.'' Then, on ``Dying in a Moment of Splendor,'' Indovina relates, ``I am an artist with a vision seeing hell his destiny.'' And in ``There Is Only You,'' Indovina sings about coming close to suicide _ though it might be just fantasy. So Johnny feels bad, but why? Is it the ozone layer? Toxic wastes? Love gone sour? Addiction? Indovina refers to an inner battle between Good and Evil, which could be tied to the struggle with addiction he relates in ``Tumble'' and ``Never Never.'' References to angels, heaven, God, demons, Easter, the Golden Rule and prayers are sprinkled through ``Feel.'' It's too bad a little holy water couldn't have been sprinkled, too, because this record sounds anything but celestial. It takes more courage to sing about inner struggles than about cars and girls. But Indovina lacks the directness of a Tracy Chapman or Bruce Springsteen that makes the pain personal enough to touch the hearts of an audience.

``Smoking in the Fields'' (RCA) _ The Del Fuegos
The Del Fuegos color the world like autumn. Burnt orange, russet, siena, sepia. On ``Smoking in the Fields,'' they sound like they've been through the lighthearted spring and summer, and now are living in a season where things are more serious and the winds blow harder, but where flashes of color and cozy blankets give warmth. ``I'll stand by you when you're feelin' tired, gray and old; honey I will be, too,'' Dan Zanes sings on ``Stand By You.'' The track is the most stripped-down on the album, featuring just Zanes, an acoustic guitar and a little help from unobtrusive strings and backing vocals. Most of the rest of this album is barroom stomp rock that would be in good company alongside Jason and the Scorchers or the LeRoi Brothers. The Fuegos get pumped on ``Move With Me Sister'' and ``No No Never,'' then slow down into the mid-tempo ``Part of This Earth'' and a blues-tinted jam on ``Lost Weekend.'' Guitars carry the tunes, and Tom Lloyd's bass is mixed up high enough to give a weighty feel. Horns add brightness. But harmonica work by the J. Geils Band's Magic Dick lends the most distinctive texture to the album. Zanes' whiskey-over-gravel voice trademarks the stuff as the Fuegos'. It's been 2{ years since the last Del Fuegos album _ the bomb ``Stand Up.'' Since then, the band has switched record labels and producers. Mitchell Froom, who produced the band's first three records, is replaced by Dave Thoener. The result, ``Smoking in the Fields,'' is an OK rock album with a gritty tinge. But it doesn't dazzle.

The Artists: Learning About the World Through Art
DOC.TEXT: In Ohio, students learned math in Japanese after seeing a Kabuki-style ``Othello.'' In New Jersey, a teacher used musical rhythms in a lesson on syllables. In upstate New York, a storyteller's yarns brought a shy schoolboy out of his shell. All were inspired by the Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education, a program that brings a unique blend of culture, academia and personal growth to thousands of students each year. ``We're not trying to teach respect or love for the arts,'' said Mark Schubart, director of the institute. ``What we're trying to do is more basic _ to teach about how people think and react and view the world.'' Each year, the institute commissions a dozen productions _ including dance, concerts and plays _ that are appropriate for children. Teachers preview the pieces on videotape and choose one for their school. What makes the program special is the involvement of artists. In the summer, artists hold workshops at Lincoln Center to help teachers experience the creative process and to show them how to reach students through the arts. In the fall, the artists go into the classroom and help teachers prepare students for the production they'll be seeing. In one workshop last summer, composer John King had teachers clap, sing and bang coffee cans to demonstrate contrapuntal techniques. ``I'm not teaching them how to be musicians,'' said King. ``I'm teaching them how to look at music by experiencing rather than listening.'' Gail Krehel, a second-grade reading teacher in Paramus, N.J., said she planned to use clapping to teach students how to divide words into syllables. Last fall, elementary school students in New York City, who were scheduled to see an adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's ``Just So Stories,'' read the book, discussed themes and characters, played games to improve their concentration and acted out scenes to learn what it's like to be a performer. ``An actor's got to change his voice and change his moving and his body and wear different clothes,'' explained Jesus Mendez, 7. ``They don't look like real people when they have those things on,'' said Aaron Tye, 5, referring to the masks worn by the ``Just So Stories'' troupe. Aaron had worn a mask himself while portraying a dog during his class's improvisations. ``I felt great. I felt like an animal,'' he said. His classmate, Tavona Cooper, played a horse. ``She came home and told me all about it,'' said her mother, Donna. ``She galloped around the house and showed me how the horse moves his hoofs.'' Cooper said she noticed a change in Tavona since those improvisational sessions with an actress from the institute. ``She's more outgoing, more motivated now,'' Cooper said Tavona's teacher, Gloria Toro, explained: ``As they're learning, their self-esteem grows because they're having so much fun and they love what they're doing.'' Louise Trucks of the Aesthetic Education Institute in Rochester, which is affiliated with the Lincoln Center Institute, agreed. ``Children can learn things through the arts that they might not have found in other ways,'' she said. One child reached by the Rochester program had been a withdrawn child, not involved with other kids in the classroom until a storyteller began visiting the class. ``By the time this storyteller left, this boy was writing stories, he was participating in the class, telling stories and recruiting other children to do so,'' she said. The Lincoln Center Institute began in 1976 with a handful of schools. Today the program reaches 100,000 children in 289 schools in New York City, Long Island, Westchester and Rockland counties, New Jersey and Connecticut. The schools finance half the institute's $2.4 million annual budget. The rest is paid by private and government grants. Programs modeled on the institute have sprung up in Albany, Binghamton, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Utica in New York, as well as in San Diego, Memphis and Nashville, Tenn., Tulsa, Okla., and other cities. In Bowling Green, Ohio, teachers used a Kabuki-style performance of ``Othello'' as a springboard for lessons on Japan. ``We had first graders doing arithmetic in Japanese,'' said director Michael Moore. But the dividends are not solely academic. ``We're training kids how to ask aesthetic questions,'' he said. ``We have third-graders who can give critiques of plays. We have kindergarteners who will sit through 90 minutes of a performance and not move. We're training people to be intelligent consumers of the arts.'' Barbara Davis of the Texas Institute for the Arts in Education in Houston agreed. ``The children can relate to a contemporary dance piece or an opera,'' she said. ``It's not just a bunch of people moving around on stage anymore.''

Music Makers: Dr. Demento Celebrates 20 Years of Mad Music
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Who is that mad-hatted man, and what is he doing on the radio? Let him speak for himself. ``Whooo, whooo, whooo, wind up your ears, dementites and dementoids! It's time for the `Dr. Demento Show' with mad music and craaaaaaaazy comedy from out of the archives and off the wall!'' Toot toot goes his toy horn, and Dr. Demento _ a.k.a. Barrett E. ``Barry'' Hansen _ is off to a nuthead start. ``The Dr. Demento Show,'' heard everywhere from Antarctica to Alabama, is the only major radio outpost for wacko recordings ranging from ``The Purple People Eater'' to early 20th century comedy to rap-scratchin' takeoffs on ``Star Trek.'' Every week, the show is on 193 commercial radio stations through the Westwood One Radio Networks, and on 35 college stations and about 500 Armed Forces Network stations on ships or bases. Hansen _ whose trademark is a tux and top hat _ is celebrating 20 years on commercial radio. Despite his goofy voice and noisemakers, he calls himself a ``straight man'' to the records he plays. Hansen isn't really a doctor, but if anyone were handing out Ph.D.'s in Music of All Persuasions, he would be first in line. His knowledge of music spans the blues, folk, classical, rock and novelty tunes. He occasionally helps Casey Kasem choose old songs for ``Casey's Top 40,'' introduced Weird Al Yankovic to the world and influences other radio personalities. ``I think he's great, I love him, I've been a fan for years,'' said Scott Shannon, vice president and program director at both Westwood One and Los Angeles' ``Pirate Radio'' (KQLZ). It all began when Hansen was 4 years old, just a pup in Minneapolis. He was already fascinated by the family's gramophone and could handle playing the fragile 78 rpm records himself. His father, an arts aficionado, brought home some Spike Jones records, including ``Cocktails for Two.'' The 1945 recording starts with a man crooning about an ``exquisite rendezvous,'' but goes crazy with loud crashes, guns going off and people screaming ``Whoopee!'' ``It planted the seed in my little brain which 25 years later became the `Dr. Demento Show,''' Hansen said in an interview during a recent visit to his alma mater, Reed College. When he was in junior high, he happened across a thrift shop record sale _ two 78s for a nickel. It was the beginning of a collection that now numbers about 250,000. ``It's not the largest collection in the world, but it's up there,'' he said. He has so many records that the floor of one room in his Sherman Oaks, Calif., home collapsed in December. Actually, contractors told Hansen the floor should have been able to hold the records _ an estimated five tons. Hansen got his start in radio at Reed's station, KRRC, where he was manager and the deejay for different shows. After graduating in 1963, he took off for the ``smogberry trees'' of Los Angeles. He worked at the Ash Grove music club, introducing such greats as Lightnin' Hopkins, Bill Monroe and Arlo Guthrie. He did short stints as a roadie for Canned Heat and Spirit, produced a couple of records and put together re-issues for Specialty Records. Hansen also took a master's degree in folk music studies at the University of California at Los Angeles, and wrote record reviews for early issues of Rolling Stone magazine. At a party in 1970, he met two men who worked at KPPC, one of the new FM underground, progressive radio stations that were popping up around the country. Hansen showed them his record collection _ then about 40,000-strong _ and was invited to do an oldies show. His first time behind the mike, he played classics by Carl Perkins, Screamin' Jay Hawkins and others, and threw in a nutty teen car crash tune, ``Transfusion,'' by Nervous Norvus. ``Somebody said, `You've got to be demented to play that on the radio,''' Hansen said. The name Dr. Demento stuck. ``I found the most bizarre and outrageous things were the ones that got the biggest response.'' So he gave the audience what it wanted. Hansen moved to Los Angeles' KMET in 1971, went into syndication in 1974 and watched radio change. When he started at KMET, DJs mixed up classical, country, jazz and rock _ all in one show. But during the '70s, the station got rid of all but its rock records, Hansen said. Then, management ``started telling (DJs) exactly what they had to play from those albums, and the next step of course was putting it all on computer programs,'' Hansen said. The same is true at most every other commercial station. But Dr. Demento survived. He switched to Los Angeles' KLSX in 1987, where he does a live version of his show that's sometimes wilder than the syndicated, pre-recorded program. ``My show in a way is the last vestige of free-form programming on commercial radio,'' Hansen said. A major source for that free form is tapes sent in by Dr. Demento's fans, who number anywhere from 300,000 to 1 million. Hansen receives 20 to 30 tapes a week, most containing several songs. Of those tapes, one or two songs will get played on the show during that week. In 1976, one 16-year-old sent in a tape about the food in his school cafeteria. That was Weird Al Yankovic, who also supplied Dr. Demento's most exciting moment in the studio when he and friends did a live performance of ``Another One Rides the Bus.'' Another artist, Barnes & Barnes, whose ``Fish Heads'' is Dr. Demento's most-requested song ever, started out by submitting a tape of ``The Vomit Song,'' which Hansen rejected. Other rejects are tapes that are racist, libelous or obscene or that feature, for example, 8-year-olds singing bad parodies of George Michael songs. Still, he said, ``I try to be outrageous.'' Hansen is grudgingly aware of guidelines set by the Federal Communications Commission, but as far as song selection goes, ``I would like to have stations that are my clients ... make that decision for me rather than the federal government,'' he said. A Miami station was fined for playing a song, ``Candy Rapper,'' that Hansen once played on his KLSX show. ``This is just a simple little song about candy,'' Hansen quipped. It uses names of candy items, such as Mounds and Big Hunk, to tell what could be an X-rated story _ without any explicit language. The crowd attending Hansen's January performance at Reed went wild for ``Candy Rapper'' and other selected hits of dementia, including ``Dead Puppies (Aren't Much Fun),'' ``They're Coming to Take Me Away, Ha-Haa!'' and ``Pencil Neck Geek.'' Hansen wishes commercial radio and major record labels would show the same enthusiasm for novelty records, which had their heyday in the '60s. But if not, he'll continue as the King of Novelty, making this world ``a happier place to live.''

Books and Authors: Tale of Christ Becomes Best Seller
DOC.TEXT: In Joseph Girzone's New Testament epilogue, Christ peddles his 2,000-year-old carpentry skills for chicken recipes, buses tables to pay his way to the Vatican and quips that he hasn't had kosher in ages. And like the Christ who became a heavy tipper among the money-changers in Jerusalem, Girzone's latter-day Jesus has radical ideas to change humanity's relationship with God. Girzone's latest book is ``Joshua and the Children,'' the second of his best-selling parable-novels about Christ's second comings _ and goings _ in today's world. Both are published by MacMillan Publishing Co. ``This is my attempt to present the clear and simple message of Jesus that's been lost over the centuries,'' Girzone, a retired Roman Catholic priest, said in an interview at a Catholic retreat in this Adirondack town about 100 miles north of Albany. He lives in the Albany suburb of Altamont. The chief persecutors of that simple message have been churches themselves, more intent on preserving their authority than spreading truth, Girzone said. ``I see the terrible, terrible hurt, the anguish people suffer,'' the author said. ``People are desperately trying to find an answer, to find a god that makes sense. I want to present them with a god that finally makes sense.'' Religions, his own included, have failed their followers, constructing artificial barriers and rituals that Christ wouldn't have respected, Girzone said. ``Christians fighting each other in the name of Christ _ it's so hypocritical,'' he said. ``My remedy is to plop Jesus, plop Joshua, right in the middle of it.'' In the first book, Jesus returns to Earth and takes the name Joshua, setting up shop as a carpenter and wood-carver. He lives simply, earning just enough to get by, and captivates people of all faiths with talk of a God who forgives human weakness, who ``did not intend to make humans little gods.'' ``To be perfectly human, as God made us, should be our goal,'' Joshua says. ``If we appear to be religious or pious, we've missed the point and our piety becomes a caricature and unauthentic.'' Like Christ, Joshua clashes with the establishment. He advises a troubled priest to fight the Catholic celibacy requirement for priests, offends religious leaders by attending services at church and synagogue alike, and faces a hostile panel of Vatican inquisitors. He also annoys the pope by calling him Peter, after the rock of an apostle on which the Catholic church was founded. Joshua tells Vatican leaders that churches are ``ruled by unfeeling and arrogant shepherds who hurt the flock and do irreparable damage to God's people with complete immunity. ... To threaten God's displeasure when people do not follow your rules is being a moral bully and does no service to God.'' Girzone, 58, retired from the priesthood for health reasons in 1981 after 26 years at schools and parishes in New York City, Pennsylvania and the Albany diocese. Too young for a church pension, he turned to writing and lecturing to make a living. He self-published three books before writing ``Joshua,'' which sold 60,000 copies under his own company's imprint, Richelieu Court Publications. Girzone sold copies to people who came to his lectures, and people who had read ``Joshua'' began ordering copies to give to friends and relatives. ``Joshua'' made Waldenbooks' best-seller list in 1986, a rare achievement for a self-published book. The sequel, the first printing of which totaled 175,000 copies, broke the Top 10 of The New York Times best-seller list. Collier Book s, a division of MacMillan, has sold nearly 400,000 copies of ``Joshua'' since issuing a paperback edition in 1987. Sales today are greater than when MacMillan published ``Joshua'' two years ago, said Barry Lippman, president of MacMillan's adult trade division. ``It's not some slick fad that's caught on,'' he said. ``Within two or three pages, there's something about the book that really clicks with people. It shows you can have faith without thinking of yourself as part of a church.'' The books have become the centerpiece for Girzone's whole new approach to Christianity, ``how you reconcile the freedom Jesus taught with the authority of the Church,'' he said. ``I hope it will undo some of the damage the Church has done to people.'' Much of Girzone's vision replays Christ's saga in modern terms. Instead of raising Lazarus from a tomb, Joshua brings a rabbi's son back to life after he has broken his neck in a fall. Instead of making five loaves and two fish feed a crowd after a sermon, Joshua stretches two sandwiches to feed 25 children on a picnic. Instead of a last supper with his disciples, Joshua is the guest at a surprise party _ on a Thursday _ before leaving for Rome. In between healing the sick and restoring sight to the blind, Joshua preaches against drugs and ocean pollution, uses TV evangelism to get his message across and buys gallon jugs of table wine from liquor stores. There's even ascension and resurrection scenes. Joshua makes a locked-room departure in the first book from a Vatican boarding house after telling the pope what he's doing wrong. In the second book, Joshua vanishes from his coffin after being gunned down by religious fanatics in Northern Ireland. Unlike Joshua, Girzone has drawn few harsh words for his ideas. He's been called a ``closet Protestant'' by some conservative Catholics, but most religious leaders say they see the truth in what Girzone preaches. The ``Joshua'' stories are told simply, in artless prose reminiscent of Christ's New Testament parables. Girzone said he wrote simply so the story wouldn't be lost in the words. Before ``Joshua,'' writing had been an agony for him, Girzone said. But the words came effortlessly for his parable of Jesus, as if a voice whispered the words in his ear, he said. ``I can't help but feel God wanted something done and is using the book to accomplish it,'' he said.

Nashville Sound: Times Have Changed for Country Group
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Downstairs a sellout crowd of 1,400 stretched across the clattering casino, fans in cowboy boots and fancy suits lining up to see the Oak Ridge Boys. Upstairs in a room overlooking the glitzy Las Vegas Strip, Duane Allen recalled another era in this city when the Oaks on stage outnumbered their sparse audience. Times change. ``We always required our supporting acts to go out in the audience and help bolster the crowd,'' said Allen, a grin flashing across his bearded face. ``One night we had 23 or 24 people in the audience. It was the smallest crowd we ever worked for.'' It's only a matter of blocks from the Landmark Hotel, where the Oak Ridge Boys nursed a flagging career in the mid-1970s, to the posh Celebrity Room at Bally's Resort, where they headline today. But the difference, for their career, is immeasurable. ``Back in those Landmark days, we had many nights where we had more people onstage than in the audience,'' said bass Richard Sterban, gazing across a room that was beginning to take on a glow as the neon-bathed Strip took life below. Those were the days the Oaks were trying to switch from gospel music to country, and were having trouble finding their niche. The Landmark, which has since fallen on hard times and is currently in bankruptcy, kept their hopes alive, Allen said. ``They took us under their wings for five years,'' he recounted. ``Working at the Landmark, for $6,000 a week, we didn't try to set our goals too high. That place still has a good feeling for us. I still get a chill when I walk by there. They saved our career. They gave us work. ``I don't forget those times,'' Allen added. ``I've seen from one end of the scale to the other.'' Today they are a top attraction in a city that boasts such acts as Frank Sinatra, Diana Ross, Wayne Newton and Barbara Mandrell. Now they play Vegas four or five weeks a year at more than 40 times the Landmark pay. Last year the Oaks played 243 dates in 113 cities, venues ranging from state fairs to concert halls to the posh showroom at Bally's. On a recent night at Bally's, the crowd was standing room only. Joe Bonsall, wearing red tennis shoes and T-shirt to match, led with their popular hit ``My Baby Is American Made.'' Sterban, in a black tux, followed with ``Dream On,'' his deep bass voice sending shudders through the sophisticated sound system. By the time they got to ``Y'All Comeback Saloon,'' the 1977 smash that transformed the Oaks from a gospel group to a country hit, the sedate showroom was reverberating with the hand-clapping fervor of a revival hall. Allen says these are the best of times for the Oaks _ who have known their share of the other kind. The group started in Knoxville, Tenn., in 1945, borrowing the name of the nearby atomic plant. It has had more than 40 members, disbanding in 1946 and again in 1956. They stretched the limits of Southern gospel music in the '60s and '70s, before such a trend was accepted, and soon faced an identity crisis, stuck between country and gospel, and some $100,000 in debt. ``Those starving days taught us not to take the prosperous times for granted,'' said Sterban, who joined the Oaks in 1972. They switched to country in 1977, signed with MCA (then ABC-Dot) and zoomed to the top of the charts with ``Y'All Come Back Saloon.'' Since then they've had more than a dozen No. 1 country singles. Their hit ``Elvira'' went platinum. Nine albums have gone gold and two platinum. There have been five Grammy awards and a host of Country Music Association awards. The past few years haven't been turbulence-free. There were well-publicized differences with William Lee Golden before he split from the group in early 1987. ``It was a very emotionally draining thing,'' Allen said. ``It was an emotional strain for three years before it became public. ``It takes full effort to be a member of a group,'' said Allen, who has been with the Oaks 24 years. ``If you have other interests that draw your attention away, everybody feels that. It became very obvious that William Lee wanted to be a solo artist. We wish him nothing but the best.'' The split found the group ``needing to have a breath of life breathed into us,'' Allen said. ``It made us realize how much more important the three of us were to each other.'' Golden's replacement, Steve Sanders, had been a member of the band since 1982, moving out front in the spring of 1987. Bonsall has been with group since 1973. ``One of the things he's added is energy,'' Allen said of Sanders. ``We needed to be pumped up again. The group needed some outside influence to help create that energy.'' The Oaks credit religious backgrounds with values they retain today. ``We used to give 10 percent of our dates back to the business,'' Allen recalled. ``We still give 10 to 15 percent to our charity work, always have.'' ``That's the way we were all raised, to tithe our money and our time,'' Sterban added. ``I think one's religion is and should be a very significant part of your life,'' Allen said. ``It's an integral part of the Oak Ridge Boys. I would hate to think I'd have to go through a day or a week or a month or a year without giving God the credit.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Out of Africa comes ``The Ivory Hunters,'' an action-adventure drama shot entirely on location in Kenya, starring John Lithgow, Isabella Rossellini and James Earl Jones. The National Audubon Society and Turner Network Television started production Jan. 22. The film is said to be the first-ever dramatic feature produced by an environmental organization. ``The Ivory Hunters'' concerns one man's crusade to stop poachers from slaughtering elephants for profit. The film will be broadcast on TNT in the United States and will be released theatrically in Europe.

The Florence Gould Foundation has awarded a grant of $250,000 to the American Friends of the Paris Opera & Ballet for an exhibition on Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. The American Friends of the Paris Opera & Ballet, which was founded in 1985 to provide support for the work of the Paris Opera, will reopen the renovated Paris Opera Museum at the Palais Garnier in 1991, featuring costumes, posters, photographs and personal effects relating to the company. With Russian-American choreographer Michel Fokine and others, Diaghilev founded the Ballets Russes in 1909 in Paris. The Russian impresario's revolutionary works attracted some of ballet's top dancers, choreographers and composers including Vaslav Nijinsky and Igor Stravinsky. In recognition of the Gould Foundation, the patrons' salon at the Palais Garnier, which was originally created for Napoleon III, will be renamed the Florence Gould Salon, after the American philanthropist who died in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Homes: The `Impossible' House
LaserPhotos NY700, NY701
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hover isn't sure what prompted a friend to tell him that a deteriorating old house standing empty in Troy, Mich., would be just right for him. Most likely it was because he had already turned a defunct fast food place into a nice restaurant in Detroit, says his wife, Jenny. Several months later he drove by the site, and Bob Hover fell in love with the Dunn Homestead, a late Victorian clapboard house with gingerbread trim. ``I had an immediate vision of how it would look when I had restored it,'' recalls Hover. Now more than a decade later, his vision has been vindicated. In January, he won an award for the renovation from the National Trust for Historic Preservation. The Hovers' now-proud home of about 2,700 square feet has a large living room, dining room, kitchen with new cabinets, leaded glass cabinet fronts and a marble countertop, four bedrooms, two full baths, a utility room and a full attic. From the beginning Hover, an entrepreneur and an artist, was convinced that he had the design and physical skills necessary to bring the house back to its former glory. His willingness to tackle the restoration led Delores Dunn-Johnson to sell it to him. She and her sister, Irene Dunn-House, were born in the homestead built by their grandfather, Terrence Dunn, in 1888. Their memories, old photos and other materials helped the Hovers carry out the detective work necessary to rehabilitate the home. Delores Johnson is now the Hovers' nearest neighbor. When he bought the house and one acre for $40,000 in 1979, Bob knew it was going to take a long time to rehabilitate it. ``I was 26 and single, so I didn't have to account to anyone.'' The place had suffered substantial fire damage and had not been lived in for years. It was, in fact, condemned by the town fire department. He spent the first four years clearing away rubble, filling a large dumpster 20 times with rubble from the site and running up a carting bill of about $4,000. Town officials didn't think the house could be rebuilt and had scheduled it for demolition. Getting a building permit took four years and the help of the Troy Historic District Commission and the two Dunn granddaughters. After the permit came through in January, 1984, Hover began the reconstruction work. Building professionals confirmed his opinion that virtually everything would have to be replaced. He needed new plumbing, electrical wiring and heating as well as a new roof, kitchen appliances and walls. ``All that was really left inside the house were the original doors, some floors, some hardware and the framing,'' he recalls. Outside, much of the trim was gone. He set up a woodworking shop in what are now the living and dining rooms, spending about $12,000 on circular and band saws, an industrial grade sander and router, and a number of hand tools. This enabled him to make all the wood components. ``It would have cost tens of thousands of dollars to have the work done by somebody else.'' he says. He used existing woodwork--often broken--as patterns for exterior ornamentation, wood frames and hoods for the 35 windows, corbels, corner blocks, kitchen cabinets and newel posts for the staircase. His father, Pete, who is retired, often helped him. The work was done on weekends and most evenings from 4 to 11 p.m. Hover did all the woodwork and painting but hired professionals to do the plumbing and electrical work and to lay the cedar shake roof. The Hovers moved into the house in 1987 _ a little prematurely they say, in something of an understatement. ``We didn't have a stove for seven months, and the rooms were covered with plaster dust,'' recalls Mrs. Hover. ``We weathered living with wild animals, falling plaster, no kitchen and several rooms with no floors. A typical dinner consisted of peanut butter and sawdust sandwiches on our dining room table saw,'' says Hover. In hindsight, however, his wife says the hardships have made them feel very tied to their new home, which is now almost complete. They are furnishing it in appropriate late Victorian style with reproduction wallpaper, lace curtains, an old fashioned claw-foot bathtub and pedestal sink and Victorian furniture. ``One of the most difficult tasks in tackling a restoration project of this size was to secure the necessary financing. Convincing a bank that my boarded up condemned home was just a `fixer-upper' was almost impossible,'' says Hover. After getting a brushoff from several local banks, Hover was finally able to secure financing from his credit union, which advanced funds in installments and checked on progress frequently. Hover says he has spent about $100,000 in addition to the original purchase price. A local real estate broker has estimated the property at about $170,000, he says. Despite, or perhaps because of, all the hard work he put into his home, Bob Hover looks back on the past decade as fun. ``I loved doing the work. From time to time, I would take off a night or a weekend, and I often wondered if I would be able to bring it off.'' This was especially so when he had to redo work. After reconstructing a staircase, he realized it was in the wrong place. So he ripped it out and rebuilt it in the right place. Every year, he documented his progress with videotape and photos, to remind him how far he had come. ``With a project like this you need that kind of encouragement,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Homes: Rehabilitation Trends
DOC.TEXT: You might not think of them as heroes, yet some of the people who rehabilitate old buildings into homes are much like the American pioneers who blazed a trail across new territory. Robert Hover wasn't daunted by the job of rehabilitating a condemned building swaying in the wind in Troy, Mich. For his work, he won an award from the National Trust for Historic Preservation. The stories of the Trust's 14 prizewinners and their projects could serve as a primer on house renovation, 1990-style. An unusual chapter would be Todd Canterbury's story. He turned a 76-foot-high silo into a 3,100-square-foot home in Fairfax County, Va., winning a first prize for adaptive reuse of a building. Robert Hodges of Baton Rouge, La., not only rescued a derelict house and moved it to a new lot but resurrected the forgotten craft of bousillage to recreate authentic walls of mud and Spanish moss. Also singled out were the restoration of a 1784 Anglo-German stone house in Virginia; re-creation of Victorian detailing that had been stripped from a New York City apartment; renovations to make a home accessible for a wheelchair-bound occupant in Philadelphia; and restoration of beautiful pine woodwork in a Texas home _ a job took five men five months and 11 55-gallon drums of stripper. ``The stories people wrote about what they did on their houses show they had a dream of what a house could be. They did enormous amounts of research to make their dreams come true,'' says Anne Powell, editor of Historic Preservation, the National Trust magazine which pictures the winning entries in its winter issue. ``There is an overall trend to be more meticulous.'' The Trust is planning a second competition. The first contest brought 182 entries from 31 states. The majority of entries (76 percent) were submitted by homeowners themselves. ``The judges noticed that many of the do-it-yourself projects could not be distinguished from projects executed by high-priced professionals,'' says Clem Labine, one of the judges and founder of The Old-House Journal, a publication which was at the vanguard of the restoration trend. Most of the homes dated from 1880 to 1895, although the oldest was built in 1672 and newest about 50 years ago. Economics are part of the growing interest in preserving late 19th century homes; earlier homes have gotten more expensive and increasingly difficult to find, as more people covet them. Early 20th century homes have become more desirable as the late 19th century places become more expensive. ``The jewel in the rough that you could buy for $25,000 and fix up is a thing of the past,'' says Labine. The high cost of acquiring and redoing an old house is forcing some people to convert them to profit-making properties, such as bed and breakfast inns. ``The historical B&B, which didn't even exist 10 years ago, is an avenue for people who want to own an old house but can't afford to.'' Redoing an old home with historical accuracy is creating an interest in architectural conservation. Many local history groups are changing their focus from genealogy to architecture, according to Labine. ``An approach we see often is for owners to renovate a building itself with historic accuracy and furnish the interior in contemporary fashion,'' he says. At the opposite extreme is the period museum approach. ``As a rule, the more carried away you get with historical accuracy the greater the danger of committing the cardinal sin of real estate: overimproving,'' says Labine. ``You can spend a lot more money in restoration than by using conventional mainstream products from the local building center.'' But some of the benefits of an accurate restoration are measured in quality of life rather than dollars and cents, he says. As restorer of an old house and former president of the Old Northside Neighborhood Association in Indianapolis, Ind., Paul Smith says the appeal of living in an old house is far more than an aesthetic appreciation for wonderful old detailing. An important motivation is the sense of community in a neighborhood of old houses. ``I can tell you the names of people who live seven or eight blocks away. A common bond is that we are restoring an old house. If I need a plumber, I call my neighbor for the name of one who is sensitive to old houses,'' he says. The restoration trend has inspired an increase in the number of products available to do the work. ``In 1976 there were 205 suppliers of goods or services for restoration; our current census found 1,973 companies engaged in supplying products or services for sympathetic rehabilitation of old houses,'' says Labine. And he notes preservation has become commercial because many people prefer old or quality reproduction homes. ``The traditional buildings are sold out, and the contemporary buildings are going begging in the marketplace.'' - The Trust's second competition closes June 30, 1990. For entry requirements and a nomination form, send a self-addressed stamped envelope to: Home Awards, The National Trust for Historic Preservation, 1785 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Homes: Housing Prices
DOC.TEXT: Housing industry officials doubt home prices will decline significantly in the near future, but falling mortgage interest rates mean both the overall cost of buying a home and monthly payments are dropping. The median price of a new home this year will be $127,200, compared with $120,000 last year, according to figures compiled by the Mortgage Bankers Association. It says the median price of an existing home will be $96,500 in 1990, up from $92,600 in 1989. The median price means that half of the homes cost more, half less. Some analysts say that while housing prices may be falling or leveling off in some areas, they are not declining on a national basis. Jay Shackford, a vice president of the National Association of Home Builders, notes there are ``thousands of (housing) markets around the country, each of which has its own dynamics driving it'' _ different economies, rates of growth, types of households _ so that prices might be rising in some areas while falling in others. Overall, Shackford says, the Home Builders expect prices nationally to increase at or slightly more than the general inflation rate. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was up 4.9 percent at an annual rate through last November. ``New home prices should continue to outpace inflation, while existing home prices should rise at about the rate of inflation,'' says David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. According to John Savacool, a real estate economist with the WEFA Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting organization, ``the last time home prices fell at the national level was during the Depression in the 1930s.'' Writing in the current issue of the National Association of Home Builders' ``Builder'' magazine, Savacool notes: ``Even following the stock market crash in October 1987, when 25,000 people lost their jobs in the New York area, home prices simply went flat for a year. They did not decline on an annual basis.'' Other studies, however, suggest that with the aging of the baby boom and fewer births in the subsequent baby bust era, demand for housing will decline, causing property values to drop as well. But whether home prices will or will not decline, falling interest rates are making monthly mortgage payments smaller and thus affordable for more people. Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. weekly surveys show rates for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped from 11.22 percent last March to 9.78 percent by year's end. For a person financing a $75,000 home, a 10 percent rate translates into monthly loan payments of about $658, compared to about $714 for a rate of 11 percent, according to the Home Builders. For someone financing a $150,000 home, the lower rate reduces total monthly prinicpal and interest payments from about $1,428 to $1,317. The Mortgage Bankers Association forecasts that interest rates will continue to drop this year to 9.4 percent on an annual basis. Fannie Mae's Berson also expects interest rates ``to continue to drift downward for a few more months.'' The National Association of Realtors index measuring the ability of a typical family to buy a home stood at 105.8 last November. That meant that a family with a median income of $33,482 had 105.8 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $93,000. The monthly principal and interest payment to finance that home would total about 23.6 percent of that family's income, the Realtors said. Another advantage of home ownership is that the mortgage interest payments are totally deductible from federal income taxes. Only 10 percent of the interest on most other loans can be deducted this year and none will be permitted in subsequent years. But while moderating interest rates tend to help prospective middle-income earners, many first-time buyers are unable to qualify financially for a typical starter home. The Realtors' most recent affordability index for first-time buyers shows that during the third quarter of 1989, first-time buyers had only 71 percent of the income needed to move from renting to owning. And even if they earned enough to make the monthly payments, many are unable to raise the 5-to-20 percent down payment now required for many mortgages. The Home Builders said the home ownership rate for households in the 25-29 age group fell from 43.3 percent in 1980 to 35.4 percent by mid-1989, and from 61.1 percent to 53.7 percent in the 30-34 age group.
