DOC.HEAD: FDA Bans Some Uses of Color Additive Red No. 3.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 5, Products for which, with new grafs 5-8. Also CORRECTS No.2 to No. 3.
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today banned some uses of the color additive Red No. 3, saying studies have shown that in very high doses it causes cancer in laboratory animals. ``Today's action prevents further use of this color additive in about one-fifth of its uses _ in cosmetics such as lipsticks, in externally applied drugs and as a pigment form called `lakes' in food, drugs and cosmetics,'' the FDA said in a news release. It said that because studies showed the risk from using Red No. 3 is considered small, consumers may continue using existing supplies of products that contain the color additive. The FDA also said it is in the process of extending the ban to cover those uses for which Red No. 3 still is approved. Some products use both the straight form of the dye as well as a pigment form, called a lake. It is the lakes, or tints, that are being banned, so products that use both will have to stop using the lake form but can continue using the straight dye. Products for which use is banned include shampoos, lipsticks, powders, skin-care products, baking mixes, wax coatings for cheese, chewing gum, confections and frostings, gelatins, puddings, fillings, hard candy, herbs, spices, seasonings, processed fruits and juices, drug tablet formulations and liquid drug preparations. Catherine J. Bailey, consumer safety officer at FDA, said products for which some use is still approved include soft candy, breakfast cereals, hard candy, juices, meat products, chewing gum, maraschino cherries, icings, cake decorations, cakes, plant protein products, canned puddings and sweet rolls. All uses of Red No. 3 in cosmetics is being banned. Other red dyes are approved for use in foods, drugs and cosmetics, the FDA said. The FDA has been studying Red No. 3 for 30 years. Under pressure from industry groups and members of Congress, the agency has been reluctant to impose a ban. ``The actual risk posed by Red No. 3 is extremely small. However, federal law in this area is clear,'' said Dr. Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Health and Human Services Department. ``There have been laboratory studies which showed that very high doses of Red No. 3, administered directly in the diet, caused cancer in rats,'' he said. ``In these circumstances, small as the risk is, we have no choice under the law but to end the provisional listing of this product,'' he said. Sullivan said the FDA's action illustrates the rigidity of the law and said Congress should consider updating the statutes ``to reflect advances in the methods of scientific assessment that were not available when the law was originally passed in 1960.'' The risk of getting cancer from Red No. 3 is no larger than 1 in 100,000 over a lifetime of consumption, the FDA said. In comparison, the risk from natural disasters is about 70 in 100,000 and from disasters such as railroad accidents and air crashes, the risk is about 6 in 100,000, the agency said. The red dye has been on a ``provisional list'' since 1960, when Congress called for a ban on foods that cause cancer in laboratory animals. At the time, about 200 color additives were put on the provisional list, allowing them to stay on the market for an additional two years pending further study. Over the years, the FDA has granted dozens of extensions to allow Red No. 3 to remain on the provisional list. The FDA's action terminating ``provisional uses'' of the dye removes the last of the full color additives from the provisional list, although tints of certain permanently listed colors remain on the list.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks $1.2 Trillion Budget to Expand `Human Frontier'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today sent Congress a $1.23 trillion budget for next year that slows the growth in military spending in response to ``dramatic changes in the world'' and calls for no general tax increase as part of a plan to cut the federal deficit by half. Bush proposed hefty spending increases for the 1991 fiscal year in space exploration, cleaning up the environment and the Head Start pre-school program. He also recommended cuts in Medicare, college student loans and farm subsidies, among other domestic programs. Bush's budget _ the first one he has written from scratch _ was certain to provoke sharp debate in the Democratic-controlled Congress. ``With an eye toward future growth, and expansion of the human frontier, the budget's chief emphasis is on investment in the future,'' Bush said in a written message that introduced the 1,569-page budget. ``At the same time, the budget maintains a strong national defense while reflecting the dramatic changes in the world political situation that are taking place, and it fulfills responsibilities to protect the environment and preserve America's cultural heritage,'' Bush said. His plan calls for $303.3 billion for defense, a cut of 2 percent after inflation is taken into account, and a reflection of the reduction in tension produced by political change in Eastern Europe. Bush's plan renews the president's call for a tax cut for capital gains, which critics say would benefit the wealthy, and introduces a new Family Savings Account aimed at middle-class taxpayers who could squirrel away up to $5,000 a year and earn interest tax free. The president's outline proposed cutting the federal deficit to $63.1 billion in the 1991 budget year, and if the target is met, it would be the lowest federal deficit in more than a decade. The president estimated this year's red ink at $123.8 billion, far above the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction target of $100 billion. ``This is a listen-to-what-I-say and forget-what-I-do budget. It predicts huge fiscal problems ahead and then goes on to propose no change in course,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. ``This document may put a very low ceiling on what we can expect to accomplish with the deficit this year.'' The administration's plan promises to balance the budget by 1993, as called for in the Gramm-Rudman law. But to do that it relies heavily on forecasts for economic growth and interest rates that many economists believe are overly optimistic. Bush forecasts that the overall economy will grow by 2.6 percent this year when measured from the fourth quarter of 1989, an assumption that most private analysts believe is too optimistic by nearly 1 percentage point. The budget document concedes that for every 1 percentage point shortfall in growth, the budget deficit will be increased by $18 billion. While not calling Bush's budget ``dead on arrival,'' the epithet hurled at most of the Reagan administration's spending plans, Democrats in Congress left no doubt that they planned to challenge many domestic cuts while seeking to get even more savings out of the Defense Department. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said Congress would demand a bigger cut in defense and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., challenged the proposed Medicare cuts as ``too deep. We've been cutting each and every year'' in this program. Proposed cuts in programs such as farm subsidies, federal retirees' benefits and benefits to help the poor pay their heating bills have been recommended before _ and created sharp debate in Congress. Bush's defense budget proposed trimming military personnel by 38,000, accompanied by an effort to close military bases nationwide. At the same time it protected expensive weapons programs such as the Star Wars nuclear shield, which would receive a $1 billion spending increase. The capital gains tax proposal was expected to generate another bruising congressional fight, just as it did last year, with the new twist of a rival proposal from Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to provide a $62 billion cut in Social Security taxes this year and next. Moynihan charges that the Social Security surpluses are not being saved for the Baby Boomers' retirement as intended, but instead are being used to mask the true size of the deficit. To counteract that argument, the administration put in the budget a proposal to use a portion of the surpluses beginning in 1993 to reduce the national debt. The various cuts in domestic programs totalled $13.9 billion in savings, with $5.5 billion of that coming from trims in doctor and hospitals payments in the giant Medicare health care program. Other major program cuts included $1.8 billion in farm price supports and crop insurance and savings of $2.9 billion by limiting pension increases to federal civilian retirees and by restraining cost of living increases to civilian and military government workers. Aid to urban mass transit systems would be cut sharply and low-income energy assistance would be trimmed by $340 million, to less than $1.1 billion. Bush recommended eliminating the federal subsidy to Amtrak, which amounted to slightly more than $600 million for the current fiscal year. The money saved from the cuts would be channeled to programs slated for increases. One of the biggest gains would come in spending commitments for space exploration, scheduled to jump 24 percent, with extra money over the next several years for an orbiting space station and for a down payment on manned trips to the Moon and Mars. Other budget details: _ A hefty increase in the war on drugs, boosting total spending in 1991 to $9.7 billion. Commitments for future years would push the total to $10.6 billion. _ $500 million more for Head Start, the preschool program for poor childen, putting total spending at $1.9 billion. _ New spending of more than $2 billion to fund an ``America the Beautiful'' program that would accelerate the cleanup of hazardous waste dumps and launch a massive tree planting program to combat the effects of global warming. _ A 16 percent increase in spending for aviation programs to expand airport capacity and upgrad the air controller system. _ A $3 billion increase in foreign aid to $14.2 billion with much of the money targeted for assistance to Eastern Europe and anti-drug efforts in Central and South America. Bush devoted one section of the budget to ideas for ``advancing states as laboratories,'' promising to reduce federal controls so state governors and legislators have greater latitude to try new methods of attacking problems. Bush called for no general tax increase, in keeping with his 1988 campaign pledge. But he recommended $5.6 billion in ``user fees'' such as charges to drug companies to cover the cost of federal drug testing. The administration's proposed Family Savings Accounts would allow individuals to invest up to $2,500 a year and families to invest up to $5,000 annually in tax-free savings accounts as long as the money was not withdrawn for at least seven years. The administration, seeking to counter a plan advanced by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, also proposed easing current restrictions on Individual Retirement Accounts, to allow up to $10,000 savings to be withdrawn without penalty if the money was used for a first-time purchase of a home. The president's budget message was boiled down to one page this year. It was supplemented by a 15-page overview written by Budget Director Richard Darman. Drafted in whimsical language, it described the federal budget as the ``ultimate cookie monster'' that mindlessly gobbles up scarce resources.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close of trading.
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed higher but below their session peaks on London's Stock Exchange Monday, held back by a humdrum performance on Wall Street. Sentiment was slightly more positive after Friday's better-than-expected British trade figures, traders said. But investors seemed wary of getting involved in equities before the corporate earnings season gets into full swing in mid-February, they said. ``Only the quality stocks are being nibbled at,'' one trader said. ``This implies that people are still cautious but still want to be in the market.'' By late in the London day, the Dow Jones industrial average was up just 3.61 points at 2,562.84. ``We haven't seen any institutional selling, so if markets were to stabilize worldwide, it would have a calming influence'' on shares, said one London brokerage firm's director. ``We might be in for a period where it's better to trade sideways for the time being.'' At the end of London trading, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 14.3 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,328.8, sharply higher than its opening low point of 2,317.8 but below its peak of 2,333.3. Volume came to a modest 419.4 million shares, compared with 560.3 million shares Friday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv31
For release AMs Wednesday, Jan. 31
DOC.HEAD: Procrastination on a Massive Scale
DOC.TEXT: Among the economy's problems are several that should have been dealt with long ago but weren't. Procrastination has made them grow. Oil is among the problems, as it was back in the 1970s. The cost of medical care is another. And a whole basket of financial issues _ the low savings rate, the budget and trade deficits, and debt at every level _ make up more. Though it has been a growing problem for decades, nobody seems to have the answer to rising medical costs. Insurers have cracked down on wasteful practices and hospitals are more efficiently run than before, but health is a unique business. Advances in technology tend to lower costs in most industries. Not in medicine. Cars and other manufactured products have built-in obsolescence; it does not pay to perfect them. When human lives are involved there is no such restraint. The attempt must be made. Nobody has the answer, and year by year the cost of medical care rises faster than the rate of general inflation. You do not even have to review the statistics to know that this was so last year _ and the year before and before that, too. Emphasizing the problem, a large employee benefits consultant, A. Foster Higgins & Co., today released a survey of 1,943 employers. It found that the cost of employer medical plans soared 20.4 percent in 1989. That increase brought the average cost of medical plans to $2,600 last year from $2,160 in 1988. Add in the cost of dental plans and health maintenance organizations, it says, and the average rose to $2,748 from $2,354. Answers to the problem have most often been sought in more efficient delivery of medical care. But that having failed to contain costs the newer efforts may be made in curtailment of care. In other words, the problem may be as much ethical as medical or economic. The oil problem was supposed to have been settled a decade ago, or at least it seemed that way from the promises: The United States would raise domestic production simultaneously with mainly self-imposed restraints by users. It seemed to work. Solar power was developed, domestic production rose, homeowners insulated their houses, the automotive industry learned to get more miles per gallon and utilities learned to burn fuel more efficiently. The various efforts produced results, with the rate of consumption falling behind the rate of economic expansion. Conservation was working, and operators of the oil cartel were forced to lower prices. Never again, Americans seemed to say, and they backed their words with statistical proof. But as inflation fell and the economy rose _ and as a sense of security returned _ many of the promises were forgotten. Now, says economist Edward Yardeni, ``the new decade begins with Americans as dependent on foreign oil as we were just before the oil crisis of 1979.'' Yardeni, an optimist who sees a lot more strength in the U.S. economy than many of his colleagues, nevertheless is worried that America is vulnerable to another oil shock. He calls it is a serious threat to his optimism. The numbers underscore his fears. Last year, the decline in domestic oil production was the biggest for any year ever _ more than half a million barrels a day to just 7.6 million barrels a day, lowest in 26 years. Meanwhile, imports of crude oil and petroleum products have been soaring. In 1985, those imports ran about 5.1 million barrels a day. Last year, the comparable figure was 8 million barrels. Unlike the health care situation, where a true dilemma exists, the answers to the oil challenge are known. The only thing lacking is the sense of urgency that would implement them, and that could come this year.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for AMs Wednesday, Jan. 31.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market was down slightly in afternoon trading after bouncing off earlier lows. About five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 2.02 points at 2,557.21.

The stock market closed lower in volatile trading today driven partly by interest-rate worries and concerns about financing of leveraged buyouts. The market opened higher, then fluctuated wildly throughout the session. Wall Street analysts said disarray in the junk bond market pressured takeover-related stocks and helped drive the market lower, particularly transportation issues. Although some traders said the market was in for a technical rebound after the recent sell-off, there was little to provide momentum. The market has lost about 8 percent since the start of the year. After hitting a record high of 2,810.15 on Jan. 1, the Dow Jones industrial average has dropped 250 points as of last Friday when it closed at 2,559.23. Analysts said investors remained concerned about the level of interest rates and their attractiveness to foreign investors. ``The problem is concern about foreign investors not participating in our markets,'' said Larry Wachtel, vice president with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``At what interest rate would it take to get them to participate?'' They said players were reluctant to make commitments ahead of next week's Treasury refunding, which could determine the level at which foreign investors are willing to buy U.S. bonds. ``The market is oversold right now. It's looking for a technical rebound but with interest rates expected to remain unstable it's difficult to sustain anything on the upside,'' said Richard Ciardullo, head trader for Raymond, James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. Higher interest rates would be a negative for the stock market because it would make government securities more competitive, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Holds Out Hope for Chrysler Plant
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber held out hope Monday that Friday's scheduled closing of Chrysler's Corp.'s Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit could be put off. Bieber said the plant's closing, which will put about 1,700 people out of work, will be among the issues he talks about Tuesday with Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca and other company executives. ``I'm always going to take advantage of one last day to make one more pitch to see if there's anything that can be done,'' Bieber said. His chances of success are practically non-existent. The UAW earlier proposed that Chrysler continue limited production of the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompacts at the plant and sell them to targeted groups of consumers. Chrysler rejected that plan. Chrysler and General Motors Corp. have announced plant closings or production reductions that will result in the indefinite layoffs of more than 13,000 auto workers by the end of March. Ford Motor Co. has been able to avoid indefinite layoffs by trimming overtime and rotating temporary layoffs. Chrysler announced in November that its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant, which has been making cars since 1907 and Chrysler products since 1924, will be shut down Feb. 2, about two years earlier than planned. The plant will be replaced in 1992 by the Jefferson North plant, now under construction next to the existing factory on Detroit's east side. The new plant will make sport-utility vehicles beginning for the 1993 model year. Chrysler invoked language in its contract with the UAW allowing it to close a plant when sales slip, as has happened with the Omni and Horizon cars. But the UAW is contesting the closing, saying Chrysler did too little to keep the cars, introduced in the 1978 model year, alive. Bieber said he and Iacocca have other topics to discuss. ``We want to talk to them about the whole question of employment and job security, what's going to happen to the workers not only at Jefferson but at the others and the industry as a whole,'' Bieber said at a news conference before speaking to the Economic Club of Detroit. Bieber tried to sidestep a question about bargaining priorities when the union opens talks with each of the Big Three automakers in July. The UAW contracts with the automakers expire at midnight, Sept. 14. The leader of the 1-million-member union said bargaining priorities will be set at a special UAW bargaining convention beginning May 21 in Kansas City, Mo. However, he said, ``Obviously, job security has got to be an issue that I feel very comfortable the delegates are going to say is of primary importance. ... So job security has got to be No. 1.'' Bieber also reiterated the union's support for a national health-care program. For years, automakers have complained about soaring worker health-care costs, and some automakers have estimated that health insurance programs add hundreds of dollars to the price of every new car.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Head Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rose Monday with wholesale home heating oil posting particularly strong gains. The contract for February delivery of No. 2 heating oil closed 1.51 cents higher at 61.11 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from Friday's decline of 0.17 cent. The March and April contracts ended with similar increases. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, February wholesale unleaded regular gasoline finished up 0.70 cent at 62.82 cents a gallon, adding to Friday's gain of 1.52 cents. Contracts for later delivery also advanced, but more moderately. Crude oil extended its rally into a third straight session after reaching a low of $21.60 a barrel during Thursday's trading. The March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, closed at $22.80 per 42-gallon barrel, up 24 cents. The contract had gone up 32 cents on Friday. Contracts for delivery of West Texas Intermediate during April through June rose by 30 cents to 34 cents a barrel. The strength in the crude oil trading pits partly reflected speculation about future refiner demand, said Andrew Lebow, a broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. Some of the buying was due to internal market dynamics, such as short covering, he said, noting that it was difficult to pinpoint specific reasons why energy prices were bid higher. Short covering involves buying back a previously sold commodity.

DOC.HEAD: Telemundo Says Silverman Resigns as CEO to Join Blackstone Group
DOC.TEXT: Telemundo Group Inc., a Spanish-language television station operator and programmer, said Monday that its president and chief executive, Henry R. Silverman, plans to resign. Silverman plans to leave the company Feb. 2 to join the private investment banking firm The Blackstone Group as a general partner, the announcement said. He will be replaced as chief executive at Telemundo by chairman Saul Steinberg. Donald G. Raider will continue to handle day-to-day management of Telemundo as executive vice president and chief operating officer. Silverman will remain on the Telemundo board and advise the company on strategic issues, the statement said. Silverman's exertise has been in the mergers and acquisitions arena, and has been associated with Steinberg in two major restructurings. As an officer of Reliance Capital Group, a subsidiary of Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings Inc., Silverman negotiated the $600 million acquisition of the Days Inn of America motel chain in 1984. He headed Days Inn until it was sold last year for $765 million. He also orchestated the formation of Telemundo as a Spanish-language television power. Telemundo was founded in November 1985 and bought a television station in Los Angeles that was converted into a Spanish-language operation. In 1986, Telemundo acquired John Blair & Co., a communications concern for $600 million. Telemundo sold all of Blair's assets except for two Spanish-language TV stations for $500 million and bought additional stations in New York, San Jose, Calif., and Houston. Telemundo also acquired a company in Miami that distributed programming via satellite and it has converted that operation into a Spanish-language TV network through which it supplies programming to 31 affiliate stations that reach 77 percent of all Hispanic households in the United States. ``Henry has played a key role in the rapid growth of Telemundo, helping to transform our vision for the companmy into a reality,'' Steinberg said in a news release. Silverman said he decided to move on because his skills are in finance and acquisitions and Telemundo ``no longer needs my abilities'' while Blackstone Group will put them to work. He said as a principal at Blackstone Group, he will concentrate on managing funds that firm has assembled for investment in companies recently bought out that have encountered financial difficulties or need to be restructured. Blackstone's co-founders, Chairman Peter G. Peterson and President Stephen A. Schwarzman, said Silverman's addtion to the firm ``adds another dimension to our financial services.'' Blackstone Group provides a wide spectrum of financial advisory services to major industrial corporations and financial institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Key Reversal Seen Halting Soybean Market's Slide
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rebounded sharply Monday from life-of-contract lows in a move that could mark a turnaround in the market after a six-week slide. Most grain futures also advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade. On other commodity markets, oil futures rose strongly; pork bellies posted limit losses while livestock futures were mixed; and precious metals declined. Soybean futures settled 5 cents to 8\ cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in March up 5 cents at $5.63{ a bushel. Wheat futures ended 2{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with March at $3.78} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.39{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent higher across the board with March at $1.38\ a bushel. During the session, March soybeans traded as low as $5.53{ a bushel, eclipsing the contract's previous low of $5.57{, but finished above the previous session's high of $5.61. Technical analysts call such a performance a ``key reversal.'' It often signals the end of a long-term trend. ``If you're going to look for places to buy the market, I think this is it, at least for a little while,'' said Pat O'Connell, grains analyst with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. in Chicago. Wheat and corn futures also closed above their lows for the day but analysts said those reversals were less significant than the soybean market's performance. Soybeans had opened mixed, with selling pressure stemming from reports of beneficial rain over the weekend in the soybean fields of Argentina. The market made its lows before noon CST, then headed higher along with the wheat market, which was rallying strongly on its own technical signals. Wheat's rally stalled, but the soybeans kept climbing into the close. When the key reversal was established, ``the market just fed on itself,'' said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``That's what gave us that extra 2 cents or so, that little push up to the final high for the day,'' she said. Wheat and soybean futures prices have been slipping since mid-December due to a lack of export demand and improved growing conditions for winter wheat and the South American soybean crop. Soybean and corn traders will soon begin to focus on crop weather in the Corn Belt, where planting begins in about three months. A 90-day forecast issued Monday by the National Weather Service predicted drier-than-normal weather for western Corn Belt states through the end of April, which could be a supportive signal for prices. Petroluem futures rose strongly, paced by the February gasoline and heating-oil contracts, which cease trading on Wednesday. Volatile price swings often precede contract expirations as traders scurry to escape or secure delivery commitments. Crude oil futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange in technically inspired buying in the absence of significant supply-and-demand developments. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 26 cents to 34 cents higher with March at $22.80 a barrel; heating oil was .67 cent to 1.51 cents higher with February at 61.11 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .36 cent to .85 cent higher with February at 62.82 cents a gallon. Most frozen pork-belly futures fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, marking the second straight day of limit losses. Analysts said the collapse reflected a combination of technical sell signals, weak cash markets, slack demand for fresh bellies by bacon slicers and high slaughter rates last week. Livestock futures were mostly lower. Live cattle settled .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .17 cent lower with March at 83.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .12 cent higher with February at 49.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.52 cents to 2 cents lower with February at 52.10 cents a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1 lower across the board with January at $419.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.7 cent to 0.8 cent lower with March at $5.253 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Not Even The Super Bowl Can Rally Dow
With AM-Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs ``The average ...'' to CORRECT date of record high to Jan. 2, sted Jan. 1. Picks up 4th graf ``According to ...''
DOC.TEXT: Joe Montana seemed like just the tonic Wall Street needed to cure its January ills. But not even a lopsided victory by the San Francisco 49ers in Sunday's Super Bowl could inspire stock traders Monday, who sent the Dow Jones industrial average down another 5.85 points to 2,553.38. The average of 30 blue-chip stocks is off more than 250 points since hitting a record high of 2,810.15 on Jan. 2. According to market lore, a Super Bowl victory by a team from the original National Football League, before its merger with the American Football League, has usually been followed by an up year for stock prices. Now, granted, there's still time for the market to rally over the course of 1990, but if Monday's performance is any indication, stock traders aren't in the mood for fun and games. ``There might have been 40 or 50 people buying on the Super Bowl outcome, but the big money, I can assure you, wasn't,'' said Yale Hirsch, a stock adviser in Old Tappan, N.J., and publisher of the Stock Trader's Almanac. In his annual almanac, Hirsch says the direction stock prices take in January has foreshadowed the full year's outcome correctly all but three times since 1950. This January, he said, will be no exception as he forecasts a bearish economy in 1990, Super Bowl victory or not. ``It's a marvelous phenomenon that's very entertaining, but I'll be damned if the outcome of a football game can predict the outlook for the economy,'' Hirsch said. Yet, a glimmer of hope ran through a few people's minds after the opening bell Monday when prices staged a brief, if uninspired rally. ``People were even saying that the early rally might be attributed to the Super Bowl win by the 49ers,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who dismissed such a notion. ``The scenario goes that if an NFC team wins by 20 points or more, then the market has gone up that year 95 percent of the time,'' said Richard Ciardullo, head trader for Raymond, James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. ``That's why I rooted for the 49ers.''

DOC.HEAD: US Sprint To Offer Voice-Activated Dialing
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint said Monday some customers will be able to place long-distance calls with their voices by summer in what would be the first voice-activated dialing offered by a long-distance company. Sprint said the new service, targeted toward business travelers, would allow a caller to use a spoken password instead of a standard long-distance travel card, which requires callers to punch in as many as 24 digits. In addition, a caller could speed-dial certain pre-registered numbers by saying passwords such as ``call home'' into a phone. The company said the new system would provide greater security against unauthorized use of calling cards by ensuring the caller's voice matched a pre-registered voice pattern. ``These are the features the tells us they want,'' said Sydtraveling public Courson, spokesman for Kansas City-based Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance company. Sprint unveiled the service Sunday in commercials broadcast during the Super Bowl. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said it has the technology to offer similar voice-activated services and is doing trials to determine what specific features are in demand. AT&T spokeswoman Fran Anderson said some products could be announced in 1990. A spokesman for MCI Communt system will be available to several hundred thousand customers by early this summer, but Courson would not specify what markets would get it first or what it would cost. Testing on the system began in December 1988, said Larry Lake, senior vice president of product management. US Sprint, which controls about 8 percent of the domestic long-distance market, is an 80-percent-owned subsidiary of United Telecommunications Inc. of Kansas City. GTE Corp., of Stamford, Conn., owns the remaining 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Slide In Volatile Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market settled broadly lower in volatile trading Monday, pressured by interest rate worries and concern about financing of corporate takeovers. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 5.85 points to 2,553.38. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 961 issues down, 541 up and 450 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 150.77 million shares, down from 198.19 million in the previous session. Stock traders said the market tried to rally several times throughout the session, starting at the opening bell, but failed to muster enthusiasm as many institutional investors remained on the sidelines. Program trading kept the market fluctuating wildly. ``Program trading was a very large part,'' said Phillip Puccio, managing director of equity trading for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``Futures seemed to be wagging the dog. With institutional trading you would see more liquidity and less volatility.'' Junk bond market woes spilled over into the stock market, pressuring takeover-related issues and helping drive the market lower, said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Many large corporate buyouts in recent years were financed with junk bonds. Transportation issues were among the hardest hit. The Dow Jones transportation average fell 26.67 to 1,074.50. ``The junk bond market has been in disarray. That's hurting deal stocks,'' said Weeks. Interest rates and the level of foreign investment in U.S. securities also remained a chief concern for the stock and bond markets. Investors worry that foreign investors will avoid buying U.S. securities and financing the U.S. government budget deficit because interest rates are higher overseas. A poor showing particularly by Japanese investors during the Treasury's refunding auction next week could force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to attract foreign investment. Higher interest rates would make government securities more competitive _ a negative for the stock market, Weeks said. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 179.16 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $12.171 billion, or 0.39 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.48 to 179.73. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Varity fell [ to 3, Security Pacific lost ] to 35\, General Electric was off } to 61} and Philip Morris was unchanged at 37. UAL also tumbled 13{ 136{, as junk bond worries raised concerns about the success of a union-proposed buyout offer, and AMR lost 2[ to 55\. Meanwhile, AT&T rose ] to 39{, Bank of New England gained | to 4[, IBM rose ] to 97\ and Exxon finished up \ at 47. Standard & Poor's industrial index slipped 0.27 to 374.31, and S&P's 500-stock composite index closed down 0.60 at 325.20. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 3.22 to 418.11. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 349.54, down 1.33.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Bans Cosmetic, Some Other Uses Of Red Dye No. 3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf pvs to DELETE extraneous word `ban'; PICKS UP 19th graf pvs, `That means...; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The government banned some uses of the color additive Red No. 3 on Monday. As a result, ``red'' may not be as ``red'' in lipstick, cake frostings, cough drops and some processed fruits and juices. The Food and Drug Administration announcement said some uses of the dye are being halted because Red No. 3 in high doses has been shown to cause cancer in rats. The cancer risk is considered so small that the FDA said that existing products that contain the color may be used. The ban on Red No. 3 will apply only to new manufacturing, the FDA said. The FDA action prevents the use of the red dye in products where the color is mixed chemically with another additive. Direct addition of the dye to a product will continue, but the FDA also announced its intention to halt this use eventually. Under the new rules, FDA spokesman Emil Corwin said Red No. 3 can no longer be used in any cosmetic product, including lipsticks, powders, blushes, shampoos, skin care lotions or bath oils. It also is excluded from use in cake frostings, cough drops, herbs and spices, flavorings, some processed fruits and juices, chewing gum, cake mixes and dietary foods. Even the wax on cheeses can no longer contain the red dye, said Corwin. Red No. 3 is one of seven primary colors approved for food, drug and cosmetic use, but it holds a very important position because it is the ``closest to primary red,'' says John Hallagan of the Certified Color Manufacturers Association. ``There will be a number of products that won't be red any more,'' said Hallagan. The six other colors are Red No. 40, Blue Nos. 1 and 2, Green No. 3, and Yellow Nos. 5 and 6. ``Because it was closest to the primary color of red, No. 3 is ideal for blending,'' said Hallagan. Mixing No. 3 with other primary colors could make a whole variety of shades based on red, ranging from orange to maroon. Without No. 3, he said, ``the pallet of colors will be reduced significantly. The variability will be reduced.'' Red No. 40, he said, is a different shade of red and is not as stable. Hallagan said that about 300,000 pounds of Red No. 3 is manufactured annually in the United States. Irene Malbin of the Cosmetic Toiletry and Fragrance Association said that a 1989 survey of cosmetic manufacturers showed that red No. 3 ``was not used in very many cosmetic products'' because of uncertainty over its status. As a result, dropping red No. 3 from cosmetic use will not have a serious effect on the colors available to customers, said Ms. Malbin. But association president Ed Kavanaugh attacked the FDA action as being ``arbitrary and capricious'' because the agency permitted Red No. 3 to continue to be used in food ``and other ingested products.'' Under the FDA order, Red No. 3 still can be applied directly to some products until further agency action is taken. That means it still can be applied directly to meat, pet food, nut products, fruit and fruit juices, candy and confections, breakfast cereals and ingested drugs. Corwin said the cherries in fruit cocktail, for example, can continue to be tinted red by the color additive. In announcing the FDA action, Dr. Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said: ``The actual risk posed by red No. 3 is extremely small. However, federal law in this area is clear. There have been laboratory studies which showed that very high doses of Red No. 3, administered directly in the diet, caused cancer in rats.'' Sullivan said that Congress should consider updating the statutes ``to reflect advances in the methods of scientific assessment that were not available when the law was originally passed in 1960.'' An FDA statement said the risk of getting cancer from Red No. 3 is no larger than 1 in 100,000 over a lifetime of consumption. This compares to a natural disaster risk of about 70 in 100,000, and a risk from death in railroad or air crashes of about 6 in 100,000, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Compaq Delays Shipment of Computers Because of Faulty Chip
DOC.TEXT: Compaq Computer Corp. will delay shipments of its new Deskpro 486-25 personal computer because of a faulty Intel Corp. chip, officials said Monday. It is the second problem found in the advanced microprocessor. ``About a week ago, on Monday, we were contacted by Intel just saying that there was an errata discovered in the 486 chip,'' said Nora Rice, media relations administrator for the Houston-based computer manufacturer. She said Intel said it was working to find a solution to the problem, but the trouble will delay introduction of the new machine. ``We were targeting shipping the computer Feb. 1,'' Ms. Rice said. ``But with this new errata, it will delay the ship date. ``It's important to understand what's causing the problem, before you put in a fix or a work-around'' that configures the computer differently, she said. Compaq discovered another problem with the advanced chip last fall, before Intel had begun shipping the microprocessor. When Compaq unveiled the Deskpro 486-25 last November it called it the most powerful desktop computer yet. Intel's 486 chip, introduced last April, is so powerful that it will allow personal computers to do certain jobs now done by engineering workstations, minicomputers and even mainframes. The most recent trouble could affect other computers using the Extended Industry Standard Architecture, or EISA, 32-bit bus, Ms. Rice said. Compaq has not released any of its other 486-based machines, Ms. Rice said. ``I think they will be delayed, but it's safe to say they will be out within the first quarter.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls in Light Trading, Gold Slips
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `In Tokyo ...,' to CLARIFY that New York yen close was up marginally from Friday's New York close.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies in light trading Monday in reaction to a drop in stock prices. Gold prices also slipped. On New York's Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold fell $1 to close at $419.10. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $418.20 a troy ounce, down $1.80 from Friday. Dealers said the dollar began trading higher in New York after it lost strength overnight on overseas markets, where the West German mark rose in value against the dollar in reaction to an announcement of earlier elections in East Germany and an easing of tension in Soviet Azerbaijan. But then stock prices fell on Wall Street, sending the dollar lower. prevailed in Europe and in New York in the morning before the stock market began weakening. Recent economic reports that indicate the U.S. economy is sluggish also worked against the dollar, said Robert Hatcher, a dealer with Barclays Bank PLC. ``I think it is resurrecting the fear within the dealer community of possible ... easing down the road,'' he said. Lower interest rates as set by the Federal Reserve Board make the dollar less attractive to overseas investors. Reports Monday showing consumer spending posted its largest increase in three years in 1989 and personal incomes rose 9 percent last year had little impact on the dollar, traders said. Charles A. Spence, a vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles, said currency dealers were awaiting the release Wednesday of the Commerce Department's leading indicators for December, which should give further evidence on the direction of the economy. ``They're looking for slightly positive numbers,'' he said. Earlier, dealers overseas said a few large orders had an exaggerated impact on the dollar because volume was thin with Hong Kong and Singapore closed for holidays. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.75 yen to a closing 143.22 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.15 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 142.98 yen, up 0.18 yen from Friday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6775 from $1.6571 late Friday. In New York, it strengthened further to $1.6810, up from $1.6635 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday rates, included: 1.6770 West German marks, down from 1.6865; 1.4815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4900; 5.6950 French francs, down from 5.7290; 1,248.00 Italian lire, down from 1,254.50; and 1.1871 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1966. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.6795 West German marks, down from 1.6935; 1.4860 Swiss francs, down from 1.4975; 5.7040 French francs, down from 5.7510; 1.8865 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9060; 1,249.75 Italian lire, down from 1,260.00; 1.1888 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1903; Gold dipped in London to a late bid price of $418.50 a troy ounce from $418.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold finished at a closing bid of $418.50, unchanged from late Friday. There was no gold trading in Hong Kong, which was closed for the Lunar New Year holiday. The market there is to reopen Tuesday. Silver prices fell marginally. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.215 a troy ounce, down from $5.222 a troy ounce Friday. It fell in London to a late bid price of $5.22 a troy ounce from $5.25 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Employees Return to Work as Union Dissidence Continues
DOC.TEXT: About one-third of the workers at Ford Motor Co.'s plant outside Mexico City returned to work Monday after a labor dispute that sparked a 22-day shutdown, a Ford spokesman said. Spokesman Carlos Bandala said 1,200 union employees went back to work at the Cuautitlan plant 15 miles north of Mexico City and another 1,200 were expected to rejoin the labor force Tuesday. ``We expect to resume full operation probably by the end of this week,'' Bandala said. The 3,800-member work force produces 450 cars and trucks a day for the Mexican market under normal conditions. Current production figures were unavailable, he said. One worker was killed and nine others injured in a Jan. 8 confrontation among employees at the plant. Between 150 and 200 people entered the plant and shot and beat workers as they arrived for the morning shift. Ford closed the plant, saying there was no security for workers. After the flareup, protesting unionists took over Ford installations demanding the ouster of union leader Hector Uriarte. Authorities issued an arrest warrant charging Uriarte with masterminding the violence. Newspaper reports Monday said dissident union members were maintaining a picket outside the company installations. Bandala said the company is negotiating with Fidel Velazquez, head of the Mexican Labor Confederation, to which the Ford union belongs. Negotiations will determine whether union members receive back pay for work time lost when the company closed the plant. Union legal adviser Gerardo Cabazos Cortez said the safety of returning workers is guaranteed.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 4th-Qtr Loss, Profit Tumbles 46 Pct for 1989
DOC.TEXT: Unocal Corp. said Monday that it lost $26 million in its fourth quarter and its yearly profit fell 46 percent because of a loss on the sale of a coal mine and other one-time unusual events. The loss for the October-December quarter, equivalent to 11 cents per share, came on revenues of $2.85 billion. In fourth-quarter 1988, Unocal earned $141 million, or 60 cents a share, on revenues of $2.85 billion. That included sale of the Unocal headquarters property in Los Angeles. For the year, the big energy company earned $260 million, or $1.11 per share, on sales of $11.36 billion, compared to $480 million, $2.06 per share, on revenues of $10.15 billion in 1988. The 1989 net earnings include a $98 million loss related to the sale of the Obed Mountain coal mine in Canada, a discontinued operation. In 1988, net earnings included a $456 million gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. Excluding the loss from discontinued coal operations, Unocal would have earned $60 million in the fourth quarter, the company said. After adjusting for one-time events, earnings for 1989 were up by 24 percent over the previous year, Chairman Richard J. Stegemeier said. The gain reflected improved petroleum exploration and production earnings, including settlements of several natural gas contract disputes, which were partially offset by lower refining and marketing earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Top Exec Resigns as Computer Giant Realigns
DOC.TEXT: A top Apple Computer Inc. executive resigned Monday in what analysts called part of the company's drive to resolve problems in switching to a new generation of products. Cupertino-based Apple, the world's No. 2 personal computer maker, has faced declining profits for nearly a year, mostly due to poor U.S. sales. Company officials announced the resignation of Allan Z. Loren as president of Apple USA, the company's foundering domestic sales and marketing unit. Loren, 51, a former insurance executive, once was considered a candidate to head the company. ``Apple has been in a hunkered-down mode since before Christmas and it is trying to put itself back onto the road, and this is a message it is making a major move in that direction,'' said Richard Shaffer, publisher of New York-based Technologic Computer Letter. Michael H. Spindler, 47, president of Apple Europe, was named chief operating officer by John Sculley, chief executive and company president. The new position is designed to help the company improve coordination of business operations and streamline day-to-day activities, Apple said in a statement. The company's latest financial results apparently sealed Loren's fate. During its latest quarter, Apple suffered an 11 percent decline in profits from a year earlier. It was the third straight quarter Apple experienced a decline in revenue and profits, with most of the problems centered on the U.S. sales and marketing division, the company's largest. Apple, which had revenues of $5.3 billion in 1989, said two weeks ago it would reduce employment by 5,500, mostly through attrition and reassignment, and would not rule out the possibility of layoffs. It also froze salaries for six months, eliminated cars for U.S.-based executives and cut back its profit-sharing plan. Apple faces a critical year in 1990 from major competitors who will be introducing their own graphic interface products, which are software programs that use symbols to allow the user to tell computers what to do. Apple's Macintosh has been the leading computer to use such a system, but there have been delays in releasing its newest Macintosh machines and criticisms they are too expensive. Benny Lorenzo, an analyst at Volpe Convington & Welty in San Francisco, said Aple has worried some investors by the level of its research and development expenses. He said Compaq Computer Corp. spent 5.3 percent of its revenue on research and development last year, compared to Apple's 8 percent, yet came out with more new computers. Although the personal computer industry in general has been hurt by sagging sales the past six months, Apple also was beset by significantly slower U.S. sales of some of its leading product lines, particularly low-end Macintosh models and the Apple II personal computers. Many software distributors have been angry over the comparatively low level of promotion by Apple last Christmas for its Apple II, developed 13 years ago. Many dealers and owners of the machine fear the company is preparing to abandon it in favor of the Macintosh. Apple also has been hurt by declining sales of peripheral equipment because of increased competition and lower minimum purchase requirements for major resellers, which encouraged the companies to order lower volumes, Lorenzo said. ``What's happened is that they've neglected the low-end of the market and concentrated on maintaining or increasing their share of the business part of the market,'' said Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. of New York. Sales figures by Storeboard Inc., a Dallas market researcher, show that unit sales of Apple computers through U.S. dealers decreased last year, while revenue increased, indicating at least in part a shift toward more expensive machines. Many of Apple's longtime customers want the company to put more effort into software for its less costly machines and to introduce better versions of those products without drastically increasing price.

DOC.HEAD: Disagreement From Trump And Resorts Bondholders Over Court Decision
DOC.TEXT: A Delaware court has ruled that the board of Resorts International, Inc., then headed by Donald Trump, acted in good faith when it approved a $36-a-share offer by entertainer Merv Griffin. Trump hailed the ruling as ``a great victory'' and said it would forestall any attempt by Resorts bondholders to sue him, but an attorney for some bondholders disputed that contention. In a decision reached Friday but announced Monday, the Delaware Supreme Court Court upheld a lower courts ruling that it was ``doubtful'' any objecting shareholders could prove the board of directors' committee acted with gross negligence or bad faith in approving Griffin's bid in June 1988. The court also dismissed the contention of shareholders who said they did not benefit from the deal between Griffin and Trump. The court said they received $36 a share from Griffin when Trump had offered only $22 a share. Resorts is incorporated in Delaware. Trump had been Resorts chairman and controlling stockholder before Griffin bought the casino company, taking on more than $900 million in debt and issuing bonds to finance that debt. Trump was paid $63.7 million to break his management contract with Resorts. He also received the unfinished Taj Mahal casino for $250 million, half the $500 million Resorts had sunk into construction. In a telephone interview from New York, Trump called the decision ``a great victory'' and said it would end speculation about disgruntled bondholders suing Trump for alleged ``fradulent conveyances.'' ``We're really very happy about it,'' Trump said. ``It puts to rest any loose ends.'' As part of a bankruptcy reorganization plan filed late last year in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Camden by Resorts International, Griffin set aside a $5 million kitty for possible legal action against Trump. Attorneys for some bondholder groups had said they might sue Trump for ``fraudulent conveyance.'' Resorts attorney Tom Gallagher said the decision would not have any impact on the reorganization plan. ``The ruling is as expected,'' Gallagher said. ``There's nothing new in it.'' Marc S. Kirschner, an attorney for some Resorts bondholders, discounted the importance of the ruling. ``I think it's irrelevant,'' he said. ``It has to do with shareholder rights and remedies and has zero to do with creditor rights and remedies.'' Most analysts say Griffin paid too much for Resorts and burdened his purchase with too much debt, estimated at about $912 million. Griffin's bankruptcy plan, which still must win approval from bondholders and state gaming regulators, would have him exchange 78 percent of his equity in the company for about two-thirds of the outstanding debt. The ``win'' or gross profits for Resorts dropped last year to $227.4 million from the $242.9 million posted in 1988, according to the state Casino Control Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Black & Decker Posts $3.2 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: Black & Decker Corp. posted a net loss of $3.2 million in the final three months of 1989 because of higher interest costs and the writeoff of goodwill following its acquisition of Emhart Corp., the company announced. The quarterly loss, which amounted to 5 cents a share, compared with net income of $38 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Operating income, which is calculated before interest and taxes, rose 80 percent in the quarter to $116 million, reflecting the Emhart acquisition and double-digit operating income growth in existing Black & Decker businesses. Sales rose 60 percent to $1.1 billion. The period constitutes a ``stub'' period following the decision by the power tool and home products company to change in its fiscal year end from the last Sunday in September to Dec. 31. Black & Decker aquired Emhart, a diversified producer of industrial and commercial products, for $2.8 billion last spring. The company also announced it has completed the sale of its Bostik adhesives business, a part of the Emhart acquisition, to Orkem SA of France for $345 million. Proceeds of the sale will be used to reduce debt, the company said. The company also plans to sell two other businesses _ its footwear materials unit to United Machinery Group Ltd. for $125 million and its capacitors business, excluding the U.S. segment, to Nissei Electric Co. Ltd. for $80 million. Both transactions are subject to negotiation of final contracts, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: America West Orders Two 747-400s, Takes Options on Two More
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines has ordered two Boeing 747-400s and taken options on two more, Boeing Commercial Airplanes said Monday. The order, along with spare parts and training, is worth about $280 million, Boeing said. America West, based in Phoenix, plans to use the jumbo jets on flights to Hawaii. Engines for the new planes have not yet been chosen. Boeing now has received orders for 246 of the long-range 747-400s from 26 customers.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Seek Sale of Company, SEC Told
DOC.TEXT: An investment group said it intends to wage a proxy fight to gain control of National Intergroup Inc., a Pittsburgh-based holding company. Centaur Partners IV, based in New York, said Monday in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it and other investors have acquired 16.53 percent of NII's stock and hope to restructure or sell the company. The move was seen as hostile by NII, which issued a statement saying Centaur Partners ``have nothing to add to the existing restructuring program which the company has been actively pursuing for the past year.'' The company said it already had sold its aluminum fabrication businesses for $135 million and made progress in negotiating the sale of the rest of its aluminum and steel operations. The company plans to concentrate its operations on pharmaceuticals and oil. NII said it expects a significant increase in earnings in fiscal 1990. Also Monday, Centaur asked the Delaware Chancery Court to prevent NII from triggering a ``poison pill'' anti-takeover device. The technique would allow NII to issue stock purchase rights to shareholders 10 days after a hostile investor gains a stake of 10 percent or more in the company. NII's stock, which has swung widely in value during the past year because of takeover speculation, lost $2 a share Monday to close at $15.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange.
